(a)  The City of South Houston, Texas, by its city council hereby elects to have the employees of all participating departments of said city (as above defined) participate in and be covered by the supplemental benefits fund of the Texas Municipal Retirement System, as provided by Chapter 312, Acts Regular Session, 56th Legislature; and all the benefits and obligations of participation in said fund are hereby accepted by the city as to such employees. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby directed to notify the board of trustees of the Texas Municipal Retirement System that the City of South Houston, Texas, has elected to participate and have the employees of the above mentioned departments participate in the supplemental benefits fund of said system. 
(c)  Each person who becomes an employee of any participating department on or after the effective date of participation of such department in said fund shall as a condition of his employment be covered into the supplemental benefits fund of said system. The City of South Houston, Texas, may in the future refuse to add new departments or new employees to said fund, but shall never discontinue as to any members who are covered into the fund. 
(d)  The city secretary is hereby directed to remit monthly to the board of trustees of the Texas Municipal Retirement System at its office in Austin, Texas, as the city's contributions to the supplemental benefits fund of the Texas Municipal Retirement System, such percentage of earnings of the above-mentioned employees of said city as may be fixed by the board of trustees of the Texas Municipal Retirement System, provided that the rate of contribution to said fund shall not exceed one-half of one percentum of the earnings of the employees of said city who are covered under said fund; and such official shall make for the city such reports as the board of trustees of the Texas Municipal Retirement System may prescribe. 
(e)  Participation of the above-mentioned employees in the supplemental benefits fund shall be effective October 1, 1979. 
(Ord. No. 653, § 1, 9-4-79)  
Sec. 2-35.2. - Supplemental death benefits. 
(a)  That the City of South Houston hereby elects to participate in the supplemental death benefits fund of the Texas Municipal Retirement System beginning on the first day of the calendar month following written notification to the system of the adoption of this section, for the purpose of providing in-service death benefits in the amounts and on the terms provided for in Section XIX of the TMRS Act (Article 6243h, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, as amended) for each of the city's employees who are members of said system, and for the purpose of providing post-retirement death benefits as provided in said Section XIX for annuitants whose last covered employment was as an employee of this city. 
(b)  The City of South Houston is hereby authorized and directed to notify the director of the system of adoption of this section and of the participation of the city in said fund. 
(Ord. No. 654, § 1, 9-4-79)  
Sec. 2-35.3. - Deposits and credits for active service in armed forces. 
(a)  Pursuant to Section 853.502, Subchapter F of Chapter 853, Title 8, Government Code as amended, the City of South Houston hereby elects to allow eligible members in its employment to establish credit in the Texas Municipal Retirement System for active military service performed as a member of the armed forces or armed forces reserves of the United States or an auxiliary of the armed forces or armed forces reserves. Eligible members as used herein shall be those employees meeting the criteria set forth in Sections 853.502(b) and 853.503 of said Subchapter F, and the amount and use of creditable military service shall be as further set forth in Section 853.505. 
(b)  In order to establish credit for military service hereunder, a member must deposit with the Texas Municipal Retirement System (in that member's individual account in the employees saving fund), an amount equal to the number of months for which credit is sought, multiplied by fifteen dollars ($15.00). The City of South Houston agrees that its account in the Municipality Accumulation Fund is to be charged at the time of the member's retirement with an amount equal to the accumulated amount paid by the member for military service credit, multiplied by the city's current service matching ratio in effect at the date the member applies for such military service credit. 
(Ord. No. 922 (12-91), §§ 1, 2, 12-3-91) 
Editor's note— Provisions enacted by §§ 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 922 (12-91), adopted Dec. 3, 1991, have been included herein at the discretion of the editor as § 2-35.3.  
Sec. 2-36. - Early retirement. 
Pursuant to the provisions of V.T.C.A. Government Code §§ 854.105 and 854.202, 854.405 of Subtit. G of Tit. 8, as amended, which subtitle shall herein be referred to as the "TMRS Act," the City of South Houston, Texas, adopts the following provisions affecting participation of its employees in the Texas Municipal Retirement System (which retirement system shall herein be referred to as the "system"): 
(a)  An employee of the city who is a member of the system may terminate employment and remain eligible to retire and receive a service retirement annuity at any time after that member attains an applicable age and service requirement, if that member has at least five (5) years of credited service performed for one or more municipalities that have authorized eligibility under V.T.C.A. Government Code § 854.202(c) of the Act or are subject to V.T.C.A. § 854.102(e) of the Act. 
(b)  An employee of the city who is a member of the system may retire and receive a service retirement annuity if that member is at least sixty (60) years old and has at least five (5) years of creditable service performed for one or more municipalities that either have authorized eligibility under this subsection or are subject to V.T.C.A. Government Code § 854.102(e) of this subtitle. 
(c)  The rights, credits and benefits herein above authorized shall be in addition to the plan provisions heretofore adopted and in force at the effective date of this section pursuant to the TMRS Act. 
(Ord. No. 778, § 1, 12-15-87; Ord. No. 2005-39, § 1, 11-1-05)  
Sec. 2-37. - Retirement and severance fund. 
(a)  The retirement and severance fund shall be segregated from the other monies of the city and that only those amounts necessary for the payment of incurred liabilities as heretofore described shall be withdrawn from the principal and accrued interest. 
(b)  The sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) each month shall be deposited in the fund and the general fund and the system fund shall pay an appropriate apportioned amount into the fund. The establishment of a permanent budget line item in both the system and general fund accounts is authorized for this purpose to be known as the retirement and severance fund account. 
(c)  One year from the date of establishment of what shall be known henceforth as the retirement and severance fund account and each succeeding year thereafter an audit of the account shall be conducted with a view toward increasing or decreasing the monthly funding based upon prevailing conditions of personnel manning and historical expenses relative to the purpose of the fund. The audit may be conducted by in-house personnel and should changes in the monthly funding be necessitated, a request to do so, in the form of a budget amendment effective at the next semi-annual budget review and approval process shall be made by the mayor. The amounts contained in the retirement and severance fund account shall be reported to the city council and the public as a portion of each finance resolution. 
(Ord. No. 848, § 3, 9-26-89) 
Editor's note— Provisions enacted by § 3 of Ord. No. 848, adopted Sept. 26, 1989, and designated as § 2-44.1, have been redesignated and included herein at the discretion of the editor as § 2-37.  
Sec. 2-37.1. - Benefit accumulation fund. 
Pursuant to Section 855.407(g) of the TMRS Act, the city hereby elects to make future normal and prior service contributions to its account in the benefit accumulation fund of the system at such combined rate of the total compensation paid by the city to employees who are members of the system, as the system's actuary shall annually determine as the rate necessary to fund, within the amortization period determined as applicable to the city under the TMRS Act, the costs of all benefits which are or may become chargeable to or are to be paid out of the city's account in said accumulation fund, regardless of other provisions of the TMRS Act limiting the combined rate of city contributions. 
(Ord. No. 2012-20, § 1, 10-23-12)  
DIVISION 2. - PERSONNEL POLICY 
 
Sec. 2-38. - Personnel policy adopted by reference; contents. 
(a)  The personnel policy of the city, inapplicable to the police department where inconsistent with state legislative civil service rules, as attached hereto and made a part hereof, is hereby approved and adopted. 
(b)  The personnel policy incorporated herein for all purposes, contains a Table of Contents; Section I, Authority in Administration; Section II, Initial Employment Information and Requirements; Section III, Attendance and Absence; Section IV, Administrative Policies; Section V, Discipline, Appeals and Grievances; Section VI, Fringe Benefits; Section VII, Miscellaneous Provisions. 
(Ord. No. 800, §§ 1, 2, 6-21-88; Ord. No. 2011-39, §§ 1, 2, 11-22-11; Ord. No. 2012-04, §§ 2, 4, 2-14-12; Ord. No. 2013-05, § 1, 2-26-13; Ord. No. 2013-06, § 2, 2-26-13; Ord. No. 2014-09, § 2, 5-13-14; Ord. No. 2014-30, § 1, 10-14-14; Ord. No. 2015-07, § 2, 6-9-15) 
Editor's note— The text of the personnel policy adopted in § 2-38 is not set out at length herein but is on file and available for inspection in the offices of the city.  
Secs. 2-39—2-47. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SOCIAL SECURITY 
 
Sec. 2-48. - Execution of agreements. 
(a)  The city council, acting for and on behalf of the city, shall enter into all necessary agreements with the state department of public welfare for the purpose of securing federal old age and survivors insurance coverage and benefits for employees of the city under applicable state and federal laws. 
(b)  The mayor is hereby appointed as agent of the city council and of the city to execute all necessary agreements and instruments for the purposes stated in subsection (a) above. 
(Ord. of 10-2-51, §§ 1, 2) 
State Law reference— Social security for municipal employees, V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 606.  
Sec. 2-49. - Duties of city secretary. 
The city secretary is hereby directed to be the person responsible for making assessments, collections, payments and reports, as required by the state department of public welfare in connection with the federal old age and survivors insurance program. 
(Ord. of 10-2-51, § 3)  
Sec. 2-50. - Fund established. 
A sufficient sum of money shall be allocated and set aside from available funds for the purpose of carrying out the provisions of the state and federal laws relative to the federal old age and survivors insurance program, such money so allocated and set aside to be known as the City of South Houston Social Security Fund, which fund shall be set aside and maintained in the regular city depository. 
(Ord. of 10-2-51, § 4)  
Secs. 2-51—2-58. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - POLICE CIVIL SERVICE 
 
Sec. 2-59. - Implementation. 
This article is enacted pursuant to the adoption of the Policemans Civil Service Act (Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, Article 1269m) by the citizens of South Houston in a referendum election of April 7, 1984. The provisions of said Act are to be fully implemented upon the effective date of this ordinance Number 717, adopted August 7, 1984 and effective from and after October 1, 1984. 
(Ord. No. 717, § 1, 8-7-84) 
Editor's note— At the discretion of the editor, § 1 of Ord. No. 717, adopted Aug. 7, 1984, has been codified herein as § 2-59.  
Sec. 2-60. - Classifications. 
There are hereby established the following classifications of employees within the South Houston Police Department which shall be subject to the provisions of V.T.C.A. Local Government Code, Ch. 143, Policemen's Civil Service, to wit: Cadet, patrolman, sergeant and captain. 
(Ord. No. 722, 10-2-84; Ord. No. 727, § 1, 6-18-85; Ord. No. 733, § 1, 12-10-85; Ord. No. 740, § 2, 7-29-86; Ord. No. 2007-17, § 2, 9-4-07; Ord. No. 2008-03, § 1, 4-1-08; Ord. No. 2009-31, § 2, 11-10-09)

That effective October 1, 2018, the rate of hourly pay for all classified civil service employees of the City of South Houston, according to the years of service in the classification held, shall be as follows:

Sec. 2-63. - Certificate pay for state-mandated certification. 
The police officers of the city shall receive the following monthly certificate pay structure for each respective state-mandated certificate, above basic required levels, earned by the police officer, which consists of a maximum of three (3): 
Intermediate certificate is worth: ..... $50.00 
Advanced certificate is worth: ..... $75.00 
Master certificate is worth: ..... $125.00 
All instructor certificates shall be grandfathered at one hundred dollars ($100.00). No additional instructor certificates will be issued. 
These payments shall be based on the number of certificates held by the police officers at the beginning of the fiscal year, e.g., October 1. No payments shall be made for those certificates earned by the police officers after October 1 and continuing to the end of the fiscal year. 
The police department dispatcher employees shall receive the following monthly certificate pay structure for each respective certificate earned by the employee: 
Intermediate telecommunication ..... $50.00 
These payments shall be based on the number of certificates held by the employees as of October 27, 2008. 
(Ord. No. 99-029, § 1, 11-9-99; Ord. No. 2003-15, § 1, 9-30-03; Ord. No. 2003-15A, § 1, 9-30-03; Ord. No. 2005-41, § 2, 11-1-05; Ord. No. 2009-09, § 1, 3-3-09; Ord. No. 2015-18, § 2, 11-24-15)  
Sec. 2-64. - Office of director of firefighter's and police officer's civil service. 
(a)  There is hereby created the officer of director of firefighters' and police officer's civil service (known as "director"). The director shall be appointed by the civil service commissioners. The commission may remove the director at any time. 
(b)  The director shall serve as secretary to the commission and perform work incidental to civil service system as required by the commission. 
(c)  The city council hereby sets the salary of the civil service director at a minimum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per month and a per hour rate of eight dollars ($8.00) per hour that the director works in the performance of the work for the civil service commission. 
(d)  The appointment of the civil service director and salary shall become effective as of March 31, 1988. 
(Ord. No. 797, § 1, 6-7-88)  
Secs. 2-65—2-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CITY COUNCIL MEETINGS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 94-015, § 2, adopted April 19, 1994, repealed former art. IV, §§ 2-81—2-86, relative to city council meetings, and § 1 of said Ord. No. 94-015 enacted a new art. IV, §§ 2-81—2-88, to read as herein set out. The provisions of former art. IV derived from Ord. No. 726, §§ 1—6, adopted April 16, 1985. 
 
Sec. 2-81. - Definitions. 
Interested party means any person who claims an interest in a matter on the council's agenda and is so situated that the disposition of the agenda may, as a practical matter, impair or impede the person's ability to protect that interest. 
Nonresident means any person who does not have a legal fixed domicile within the boundaries of the City of South Houston, Texas. 
Presiding officer means the mayor who shall preside at all meetings of the governing body. If the mayor is absent, fails, is unable, or refuses to act, the president pro tempore shall preside. If the mayor and the president pro tempore are absent, fail, are unable, or refuse to act, any alderman may be appointed to preside at the meeting by a majority of the aldermen in attendance. 
Resident means any person having a legal fixed domicile within the boundaries of the City of South Houston, Texas. 
Secretary means the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94)  
Sec. 2-82. - Time and location of regular meetings. 
The governing body shall hold its regular meetings on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month at a place and time designated on the agenda. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. 96-010, § 1, 7-16-96; Ord. No. 96-029, § 1, 12-10-96; Ord. No. 97-002, § 1, 1-14-97; Ord. No. 97-021, § 1, 8-5-97; Ord. No. 98-013, § 1, 10-13-98; Ord. No. 98-015, § 1, 10-27-98; Ord. No. 98-025, § 1, 12-1-98; Ord. No. 2000-111, § 1, 7-11-00; Ord. No. 2009-16, § 1, 7-7-09)  
Sec. 2-83. - Agenda. 
(a)  The secretary shall make public, in accordance with the Texas Open Meetings Act, an agenda containing all business to be discussed at a meeting of the city council. 
(b)  Any city council member or mayor wishing to place any item(s) on the council agenda may submit the item(s) in writing to the secretary not later than 12:00 noon of the fourth day preceding the meeting. The secretary shall designate verbatim, and post on said agenda for each city council meeting, in the chronological order requested, any items timely requested by any one or more city council members, or the mayor, for inclusion and consideration and/or action on the agendas of meetings of the South Houston City Council, without modification. No other member or members of the governing body may preclude, prevent, impede or otherwise interfere with the inclusion or consideration of such agenda items and/or action thereon. 
(c)  Any resident or non-resident wishing to address or discuss with the city council a topic which has not been placed on the council agenda may submit a written request to the secretary to place such topic on the agenda. Such written request must be received not later than 12:00 noon on the fourth day preceding the meeting. If the request is approved by any member of the governing body of the City of South Houston, the secretary shall place the item(s) on the agenda of the council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. 95-018, § 1, 10-3-95; Ord. No. 96-007, § 2, 6-4-96; Ord. No. 2004-23, § 1, 7-20-04; Ord. No. 2006-16, § 2, 5-16-06)  
Sec. 2-84. - Parliamentary procedure. 
To ensure that the will of the majority prevails while the right of the minority to be heard is protected, "Robert's Rules of Order" shall prevail at all meetings of the city council to the extent that "Robert's Rules of Order" does not conflict with the Texas Open Meetings Act, state statute, or this ordinance. Unless otherwise prescribed by law, council action on all motions shall be decided by a simple majority vote of the council. All of the chairman's decisions regarding procedures, including the chairman's refusal to allow a motion to be considered, are subject to appeal by any member of the council. A simple majority vote is all that is required to overrule the chairman on procedural issues. If the chairman refuses to honor the appeal, the person making the appeal may state the question and put the question to a vote. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94)  
Sec. 2-85. - Minutes. 
(a)  The city secretary shall attend each meeting of the governing body and shall keep, in a record provided for that purpose, accurate minutes of the governing body's proceedings. 
(b)  A council member shall have the privilege of entering an abstract of his statements on any subject pertaining to city business and affairs in the minutes. 
(c)  The city secretary, with consent of the council, may enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the council. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94)  
Sec. 2-86. - Presentation to the city council. 
(a)  Request by resident. Any resident who wishes to address the council on any matter on the council agenda may do so by signing a list provided at any time prior to opening of the meeting and specifying the particular subject matter of such address. If the subject matter listed by the resident who wishes to speak refers to an agenda item that has been placed on the agenda for the particular council session, the resident will be allowed to speak prior to any council action on that agenda item. 
(b)  Request by nonresident. Any nonresident wishing to address the council shall notify the secretary and specify his interest in the matter being considered twenty-four (24) hours prior to the time the meeting is being held. Upon timely notification, a nonresident shall be permitted to address the council when the applicant claims an interest in a matter on the council's agenda, and he is so situated that the disposition of the agenda may, as a practical matter, impair or impede his ability to protect that interest. 
(c)  Reading of protests, etc. Upon complying with the provisions of this section, interested persons may, at their discretion, address the council by reading of protests, petitions, or communications in regard to matters under the council's consideration. 
(d)  Written communication. All interested parties or their authorized representatives may address the council by written communication regarding matters under the council's consideration. 
(e)  Recognition. No person shall address the council without first being recognized by the presiding officer or a majority of members of the council in attendance. 
(f)  Procedure. Each person, upon being properly recognized, shall address the council through the microphone provided for the use of the public and give his name and address in an audible tone of voice for the records, state the subject he wishes to discuss, state whom he is representing if he represents an organization or other persons, and unless further time is granted by majority vote of the council, shall limit his remarks as follows: When speaking on agenda items, limit to five (5) minutes or, if speaking on nonagenda items, to ten (10) minutes. All remarks shall be addressed to the council as a whole and not to any member thereof. Members of council may enter into discussion with or question the person addressing council. 
(g)  Spokesperson for group. In order to expedite matters and to avoid repetitious presentations, whenever any group of persons wishes to address the council on the same subject matter, it shall be proper for the presiding officer to request that a spokesperson be chosen by the group to address the council and, in case additional matters are to be presented by any other member of said group, to limit the number of such persons addressing the council. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94)  
Sec. 2-87. - Rules of decorum. 
(a)  Members of the governing body. While the council is in session, all members of the governing body must preserve and maintain order and decorum. 
(1)  Subject matter. Every member desiring to speak shall confine discussion to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language. 
(2)  Interruptions. A member of the city council shall not be interrupted while speaking. 
(3)  No member of the governing body shall speak during the citizens' hearing, except as herein permitted, and all members shall refrain from making expressly impertinent, slanderous, discourteous or profane remarks and shall not willfully utter loud, threatening or abusive language, nor engage in any disorderly conduct which would impede, disrupt, or disturb the orderly conduct of any meeting, hearing, or other proceedings. 
(4)  No member of the governing body shall violate any portion of section 2-87, as amended, including, but not limited to, subsection (a)(1) styled "subject matter" which says; "Every member desiring to speak shall confine discussion to the question under debate, avoiding all personalities and indecorous language." This quoted portion of subsection (a)(1) is interpreted to apply to all other portions of the agenda when the public is restricted from speaking. 
(b)  Persons addressing council. Any resident may address council during the citizens' hearing portions of any agenda. Addressing council means that comments shall be directed to council, not questions asked of council. Those who are permitted to address council do not include members of the governing body. This is for citizens, as distinguished from council members, because council members are not restricted to one part of the agenda and they have adequate time to speak during the rest of the meeting when the public is not allowed to speak. The public only has these two (2) agenda positions to make their desires known to council. The citizens' hearing for agenda items to be limited to five (5) minutes from the time he or she commences talking. The citizens' hearing for nonagenda items to be limited to three (3) minutes from the time he or she commences talking. No council member shall be permitted to speak or interrupt during the citizens' hearing portion of the agenda, without the consent of a majority of council, unless an express exception applies, and his or her attempt to speak during the citizens' hearing shall be out of order. These are the exceptions: 
(1)  The mayor may speak on parliamentary procedure and shall speak to preserve order. During the citizens' hearing portion of the agenda, the mayor shall confine his or her comments to the ceremonial aspects of his or her role and to matters pertaining to how the meeting shall proceed. On any item other than a discussion of procedure or reasonable and valid point of order, he or she shall not permit a council member to speak without the approval of a majority of council. 
(2)  A council person may speak to exercise his or her right to remove a disorderly member of the audience, allowed herein and to raise points of parliamentary procedure on a valid point of order. 
(3)  A council person may speak about removal of violators of decorum rules and during and about parliamentary matters dealing with rulings or actions by the presiding officer, but not otherwise. 
Any member of the public making expressly impertinent, slanderous, discourteous or profane remarks or who willfully utters loud, threatening or abusive language, or who engages in any disorderly conduct which would impede, disrupt, or disturb the orderly conduct of any meeting, hearing, or other proceedings, shall be called to order by any member of the governing body, and if such conduct continues, may, at the discretion of any member of the governing body, be removed and barred from further audience before the council during the meeting. Such removal power shall not be exercised to eject from the meeting a voting member of council, or any officer, employee or consultant, for the city scheduled to assist council (as part of his or her job) in meetings to make a presentation or give testimony about a particular agenda item on the agenda when that agenda item is under deliberation, at the meeting at which he or she is in attendance. Physical intimidation, taunts, threats or similar menacing conduct shall not be tolerated from a member of the audience or from a member of the governing body. If a mayor or member of council persists in such unacceptable behavior, he or she may be publicly censured by council and council may pursue other remedies until such conduct ceases or that person is no longer a member of council. The remedy for boorish and/or menacing behavior in a public official shall be reprimand, censure, impeachment or removal from office but not removal from a meeting at which he or she has a right to vote, unless he or she commits a breach of the peace or a violation of the Texas Penal Code. In other words, this section shall not be used to remove such an official, but there are limits to such conduct that may justify removal. 
(c)  Members of the audience. No person in the audience shall engage in disorderly conduct such as hand clapping, stamping of feet, whistling, use of profane or vulgar language, yelling, holding placards and similar demonstrations, which conduct disturbs the peace and good order of the meeting. 
(d)  Persons authorized to be within certain area. No person except members of the council and the city staff shall be permitted past the speaker's stand without the consent of the presiding officer or a majority vote of council members in attendance. 
(e)  No member of the public shall violate any portion of section 2-87 of the South Houston Code, as amended. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful to violate any provision of this section and the penalties shall be those provided for ordinance violation in the City Code. 
(g)  The provisions of this section are severable. If any portion is declared to be unenforceable, the remaining portions shall be enforceable. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94; Ord. No. 97-018, §§ 1—5, 7-22-97; Ord. No. 97-020, §§ 1—5, 8-5-97)  
Sec. 2-88. - Lighting for cameras and recording devices. 
Supplemental lighting for television and motion picture cameras shall be used only with the exercise of extreme discretion with regard to the intensity and duration of such lighting and with a view to creating the least amount of interference with or disturbance of the proceedings of the council and the least amount of discomfort to council members and the public in attendance. The majority of council members shall have the authority to determine whether the intensity and/or duration of supplemental lighting is such that it disturbs the proceedings of the council and upon making such a determination require that the use of such lighting be discontinued. 
(Ord. No. 94-015, § 1, 4-19-94)  
Secs. 2-89—2-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - RECORDS AND INFORMATION MANAGEMENT[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 892, § 1, adopted Nov. 21, 1990, amended the Code by the addition of provisions designated as Art. V, which provisions have been included herein at the discretion of the editor as §§ 2-101—2-116. 
 
Sec. 2-101. - Definition of municipality records. 
All documents, papers, letters, books, maps, photographs, sound or video recordings, microfilm, magnetic tape, electronic media, or other information recording media, regardless of physical form of characteristic and regardless of whether public access to it is open or restricted under the laws of the state, created or received by South Houston or any of its officers or employees pursuant to law or in the transaction of public business are hereby declared to be the records of the City of South Houston and shall be created, maintained, and disposed of in accordance with the provision of this article or procedures authorized by it and in no other manner. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(1), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-102. - Additional definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed: 
Department head means the officer who by ordinance, order, or administrative policy is in charge of an office of the city that creates or receives records. 
Essential record means any record of the city necessary to the resumption or continuation of operations of the city in an emergency or disaster to the re-creation of the legal and financial status of the city, or to the protection and fulfillment of obligations to the people of the state. 
Permanent record means any record of the city for which the retention period on a records control schedule is given as permanent. 
Records control schedule means a document prepared by or under the authority of the records management officer listing the record maintained by the city, their retention periods, and other records disposition information that the records management program may require. 
Records liaison officers means the persons designated under section 2-110. 
Records management means the application of management techniques to the creation, use, maintenance, retention, preservation, and disposal of records for the purposes of reducing the costs and improving the efficiency of recordkeeping. The term includes the development of records control schedules, the management of filing and information retrieval systems, the protection of essential and permanent records, the economical and space-effective storage of inactive records, control over the creation and distribution of forms, reports, and correspondence, and the management of micrographics and electronic and other records storage systems. 
Records management committee means the committee established in section 2-107. 
Records management officer means the person designated in section 2-105. 
Records management plan means the plan developed under section 2-108. 
Retention period means the minimum time that must pass after the creation, recording, or receipt of a record, of the fulfillment of certain actions associated with a record, before it is eligible for destruction. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(2), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-103. - Municipal records declared public property. 
All municipality records as defined in section 2-101 are hereby declared to be the property of the city. No municipality official or employee has, by virtue of his or her position, any personal or property right to such records even though he or she may have developed or complied them. The unauthorized destruction, removal from files, or use of such records is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(3), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-104. - Policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the city to provide for efficient, economical, and effective controls over the creation, distribution, organization, maintenance, use, and disposition of all municipal records through a comprehensive system of integrated procedures for the management of records from their creation to their ultimate disposition, consistent with the requirements of the Texas Local Government Records Act and accepted records management practice. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(4), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-105. - Records management officer—Designation. 
The city secretary, and the successive holders of said office, shall serve as records management officer for the city. As provided by state law, each successive holder of the office shall file his or her name with the director and librarian of the Texas State Library within thirty (30) days of the initial designation or of taking up the office, as applicable. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(5), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-106. - Same—Duties. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article, the records management officer shall: 
(1)  Administer the records management program and provide assistance to department heads in it implementation; 
(2)  Plan, formulate, and prescribe records disposition policies, systems, standards, and procedures; 
(3)  In cooperation with department heads identify essential records and establish a disaster plan for each municipality office and department to ensure maximum availability of the records in order to reestablish operations quickly and with minimum disruption and expense; 
(4)  Develop procedures to ensure the permanent preservation of the historically valuable records of the municipality; 
(5)  Establish standards for filing and storage equipment and for recordkeeping supplies; 
(6)  Study the feasibility of and, if appropriate, establish a uniform filing system and a forms design and control system for the city; 
(7)  Provide records management advice and assistance to all municipal departments by preparation of a manual or manuals of procedure and policy and by on-site consultation; 
(8)  Monitor record retention schedules and administrative rules issued by the Texas State Library and Archives Commission to determine if the records management program and the municipality's records control schedules are in compliance with state regulations; 
(9)  Disseminate to the municipality and department heads information concerning state laws and administrative rules relating to local government records; 
(10)  Instruct records liaison officers and other personnel in policies and procedures of the records management plan and their duties in their records management program; 
(11)  Direct records liaison officers or other personnel in the conduct of records inventories in preparation for the development of records control schedules as required by state law and this article; 
(12)  Ensure that the maintenance, preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition of municipality [records] is carried out in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program and the requirements of state law; 
(13)  Maintain records on the volume of records destroyed under approved records control schedules, the volume of records microfilmed or stored electronically, and the estimated cost and space savings as the result of such disposal or disposition; 
(14)  Report annually to the municipality on the implementation of the records management plan in each department of the city, including summaries of the statistical and fiscal data compiled under subsection (13); and 
(15)  Bring to the attention of the municipality noncompliance by department heads or other municipal personnel with the policies and procedures of the records management program or the Local Government Records Act. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(8), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-107. - Establishment of records management committee; duties. 
A records management committee consisting of the department head's records liaison officers is hereby established. The committee shall: 
(1)  Assist the records management officer in the development of policies and procedures governing the records management program; 
(2)  Review the performance of the program on a regular basis and propose changes and improvements if needed; 
(3)  Review and approve records control schedules submitted by the records management officer; 
(4)  Give final approval to the destruction of records in accordance with approved records control schedules; and 
(5)  Actively support and promote the records management program throughout the city. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(6), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-108. - Records management plan to be developed; approval of plan; authority of plan. 
(a)  The records management officer and the records management committee shall develop a records management plan for the city for submission of the municipality. The plan must contain policies and procedures designed to reduce the costs and improve the efficiency of recordkeeping, to adequately protect the essential records of the municipality that are of historical value. The plan must be designed to enable the records management officer to carry out his or her duties prescribed by state law and this article effectively. 
(b)  Once approved by the city the records management plan shall be binding on all offices, departments, divisions, programs, commissions, bureaus, boards, committees, or similar entities of the city and records shall be created, maintained, stored, microfilmed, or disposed of in accordance with the plan. 
(c)  State law relating to the duties, other responsibilities, or recordkeeping requirements of a department head do not exempt the department head or the records in the department head's care from the application of this article and the records management plan adopted under it and may not be used by the department head as a basis for refusal to participate in the records management program of the city. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(7), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-109. - Duties and responsibilities of department heads. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article, department heads shall: 
(1)  Cooperate with the records management officer in carrying out the policies and procedures established in the city for the efficient and economical management of records and in carrying out the requirements of this article; 
(2)  Adequately document the transaction of government business and the services, programs, and duties for which the department head and his or her staff are responsible; and 
(3)  Maintain the records in his or her care and carry out their preservation, microfilming, destruction, or other disposition only in accordance with the policies and procedures of the records management program of the city and the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(9), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-110. - Records liaison officers—Designated. 
Each department head shall designate a member of his or her staff to serve as a records liaison officer for the implementation of the records management program in the department. If the records management officer determines that in the best interests of the records management program more than one records liaison officer should be designated for the department, the department head shall designate the number of records liaison officers specified by the records management officer. Persons designated as records liaison officers shall be thoroughly familiar with all the records created and maintained by the department and shall have full access to all records of the city maintained by the department. In the event of the resignation, retirement, dismissal, or removal by action of the department head of a person designated as a records liaison officer, the department head shall promptly designate another person to fill the vacancy. A department head may serve as records liaison officer for his or her department. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(10), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-111. - Same—Duties and responsibilities. 
In addition to other duties assigned in this article, records liaison officers shall: 
(1)  Conduct or supervise the conduct of inventories of the records of the department in preparation for the development of records control schedules; 
(2)  In cooperation with the records management officer coordinate and implement the policies and procedures of the records management program, in their departments; and 
(3)  Disseminate information to department staff concerning the records management program. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(11), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-112. - Records control schedules to be developed; approval; filing with state. 
(a)  The records management officer, in cooperation with department heads and records liaison officers, shall prepare records control schedules on a department by department basis listing all records created or received by the department and the retention period for each record. Records control schedules shall also contain such other information regarding the disposition of municipal records as the records management plan may require. 
(b)  Each records control schedule shall be monitored and amended as needed by the records management officer on a regular basis to ensure that it is in compliance with records retention schedules issued by the state and that it continues to reflect recordkeeping procedures and needs to the department and the records management program of the city. 
(c)  Before its adoption a record control schedule or amended schedule for a department must be approved by the department head and the members of the records management committee. 
(d)  Before its adoption a records control schedule must be submitted to and accepted for filing by the director and librarian as provided by state law. If a schedule is not accepted for filing, the schedule shall be amended to make it acceptable for filing. The records management officer shall submit the records control schedules to the director and librarian. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(12), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-113. - Implementation of records control schedules; destruction of records under schedule. 
(a)  A records control schedule for a department that has been approved and adopted under section 2-108 shall be implemented by department heads and records liaison officers according to the policies and procedures of the records management plan. 
(b)  A record whose retention period has expired on a records control schedule shall be destroyed unless an open records request is pending on a record, the subject matter of the record is pertinent to a pending law suit, or the department head shall request in writing to the records management committee that the record be retained for an additional period. 
(c)  Prior to the destruction of a record under an approved records control schedule, authorization for the destruction must be obtained by the records management officer from the records management committee. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(13), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-114. - Destruction of unscheduled records. 
A record that has not yet been listed on an approved records control schedule may be destroyed if its destruction has been approved in the same manner as a record destroyed under an approved schedule and the records management officer has submitted to and received back from the director and librarian an approved destruction authorization request. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(14), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-115. - Records center. 
A records center, developed pursuant to the plan required by section 2-108 shall be under the direct control and supervision of the records management officer. Policies and procedures regulating the operations and use of the records center shall be contained in the records management plan developed under section 2-108. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(15), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-116. - Micrographics. 
Unless a micrographics program in a department is specifically exempted by order of the municipality, all microfilming of records will be centralized and under the direct supervision of the records management officer. The records management plan will establish policies and procedures for the microfilming of municipality records, including policies to ensure that all microfilming is done in accordance with standards and procedures for the microfilming of local government records established in rules of the Texas State Library and Archives Commission. The plan will also establish criteria for determining the eligibility of records for microfilming. The plan will also establish criteria for determining the eligibility of records for microfilming, and protocols for ensuring that a microfilming program that is exempted from the centralized operations is, nevertheless, subject to periodic review by the records management officer as cost-effectiveness, administrative efficiency, and compliance with commission rules. 
(Ord. No. 892, § 1(16), 11-21-90)  
Sec. 2-117. - Fees—Birth certificates and death certificates. 
The City of South Houston shall charge a fee or fees, as set forth in the following schedule for issuance of birth certificates and death certificates: 
Issuance of a birth certificate ..... $22.00 
Additional copies ordered at the same time, each ..... $3.00 
Issuance of a death certificate ..... $20.00 
Additional copies ordered at the same time, each ..... $3.00 
Fees collected on the issuance of a vital statistics record ..... $1.00 
(Ord. No. 2004-28, § 1, 8-17-04; Ord. No. 2005-46, § 1, 12-6-05; Ord. No. 2006-10, § 1, 4-18-06)  
Sec. 2-118. - "Dead-letter" file. 
No document may be removed from an employee's personnel file, except by council action. Any council action removing any document from any employee's personnel file shall be attached to the document to be removed and refiled in a "dead-letter" file to be kept and maintained by the human resources department as a public record. 
All other documents shall remain in the employee's personnel file for the retention period. 
(Ord. No. 2007-05, § 1, 3-6-07)  
Secs. 2-119—2-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - CITY-OWNED VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, adopted December 21, 1993, amended the Code by the addition of §§ 2-200—2-208, which provisions have been redesignated at the discretion of the editor as §§ 2-131—2-139. 
 
Sec. 2-131. - Assignment of vehicles. 
Individuals may be assigned a city-owned vehicle by the city council if they meet one of the following criteria: 
(a)  They work alone and are away from the usual worksite a minimum of fifty (50) percent of the scheduled work time; 
(b)  The vehicle is a special use vehicle specific to the job or is used for transporting special equipment; or 
(c)  The individual to whom the vehicle is assigned is a person with on-call status. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-132. - Responsibility. 
Employees or other individuals assigned said vehicles will be responsible for seeing that the vehicle is kept in good working condition and for maintaining its current state vehicle inspection status. Maintenance service and repair shall be in accordance with usual city practices. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-133. - Home storage restrictions. 
An individual assigned a vehicle for home storage, rather than on work-site storage, may drive that vehicle to and from home provided all the following factors are met: 
(a)  Adequate safe parking is available; 
(b)  The home is within one mile of South Houston city limits, or is within the city limits; 
(c)  The vehicle is not used for personal business, except as specified in this policy. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-134. - Home storage assignments. 
City employees who may be assigned a city-owned vehicle for home storage are: 
(a)  Personnel with substantial emergency responsibilities; 
(b)  Police officers assigned a marked vehicle under police department policy approved by the governing body. 
(c)  The city's warrant officer is exempt from the provisions of this article VI pertaining to the city-owned vehicle assigned to him. 
(d)  One detective on call is authorized for home storage of his vehicle during the times that he is designated as "detective on call". 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93; Ord. No. 2004-11, §§ 1, 2, 4-20-04)  
Sec. 2-135. - Special vehicles. 
Special vehicles which can respond directly to a call or emergency and are assigned to an individual on call may be stored at home provided all the conditions in sections 2-131 through 2-139 of this article are met. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93; Ord. No. 2004-08, § 2, 4-6-04)  
Sec. 2-136. - Statement of policy. 
Employees' convenience does not constitute a basis for home storage authorization and the city has no obligation to provide employees means of transportation to and from work. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-137. - Marking of vehicles. 
All city vehicles will be marked in accordance with the state law. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-138. - Driver's license required. 
All employees who drive city vehicles must keep on file with the city secretary a copy of a valid Texas driver's license. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-139. - Personal use of city vehicles. 
(a)  An individual who is on call or scheduled stand-by and has been assigned a vehicle for home storage, and who is subject to call at a moment's notice, may use the vehicle as personal transportation. 
(b)  An individual who is assigned a city-owned vehicle and does not have a personal car with him at work may use the city vehicle for going to lunch, doctor's appointments, etc., that require leaving and returning to the workplace, provided that the trip is not outside the city. 
(c)  An individual can make short stops in the city vehicle when going to and from work, but reasonable discretion should be used. 
(d)  If a take-home city vehicle is issued to an employee and is being used for personal use because of being subject to an emergency call, his/her immediate family members, who reside with the employee, may be carried as passengers. When the vehicle is being used for city business, only city employees may be in the vehicle. 
(e)  Other personal use of the city-owned vehicle is specifically prohibited. Violation of this policy constitutes just cause for employee discipline and/or termination. 
(Ord. No. 990 (12-93), § 1, 12-21-93)  
Sec. 2-140. - Chief of police and the two captains in command. 
The chief of police and the two captains in command are exempt from the provisions of this article VI pertaining to the city owned vehicles assigned to them, providing their residences are within twenty (20) miles of South Houston city limits, or within the city limits. 
(Ord. No. 2004-08, § 1, 4-6-04; Ord. No. 2006-29, § 2, 10-3-06)  
Sec. 2-141. - Crime control and prevention district. 
Police officers assigned to the crime control and prevention district are exempt from the provisions of this article VI pertaining to the city-owned vehicles assigned to them. 
(Ord. No. 2004-11, § 3, 4-20-04)  
Sec. 2-142. - Public works director. 
The public works director is exempt from the provisions of this article VI pertaining to the city owned vehicle assigned to him. 
(Ord. No. 2005-05, § 1, 3-1-05)  
Chapter 2.5 - ALARM SYSTEMS 
 
Sec. 2.5-1. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to this chapter: 
Alarm agent: Any individual employed by an alarm business whose duties including altering, installing, maintaining, moving, repairing, replacing, selling, servicing, responding to, or monitoring an alarm system. It shall also mean any person employed or otherwise associated with an alarm business who has access to confidential information relating to a customer or subscriber of such alarm business which could be used to compromise or defeat an alarm system. 
Alarm user: Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained, except for alarm systems on private residential property, or on motor vehicles, and except for alarm systems maintained by federal, state, county or municipal governments. 
Central station: Any premise, usually maintained by an alarm company, equipped to receive and displace signals from any type alarms. 
Chief of police: The Chief of the South Houston Police Department or his designated representative. 
City: The City of South Houston, Texas. 
Dial alarm: Any alarm or device which automatically selects a telephone line connected to police headquarters and reproduces a prerecorded message to report a criminal intrusion or other emergency requiring police response. 
False alarm: The activation of an alarm system or device through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, inclement weather, or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or device or his employees, agents or representatives. Specifically excepted are acts of God, such as false alarms caused by hurricanes, tornadoes, earthquakes and the like. 
Hold-up alarm: Any type alarm system or device designated to be activated by the alarm user or subscriber in the event of a hold-up or robbery. 
Home alarm: Any alarm device or system which is connected to a residence, excluding smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors. 
Person: Any individual, corporation, business, school district or other organization. 
Subscriber: A person that buys, leases or otherwise obtains an alarm system, other than a residential alarm system, and who contracts with an alarm business to monitor and/or service the alarm system 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(I), 11-26-96; Ord. No. 97-030, § 1, 11-11-97)  
Sec. 2.5-2. - Records. 
(a)  Every subscriber or alarm user of an alarm system or device within the city shall supply the records division or designated agent, with the name of at least two (2) people or an answering service which can reach people having access to and control over the building or area protected by such alarm system or device, who must be capable of disengaging the alarm. The subscriber must update such information with chief of police within three (3) days after any such person in no longer employed, available, or entitled to enter and exercise control over the premises and disengage such alarm. 
(b)  The person designated by the subscriber above shall be present at the scene of an alarm activation within twenty-five (25) minutes of being notified by the alarm agent or the city police department. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(II), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-3. - Permits. 
(a)  Before any alarm system is installed in the city, the person performing the installation, whether the alarm system company, user, or subscriber shall obtain a user permit for said installation. Such permit shall be maintained at the police department and shall be obtained from the chief of police or his designee by January 31 of each year. Any unlicensed alarm user, subscriber or person maintaining an alarm system with the city shall, within thirty (30) days of notification by the city police department, obtain a permit for the use of the system. The alarm user shall be responsible for renewal of the user permit, which renewal shall be obtained from the chief of police or his designee by January 31 of each year. Current alarm users or subscribers shall have until January 15, 1997, to come into compliance with this chapter requiring permits. Any system installed or any permit applied for at any time during the calendar year shall require a permit prior to installation, which permit cost shall be for the balance of the calendar year. Such permit shall expire on December thirty-first of the year issued. 
(b)  The permit shall require a fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) per year in the event the sound or signal produced is not activated at the police station and shall require thirty dollars ($30.00) per year in the event of activation of a sound or signal at the police station. An application for such permit shall be furnished by the police department to the applicant and shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant; 
(2)  Telephone number of applicant; 
(3)  Location of the alarm system and detailed description of the alarm system. 
(4)  Name of two (2) people capable of disengaging the system. 
(c)  The purpose of the permit is to provide sufficient information so that the city police department, when necessary, may provide assistance at the scene without undue delay caused by lack of information such as addresses, phone numbers and the like. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(III), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-4. - Power supply. 
Any alarm system which necessitates response by a law enforcement agency or is a public alarm shall be provided with standby power to automatically maintain the system in a normal condition for a period of four (4) hours in the event of the interruption of the primary power source. This does not apply where the central monitoring equipment produces a distinctive signal indicating power failure at the protected premises and a police response is not required. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(IV), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-5. - Maintenance. 
All alarm systems shall be subject to repair of correction no later than the end of the business day following the day on which the user or alarm agent receives notification of the need for such service. Each installation shall be thoroughly inspected once each year. A copy of the inspection shall be sent to the chief of police by the alarm agent on a yearly basis. The police chief of his delegate may require more frequent inspection. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(V), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-6. - Mechanical malfunctions. 
Whenever two (2) false alarms have been received within a one month period by the police department, it shall be the responsibility of the alarm agent to inspect and repair the alarms upon notification by alarm user or subscriber. The alarm agent shall send a copy of the inspection to the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(VI), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-7. - Dial alarm receiving equipment. 
After the enactment of this chapter, no automatic protection devices known as dial alarms or dialers will be installed and keyed to any police emergency trunk line. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(VII), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-8. - Testing of equipment. 
No person shall conduct any test or demonstration of a police alarm device or system in the city without first obtaining permission from the chief of police or his authorized representative. Permission to conduct such test of a police alarm device or system shall not be necessary when the alarm device is connected to an intermediary receiver and not relayed to police headquarters and precaution has been taken to ensure that such test will not cause police response or alarm to the general public. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(VIII), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-9. - Inspection. 
The city shall be entitled to inspect any alarm installation during regular business hours. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(IX), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-10. - Penalties. 
(a)  Violation of any section of this chapter shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed the fine established in section 1-7 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of South Houston. 
(b)  The knowing failure of an alarm user to inspect or repair an alarm where required herein is an offense hereunder. Each day during which such failure continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  The intentional installation or maintenance of an alarm not in accordance with the requirements of this chapter is an offense hereunder. 
(d)  It is an offense to knowingly or recklessly fail to attend upon the scene of an alarm activation within the time period set forth herein after actual notice has been given to the person designated to enter and control any premises. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(X), 11-26-96)  
Sec. 2.5-11. - Cost of response. 
The following fees shall be charged to the alarm user for each response by the city for an alarm which has caused or experienced more than five (5) false alarms in any one calendar year: 
For the 6th, 7th, 8th and 9th alarm response call: Twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per call. 
For the 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, 14th and 15th alarm response call: Fifty dollars ($50.00) per call. 
For the 16th and any more alarm response calls: Seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per call. 
These charges or fees shall be due and payable whether or not any of the 6th through the 16th or greater alarm response calls are characterized as false alarms. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(XI), 11-26-96; Ord. No. 97-030, § 2, 11-11-97)  
Sec. 2.5-12. - Exemption for charge for cost of response. 
An exemption from the above-delineated charge for response to false alarms may be granted, upon recommendation of the chief of police, for alarms that are activated by telephone circuit problems. 
(Ord. No. 96-030, § 1(XII), 11-26-96)  
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Alcoholic beverages, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 1.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
All definitions of words, terms, and phrases, as set forth in the Texas Liquor Control Act, are hereby adopted and made a part hereof by reference for the purpose of enforcing and interpreting this chapter. 
(Ord. of 1-9-50, § 1)  
Sec. 3-2. - License to manufacture, sell, distribute, etc. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, brew, distill, sell or distribute any wine, beer, liquor or other alcoholic beverage, or engage in any other activity for which a license or permit is required by the Texas Liquor Control Act, within the city, without first obtaining a license so to do from the city secretary. The annual fee for such license shall be one-half (½) the amount of the permit or license fee charged by the state for a similar activity. Licenses issued pursuant to this section shall run concurrently with the state license or permit held by the licensee. 
(b)  Any person violating this section shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(Ord. of 1-9-50, §§ 2—8) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to levy and collect fees for alcoholic beverage licenses and permits, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code 11.38, 61.36.  
Sec. 3-3. - Sale for on-premises consumption restricted to certain locations. 
(a)  The sale of alcoholic beverages for consumption on the premises where sold shall be permitted only in establishments located on the following streets or portions thereof: 
(1)  Galveston Highway, from Winkler Highway to the south city limits. 
(2)  College Avenue, from East Haven Boulevard to Galveston Highway. 
(3)  Shaver Street, from the north city limits south to the north side of Pampa Street. 
(4)  Spencer Highway, from Shaver Street to Galveston Highway or Houston Boulevard. 
(5)  Winkler Highway, from Main Street to Allen Street. 
(6)  Lots 1 through 4, Block 13, City of South Houston, Harris County, Texas, on the south side of Virginia Avenue between Jackson Street and Galveston Street. 
(7)  Lots 1, 2, 3, 10, 11 and 12, Block 327, City of South Houston, Harris County, Texas, otherwise known as 401 Pennsylvania, South Houston, Texas. 
(8)  Allen-Genoa Road, from Kolb Road to South Shaver Street, providing 60% of business comes from sources other than alcoholic drinks. 
(b)  No license shall be issued authorizing the sale of alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption in any establishment not located in accord with this section. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to authorize the sale of any alcoholic beverage in violation of section 3-4. 
(Ord. No. 498, §§ 2—4, 11-14-62; Ord. No. 957 (9-92), § 1, 9-15-92; Ord. No. 2006-09, § 2, 4-18-06; Ord. No. 2006-15, § 2, 5-16-06)  
Sec. 3-4. - Sale near church, school or hospital. 
The sale of beer, wine, liquor or other alcoholic beverages by any dealer whose principal business is the sale of such beverages is hereby prohibited in all cases where the place of business of such dealer is within three hundred (300) feet of any church, hospital, school or other educational institution, the measurements to be along the property lines of the street fronts, from front door to front door, and in a direct line across intersections where they occur. 
(Ord. of 1-9-50, § 9; Ord. No. 498, § 3, 11-14-62) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, V.T.C.A., Alcoholic Beverage Code § 109.33.  
Sec. 3-5. - Consumption in public places. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drink any alcoholic beverages in any public place within the limits of the city, except in taverns and other establishments licensed by the state for the sale of such beverages for consumption on the premises. 
(Ord. No. 356, 6-20-55)  
Chapter 3.5 - AMBULANCE SERVICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— City-owned vehicles, § 2-131 et seq.; emergency management, Ch. 8.5; police, Ch. 16.5; traffic, Ch. 22. 
 
Sec. 3.5-1. - Ambulance transportation fees. 
Beginning November 1, 1996, the city's emergency medical services (EMS) department shall invoice persons receiving the following services: 
(1)  Ambulance transport ..... $350.00 
(2)  Expenses for other services and drug treatments: 
a.  BLS routine disposable supplies, to be added to all invoices from the EMS department ..... 25.00 
b.  Oxygen ..... 6.00 
c.  Intravenous solutions, each ..... 10.00 
Routine drugs, each ..... 10.00 
Drugs: Adenosine, each ..... 25.00 
Disposable drug delivery system, to be added to invoices involving drug treatments ..... 15.00 
(Ord. No. 96-031, 10-15-96) 
Cross reference— Procedure upon approach of authorized emergency vehicle, § 22-23.  
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-1. - City designated as bird sanctuary. 
The entire area embraced within the corporate limits of the city is hereby designated as a bird sanctuary. 
(Ord. No. 599, 5-2-72)  
Sec. 4-2. - Trapping, shooting, molesting, etc., birds or wild fowl. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to trap, hunt, shoot or attempt to shoot or molest in any manner any bird or wild fowl or to rob bird nests or wild fowl nests within the city. 
(Ord. No. 599, 5-2-72) 
Cross reference— Prohibition against discharge of firearms in city, § 12-4.  
Sec. 4-3. - Destruction of birds constituting nuisance or menace to health. 
Notwithstanding the provisions of section 4-2, if Starlings or similar birds are found to be congregating in such numbers in a particular locality that they constitute a nuisance or a menace to health or property, in the opinion of the proper health authorities, such authorities shall meet with representatives of the Audubon Society, Bird Club, Garden Club or Humane Society, or as many of such clubs as are found to exist in the city, after having given at least three (3) days' actual notice of the time and place of such meeting to the representatives of such clubs. If, as a result of such meeting, no satisfactory alternative is found to abate such nuisance, such birds may be destroyed in such numbers and in such manner as is deemed advisable by the health authorities under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 599, 5-2-72) 
State Law reference— Authority to define and abate nuisances, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 217.002.  
Sec. 4-4. - Keeping or exhibiting wild or dangerous animals. 
(a)  The keeping, housing, caging or exhibiting of any wild animals or domestic animals that might be or become dangerous, obnoxious or a public nuisance or disturb or affect the health and peace of the citizens of the city is hereby prohibited. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to animals exhibited by a circus, animal show or educational exhibit for not more than ten (10) days, when a permit for the exhibition has been issued and proper safety guards are used and such animals are confined in cages such as are used or approved by the public zoo, or the building inspector or the chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 530, §§ 1, 2, 6-15-65)  
Sec. 4-5. - Rabies control generally. 
(a)  Every animal that has rabies or symptoms thereof, or any animal that bites, scratches or otherwise attacks any person within the city, shall be impounded and held for a period of fourteen (14) days in the city dog pound or any veterinary hospital designated by the health officer, and under the supervision of the health officer. 
(b)  Every animal that has been exposed to rabies shall be confined at once in the city dog pound or in some veterinary hospital designated by the health officer and kept there under the supervision of the health officer for such period of time as he may deem necessary. 
(c)  Any animal that has rabies or that is suspected of having rabies shall not be allowed, at any time, on the streets or public ways of the city until such animal is released from observation by the health officer or his deputy. 
(d)  The owner, keeper or person in charge of any animal that has rabies, or that has been exposed to rabies, or that has symptoms thereof, or that has bitten, scratched or otherwise attacked any person within the city, shall, on demand, turn over such animal to the health officer or to his deputy. 
(e)  The body of any animal that has died of rabies shall not be disposed of except as directed by the health officer. 
(f)  The provisions of this section relating to animals which have bitten a person shall not apply to dogs. In the case of a dog having bitten a person, the procedure prescribed by section 4-24 shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 452, Art. III, § 1, 3-3-60)  
Sec. 4-6. - Veterinarians to report communicable diseases. 
Every veterinarian or other person who is called to examine or professionally attend any animal within the city having glanders or farcy, rabies, tuberculosis or any other communicable disease shall, within twenty-four (24) hours thereafter, report in writing to the health officer the following facts:. 
(1)  A statement of the location of such diseased animal. 
(2)  The name and address of the owner thereof. 
(3)  The type and character of the disease. 
(Ord. No. 452, Art. III, § 4, 3-3-60)  
Sec. 4-7. - Training animals or fowl for fighting. 
No person shall possess, harbor, or maintain care or custody of any animal or fowl for fighting contests, nor shall any person train, torment, badger, bait, or use any animal for the reason of causing or encouraging the animal to attack human beings or domestic animals. 
(Ord. No. 2002-12, § 1, 6-4-02)  
Sec. 4-8. - Advisory board to humane department. 
(a)  There is hereby created an advisory board to the humane department of the city consisting of five (5) members, appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(b)  The advisory board shall consist of: 
(1)  A duly licensed veterinarian. 
(2)  A municipal official. 
(3)  Two (2) persons whose duties include the daily operation of the animal shelter. 
(4)  A person who is a representative of an animal welfare organization. 
(c)  The first appointments to positions created hereby shall be made immediately after the final passage hereof, and appointments thereafter shall be made on or before January 2nd of each year and take effect on that date. All appointments shall be from the effective date of appointment until January 2, 2005, and on each January 2nd thereafter; but each member of the board shall serve until his/her successor has been appointed and qualified. 
(d)  Members of the advisory board shall serve without pay. 
(e)  Three (3) members of the advisory board present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business of the board and a majority vote of the members present shall prevail. 
(f)  The board shall elect its chairman, vice-chairman and a secretary. Employees of the city shall not serve as officers of the board. The terms of all elected officers shall be concurrent and limited within the term of the officers' board membership. The meeting procedure and order of business shall be prescribed by the board. 
(g)  The advisory board shall prepare a written report to the mayor indicating therein the official actions of the board. 
(h)  The board shall make such investigations regarding the humane department and the animal shelter operated by the city as deemed necessary or advisable by the board and prepare a written report thereon. 
(Ord. No. 2003-21, §§ 1—8, 12-2-03)  
Secs. 4-9—4-16. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DOGS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Registration and restraint of dogs, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.031 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-17. - License. 
(a)  An initial issuance or renewal of each license must be made by the owner and be accompanied by a fee of ten dollars ($10.00); provided, however that the fee for an animal that has been spayed or neutered shall be a one-time fee of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) valid for the life of the animal. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to own, keep or have in his possession in the city on the premises owned or occupied by him, or at any other place, a dog for which a license for the current year has not been obtained as provided in this section. 
(c)  The provisions of this section requiring the licensing of dogs shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Dogs under the age of six (6) months, if kept within a sufficient enclosure. 
(2)  Dogs owned by, or in custody or under the control of, persons who are nonresidents of the city, traveling through the city, or temporarily sojourning therein for a period not exceeding thirty (30) days. 
(3)  Dogs brought to the city exclusively for the purpose of entering the same in any dog show or exhibition, and which are actually entered in and kept at such show or exhibition. 
(4)  Dogs duly and properly trained to aid or assist blind persons when any such dogs are actually being used by blind persons for the purpose of aiding or assisting such blind persons in going from place to place. 
(5)  Dogs kept in kennels, as defined in section 4-31, but the owner or keeper of such kennel shall pay a kennel license fee as provided in section 4-32. 
(d)  The office of the assessor and collector of taxes and the office of the humane officer of the city shall be the places where persons owning, keeping or having in possession any dog shall pay the license fee provided for in this section. Upon the payment of such fee, it shall be the duty of the issuing authority to furnish the person paying same with a license tag upon which shall be a number and the year for which it is issued, which tag shall be attached to the collar or harness of the dog for which issued, and worn by the dog at all times when upon the streets, alleys, sidewalks or public grounds of the city; provided, nothing in this section shall be construed as in any way excusing a licensed dog from the restrictions imposed by section 4-19. 
(e)  No dog license shall be issued unless there is exhibited to the licensing authority a certificate by a veterinarian showing that the dog to be licensed has, within twelve (12) months prior to the date of the license to be issued, been inoculated against rabies as required by section 4-18. 
(f)  The license issuing authority shall keep a permanent record of all licenses issued under the terms of this section, which record shall show the name and address of all persons being issued a license tag, the number of the license tag issued, the date issued and the amount paid therefor. 
(Ord. No. 452, Art. II, §§ 2—6, 3-30-60; Ord. No. 567, § 4, 3-5-68; Ord. No. 94-026, § 1, 9-6-94)  
Sec. 4-18. - Rabies vaccination. 
(a)  All dogs in the city over six (6) months of age must be vaccinated for rabies at least one time annually. All dogs in the city, as and when they become six (6) months of age, shall, upon attaining such age, be vaccinated one time for rabies and shall be vaccinated for rabies at least one time annually thereafter. All dogs which are brought into the city and which are more than six (6) months of age and which have not been vaccinated for rabies within twelve (12) months prior thereto shall be vaccinated at least one time for rabies within fifteen (15) days after their arrival in the city and shall likewise be vaccinated for rabies at least one time annually thereafter. Any person owning, keeping, harboring or maintaining a dog in the city who fails or refuses to comply with the vaccination requirements aforesaid shall be deemed guilty of an offense. 
(b)  A certificate of a duly licensed and qualified veterinarian of the vaccination required by this section, bearing the date thereof and the identification of the dog by breed color and sex and the license tag number and the name and address of the owner, shall be evidence of such vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 452, Art. II, § 13, 3-3-60)  
Sec. 4-19. - Running at large prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person owning or having in possession any dog to allow such dog to be at large upon the streets, sidewalks or public grounds of the city or upon the property of any person other than the owner or keeper of such dog. Any dog on the streets, sidewalks or public grounds of the city or on the property of such other person shall be considered to be at large in violation of this section, except a dog under the control of a person by means of a chain, rope, cord or leash of not more than fifteen (15) feet in length and of sufficient strength to control the action of such dog. 
(Ord. No. 452, Art. II, § 1, 3-3-60) 
State Law reference— Authority to prohibit dogs running at large, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 826.033.  
Sec. 4-20. - Impoundment generally.
