Chapter 6.1 - DISCRIMINATION  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6.1-1. - Grievance procedure relative to discrimination against the handicapped. 
(a)  Purpose. There is hereby created a discrimination against the handicapped grievance procedure to provide for the prompt and equitable resolution of complaints alleging actions prohibited by Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1983 as incorporated into 31 U.S.C. 6701 through 6724, the "Revenue Sharing Act" and regulated by 31 C.F.R., Sec. 51.55. 
(b)  Grievance procedure. Complaints alleging discrimination against a qualified handicapped individual cognizable under the acts or regulations set out in Section 504. 
Step 1. The person allegedly discriminated against shall submit the complaint or grievance with the Section 504 Coordinator, John Booher, P.O. Box 238, S. Houston, Texas, 77587. 
Step 2. The complaint shall contain a concise statement of the nature of the complaint, the requested action, and shall be in writing unless the handicap of the person dictates the use of alternate means of communication. All complaints shall be answered in writing within ten (10) days. 
(Ord. No. 719, §§ 1, 2, 9-18-84) 
Editor's note— Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 719, adopted Sept. 18, 1984, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein of said provisions as § 6.1-1 was at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 6.1-2—6.1-10. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - DISCRIMINATORY HOUSING PRACTICES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Article II, §§ 6.1-11—6.1-23, is derived from Ord. No. 643, §§ 1—13, enacted Dec. 5, 1978, which ordinance was nonamendatory of this Code. 
 
Sec. 6.1-11. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meanings given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words so used in the present tense include the future; words in the masculine gender include the feminine; words in the plural number include the singular, and words in the singular number include the plural. 
(a)  Discriminatory housing practice means an act that is unlawful under sections 6.1-12, 6.1-13, or 6.1-14 of this article. 
(b)  Dwelling means any building, structure or portion thereof which is occupied as, or designed and intended for occupancy as a residence by one or more families or any vacant land which is offered for sale or lease for the construction or location thereon of any such building, structure or portion thereof. 
(c)  Family includes a single individual. 
(d)  Person includes one or more individuals, corporations, partnerships, associations, labor organizations, legal representatives, mutual companies, joint stock companies, trusts, unincorporated organizations, trustees, fiduciaries, and any other organization or entity of whatever character. 
(e)  To rent includes to lease, to sublease, to let and otherwise to grant for a consideration the right to occupy premises not owned by the occupant. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 1, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-12. - Discrimination in the sale or rental of housing. 
Except as exempted by section 6.1-15, it shall be unlawful for any person to: 
(a)  Discrimination against any person in the terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of a dwelling, or in the provisions of services or facilities in connection therewith, because of race, color, sex, religion or national origin; 
(b)  Make, print, publish, or cause to be made, printed or published any notice, statement or advertisement regarding the sale or rental of a dwelling that indicates any preference, limitation or discrimination based on race, color, sex, religion or national origin, or an intention to make any such preference, limitation or discrimination; 
(c)  Represent to any person because of race, color, sex, religion or national origin that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when such dwelling is in fact so available; 
(d)  For profit or with the hope or expectation of profit, induce or attempt to include any person to sell or rent any dwelling by representations regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood of a person or persons of a particular race, color, sex, religion or national origin; 
(e)  For profit or with the hope or expectation of profit to influence or attempt to influence, by any word, acts, or failure to act, any seller, purchaser, landlord or tenant of a dwelling so as to promote the maintenance of racially segregated housing or so as to retard, obstruct or discourage racially integrated housing. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 2, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-13. - Discrimination in the financing of housing. 
It shall be unlawful for any bank, building and loan association, insurance company or other corporation, association, firm or enterprise whose business consists in whole or in part of the making of commercial or residential real estate loans, to deny a loan or other financial assistance to a person applying therefor for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining a dwelling; or to discriminate against any such person in the fixing of the amount, interest rate, brokerage points, duration; or other terms or conditions of such loan or other financial assistance, because of: 
(a)  The race, color, sex, religion or national origin of such person or of any person associated with him in connection with such loan or other financial assistance; or 
(b)  The race, color, sex, religion or national origin of the present or prospective owners, lessees, tenants or occupants of the dwelling or dwellings for which such loan or other financial assistance is to be made or given. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 3, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-14. - Discrimination in the provision of brokerage services. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deny access to or membership or participation in any multiple listing service, real estate brokers' organization or other service, organization or facility relating to the business of selling or renting dwellings, or to discriminate in the terms or conditions of such access, membership or participation on account of race, color, sex, religion or national origin. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 4, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-15. - Exemptions and exclusions. 
(a)  There shall be exempted from the application of section 6.1-12 hereof all transactions involving: 
(1)  The rental of units in dwellings containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than four (4) families living independently of each other if the owner actually maintains and occupies one of such units as his residence. 
(2)  The rental of a single room is a dwelling containing living quarters occupied or intended to be occupied by no more than one family if the person offering such room for rental actually maintains and occupies the remainder of such dwelling as his residence and not more than four (4) such rooms are offered. 
(3)  The sale or rental of any single house by a private individual who owns such house, provided that: 
a.  The sale or rental is made without the use in any manner of the sales or rental facilities or the sales or rental services of any real estate broker, agent or salesman or of such facilities or services of any person in the business of selling or renting dwellings or of an employee or agent of any such broker, agent, salesman or person; and 
b.  The sale is made without the publication, posting or mailing of any advertisement or written notice in violation of subsection (c) of this section (this shall not prohibit the use of attorneys, escrow agents, abstractors, title companies and other such professional assistance as necessary to perfect or transfer the title); and 
c.  The owner does not own more than three (3) single-family houses at the time of the sale; and 
d.  The owner does not own any interest in, nor is there owned or reserved on his behalf, under any express or voluntary agreement, title to or any right to all or any portion of the proceeds from the sale or rental of more than three (3) such single-family houses at any one time. 
e.  If the owner does not reside in the house at the time of sale or was not the most recent resident of such house prior to the sale, the exemption granted by this subsection shall apply only with respect to one such sale within any twenty-four-month period. 
(b)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit a religious organization, association or society or any nonprofit institution or organization operated, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious association or society from limiting the sale, rental or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons, unless membership in such religion is restricted on account of race, color, sex or national origin. 
(c)  Nothing in this article shall prohibit a bona fide private club, not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose, provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodgings to its members or from giving preference to its members. 
(d)  Nothing in this article shall bar any person from owning or operating a housing accommodation in which a room or rooms are leased, subleased or rented only to persons of the same sex, when such housing accommodation contains common lavatory, kitchen or similar facilities available for the use of all persons occupying such housing accommodation. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 5, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-16. - Fair housing administrator. 
The mayor shall appoint and council shall confirm a fair housing administrator (hereinafter referred to as "administrator"), who shall have the responsibility for implementing this article. The administrator may delegate his authority to investigate and conciliate complaints to other city employees under his direction. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 6, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-17. - Complaints. 
(a)  Only the person who claims to have been injured by a discriminatory housing practice who believes he will be irrevocably injured by a discriminatory housing practice that has occurred or is occurring (hereafter referred to as "person aggrieved") may file a complaint with the administrator. Such complaints shall be in writing and shall identify the person alleged to have committed or alleged to be committing a discriminatory housing practice and shall state the facts upon which the allegations of a discriminatory housing practice are based. The administrator shall prepare complaint forms and furnish them without charge to any person, upon request. 
(b)  If at any time the administrator shall receive or discover credible evidence and shall have probable cause to believe that any person or persons have committed or are committing a discriminatory housing practice as to which no complaint has been filed, the administrator may prepare and file a complaint upon his own motion and in his own name and such complaint shall therefore be treated in the same manner as a complaint filed by a person aggrieved. 
(c)  The administrator shall receive and accept notification and referral complaints from the U.S. Attorney General and the secretary of housing and urban development pursuant to the provisions of Title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1968, Public Law 90 284, and shall treat such complaints hereunder in the same manner as complaints filed pursuant to paragraph (a) of this section. 
(d)  All complaints shall be filed within sixty (60) days following the occurrence of an alleged discriminatory housing practice. Upon the filing or referral of any complaint, the administrator shall provide notice of the complaint by furnishing a copy of such complaint to the persons named therein who allegedly committed or were threatening to commit an alleged discriminatory housing practice. The accused may file an answer to the complaint within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the written complaint. 
(e)  All complaints and answer shall be subscribed and sworn to before an officer authorized to administer oaths. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 7, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-18. - Investigation. 
(a)  Upon the filing or referral of a complaint as herein provided, the administrator shall cause to be made a prompt and full investigation of the matter stated in the complaint. 
(b)  During or after the investigation, but subsequent to the mailing of the notice of complaint, the administrator shall, if it appears that a discriminatory housing practice has occurred or is threatening to occur, attempt by informal endeavors to effect conciliation, including voluntary discontinuance of the discriminatory housing practice and adequate assurance of future voluntary compliance with the provisions of this article. Nothing said or done in the course of such informal endeavors may be made public by the administrator, by the complainant or by any other party to the proceedings without the written consent of all persons concerned. 
(c)  Upon completion of the investigation and informal endeavors at conciliation by the administrator, but within thirty (30) days of the filing of the complaint with the administrator, if the efforts of the administrator to secure voluntary compliance have been unsuccessful, and if the administrator has made a determination that a discriminatory housing practice has in fact occurred, the administrator shall recommend to the city attorney that such violation be prosecuted in the municipal court of the City of South Houston. With such recommendation, the administrator shall refer his entire file to the city attorney. The city attorney shall, within thirty (30) days after such referral make a determination as to whether to proceed with prosecution of such complaint in municipal court. If the city attorney determines to prosecute, he shall institute a complaint and prosecute same to conclusion within thirty (30) days after such determination or as soon thereafter as practical. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 8, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-19. - Cumulative legal effect. 
This article is cumulative in its legal effect and is not in lieu of any and all other legal remedies which the person aggrieved may pursue. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 9, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-20. - Unlawful intimidation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to harass, threaten, harm, damage or otherwise penalize any individual, group or business because he or they have complied with the provisions of this article, because he or they have exercised his or their rights under this article, or enjoyed the benefits of this article, or because he or they have made a charge, testified or assisted in any manner in any investigation, or in any proceeding hereunder or have made any report to the administrator. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 10, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-21. - Cooperation with secretary of housing and urban development. 
The administrator and the city attorney are authorized to cooperate with the secretary of housing and urban development and the U.S. Attorney General pursuant to the provisions of Title VIII, Fair Housing Act of 1968, Public Law 90-284, and may render such service to the secretary as they shall deem appropriate to further the policies of this article. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 11, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-22. - Education and public information. 
In order to further the objectives of this article, the administrator may conduct educational and public information programs. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 12, 12-5-78)  
Sec. 6.1-23. - Penalty. 
Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be fined a sum not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation. Each day a violation continues after passage of seventy-five (75) days from date of the filing of the initial complaint with the administrator shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article may be enjoined by a suit filed by the city in a court of competent jurisdiction, and this remedy is in addition to any other penalty provision. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 13, 12-5-78)  
Chapter 7 - ELECTIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Elections, V.T.C.A., Election Code § 1.001 et seq.; candidate for city office, V.T.C.A., Election Code ch. 143. 
 
Sec. 7-1. - State law governs. 
All elections pertaining to municipal affairs shall be governed by the election laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 1, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-2. - General duties of mayor, city secretary and city council. 
In all city elections, the mayor, city secretary or the city council shall do and perform each act in other elections required to be done and performed respectively by the county judge, the county clerk or the commissioners' court. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 1, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-3. - Order and notice of election. 
In all city elections the mayor, or if he fails to do so, the city council, shall order the election and give notice thereof. In general elections for officers, the notice or proclamation shall be issued and posted at the polling places not later than twenty (20) days before the first Saturday in April of the year in which the election is to be held. The chief of police shall post a properly executed copy of the election proclamation and notice at the place where the election is to be held and two (2) other public places in the city. 
(Ord. No. 455, §§ 1, 9, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-4. - Elective officers. 
All municipal elections shall be conducted by one presiding officer or judge, one assistant judge and additional clerks, if the need arises and as set forth in the election order. Such judges and clerks shall be appointed by the mayor and shall receive such compensation as is prescribed by the city council. Such compensation shall be paid from the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 7, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-5. - Numbering of aldermanic positions. 
The city council shall number the positions of aldermen in the order in which the terms of office of those serving in 1960 expire, the expiring terms which are to be filled at the first election to be numbered Position No. 2, Position No. 3 and so on, and the next succeeding terms expiring to take the next two (2) larger numbers and the one lower number (Position No. 1) until all five (5) positions have been numbered. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 2, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-6. - Candidates' application generally. 
(a)  Any eligible and qualified person may have his name printed upon the official ballot as an independent candidate for the office of mayor or alderman or other city office by filing his sworn application with the mayor at least thirty (30) days prior to the election day. The application shall state the specific office or place being sought by the applicant and that the applicant is eligible and qualified under the laws of the state to become a candidate for and hold the office being sought, if elected. In the case of a person seeking the office of alderman, his application shall disclose the position number for which he is a candidate or the name of the incumbent holding the position. 
(b)  The form of the sworn application required by this section shall be substantially as follows: 
"To the Mayor of the City of South Houston, Texas, Greetings: 
"I, _______, hereby make application to have my name printed on the official ballot as an independent candidate for the office of _______ (state position number, if alderman) to be voted upon at the city election to be held on the _______ day of April, 19_______; and I hereby certify that I am qualified to make this application and that I am legally qualified to hold such office, if elected. 
"STATE OF TEXAS COUNTY OF HARRIS 
_______, being duly sworn, deposes and says that the statements contained in the foregoing application are true. 
(Signed) _______ 
"Subscribed and sworn to before me this the _______ day of ________, 19___. 
(SEAL) 
	      Notary Public in and for 
 	 
Harris County, Texas" 
(c)  The sworn application provided for in this section may be accompanied with a petition signed by qualified electors, although such petition is not required. 
(Ord. No. 455, §§ 2, 3, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-7. - Candidate's loyalty affidavit. 
The sworn application provided for by section 7-6 shall be accompanied by an executed copy of the loyalty affidavit as required by article 6.02 of the state election code, in substantially the following form: 
"I, _______, of the City of South Houston, County of Harris, State of Texas, being a candidate for the office of _______, do solemnly swear that I believe in and approve of our present representative form of government, and if elected, I will support and defend our present representative form of government and will resist any effort or movement from any source which seeks to subvert or destroy the same or any part thereof, and I will support and defend the Constitution and Laws of the United States and of the State of Texas. 
	      (Candidate's signature) 
 	 
"Sworn to and subscribed before me at South Houston, Texas, this the _______ day of _______, A.D. 19_______. 
(SEAL) 
	      Notary Public in and for Harris County, Texas" 
 	 
(Ord. No. 455, § 3, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-8. - Posting list of candidates. 
The names of all those persons who have filed their sworn applications to have their names printed on the official ballot as candidates shall be posted by the city secretary in a conspicuous place at his office for the inspection of the public for at least ten (10) days before he orders the ballots to be printed. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 4, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-9. - Objections to candidates. 
(a)  All objections to the regularity or validity of the application of any person as a candidate shall be made within five (5) days after posting the list of candidates by written notice filed with the city secretary setting forth the grounds of objections. Such objections will not be accepted, unless the person making them is a resident of the city qualified to vote in an election of the city. 
(b)  In case no such objection is filed within the time prescribed, the regularity or validity of the application of no person whose name is so posted shall be thereafter contested. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 4, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-10. - Printing of ballots; withdrawal of candidates. 
(a)  Any person eligible to the office of mayor, alderman or other office who has filed his sworn application in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall have his name printed on the official ballots. The names shall be arranged on the ballot in the order of being drawn by lot by the election judge prior to the printing of the ballots. 
(b)  Any candidate may cause his name to be withdrawn at any time before the official ballots are actually printed, by filing in writing with the city secretary a request to that effect over his own signature, duly attested by a notary public. No name so withdrawn shall be printed on the ballots. Not later than twenty (20) days before the city general election, the city secretary shall have the official ballots printed. 
(Ord. No. 455, §§ 2, 5, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-11. - Voting place and time. 
All elections for the selection of city officials shall be held at the City Office or City Hall between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 8, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-12. - Absentee voting. 
Each qualified voter who desires to cast an absentee vote and who expects to be absent on the day of the city general election shall be entitled to an official ballot and the right to cast such ballot in accordance with the provisions of article 5.05 of the State Election Code. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 6, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-13. - Notice to persons elected; failure to qualify. 
It shall be the duty of the city secretary to notify all persons elected, and all newly elected officers may enter upon their duties on the fifth day thereafter, Sundays excepted. If any such officer fails to qualify within thirty (30) days after his election, his office shall be deemed vacant, and a new election shall be held to fill the same. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 10, 5-17-60)  
Sec. 7-14. - Records to be kept. 
The city secretary shall preserve in his office, for a period of two (2) years, all applications, notice of objections and other related papers pertaining to elections. 
(Ord. No. 455, § 4, 5-17-60)  
Chapter 8 - ELECTRICAL CODE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 98-004, §§ 1, 2, adopted April 28, 1998, repealed chapter 8 in its entirety and adopted a new Electrical Code. Formerly, such chapter pertained to similar provisions and derived from Ord. No. 97-035, §§ 1, 2, 11-25-97; Ord. No. 97-011, 4-8-97; Ord. No. 96-017, 10-1-96; Ord. No. 874, 7-17-90; Ord. No. 774, 12-1-87; Ord. No. 537, 12-21-65. 
Cross reference— Buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 6; fire prevention and protection, Ch. 9; applicability of electrical code to mobile homes permanently located outside mobile home park, § 13-45; plumbing and gas fitting, Ch. 17; signs, Ch. 18. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 8-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is the practical safeguarding of person and property from hazards arising from the use of electricity, and shall be known and cited as the "City of South Houston Electrical Code." 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-2. - Scope. 
(a)  Covered. This chapter covers: 
(1)  Electric conductors and equipment installed within or on public and private buildings or other structures, including mobile homes and recreational vehicles, and other premises such as yards, carnival, parking and other lots, and industrial substations. 
(2)  Conductors that connect the installations to supply of electricity, 
(3)  Other outside conductors on the premises. 
(b)  Not covered. This chapter does not cover: 
(1)  Installation in ships, watercraft, railway rolling stock, aircraft or automotive vehicles other than mobile homes and recreation vehicles. 
(2)  Installations underground in mines. 
(3)  Installations of railways for generation, transformation, transmission or distribution of power used exclusively for operation of rolling stock or installations used exclusively for signaling and communications purposes. 
(4)  Installations of communications equipment under the exclusive control of communications utilities, located outdoors or in building spaces used exclusively for such installations. 
(5)  Installations under the exclusive control of electric utilities for the purpose of communication, or metering, or for the generation, control, transformation, transmission and distribution of electric energy located in buildings used exclusively by utilities for such purposes or located outdoors on property owned or leased by the utility or on public highways streets, roads, etc., or outdoors by established rights on private property. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-3. - Definitions. 
Board member. Where used herein, "board member" shall be understood to mean any member of the electrical board of the City of South Houston. 
Building official. When the terms "building official is used, it shall be understood to mean the officer of the City of South Houston charged with the administration and enforcement of the building codes of the City of South Houston or their duly authorized deputy. 
City. The word "city" shall be construed to mean the municipal corporation, the City of South Houston, Harris County, Texas. 
Code. The word, "code" as used singular herein, shall be interpreted to mean the City of South Houston Electrical Code. 
Electrical inspector. When the term electrical inspectors is used, it shall be understood to mean the Electrical Inspector of the City of South Houston. 
Electrical maintenance work. "Electrical maintenance work" shall mean to keep in safe repair all electrical installations, apparatus, and equipment, to move or relocate existing electrical equipment within a building or the premises where the "maintenance electrician" is employed on a permanent basis for which a work permit is required. This does not include the installation of new electrical equipment or apparatus for which additional electrical work is required. 
Electrical work. When the term "electrical work" is used herein, it shall be interpreted to mean the installation, maintenance, alteration, repair or erection of any electrical wiring system, apparatus, device, appliance, fixture or equipment for which a permit is required under the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
N.E.C. The "N.E.C" shall mean the latest edition of the "National Electrical Code" as sponsored by the National Fire Protection Association through its National Electrical Code Committee and approved by the American National Standards Institute. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-4. - Franchise to install equipment on, under or over streets, ductline, etc. 
No person, firm or corporation that does not operate under a franchise granted by the city shall have the right to install any electrical conduit, wire, pole or equipment for the transmission, distribution or utilization of electrical energy, or for the operation of signals or the transmission of, intelligence on, over, or under the streets or public utility easements in the City of South Houston, without first obtaining from city council a franchise right or grant for the particular installation to be made. The installation so made under such franchise or grant shall be in strict conformance with all rules, regulations and ordinances of the city. 
Any installation of duct line, conduit, or wires under the public streets shall be in accordance with this Code and the city ordinances covering the use of public places and street. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-5. - Installation to conform with law. 
No certificate of approval shall be issued unless the installation is in strict conformance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-6. - Adoption of National Electrical Standards. 
The 2017 edition of the National Electrical Code is hereby adopted as part of this chapter, and shall govern and be followed in all electrical work, except in event of conflict with this chapter. The provisions of this chapter shall prevail. 
(1)  The National Fire Protection Association Pamphlet No. 70, "National Electrical Code". 
(2)  When the electrical board deems it necessary to add, suspend or revoke the use of certain materials or wiring techniques, the addition suspension or revocation shall not become effective until thirty (30) days after date of such addition suspension or revocation. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 2017-28 , § 2, 7-25-17)  
Sec. 8-7. - Suspension of approved material or wiring techniques. 
(a)  When the electrical board deems it necessary, it may suspend or revoke the use of certain materials or wiring techniques after written or public notification. 
(b)  No electrical material, apparatus, device, appliance, fixture or equipment shall be installed in the city unless it is listed. 
The maker's name, trademark or other identification symbol shall be placed on all electrical material, apparatus, device, appliance, fixture and equipment used or installed under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-8. - General notes. 
(a)  Liability for damages. This chapter shall not be interpreted to relieve from or lessen the responsibility of any party owning, operating or controlling any electric wiring, apparatus, devices, appliances, fixtures or equipment for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein, nor shall the city be held responsible for any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized or the certificates of approval issued. 
(b)  Penalty for violation of ordinance provisions. Any person, firm, corporation or the agent violating any of the provisions of the ordinance from which this chapter derives shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense, and in case of willful and continuous violation of the provisions of this chapter, the electrical inspector shall revoke and repeal all permits and privileges granted to person, firm or corporation 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-9. - Savings clause. 
All rights and remedies which have accrued in favor of the city under this chapter and amendments thereto shall be and are preserved for the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-10. - Penalty clause. 
(a)  That any person, firm or corporation who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter or who shall fail to comply with any requirement of this chapter or of the National Electric Code of latest issue, hereby adopted, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined in the sum not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and each and every day's continuance of any violation of any provision of this chapter shall constitute and be deemed a separate offense. 
(b)  That in case of any such violation of any of the terms or provisions of this chapter by a corporation or company, the officers, agents and person or persons responsible for directing, authorizing or permitting the violation shall be subject to the penalties herein provided. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-11. - Severability clause. 
The City Council of the City of South Houston, Texas does hereby declare that if any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause, phrase, word or portion of this chapter is declared invalid or unconstitutional by final judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction, that in such event, it would have passed and ordained any and all remaining portions of this chapter without the inclusion of that portion or portions which may be so found to be invalid or unconstitutional and declares that its intent is to make no portion of this chapter dependent upon the validity of any other portion thereof, and that all said remaining portions shall remain and continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-12—8-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ELECTRICAL BOARD 
 
Sec. 8-26. - Electrical board created. 
There is hereby created an electrical board consisting of five (5) members, appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-27. - Members of electrical board. 
(a)  Each member shall be a qualified person, and shall have at least a journeyman's electrical experience. 
(b)  If possible, members shall be residents of South Houston, Texas. 
(c)  Members of the electrical board shall receive a South Houston Master Electrician's License upon acceptance of the office after being appointed. 
(d)  At the time of passage of this chapter, a prior ordinance has been in place. The electrical board as of the date of passage of this chapter consists of the following persons: 
(1)  _______ who serves until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(2)  _______ who serves until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(3)  _______ who serves until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(4)  _______ who serves until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
(5)  _______ who serves until his successor is appointed and qualified. 
For purposes of continuity, the initial board under the new ordinance shall be the above described incumbent members of the previous board, who shall serve until their successors are appointed and qualified. If there is a vacancy in the prior board at the time of passage of this chapter, there shall be a vacancy in the new board to be filled as in any other vacancy. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-28. - Appointments, terms, removal. 
Each member of the board shall serve until his or her successor has been appointed and qualified. Any member of the board may be removed by majority vote of the city council, with or without cause. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-29. - Compensation. 
Fees or salaries for members of the electrical board shall be decided upon, as amount and time of payment, by the mayor and city council and any and all such payments shall be made directly to such member by the city. Electrical board members are to receive licenses free of charge as long as they serve on the board. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-30. - Quorum. 
Three (3) members of the electrical board present at any meeting shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of all business of the board, and a majority vote of the members present shall prevail. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-31. - Officers, procedure, order of business. 
The officers of the board shall consist of a chairman, vice-chairman, and a secretary. The chairman, vice-chairman, and the secretary shall be nominated by the members of the board each year in its first meeting after January 2nd. Each officer shall be a broad member and shall be elected by a majority vote of the then qualified and serving members of the board. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-32. - General powers and duties. 
(a)  The electrical board shall be responsible for making interpretations of the rules for deciding upon the approval of equipment, material installation techniques, and granting special permission for the condition, material and installations not covered herein. Permission for such deviation shall be obtained in writing from the electrical board. 
(b)  The electrical board shall select reputable agencies to give examinations for master electricians, electrical sign contractors, maintenance electricians, and journeyman electrician's licenses. All questions and disagreements with the examinations shall be directed to the agency giving the examination. 
(c)  No member of the electrical board shall be given an electrical examination. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 99-001, 1-26-99)  
Sec. 8-33. - Reports. 
It shall be the duty of the electrical board at such times as it may deem proper, to submit to the mayor and city council, written suggestions and recommendations for the improvement of the electrical board's methods and procedures and the electrical inspector's practices. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-34. - Investigations. 
The electrical inspector shall make such investigations regarding electrical work as deemed necessary or as requested by the mayor, building official, or fire marshal of the city, and prepare a written report thereon. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-35. - Right to appeal electrical board decisions. 
Any person, firm, corporation, or organization that questions a decision of the electrical board shall have the right to appeal. Such appeal shall be made in writing to the city secretary within ten (10) days after the decision of the board. After receipt of such appeal, the city council shall set the date for a hearing, and the city secretary shall notify the appellant and the chairman of the electrical board. The electrical board, as well as the appellant, shall have the right to be heard. The city council shall affirm, modify or reverse the action and/or decision of the electrical board. The action of the city council shall be final. If no appeal be taken within the time and manner herein provided, the ruling of the electrical board shall be final. The action of the electrical board shall in all things be effective until reversed or modified by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-36—8-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRICAL INSPECTORS 
 
Sec. 8-46. - Electrical inspector. 
The electrical inspector shall have direct supervision of such clerical employees as may be assigned to the electrical inspection department. The person chosen to fill the office of electrical inspector shall possess such executive ability as is requisite for the performance of such duties, and shall have a thorough knowledge of the standard materials and installation methods used for electrical work. The electrical inspector shall be well versed in the electrical ordinances of the City of South Houston, and any orders, rules and regulations issued by authority thereof. The electrical inspector shall have had at least five (5) years practical electrical experience as a electrician, and be licensed as a master electrician in the City of South Houston. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-47. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the electrical inspector to engage in electrical wiring apparatus, devices, appliances, fixtures, or equipment either directly or indirectly, and they shall have no financial interest in any engaged in such business in the city at any time while holding the office of Electrical Inspector of the City of South Houston. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person connected with the Electrical Inspection Department of the City of South Houston in any way whatsoever to solicit business of any kind for any master electrician. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person connected with the Electrical Inspection Department of the City of South Houston to prevent or assist in preventing any person from doing business with any master electrician whose license has not been suspended or revoked. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-48. - Duties of electrical inspectors. 
Electrical inspector shall be responsible for the inspection and re-inspections of all electrical installations. He shall keep a complete record of all permits issued, inspections and re-inspections made, and other official work performed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-49. - Authority granted electrical inspectors. 
(a)  The electrical inspectors or authorized deputies shall have the right to enter any building or premises in the City of South Houston, Texas, at any reasonable time, in the discharge of their official duties. The electrical inspectors shall have the authority in cases of emergency to cut or disconnect any electric wire which may present a hazard to life or property or which may interfere with the work of the fire department. 
(b)  The electrical inspector are hereby authorized to disconnect or to order the termination of electrical service to any apparatus, device, appliance, fixture or equipment found to be dangerous to life or property until such wiring, apparatus, device, appliance, fixture or equipment has been made safe. 
(c)  The electrical inspector shall be issued an identification card by the City of South Houston, and upon display of this card by an electrical inspector, any person performing "electrical work" or "electrical maintenance work" as defined in section 8-3, "electrical work" and "electrical maintenance" of this chapter, shall immediately furnish and display their City of South Houston Electrical License, authorizing him to engage in electrical work or electrical maintenance work within the City of South Houston when requested to do so by an electrical inspector. Failure to display such license shall be considered a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-50. - Right to appeal electrical inspectors decisions. 
Any person, firm, corporation or organization dissatisfied with a decision of an electrical inspector shall have the right to appeal such decision. The appeal shall be in writing for review to the electrical board within four (4) working days after such decision thereupon, the electrical board within fifteen (15) working days, shall determine said appeal. The board shall have the right to affirm, modify or reverse the action of the electrical inspector, provided, that until such time as the inspector's action is reversed or modified, such action shall in all things be effective. The decision of the electrical board shall be subject to review by the city council as provided for in section 8-35. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-51—8-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LICENSE AND REGISTRATION OF ELECTRICIANS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 8-61. - Who may do electrical work. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do electrical work or electrical maintenance work within the City of South Houston without a license issued under the provisions of this chapter. All such electrical work shall be done under the control, supervision, direction and responsibility of a master electrician. A journeyman or apprentice electrician who perform electrical work shall be an employee of the master electrician who owns their business, or an employee of the person, firm or corporation for whom the master electrician is employed as provided in section 8-65 at least one master or journeyman electrician shall be on each jobsite, and not more than two (2) apprentice electricians shall work under the supervision of a journeyman. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-62. - Electrical work by homeowner. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall ever be construed or operated to prevent any homeowner from actually doing the electrical work in or on his own property, provided he must first obtain and pay for a regular permit at the established rates before the work is started, and he must use such materials and equipment as will bring the work into strict accord with the Fire Underwriter's Code and the City Ordinances. In doing the work on his own property, such person shall not be permitted to use any hired assistant unless such assistant is duly licensed under the terms of this ordinance by the City of South Houston, and it is further provided that approval of the city electrical inspector must be obtained for the work done by the owner on his own property by the terms of this section, otherwise the Inspector may refuse to permit the current or power to be turned on or if turned on, may require it to be discontinued until the inspection may be made and the work found to meet the requirements of this chapter. 
Any person owning and improving a residential subdivision for sale or rent, or engaged in the business of purchasing and improving property for sale or rent, shall be excluded from the provisions of this section of this chapter, and shall not be entitled to do his own electrical work on such property unless he is a duly licensed electrician under the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-63. - Master electrician as employee of person, firm or corporation. 
A person (not licensed as a master electrician), firm or corporation engaged in electrical contracting shall employ a master electrician on a full-time permanent basis, and the master electrician shall supervise, direct and control the electrical work for the person, firm or corporation (and be responsible for the competency of all persons performing electrical work) this master electrician shall register the person, firm or corporation with the electrical permit department as their employer. Upon termination of such employment, notice shall be given to the electrical permit department within five (5) days from the date of termination by the master electrician. In the event of termination by the employer, the services of the master electrician shall not terminate responsibility of the master electrician and/or the employer for the completion of the electrical work for which the permit was obtained by the master electrician. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-64. - Registration of more than one firm by a master electrician. 
No master electrician shall be permitted to register a person, firm or corporation as their employer as provided in section 8-64 of this chapter while registered or employed by another person, firm or corporation as a master electrician. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-65. - Death of master electrician. 
Any person, firm, partnership or corporation engaged as an electrical contractor shall have the privilege of completing electrical permits started for a period of sixty (60) days or completion after the death of the master electrician who had been securing electrical permits for the person, firm, partnership or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-66. - Change of status. 
A master electrician or electrical sign contractor may change their license status from active to inactive by application. An inactive license places the master electrician or electrical sign contractor in the position that they may renew their license to active status by complying with section 8-68 and payment of fee as required for active license. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-67. - License non-assignable. 
No license issued in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be assignable or transferable. No master electrician shall assign or in any other way convey their licenses, the use thereof, or any rights thereunder, to anyone by power of attorney or any other process or become involved in any type of agreement, assignment or use whereby the master electrician will not have supervision, direction and control of the electrical work for which the permit was obtained. Should any master electrician violate this provision or any of the provisions specifying that they supervise and control the work for which they obtained a permit, their master electrician's license shall be revoked by the electrical board as provided by the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-68. - Examination and fees. 
(a)  Examination for master electricians, electrical sign contractors and maintenance electricians shall be given as provided in subsections 8-32(b) and (c) of this chapter. Any applicant who shall have failed a master electrician's, electrical sign contractor's or maintenance electrician's examination the first time shall be allowed to take a second examination. After the second failure, the applicant must wait at least one year for each additional examination. 
(b)  Licenses shall be renewed by the electrical inspector upon application and payment of the required fee, provided no license shall have expired for more than six (6) months, license expired for more than six (6) months shall not be renewed except upon re-examination as provided for herein. If person is using an outside testing agent, the person applying for reinstatement of their license must have taken required tests from the outside agency within the past ninety (90) days of application. It shall also be required that all master electricians, electrical sign contractors, maintenance electricians, and journeymen electricians renewing their license shall show proof of eight (8) hours of continuing education on the latest edition of the National Electrical Code, except for inactive status and those whose examination was based on the latest NEC. 
After the effective date of the latest edition of the National Electrical Code, the eight-hour continuing education course requirement on the latest edition of the N.E.C. shall be waived during the first license renewal period for new licenses, and for new license renewals. 
(c)  Before a master electrician, electrical sign contractor's license or maintenance electrician is issued or renewed the applicant shall pay a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). Before a journeyman electricians license is issued or renewed the applicant shall pay a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(d)  Fee for renewal of an inactive master electrician or electrical sign contractor's license shall be ten dollars ($10.00) per year. 
(e)  A duplicate license may be issued upon request after payment of a fee of five dollars ($5.00). 
(f)  All fees for licenses shall be paid to the clerk of the permit department, city hall, City of South Houston, Texas. All licenses shall expire on December 31st each year. 
(g)  Contractor registration fee: 
Annual fee: January through December 31: 
(1)  Electrical contractor ..... $100.00 
(2)  Electrical maintenance contractor ..... $100.00 
(3)  Electrical sign contractor ..... $100.00 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 99-001, 1-26-99; Ord. No. 2004-15, § 1, 5-18-04; Ord. No. 2004-37, § 1, 11-9-04)  
Sec. 8-69. - Suspension, withholding or revocation of license or certificate. 
When given a ten-day notice by registered mail, and after a hearing before the electrical board, the person notified may have their license or certificate revoked, suspended or placed on probation for any of the following reasons: 
(1)  Habitual drunkenness or the use of narcotics; 
(2)  Conviction of a crime involving moral turpitude; 
(3)  Adjudication of insanity; 
(4)  Fraud or misrepresentation in obtaining a license or permit; 
(5)  Violating either willfully or maliciously or by reason of incompetence, any provision of this electrical code or amendment thereto; 
(6)  Conviction of defrauding any person for whom he has rendered or contracted to render service; 
(7)  To secure a permit for electrical work not actually controlled by the master electrician or performed by licensed employees under their control, supervision and direction; 
(8)  Securing permits under any pretext for which applicant has no valid contract. (This is intended to prevent a master electrician from securing a permit for the purpose of evading the spirit and intent of this chapter by any simulated scheme, transaction or device or performing electrical work without a valid permit). 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-70—8-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MASTER ELECTRICIANS 
 
Sec. 8-81. - Master electrician defined. 
The holders of the license provided for in section 8-82(a) shall be known as master electricians. All master electricians shall be assigned a permanent identification number. This assigned number will appear on the master electricians license, and shall be displayed in their current place of business. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-82. - Procedure to obtain a master electrician license. 
(a)  Qualifications. All electrician's licenses previously issued by the South Houston Electrical Board shall be valid and in good standing, so long as the holder of said license has performed all requirements of the city for maintaining said license. All applicants for a master electrician's examination shall have either of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Five (5) years active and practical experience in electrical work as defined herein as a journeyman electrician under the control, supervision, direction and responsibility of a licensed master electrician. 
(2)  Five (5) years experience as a journeyman electrician as defined herein or the equivalent thereof as specifically approved by the electrical board. The completion of each year of study of an electrical engineering curriculum at an accredited college of engineering shall count as one year of experience, but not more than three (3) years shall be credited. 
(b)  Application. Application for licensing as a master electrician shall be made in writing on a form provided by the city permit department. All applications shall be notarized by a Public Notary in and for the State of Texas under their seal and shall be accompanied by documents verifying their qualifications as specified in section 8-82(a) of this chapter. All applications shall be submitted to the electrical board for approval. 
(c)  Examination. Applicants for master electrician license shall be given a reasonable examination in writing in two parts as follows: 
(1)  Part I and part II shall consist of questions and problems on code and theory as it pertains to electrical work. 
(d)  License issued. The electrical inspector shall issue a license to each applicant who makes a grade of seventy (70) percent or better on each of the two parts of the examination, based on the latest NEC, or if test is based on earlier NEC, an eight-hour course of continuing education on the latest NEC is required. No license shall be issued until after payment of the fee provided for in subsections 8-68(a) and (c). For review of the examination, see subsection 8-32(b). 
After the effective date of the latest edition of the National Electrical Code, the eight-hour continuing education course requirement on the latest edition of the N.E.C. shall be waived during the first license renewal period for new licenses, and for new license renewals. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 99-001, 1-26-99)  
Sec. 8-83. - Insurance required. 
No permit shall be issued under any master electrician or electrical sign contractor's license until he has complied with the following insurance requirements. 
(a)  Workman's compensation insurance on each of their employees, and this insurance shall be in accordance with the provisions of the Workman's Compensation Act of the State of Texas. 
(b)  Public liability insurance to the extent of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for any one accident and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one person. 
(c)  Property damage insurance to the extent of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for any one accident and ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) for any one piece of property. Such insurance shall be written by an accredited company under the supervision of the Board of Insurance Commissioners of the State of Texas. Evidence of compliance with these requirements shall be met when the policy, or a certificate of insurance has been filed with and approved by the City of South Houston. The policy shall include an endorsement thereon that the City of South Houston will be notified at least ten (10) days in advance in the event of cancellation or expiration of the policy or policies. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-84—8-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - MAINTENANCE ELECTRICIANS 
 
Sec. 8-91. - Maintenance electrician defined. 
The electrician who performs work only in the confines of a building or on the premises thereof, and who is regularly employed on a permanent basis to do electrical maintenance defined in section 8-3, "electrical maintenance work", shall be known as a maintenance electrician. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-92. - Procedure to obtain a maintenance electrician's license. 
(a)  Qualifications. All electrician's licenses previously issued by the South Houston Electrical Board shall be valid and in good standing, so long as the holder of said license has performed all requirements of the city for maintaining said license. All applicants for a maintenance electrician's examination shall have one of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Four (4) years experience as an apprentice electrician verified by letters from previous employers; 
(2)  Certificate of completion of a four (4) year minimum federally approved apprenticeship program. 
(b)  Application. An application for license as a maintenance electrician shall be in writing on the form provided by the city permit department. All applications shall be notarized by such Notary Public in and for the State of Texas under their seal of office. The application for license shall be submitted to the electrical board for approval. 
(c)  Examination. Applicants for maintenance electrician license shall be given a written examination to verify their qualifications to perform electrical maintenance work as defined in section 8-3, "electrical maintenance work." For review of examination, see subsection 8-32(b) 
(d)  License issued. The electrical inspector shall issue a license to each applicant who makes a grade of seventy (70) percent or better on the examination, based on the latest NEC, or if test is based on earlier NEC, an eight-hour course of continuing education on the latest NEC is required. No license shall be issued until after payment of the fee provided for in subsection 8-68(c) and approved by electrical board. 
After the effective date of the latest edition of the National Electrical Code, the eight-hour continuing education course requirement on the latest edition of the N.E.C. shall be waived during the first license renewal period for new licenses, and for new license renewals. 
(e)  Change of employer. The maintenance electrician shall notify the electrical inspector immediately of any change in their employment, giving the name of their new employer and the location at which they will perform electrical maintenance work. 
(f)  Display of license. The maintenance electrician shall have their license in their possession while performing electrical maintenance work. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § IV(G), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 99-001, 1-26-99)  
Sec. 8-93. - Performance of electrical maintenance work. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to do electrical maintenance work as defined in subsection 8-3, "electrical maintenance work" unless such person is a licensed maintenance electrician, provided that this shall not prohibit a journeyman electrician (employed, not on a permanent basis) from doing electrical maintenance work under the supervision, direction and control of a licensed maintenance electrician. If the journeyman electrician at any time brings themselves within the definition of a maintenance electrician by becoming employed on a permanent basis, such journeyman electrician shall be required to obtain a license as a maintenance electrician, in addition to their journeyman electrician's license. An apprentice electrician may perform electrical maintenance work under the constant supervision, direction and control of a maintenance electrician. 
(b)  Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a master electrician to perform electrical maintenance work or limit electrical maintenance work from being performed by an apprentice or journeyman electrician under the supervision, direction or control of a master electrician. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-94—8-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - JOURNEYMAN ELECTRICIANS 
 
Sec. 8-101. - Journeyman electrician defined. 
Except as otherwise provided, those undertaking electrical work as defined in section 8-3, "electrical work" under the supervision, direction and control of a master electrician, shall be known as a journeyman electrician. The term journeyman electrician, however, shall not include an apprentice electrician. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-102. - Procedure to obtain a journeyman electrician license. 
(a)  Qualifications. All electrician's licenses previously issued by the South Houston Electrical Board shall be valid and in good standing, so long as the holder of said license has performed all requirements of the city for maintaining said license. All applicants for a journeyman electrician's examination shall have one of the following qualifications: 
(1)  Four (4) years active and practical experience in electrical work as defined herein under the control, supervisions direction and responsibility of a licensed master electrician. 
(2)  Certificate of completion of a four-year minimum federally approved apprenticeship program. 
(3)  Hold a current journeyman's license in Houston or Pasadena, Texas. 
(b)  Application. Application for licensing a journeyman electrician shall be made in writing on a form provided by the city permit department. All applications shall be accompanied by documents verifying their qualifications as specified in subsection 8-102(a) of this chapter. All applications shall be submitted to the electrical inspector for approval and no applicant shall be issued a license until their application has been approved by the electrical inspector. 
(c)  Display of certificate. Every holder of an journeyman electrician license shall have the license in their possession while performing electrical work. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-103—8-110. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - APPRENTICE ELECTRICIANS 
 
Sec. 8-111. - Apprentice electrician defined. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided, those who perform electrical work or defined in section 8-3, "electrical work" under the direct constant, personal supervision and control of either a master or journeyman electrician shall be known as apprentice electricians. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-112. - Registration of apprentice electricians. 
Application for registration as an apprentice electrician shall be on the form provided by the city permit department. The applicant shall furnish with their application a letter from a master electrician licensed by the City of South Houston recommending the applicant for registration and stating that the master electrician will employ the applicant as an apprentice electrician. The application shall be notarized by a Public Notary in and for the State of Texas under this seal of office. The application shall be submitted to the electrical inspector for approval. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-113. - Registration fee. 
Before registration certificate is granted or renewed by the electrical board, the applicant for apprentice electrician shall pay a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-114. - Display of certificate. 
Every holder of an apprentice electrician's certificate shall have certificate in their possession while performing electrical work. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-115—8-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - ELECTRICAL SIGN CONTRACTORS 
 
Sec. 8-121. - Application; definition; assignment of identification number. 
This chapter shall apply to those who undertake the business to manufacture and/or install electrical sign, conductors and equipment for signs and outline lighting as defined in the National Electrical Code, and for inside lighting with high-voltage gas tubes. Those qualifying under this chapter shall be known as an electrical sign contractor. All electrical sign contractors shall be assigned a permanent identification number; this number shall appear on the license and shall be displayed at their place of business. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-122. - To obtain electrical sign contractor's license. 
(a)  Qualifications. The qualifications and terms of license shall be the same as that for a master electrician in subsection 8-82(a) in all respects. 
(b)  Application. Application for licensing as an electrical sign contractor shall be made in writing on a form provided by the city permit department. All applications shall be notarized by a Public Notary in and for the State of Texas under their seal and shall be accompanied by documents verifying their qualifications as specified in subsection 8-82(a) of this chapter. All applications shall be submitted to the electrical board for approval. 
(c)  Examination. The written examination given the applicant for an electrical sign contractor's license shall cover only electrical sign work. For examination review, see subsection 8-32(b). 
(d  License issued. The electrical inspector shall issue a license to each applicant who makes a grade of seventy (70) percent or better on the examination, based on the latest NEC, or if test is based on earlier NEC, an eight-hour course of continuing education on the latest NEC is required. No license shall be issued until after payment of fee as provided for in subsection 8-68(c). 
After the effective date of the latest edition of the National Electrical Code, the eight-hour continuing education course requirement on the latest edition of the N.E.C. shall be waived during the first license renewal period for new licenses, and for new license renewals. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 99-001, 1-26-99)  
Sec. 8-123. - Electrical work. 
(a)  Scope of work. An electrical sign contractor shall be permitted to manufacture, install and to connect the sign, outline lighting or inside lighting to an existing circuit or circuits that have been approved by the building official for connection of the specific load covered by the permit issued. Should the available circuit or circuits not be adequate for the specific sign or outline lighting load, then a master electrician shall be employed to install the necessary wiring required. 
(b)  The electrical sign contractor shall be permitted to install the necessary circuits for an isolated sign and/or outline lighting installation. 
(c)  The electrical sign contractor shall employ only properly registered journeyman electricians and apprentice electricians to perform any electrical work requiring a permit. 
(d)  Isolated sign and/or outline lighting. An isolated sign and/or outline lighting installation shall be defined as an installation in which neither the meter nor service supplying the sign, signs or outline lighting are mounted on or in any building or structure not a part of a sign, signs or outline lighting. As applied in this chapter, signs or outline lighting on the exterior of a building must have a disconnect available on the exterior of the building. Nothing herein is intended to limit or repeal the effect of the City of South Houston Building Code covering Chapter 18, "Outdoor signs and Display Structures", but shall be cumulative thereof. 
(e)  All work performed, materials, apparatus, devices, appliances, fixture or equipment used shall conform with the full requirements of this chapter. 
(f)  Any electric sign built within the City of South Houston and to be installed within the city shall have a shop inspection by the Electrical Inspector before the sign is shipped. The shop inspection fee shall be separate from and double that required for signs as specified in section 8-141 of this chapter signs constructed outside the city but erected within the city shall be subject to the same rules and regulations as apply to signs constructed within the city after approval, the inspector shall attach an approval label or stamp to the sign. 
(g)  Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prevent a licensed master electrician from engaging in the business of electrical sign contractor, but the master electrician shall comply with the requirements of this chapter for sign work. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-124—8-130. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 8-131. - Who may apply for electrical permits. 
(a)  Only those hereinafter specified shall have the privilege to apply for electrical work, electrical maintenance work, or electrical sign contractor work permits. 
(b)  The master electrician, or their duly authorized agent, licensed by the City of South Houston, who is engaged in electrical contracting by himself, shall apply for only electrical permits for their own business, and no electrical permit shall be obtained by any master electrician who does not supervise, direct and control the electrical work for which the permit was obtained. 
(c)  The master electrician, or their duly authorized agent, licensed by the City of South Houston, who is employed by a person, firm or corporation as a master electrician, shall take out permits only for their employer, and shall supervise, direct and control the electrical work for which that permit was obtained. 
(d)  The electrical sign contractor, or their duly authorized agent, licensed by the City of South Houston, shall obtain permits for electrical signs only and shall also comply with subsections 8-131(b) and (c). 
(e)  The maintenance electrician who is employed by a person, firm or corporation shall take out maintenance work permits only for their employer, and shall perform or supervise, direct and control the electrical maintenance work for which the permit was obtained. 
(f)  A homeowner may apply for a permit for electrical work in and/or on their residence when the electrical work is to be performed by himself (see section 8-62.) 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-132. - Application for electrical permit. 
To obtain an electrical permit, the licensed master electrician, electrical sign contractor, or their duly authorized agent, shall first file an application in writing on a form furnished for that purpose. Each application shall: 
(1)  Identify and describe the scope of work to be covered by the permit. 
(2)  Describe the location where the proposed work will take place by street address or similar description that will readily identify and locate the jobsite. 
(3)  Show the use, function or occupant of the building and or project. 
(4)  Be accompanied by plans and specifications as required in section 8-133. 
(5)  Be signed by the licensed electrician, who may be required to submit evidence to indicate such authority. 
(6)  State that the applicant requesting the issuance of a permit has read this ordinance entirety and will supervise, direct and control all electrical work performed under it or supervise, direct and control the electrical maintenance work for which the permit was obtained. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-133. - Plans and specifications. 
(a)  With each application for an electrical permit, when required by the electrical inspector, one set of plans and specifications shall be submitted. The electrical inspector may require that such plans and specifications bear the seal of a registered professional electrical engineer licensed by the State of Texas if for commercial or industrial. 
(b)  All public buildings shall be required to submit plans and specifications before securing any permit, except minor additions or alterations to existing facilities when specifically exempted by the electrical inspector. Plans and specifications shall be submitted for all buildings and places of assembly where emergency electric systems are required, except minor additions or alterations to the existing facilities when specifically exempted by the electrical inspector. 
(c)  Secure and submit a service outlet and data statement issued by the local electric utility for modifications or new construction of an electrical service entrance. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-134. - Approval of plans and specifications. 
(a)  The applications, plans and specifications submitted shall be reviewed by the electrical inspector such plans may be reviewed by other departments of the city for compliance with laws and ordinances under their jurisdiction. If the electrical inspector concurs that the work described in the specifications and plans confers to the requirements of the city, he shall authorize a permit to be issued. 
(b)  When the electrical inspector authorizes a permit, he shall stamp the set of plans and specifications, "approved", and affix their signature thereto. 
(c)  No work permit shall be transferred or assigned to any person by the original applicant. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-135. - Validity. 
(a)  To issue or grant a permit with approval of plans and specifications shall not be construed to be a permit for, or an approval of, any violation of the provisions of this chapter. No permit shall give authority to violate or cancel the provisions of this chapter, except to authorize the work or use as lawful. 
(b)  To issue a permit based on plans and specifications shall not prevent the electrical inspector from thereafter requiring the correction of errors in the plans and specifications or from preventing building operations from being carried out when in violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-136. - Display of permit at jobsite. 
(a)  The permit on all new construction for electrical work shall be displayed on the jobsite in a readily accessible location throughout the period of such installation. 
(b)  A permit for an existing installation which approved or where additional electrical work is required on a job in progress, the permit for such installation or alteration shall be delivered to the person or firm for whom the installation is to be made and posted at the jobsite as directed by the electrical inspector before the addition or alteration is started. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-137. - Expiration of permit. 
Each permit issued by the electrical inspector shall expire by limitation and become null and void if the project authorized has not started within sixty (60) days from the date of such permit, or if the project is suspended or abandoned at any time after the work has started for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days. Before such work can be again started, a new permit shall be obtained. The fee shall be one-half (½) the amount required for a new permit, provided no changes have been made in the original plans and specifications, and provided further, that such suspension or abandonment has not exceeded one year, in which case a new, full fee permit shall be required. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-138. - Suspension or revocation of permit. 
(a)  The electrical inspector may, in writing, suspend or revoke a permit issued under the provisions of this chapter whenever the permit issued is in error based on incorrect information supplied, or when in violation of any provision of this chapter. 
(b)  Failure of any registered master electrician or electrical sign contractor to correct any defect, error or deficiency in any work installed under an Electrical permit issued to him within fifteen (15) days after written notification thereof from the electrical inspector shall, without further notice, cause the issuance of permits to the master electrician or electrical sign contractor to stop until such corrections have been made, inspected and approved. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-139. - Emergency permits. 
The electrical inspector may issue and enforce the rules and regulations to cover emergency permits where real emergencies exist. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-140. - Temporary permits. 
No temporary permits shall be for a period longer than three (3) months, and after three (3) months the electrical inspector shall issue written instructions to the electric public service company or others having control of the supply of energy to disconnect the service, unless a permanent approval or an additional temporary approval has been obtained. To expedite the removal of electrical service, the electrical inspector shall notify the electric service company or others who have control, ten (10) days prior to the date of termination of the permit, and shall notify the owner of the installation. A letter addressed to the "occupant" at the temporary jobsite location shall be sufficient notification. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-141. - Fees 
(a)  Schedule of fees. Electrical permit fees shall be assessed and collected as follows: as set forth in "Exhibit A," as amended.
