(b)  The minimum fee shall apply to move and relocate electrical equipment authorized to be done by a licensed electrician or an electrical sign contractor for which a permit inspection fee is not otherwise provided. 
(c)  South Houston Electrical Code Ordinance shall require a fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98; Ord. No. 2010-18, § 1(Exh. A), 9-14-10; Ord. No. 2014-04, § 1(Exh. A), 1-14-14; Ord. No. 2014-17, § 1(Exh. A), 8-12-14; Ord. No. 2017-28 , § 1(Exh. A), 7-25-17)  
Sec. 8-142. - Re-inspection fee. 
When it becomes necessary to make a re-inspection prior to final approval, and at final inspection if found to be unsafe, the master electrician or the electrical sign contractor shall pay for each re-inspection a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). This provision is to apply only to that work covered by the permit. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-143. - Double fees. 
All electrical fixture and appliance inspection permit fees shall apply except that when application is made for a permit after the work has been started, or after the work partially completed or concealed, then the fee or fees will be doubled. These double fees shall be paid by the electrical contractor to whom the permit was issued. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-144. - Failure to pay permit inspection fees. 
The failure of a master electrician or an electrical sign contractor to pay the city in full the fees provided within ten (10) days after the final certificate of approval is granted for electrical work, the license of such master electrician or electrical sign contractor shall be automatically suspended without action on the part of the electrical board, and the licenses shall be of no force and effect, until such fees are paid in full. No license which has been suspended under the terms and provisions of this chapter longer than six (6) months shall be renewed, except upon re-examination on the same terms and conditions as provided for in the case of original examination. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-145. - When a permit is required. 
No wire, pole, duct line, guy anchor, apparatus, device, appliance, fixture or equipment for the transmission, distribution or utilization of electrical energy for any purpose shall be installed within the City of South Houston, nor shall any alteration or additions be made to any of the aforementioned without first securing a permit from the electrical inspector, except as exempted herein. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-146. - Permit for maintenance electrician's employer. 
(a)  An annual permit is required for any person or firm employing a maintenance electrician licensed by the City of South Houston to perform electrical maintenance work within the confines of a building in or on the premises where he is employed. The application for the annual permit shall be made on the form provided by the city permit department and shall contain a description of the location and the maintenance work anticipated. 
(b)  The fee of the annual permit shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) and shall expire on December 31st each year. 
(c)  The maintenance electrician shall be required to obtain a permit to move and relocate electrical equipment authorized to be done under the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-147. - When a permit is not required. 
(a)  No permit shall be required for replacing fuses or lamps or the connection of portable equipment to suitable receptacles which have been permanently installed or for repair to portable appliance. 
(b)  No permit shall be required for minor repair work such as repairing or replacing flush and snap switches, receptacles and lamp-sockets, or minor repairs on permanently connected electrical apparatus, appliances, fixtures or equipment, or the installation of light globes. 
(c)  No permit shall be required for any official electrical work performed in the city by employees of the State of Texas or County of Harris or city employees. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-148. - Companies exempted. 
(a)  Electric public service company. No permit shall be required for the electrical work by an electric public service company franchised by the City of South Houston for the use of such company in the generation, transmission, distribution or sale of energy. However, the company shall not do any wiring on a customer's premises other than wiring which is a part of the company's distribution system, including metering equipment and transformer vaults in which the company's transformers are located, nor shall any of its employees do any work other than that done for said company as herein before provided for, by virtue of this exception. 
(b)  Railroad company. No permit shall be required for the installation and maintenance of railway crossing signal devices when such is performed by due authority of the railroad and in accordance with the standards of the American Railroad Association and in collaboration with and approval of the Director of Traffic of the City of South Houston 
(c)  Others. No permit shall be required for the installation, maintenance, or alteration of material or equipment for telegraph or telephone signal service. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-149—8-160. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - INSPECTION REVIEW OF DECISIONS ETC. 
 
Sec. 8-161. - Notification of cover-up work. 
(a)  When any part of an electrical installation is to be hidden from view by the permanent placement of parts of a structure, the licensed electrician or electrical sign contractor shall notify the electrical permit department and the electrical inspector, who must concur that the work necessarily proceed continuously. The licensed electrician or electrical sign contractor shall give the electrical inspector due notice and inspection shall be made periodically during the progress of work, and where, at the discretion of the electrical inspector, a notice shall be posted on the premises stating that work is approved and be covered, or is not approved and shall not be covered pending further inspection. Any person removing, destroying, altering or defacing the notice shall be stayed pending further necessary inspection. Upon the completion of the work which has been authorized, it shall be the duty of the licensed electrician or electrical sign contractor, to immediately notify the electrical inspector, who shall inspect such installation within forty-eight (48) hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. 
(b)  Where it is necessary to have a cover-up inspection and the inspector is notified between 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., it shall be their duty to make this inspection within forty-eight (48) hours. In the event such work is turned down, he shall so notify the person requesting the inspection within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(c)  After the final inspection is made, and the electrical work is approved, the electrical inspector, subject to the other applicable provisions of this ordinances shall issue a final certificate of approval to the public utility company, which shall authorize connection of such approved work and the use of the installation. No connection shall be made until such authorization and final certificate is issued. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-162. - Re-inspection; correction of unsafe conditions. 
(a)  The electrical inspector or authorized deputies shall have the authority to make at any reasonable time, if he has knowledge or belief that faulty conditions exist, a thorough re-inspection of any electrical workmanship, material or equipment now installed or that may hereafter be installed within the city. 
(b)  When the electrical work is found to be at variance with the original permit issued, or to be in a dangerous or unsafe condition, or that the electrical measuring device has been tampered with to create an unsafe condition, the owner, using or operating the unsafe condition shall be notified in writing. After notification, the owner shall have the necessary repairs or changes made to place such equipment in safe condition and shall have such work commence within fifteen (15) days and completed in thirty (30) days or a reasonably longer period specified by the electrical inspector. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-163. - Connections to installations. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection from a source of electrical energy to any electrical wiring, apparatus, devices, appliance fixtures or equipment for the installation of which a permit is required until a certificate of approval has been issued by the electrical inspector authorizing such connection. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make connection from a source of electrical energy to any electric wiring, apparatus devices, appliances fixtures and equipment which have been disconnected by the electrical inspector or the use of which has been ordered by the electrical inspector to be discontinued until a certificate of approval has been issued. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-164. - Interference with or change of installation. 
It shall be unlawful for any person in any manner to interfere with any electrical wiring installed or being installed in, or on within or without, any structure or building. If, in the course of erection of a building or structure, the wiring is in such position as to interfere with the erection or completion of the building or structure as called for by plans, notice shall immediately be given the person installing the wiring and the needed change shall be made by such person 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Secs. 8-165—8-175. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - TECHNICAL REQUIREMENTS 
 
Sec. 8-176. - General. 
In general, any type of wiring system may be used in this city limits of South Houston as approved in the National Electrical Code, except where specifically prohibited herein. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-177. - Service and interior feeders. 
All service and interior feeders shall be installed in rigid metal conduit, electrical metallic tubing, approved metal sheath cable, or approved busways, except that underground services, feeders and branch circuits may be installed in approved ducts or rigid nonmetallic conduit. Overhead services or feeders between two (2) buildings less than six (6) feet apart shall be installed in rigid metal conduit, approved busways or duct. Where wiring is installed in approved non-metallic duct or conduit, a continuous ground wire shall be installed within the duct to insure continuity of ground and the entire wiring system must be installed in a manner approved by the electrical board. Where conduit fittings are used ahead of meter cabinets, same shall be of sealable type and shall be plainly visible. 
(1)  Exception: Interior feeder for residential properties may be of non-metallic cable as long as a bond wire is part of the cable. 
(2)  All single family residences shall have a minimum of one hundred (100) amp service. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-178. - Flexible metallic conduit. 
Flexible metallic conduit may be used only for: temporary work, for connection to store fixtures, for connection to light fixtures installed within buildings, for electric range connection, and for motor connection. Connection to individual light fixtures may not exceed six (6) feet in length, and connections to motors or ranges may not exceed four (4) feet in length. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-179. - Non-metallic sheathed cable. 
Non-metallic sheathed cable shall be used only for temporary work or within apartment houses and residential dwellings. Conductors in or on all tile and masonry walls of such buildings shall be encased in rigid conduit, electrical metallic tubing or type AC cable. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-180. - Type UF cable. 
Type UF cable may be used only for branch circuit wiring on residential properties. Where installed underground, the cable shall be buried eighteen (18) inches. The cable shall be protected by rigid conduit on exterior walls and at the points where it enters and leaves the ground. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-181. - Open wiring. 
Open wiring is approved only for temporary work and in central stations, transformer vaults, substations and switchboards. Elsewhere than in central stations and substations, all circuits operating at more than six hundred (600) volts shall enter buildings or structures in conduit run underground or extended overhead from another structure. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-182. - Location of disconnecting means. 
Service disconnecting means shall be located so that the height to the center of the operating handle shall be not less than four (4) feet and not more than six (6) feet above the floor or finished grade, except as installed in free standing or building type switchgear built to N.E.M.A. specifications. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-183. - Temporary saw poles. 
Temporary saw poles shall be constructed of four-inch by four-inch timbers or equivalent wood structure. All electrical materials shall be weather proof. All one hundred twenty-five-volt, single-phase, fifteen (15) and twenty (20) ampere receptacles, shall have ground-fault protection, service conductors shall be No. 8 AWG or larger installed in conduit with No. 8 or larger armored ground wire connected to driven electrode. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-184. - Conductors. 
In general, all conductors, wire, and circuits referred to in the ordinance shall be understood to be copper conductors. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-185. - Test required on emergency systems. 
The owner or management of each building or place of assembly where an emergency electric system is required and installed shall have periodic maintenance check and test of the emergency equipment. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-186. - Circuits and receptacles for specific equipment in residence. 
(a)  Small appliances in kitchen laundry etc. For the appliance loads in the kitchen, breakfast and dining area, two (2) or more twenty-ampere branch circuit with not more than five (5) duplex receptacles per circuit shall be provided and shall have no other outlets (clock outlets excepted). 
(b)  Window A/C units and space heaters branch circuit wiring for window air conditioning or resistance-type space heaters shall be wired for the nameplate amperes plus twenty-five (25) percent and shall not be smaller than #12 AWG copper wire. Not more than one unit or receptacle shall be installed on any single or multi-wire branch circuit. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-187. - System neutral. 
Shall be grounded to a driven electrode, in addition to any other approved method. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-188. - Circuits for unsupported signs or decorative lighting. 
All circuits extending from buildings to signs or decorative lighting, which are not supported by the building from which the circuit originates, shall be place in rigid conduit and underground. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-189. - Branch circuits and outlets for small appliances in kitchens, laundry rooms, etc. 
(a)  Laundry equipment in dwelling occupancies shall be supplied by one twenty-ampere branch circuit for that use only. Not more that two (2) duplex receptacles may be connected to this circuit and such receptacles must be of the grounding type. 
(b)  Dishwashers in dwelling occupancies shall be supplied by one twenty-ampere branch circuit for that use only and such circuit shall have no other outlets. 
(c)  Garbage disposal units in dwelling occupancies shall be supplied by one twenty-ampere branch circuit. Additional connections to such circuits shall be limited to one kitchen vent fan and one light outlet. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-190. - Splicing or jointing of conductors. 
Conductors shall be spliced or joined by soldering or by the use of an approved solderless connector of the positive pressure type or of the "screw on" type. All joints must be twisted. All conductors feeding a duplex receptacle shall be pigtail to feed each outlet or device in the outlet box. This is to be done in all residential and commercial location. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-191. - Romex to be clear of pipes. 
Nonmetallic sheath cable (Romex) shall be installed clear of all pipes. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-192. - Supporting branch-circuit wiring. 
Branch-circuit wiring associated with equipment that is located within, supported by, or secured to a non-fire-rated floor or roof/ceiling assembly shall be permitted to supported by the ceiling support wires. 
(Ord. No. 98-004, § 2(Exh. A), 4-28-98)  
Sec. 8-193. - Maximum number of conductors in conduit.

Chapter 8.5 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2009-29, §§ 1—8, adopted October 27, 2009, did not specifically amend the code. Therefore, such ordinance has amended chapter 8.5 to read as herein set out. Formerly, such chapter pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 701, §§ 1—12, 2-1-83. 
 
Sec. 8.5-1. - Organization. 
There exists the office of Emergency Management Director of the City of South Houston, which shall be held by the mayor in accordance with state law. 
(a)  An emergency management coordinator may be appointed by and serve at the pleasure of the director. 
(b)  The director shall be responsible for a program of comprehensive emergency management within the city and for carrying out the duties and responsibilities set forth in this chapter. He/she may delegate authority for execution, but responsibility shall remain with the director. 
(c)  The operational emergency management organization of the City of South Houston shall consist of the officers and employees of the city so designated by the director in the emergency management plan, as well as organized volunteer groups. The functions and duties of this organization shall be distributed among such officers and employees in accordance with the terms of the emergency management plan. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 1, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-2. - Emergency management director—Powers and duties. 
The duties and responsibilities of the emergency management director shall include the following: 
(a)  Surveying actual or potential hazards that threaten life and property within the city and identifying and requiring or recommending the implementation of measures that would tend to prevent the occurrence or reduce the impact of such hazards if a disaster did occur. 
(b)  Supervision of the development and approval of an emergency management plan for the City of South Houston, and recommendation for adoption by the city council all mutual aid arrangements deemed necessary for the implementation of such plan. 
(c)  Authority to declare a local state of disaster. The declaration may not be continued or renewed for a period in excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the city council. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or terminating a local state of disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the city secretary. 
(d)  Issuance of necessary proclamations, regulations, or directives that are necessary for carrying out the purposes of this chapter. Such proclamations, regulations, or directives shall be disseminated promptly by means calculated to bring their contents to the attention of the general public and, unless circumstances attendant on the disaster prevent or impede, promptly filed with the city secretary. 
(e)  Direction and control of the operations of the emergency management organization as well as the training of emergency management personnel. 
(f)  Determination of all questions or authority and responsibility that may arise within the emergency management organization of the city. 
(g)  Maintenance of liaison with other municipal, county, district, state, regional or federal emergency management organizations. 
(h)  Marshaling of all necessary personnel, equipment, or supplies from any department of the city to aid in the carrying out of the provisions of the emergency management plan. 
(i)  Supervision of the drafting and execution of mutual aid agreements, in cooperation with the representatives of the state and of other local political subdivisions of the state, and the drafting and execution, if deemed desirable, of an agreement with the county in which said city is located and with other municipalities within the county, for the county-wide coordination of emergency management efforts. 
(j)  Supervision of, and final authorization for the procurement of all necessary supplies and equipment, including acceptance of private contributions, which may be offered for the purpose of improving emergency management within the city. 
(k)  Authorizing of agreements, after approval by the city attorney, for use of private property for public shelter and other purposes. 
(l)  Surveying the availability of existing personnel, equipment, supplies, and services which could be used during a disaster, as provided for herein. 
(m)  Other requirements as specified in the Texas Disaster Act (V.T.C.A. Government Code, Ch. 418). 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 2, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-3. - Emergency management plan. 
A comprehensive emergency management plan shall be developed and maintained in a current state. The plan shall set forth the form of the organization; establish and designate divisions and functions; assign responsibilities, tasks, duties, and powers; and designate officers and employees to carry out the provisions of this chapter. As provided by state law, the plan shall follow the standards and criteria established by the State Division of Emergency Management of the State of Texas. Insofar as possible, the form of organization, titles, and terminology shall conform to the recommendations of the state division of emergency management. When approved, it shall be the duty of all departments and agencies to perform the functions assigned by the plan and to maintain their portion of the plan in a current state of readiness at all times. The emergency management plan shall be considered supplementary to this chapter and have the effect of law during the time of a disaster. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 3, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-4. - Inter-jurisdictional program. 
The mayor is hereby authorized to join with the County Judge of the County of Harris and the mayors of the other cities in said county in the formation of an inter-jurisdictional emergency management program for the County of Harris, and shall have the authority to cooperate in the preparation of an inter-jurisdictional emergency management plan and in the appointment of a joint emergency management coordinator, as well as all powers necessary to participate in a county-wide program of emergency management insofar as said program may affect the City of South Houston. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 4, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-5. - Override. 
At all times when the orders, rules, and regulations made and promulgated pursuant to this ordinance shall be in effect, they shall supersede and override all existing ordinances, orders, rules, and regulations insofar as the latter may be inconsistent therewith. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 5, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-6. - Liability. 
This chapter is an exercise by the city of its governmental functions for the protection of the public peace, health, and safety and the City of South Houston, the agents and representatives of said city, any individual, receiver, firm, partnership, corporation, association, or trustee, and any of the agents thereof, in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with, any order, rule, or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this chapter shall, to the extent permitted by Texas and federal law as amended, be protected from liability for any damage sustained to persons as the result of said activity. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 6, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-7. - Expenditure of public funds. 
(a)  Use of disaster recovery funds. All infrastructure programs funded with disaster recovery funds will be designed so that any publicly accessible infrastructure projects and associated facilities are fully accessible to persons with disabilities. 
(b)  No person shall have the right to expend any public funds of the city in carrying out any emergency management activity authorized by this ordinance without prior approval by the city council, nor shall any person have any right to bind the city by contract, agreement, or otherwise without prior and specific approval of the city council unless during a declared disaster. During a declared disaster, the mayor may expend and/or commit public funds of the city when deemed prudent and necessary for the protection of health, life, or property. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 7, 10-27-09; Ord. No. 2011-31, § 1, 10-11-11)  
Sec. 8.5-8. - Offenses; penalties. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to obstruct, hinder, or delay any member of the emergency management organization in the enforcement of any rule or regulation issued pursuant to this chapter. 
(b)  It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry, or display any emblem, insignia, or any other means of identification as a member of the emergency management organization of the City of South Houston, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper officials. 
(c)  Convictions for violations of the provisions of this chapter shall be punishable by fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000), or such maximum amount as is set by V.T.C.A. Government Code, § 418.173(b), as amended. 
(Ord. No. 2009-29, § 8, 10-27-09)  
Sec. 8.5-9. - Certificate pay for state-mandated certification. 
(a)  Emergency management employees shall receive the following monthly certificate pay structure for each respective certificate earned by the employee: 
FEMA - Emergency Management ..... $50.00 
(b)  EMS employees shall receive the following monthly certificate pay structure for each respective certificate earned by the employee: 
EMT - Intermediate ..... $25.00 
Paramedic ..... $50.00 
These payments shall be based on the number of certificates held by the employees as of October 27, 2008. 
(Ord. No. 2009-07, § 1, 3-3-09; Ord. No. 2009-08, § 1, 3-3-09)  
Chapter 9 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Election and approval of fire chief, §§ 2-3, 2-9; volunteer fire department, § 2-9.1; city exempt from Volunteer Fire Fighters Relief and Retirement Fund Act, § 2-9.2; buildings and general building regulations, § Ch. 6; electrical code, Ch. 8; fire prevention and protection requirements for oil and gas wells, §§ 14-4, 14-5; plumbing, Ch. 17; signs not to obstruct fire escapes or exits, § 18-8; signs not be erected on or anchored to fire walls, § 18-9; burning of leaves, paper, etc., on streets and sidewalks, § 19-22. 
State Law reference— Fire protection in cities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 342.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 9-1. - Piling or storing flammable material near buildings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to pile, stack or store trash or other flammable material next to the walls of any building within the limits of the city or so near to any such building that a fire within such material might be dangerous to such building or to any adjacent building. 
(Ord. No. 351, 6-20-55)  
Sec. 9-2. - Sale, storage or discharge of fireworks prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to store, sell, offer or expose for sale or have in possession with intent to sell or to use, discharge, or cause to be discharged, ignited, fired or otherwise set in action, within the limits of the city, any fireworks, firecrackers, rockets, sparklers, torpedoes, Roman candles, fire balloons or other fireworks or substances of any combination whatsoever designed or intended for pyrotechnic display. 
(Ord. of 12-5-50) 
State Law reference— Local regulation of fireworks, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2154.004.  
Sec. 9-3. - Sellers of gasoline and kerosene not to place same in glass or plastic receptacles. 
It shall be unlawful for any seller of gasoline or kerosene or any by-products thereof to place the same, upon the purchase thereof, in any type of receptacle made of glass, glass products or plastic unless approved by the U.S. Department of Transportation. 
(Ord. No. 471, § 1, 11-19-60; Ord. No. 854, § 1, 12-27-89)  
Sec. 9-4. - Handling and use of flammable liquids at retail service stations. 
The city council hereby adopts article 9201, Vernon's Annotated Civil Statutes, and the rules and regulations adopted by the state board of insurance, to insure uniform force and effect throughout the state in enforcing the rules and regulations for the safe storage, handling and use of flammable liquids at retail service stations. 
(Ord. No. 581, § 1, 8-4-70)  
Sec. 9-5. - Fire code adopted; amendments. 
(a)  The International Fire Code, 2006 Edition, including Appendix Chapters as published by the International Code Council, be and is hereby adopted as the code of the City of South Houston for regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling, and use of hazardous substances, materials, and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises in the City of South Houston and providing for the issuance of permits for hazardous uses or operations; and each and all of the regulations, provisions, conditions, and terms of such International Fire Code, 2006 Edition, published by the International Code Council, on file in the office of the City Secretary of the City of South Houston are hereby referred to, adopted, and made a part hereof as is fully set out in this section. 
(b)  The following sections of the International Fire Code are hereby amended as follows: 
Section F101.1. Insert: City of South Houston. 
Section F109.3. Insert: misdemeanor, $2,000, -0- 
Section F111.4. Insert: $200, $2,000 
The limits referred to in certain sections of the 2006 International Fire Code are hereby established as follows: 
Section F3204.3.1.1. (limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenic fluids in stationary containers is prohibited): 10 feet. 
Section F3404.2.9.5.2. (limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited): 10 feet. 
Section F3406.2.4.4. (limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited): 10 feet. 
Section F3804.2. (limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas): 300 feet. 
(Ord. No. 668, § 1, 4-1-80; Ord. No. 854, § 2, 12-27-89; Ord. No. 94-032, § I, 10-4-94; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98; Ord. No. 2002-16, §§ 1, 4—6, 6-4-02; Ord. No. 2010-22, § 4—6, 9-28-10)  
Sec. 9-6. - Fire regulations for childcare facilities adopted. 
The "Minimum Fire Safety Regulations for Child Care Facilities in Texas," promulgated by the Texas Board of Insurance, effective February 24, 1972, on file in the city secretary's office, is hereby adopted as the fire code regulating childcare facilities in South Houston, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 668, § 2, 4-1-80)  
Sec. 9-7. - Penalty for violation of sections 9-5 and 9-6; applicability to building owner and agents. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating a provision of section 9-5 or section 9-6, including the referenced code and regulations, or failing to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereon shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction, shall be fined not exceeding that fine set out in Section 1-7 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of South Houston. Each such person, firm or corporation shall be guilty of a separate offense for each and every day during which any violation thereof is committed or continued. The owner or owners of any building or structure failing to comply with any of the provisions of those sections, and the owner or owners of any premises where in a violation thereof occurs, and any architect, engineer, designer, builder, contractor, agent, person, firm or corporation employed therewith and who has assisted in the separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 668, § 4, 4-1-80; Ord. No. 854, § 3, 12-27-89)  
Secs. 9-8—9-14. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE MARSHAL 
 
Sec. 9-15. - Office created; members, supervision, etc. 
The office of the fire marshal is hereby created, with duties, powers and responsibilities as set forth herein. Such office shall consist of one fire marshal, one assistant fire marshal and two (2) fire inspectors, with the fire marshal and the other three (3) members of his department functioning through and reporting directly to the mayor and the city council. Such office(s) shall be filled pursuant to the directives of the personnel policy of South Houston, as amended. The fire marshal and all subordinate officers within the division of the fire department shall possess all qualifications required by law, local, state or federal, for such personnel and shall only be removed if unqualified or for cause, or both. The fire marshal and the assistant fire marshal shall receive reimbursement for expenditures. The supervision of the fire marshal division itself shall be the responsibility of the fire marshal, who shall report to and be supervised by the fire chief. The budget of the fire marshal division shall be combined and consolidated with the budget of the fire department. The fire chief shall enforce and be responsible for and in charge of the combined budget. 
(Ord. of 2-5-29, § 1; Ord. No. 97-003, § 1, 1-28-97; Ord. No. 97-005, § 1, 2-11-97; Ord. No. 2005-08, § 1, 3-1-05; Ord. No. 2012-15, § 1, 9-11-12)  
Sec. 9-16. - Appointment; qualifications; removal. 
The fire marshal and the assistant fire marshal shall be appointed by the mayor, by and with the consent of the city council. The fire marshal and the assistant fire marshal shall be properly qualified for their duties, and shall be removed only for cause. 
(Ord. of 2-5-29, § 1; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-17. - Duty to investigate fires. 
The fire marshal shall investigate or cause to be investigated, the cause, origin and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city by which property has been destroyed or damaged, and shall especially make investigation or cause investigation to be made as to whether such fire was the result of carelessness or design. Such investigations shall be begun within twenty-four (24) hours, not including Sunday, of the occurrence of the fire. 
(Ord. of 2-5-29, § 2; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-18. - Taking of testimony; administration of oaths. 
(a)  The fire marshal, when in his opinion further investigation is necessary, shall take or cause to be taken the testimony, on oath, of all persons supposed to be cognizant of any facts or to have means of knowledge in relation to the matter under investigation, and shall cause the same to be reduced to writing. 
(b)  The fire marshal or his designee is hereby authorized and empowered to administer oaths and affirmations to any persons appearing as witnesses before him. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, §§ 3, 4; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-19. - Authority to summon witnesses and require production of documents. 
The fire marshal or his authorized designee shall have the power to summon witnesses before him to testify in relation to any matter which is, by the provisions of this article, a subject of inquiry and investigation, and may require the production of any book, paper or document deemed pertinent thereto. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, § 4; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-20. - Investigations may be private; sequestering witnesses. 
All investigations held by or under the direction of the fire marshal may, in his discretion, be private, and persons other than those required to be present may be excluded from the place where such investigation is held, and witnesses may be kept separate and apart from each other and not allowed to communicate with each other until they have been examined. 
(Ord. of 2-5-29, § 6)  
Sec. 9-21. - Duty when evidence indicates crime in connection with fire. 
If the fire marshal or his authorized designee is of the opinion that there is evidence sufficient to charge any person with the crime of arson, or with the attempt to commit the crime of arson, or of conspiracy to defraud, or criminal conduct in connection with any fire, he shall cause such person to be lawfully arrested and charged with such offenses or either of them, and shall furnish to the proper prosecuting attorney all such evidence, together with the names of witnesses and all of the information obtained by him, including a copy of all pertinent and material testimony taken in the case. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, § 3; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-22. - Misconduct of witnesses summoned by fire marshal or his authorized designee. 
Any witness who refuses to be sworn, or who refuses to appear or testify, or who disobeys any lawful order of the fire marshal or his authorized designee, or who fails or refuses to produce any book, paper or document touching any matter under examination, or who is guilty of any contemptuous conduct during any of the proceedings of the fire marshal or his designee in the matter under investigation or inquiry, after being summoned to give testimony in relation to any matter under investigation, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and it shall be the duty of the fire marshal or his designee to cause all such offenders to be prosecuted. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, § 5; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-23. - Inspection of premises; removal or repair of dangerous conditions. 
The fire marshal or his designee, upon complaint of any person having an interest in any building or property adjacent, and without any complaint, shall have a right at all reasonable hours, for the purpose of examination, to enter into and upon all buildings and premises within the city, and it shall be his duty, yearly or more often to enter upon and make or cause to be entered and made, a thorough examination of all mercantile, manufacturing and public buildings, together with the premises belonging thereto. Whenever he shall find any building or other structure which, for want of repair, or by reason of age or dilapidated condition, or for any cause, is especially liable to fire, and which is so situated as to endanger other buildings or property, or so occupied that fire would endanger persons or property therein, and whenever he shall find an improper or dangerous arrangement of stoves, ranges, furnaces or other heating appliances of any kind whatsoever, including chimneys, flues and pipes with which the same may be connected, or a dangerous arrangement of lighting devises or systems, or a dangerous or unlawful storage of explosives, compounds, petroleum, gasoline, kerosene, dangerous chemicals, vegetable products, ashes, combustible, inflammable and refuse materials, or other conditions which may be dangerous in character or liable to cause or promote fire or create conditions dangerous to the firemen or occupants, he shall order the same to be removed or remedied, and such order shall be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant of such building or premises. If such owner or occupant deems himself aggrieved by such order, he may, within five (5) days, appeal to the mayor, who shall investigate the cause of the complaint and, unless by his authority the order is revoked, such order shall remain in force and be forthwith complied with by the owner or occupant. Any owner or occupant who fails or refuses to comply with such order shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. Every day's maintenance of any of the conditions covered by such order shall be a distinct and separate offense. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, §§ 8—13; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-24. - Right of entry in case of fire. 
The fire marshal or his designee shall have the authority at all times of day or night, when necessary in the performance of the duties imposed upon him by the provisions of this article, to enter upon and examine any building or premises where any fire has occurred, and other buildings and premises adjoining or near the same, which authority shall be exercised only with reason and good discretion. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, § 7; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-25. - Records to be kept. 
The fire marshal shall keep or cause to be kept in his office a record of all fires, together with all facts, statistics and circumstances, including the origin of the fires and the amount of the loss, which may be determined by the investigation required by this article. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, § 2; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-26. - Reports to state fire marshal. 
The fire marshal shall report or cause to be reported to the state fire marshal all existing hazardous conditions, together with a report on each fire occurring in the city as often as required by the state fire marshal. The information shall be submitted in a form acceptable to the state fire marshal. 
(Ord. Of 2-5-29, § 8; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
Sec. 9-27. - Assistant fire marshal. 
The assistant fire marshal's position is hereby created. He shall have the same duties and responsibilities as the fire marshal, whether or not the fire marshal is absent, except that he shall report to the fire marshal. In the case of the fire marshal's absence or inability to perform the duties of his office, the assistant fire marshal shall maintain control of the fire marshal's office until the fire marshal's return, or a replacement is installed in accordance with section 9-16 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 708, § 1, 9-20-83; Ord. No. 98-011, 8-11-98; Ord. No. 98-012, 9-8-98)  
ARTICLE III. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS 
 
Sec. 9-28. - Definitions. 
(a)  Hazardous materials. A substance classified as a hazardous material under state or federal law or under a rule adopted pursuant to state or federal law. 
(b)  Person. The word "person" shall extend to be applied to any associations, corporations, firms, partnerships, and bodies politic in corporate as well as to any individuals. 
(c)  Fire official. The term "fire official" herein shall mean the fire marshal/and or fire chief of the City of South Houston. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-29. - Reporting required. 
It shall be the responsibility of an owner, and/or person acting for or in concert with the owner, to report any hazardous material as set out in this article to the city fire official in the following manner: 
(1)  Identification of the hazardous material by trade name and or chemical content or both in accordance with the latest addition of D.O.T. P-5800 entitled Emergency Response Guidebook. 
(2)  Quantity of hazardous material. 
(3)  Location for the hazardous material, (i.e., N.W. corner of the building, center, second floor, etc.). 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-30. - Persons required to report. 
Any and all persons who may handle or store the quantities of hazardous material listed in section 9-32 of this article, in or on property under their care and control and custody, shall be required to report in the same manner as a business. The responsible party shall be the owner or lessee who is the occupant of the location. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-31. - Method of reporting. 
[The method of reporting shall be] by certified mail, return receipt requested or in person to a fire official as designated herein. In the event that there is personal delivery, such delivery shall be acknowledged by a receipt. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-32. - Unlawful acts. 
It shall be unlawful to store and fail to report the following: 
Any hazardous substance, solid, liquid or gas which is subject to be stored or handled, in quantities of or in excess of fifty (50) pounds of solid or powder or more than fifty (50) gallons of liquid or gas, shall be reported to a South Houston Fire Official. This report shall be made in writing and shall be made within seventy-two (72) hours of receipt of the materials in the city limits of the City of South Houston. It shall contain the description, content, amount, emergency response guide book number from the latest edition of D.O.T. P-5800, location, quantity, and type container in which the material is stored. It shall also include the name of the person or persons who can be contacted in case of fire or other emergency and the phone number or numbers where this person can be located after business hours. The report shall also include a comprehensive floor plan of the business or residence with the location of the hazardous material shown. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89; Ord. No. 841, § 1, 7-5-89)  
Sec. 9-33. - Unlawful quantities. 
It shall be unlawful to fail to report the following items in any quantity: Explosives, poisonous gases, or radio active materials, by their generic name, common usage or known harmful qualities. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-34. - Change of amounts or locations. 
In the event that there is any significant change in the amounts or locations of materials covered under this article or any change in the responsible person or the emergency number to contact, it shall be reported in writing to the South Houston Fire Department/Fire Marshal within seventy-two (72) hours of the change. A significant change is construed as that which would required added or diminished precautions on behalf of those emergency personnel in the event of their being summoned. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-35. - Authority to inspect. 
The South Houston Fire Department or the South Houston Marshal's office shall have the authority to inspect any business or residence for the presence of materials covered by this article upon request. It shall be the duty of the fire official or his designated agent to issue citations regarding any violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1, 5-16-89)  
Sec. 9-36. - Vehicle transporting flammable or hazardous materials. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person(s) to cause any vehicle transporting hazardous or flammable materials to be parked, unattended for a period of more than one (1) hour, within two thousand five hundred (2,500) feet of any residential areas, including but not limited to apartment buildings, condominiums, etc.; hospitals, medical facilities, nursing homes, schools, institutions, hotels, motels, day care centers, wholesale and retail general business establishments accessible to the public. 
(b)  All vehicles transporting hazardous or flammable materials shall display content identification placards as required by federal regulations. 
(Ord. No. 873, § 1, 7-17-90)  
Secs. 9-37—9-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING IN FIRE LANES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No 866, adopted May 15, 1990, amended Ch. 9 of the Code by the addition of Art. III, §§ 9-28—9-38, and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been redesignated and included herein as Art. IV, §§ 9-51—9-61 in order to avoid duplicative article and section numbering. 
Cross reference— Traffic, C. 22; stopping, standing and parking, § 22-73 et seq. 
 
Sec. 9-51. - Definitions. 
(a)  Fire lane is defined for the purpose of this article to mean an area appurtenant to entrances or exits of an assembly building, shopping center, hospital, apartment house, hotel/motel, school, or other commercial buildings which are deemed necessary by the fire official to remain free and clear of parked vehicles and other obstructions in order to provide access to such building in case of fire or other emergency and designated by the fire official. Such land shall be of a width of not less than twenty (20) feet perpendicular to such exits and entrances and shall extend for the minimum length necessary to provide access to such building in case of fire or other emergency and designated by the fire official. It is further provided that the fire official shall not designate a lane of more than fifteen (15) feet perpendicular to exits or entrances of buildings if the designation of a lane of more than fifteen (15) feet would necessitate structural changes to existing buildings. 
(b)  Shopping center is defined for the purpose of this article to mean a group of commercial business establishments, planned, developed, owned or managed as a unit, with off-street parking provided on the property, and related in location, size, and types of shops to the trade area that the unit serves. 
(c)  Hospital is defined for the purposes of this article to mean any public or private hospital, convalescent home or nursing home. 
(d)  Apartment house is any building, or portion thereof, which is designed, built, rented, leased, let or hired out to be occupied, or which is occupied as the home or residence of three (3) or more families living independently of each other and doing their own cooking in such building, and shall include flats and apartments. 
(e)  Assembly building is a building, or portion of a building used for the gathering together of fifty (50) or more persons for such purposes as deliberation, education, instruction, worship, entertainment, amusement or awaiting transportation, or of one hundred (100) or more persons in drinking or dining establishments. 
(f)  School is a building, public or private, used for educational purposes, and having an attendance of fifty (50) or more persons. 
(g)  Fire official is the fire marshal. 
(h)  Proper officer, for the purposes of this article, shall include the fire marshal, fire chief, chief of police, inspectors of the fire prevention department, and officers of the police department. 
(i)  Fire protection device shall mean a device such as sprinkler connection, stand pipe connections, and fire hydrants, public or private. 
(j)  Commercial building shall mean a structure which is used for the carrying on of business or trade. 
(k)  Hotel/motel shall mean any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses, or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration but shall not include hospitals, sanitariums, or nursing homes. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 1, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-52. - Fire official's authority. 
The Fire Official of the City of South Houston is hereby authorized to designate fire lanes on the property of shopping centers, hospitals, apartment houses, assembly buildings, hotel/motel, schools, and other commercial buildings as defined herein, appurtenant to buildings or the entrances or exits to stores, groups of stores or buildings, where, in his opinion, such areas must be kept free of parked vehicles and other obstructions to provide ready access in case of fire or other emergency, provided that the establishment of said fire lanes have the approval of city council. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 2, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-53. - Notice of parking. 
Every owner of premises subject to this article shall, within thirty (30) days after designation of fire lanes, erect signs and/or paint the fire lane in compliance with this article. Failure to erect signs and/or paint the fire lanes is a misdemeanor and is punishable as provided herein. The designation by the fire official of such fire lanes shall never be held to make the City of South Houston responsible for the maintenance of such fire lanes on private property, but the owner of such property shall continue to be responsible for the maintenance of such area. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 3, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-54. - Notification of fire lane. 
Every designation, determination, or location of a fire lane by the fire official pursuant to the authority granted in this article shall be described in writing and filed with the city secretary. Such writing shall constitute a public record, and all persons shall be charged with notice of the contents of the same and unless otherwise designated therein by the fire official it shall be deemed permanent. In the event of a change of location, cancellation, or temporary suspension of a fire lane by the fire official, such change, cancellation or temporary suspension shall be described in writing and filed with the city secretary as aforesaid, provided that such change of location, cancellation or temporary suspension has the approval of city council. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 4, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-55. - Notice to owners; posting. 
Upon designation of a fire lane pursuant to this article, the fire official shall give notice of such designation to the owner of such shopping center, hospital, apartment houses, assembly building, or school, directing the owner to cause signs to be posted at the expense of the owner. Posting shall be at the extremities of such fire lane, and shall be lettered, "Fire Lane - City Ordinance," and such sign shall have the lettering and size as attached hereto and incorporated herein as Exhibit "A". Such signs shall be of a standard size, color, lettering, and mounting so as to conform to samples and instructions for same to be obtained from the Street and Bridge Department of the City of South Houston. 
Fire lanes shall be marked with a red painted line at least five (5) inches wide around the perimeter thereof with the words "FIRE LANE" and "NO PARKING" in white letters of at least four (4) inches high painted on the surface. The words "FIRE LANE" and "NO PARKING" shall be repeated every fifteen (15) feet, or in the event fire lanes are designated on surfaces which are not amenable to paint, the area will be conspicuously designated by signs not fewer than four (4) feet tall. 
 
Exhibit "A" 
(Ord. No. 866, § 5, 5-15-90; Ord. No. 944 (4-92), § 1, 4-28-92; Ord. No. 2018-19 , § 2, 10-23-18)  
Sec. 9-56. - Notice of violation. 
(a)  Vehicles or other obstructions found in or interfering with fire lanes shall be in violation of this article. Such vehicles or obstructions are subject to citation and being removed from such fire lanes. 
(b)  Proper officers are hereby authorized to provide for the removal of vehicles in violation of this section when, in the opinion of such officers, the vehicles could constitute a hazard in regard to fire prevention and protection. Vehicles so removed shall be delivered to the nearest authorized garage or other place of impoundment designated by the city council. No vehicle impounded as herein provided shall be released until the charges for towing such vehicle and any accumulated storage charges have been paid. 
(c)  Citations for violation of this section may be issued by a proper officer. Such citation shall specify the location of the fire lane in which such violation occurred and the date and time of such violation. Any citation for violation shall be issued on the official form theretofore prescribed by the city. Such citation shall require the appearance of the violator before the municipal court, and all fines paid by the violator shall be paid to the municipal court clerk. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 6, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-57. - Presumption of violation. 
In any prosecution charging a vehicle violation of this article, there shall be a rebuttal presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such vehicle in the proscribed area. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 7, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-58. - Unlawful parking. 
It is hereby declared unlawful to park any vehicle other than an authorized emergency vehicle on an emergency at a location in any fire lane where the signs provided for herein have been erected. Provided, however, if the signs are not in proper position and sufficiently legible to be seen by an ordinarily observant person, it shall be a defense to any alleged violation thereof. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 8, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-59. - Alteration or removal of signs. 
It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person, without lawful authority, to attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, or knock down, or remove any sign designating a fire lane which has been erected under the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 9, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-60. - Abandonment of fire lane. 
No owner, manager, or person in charge of any premises served by a required fire lane shall abandon or close any such fire lane without the permission of the fire official; and, such person shall keep the fire lanes clear of parked vehicles and/or objects that would impede escape from or access to said premises. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 10, 5-15-90)  
Sec. 9-61. - Penalty. 
Any person found in violation of this article shall guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished in accordance with section 1-7. 
(Ord. No. 866, § 11, 5-15-90)  
Chapter 9.8 - GARAGE SALES AND OCCASIONAL SALES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 772, adopted Sept. 24, 1987, did not specifically amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor §§ 1—5 have been included herein as Ch. 9.8, §§ 9.8-1—9.8-5. 
 
Sec. 9.8-1. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter the following terms shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them: 
Garage sale: Any sale entitled "garage sale," "yard sale," "patio sale," "rummage sale," "flea market sale," or any similar casual, occasional sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of said sale. 
Goods: Any commodity, ware, merchandise, or any other property capable of being the object of sale. 
Occasional sale: For the purpose of this chapter, the definitions of garage sale and occasional sale shall be synonymous. Such sales are by persons not in the general business of selling, leasing, or renting. 
(Ord. No. 772, § 1, 9-24-87)  
Sec. 9.8-2. - Permits. 
It shall hereinafter be unlawful for any person or persons to conduct a garage sale in the city without first filing with the city's inspection department the information hereinafter specified and obtaining a permit and sign stickers to do so, herein to be called a garage sale permit. The fee for a garage sale permit and stickers shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Said permit shall be issued to any one person at a specific address and no such permit shall be issued for more than two (2) consecutive calendar days. Each permit shall be prominently and conspicuously displayed on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted so as to be readily seen from the street during the entire period of the permitted sale. There shall be issued five (5) sign stickers for each garage sale permit. One sticker shall be placed on the lower left corner of each garage sale sign, which is displayed on the city right-of-way by permit holder. Each permit holder shall be allowed to conduct a maximum of two (2) garage sales within any twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 772, § 2, 9-24-87; Ord. No. 810, § 1, 8-2-88; Ord. No. 95-007, § 1, 6-20-95; Ord. No. 95-008, § 1, 7-20-95; Ord. No. 2005-25, § 1, 7-5-05; Ord. No. 2009-18, § 1, 8-25-09; Ord. No. 2011-32, § 2, 10-11-11; Ord. No. 2013-15, § 2, 7-9-13)  
Sec. 9.8-3. - Permit application. 
Information to be filed with the city inspection department by an applicant for a garage sale shall include the following: 
(1)  Name of person, firm, group, corporation, association, or organization conducting said sale. 
(2)  Specific address at which sale is to be conducted. 
(3)  Number of days and dates of the sale. 
(4)  Dates of any past sales at the specific address. 
(5)  Relationship or connection the applicant may have had with any person, firm, group, organization, association, or corporation conducting said sale and the date or dates of such sale. 
(6)  Whether or not the applicant has been issued any other vendor's, resale or peddler's license by any local, state, or federal agency. 
A statement shall be given by the person signing the garage sale permit application that the information contained therein is full, true and correct, and known to the applicant to be so. 
(Ord. No. 772, § 3, 9-24-87; Ord. No. 95-008, § 1, 7-20-95)  
Sec. 9.8-4. - Exemptions from permit requirements. 
The provisions of this chapter requiring a garage sale permit shall not apply to or affect the following: 
(1)  Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(2)  Persons acting in accordance with the powers and duties of public officials. 
(3)  Any person selling or advertising for sale a good or goods of personal property which are specifically named and described in an advertisement and which separate goods do not exceed five (5) in total number. 
(4)  The permit fee shall not apply to any nonprofit church, civic club, fraternal, or charitable organization. 
(Ord. No. 772, § 4, 9-24-87; Ord. No. 810, § 2, 8-2-88)  
Sec. 9.8-5. - Enforcement. 
Provisions and terms of this chapter shall be enforced by the South Houston Police Department. Further, any person violating any part of this chapter shall be required to pay a fine which is double the amount of the permit fee. 
(Ord. No. 772, § 5, 9-24-87; Ord. No. 2013-15, § 4, 7-9-13; Ord. No. 2017-34 , § 2, 8-8-17)  
Chapter 10 - SOLID WASTE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2002-27, §§ 1, 2, adopted November 19, 2002, repealed specific ordinances affecting chapter 10, §§ 10-1—10-6 and enacted a new chapter 10 as set out herein. However, such ordinance did not specifically repeal previous Ord. No. 2002-14, adopted June 4, 2002, and Ord. No. 2002-23, adopted Oct. 1, 2002, therefore these ordinances were treated as being added along with Ord. No. 2002-27, at the discretion of the editor. The former chapter 10 pertained to garbage and trash and derived from Ord. No. 350, 6-20-55; Ord. No. 562, § 11, 8-1-67; Ord. No. 582, §§ 1, 2, 6, 7, 8-4-70; Ord. No. 595, § 7, 11-16-71; Ord. No. 634, § 6, 8-16-77; Ord. No. 651, § 1, 8-7-79; Ord. No. 705, § 1, 7-1-83; Ord. No. 974 (3-93), § 1, 3-2-93. 
Cross reference— Storage and disposal of manure, § 4-52; authority of fire marshal with respect to dangerous accumulations of refuse material, § 9-23; junk, Ch. 11; burning of rubbish on streets and sidewalks, § 19-22. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 10-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
Garbage means all putrescent wastes, including vegetables, animal and poultry offal, carcasses of small animals and dead fowl, and includes all such substances from all public and private establishments and from all residences. 
Rubbish means solid and ordinary waste, other than garbage, accumulated by family residents, including glass and ashes, broken ware, discarded clothing, trash, tin cans, bottles, papers, and tree limbs, grass and weed cuttings properly contained or bundled as described in this chapter. 
Rubble means dirt, rocks and debris resulting from the construction, reconstruction or repair of buildings and other earthen, wooden or metal waste materials longer, larger or heavier than rubbish, including abandoned or waste home appliances, lumber and timber. 
Trash means rubbish such as feathers, coffee grounds, ashes, tin cans, paper, boxes, glass, grass, shrubs, yard cleanings, grass clippings, leaves and tree trimmings and any other matter commonly understood to be trash. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-2. - Purpose. 
The accumulation of garbage, rubble, trash and rubbish on the premises of private residences, businesses, public and private institutions, vacant lots and in the streets and alleys of the city constitutes a public menace and nuisance and greatly increases the danger of the spread of infectious, contagious and epidemic diseases, and this chapter is adopted for the purpose of preserving and protecting the public health, safety and general welfare by requiring property owners, tenants, occupants and lessees to secure and maintain containers and receptacles of sufficient size and material for the deposit of garbage, trash and rubbish for collection and removal at regular intervals. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-3. - Enforcement inspections. 
During reasonable hours, the city is authorized to inspect any premises within the city for the purpose of enforcing this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-4. - Unlawful deposits. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, unload, discharge or in any manner place thereon, or cause to be placed thereon, any garbage, trash or other waste materials on any lot, tract or parcel of land located within the city limits, except garbage dumps or dumping grounds which are owned, maintained or operated by the city or at such places as are designated for garbage disposal by the director of public works. 
(b)  No garbage, ashes, rubbish, old automobile parts or junk of any nature whatsoever shall be thrown or disposed of in any street or alley or upon any sidewalk or between any curb and sidewalk or on any other public property in the city. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to cast, throw or allow in any manner to be blown, carried or placed on any lot, street, sidewalk, tract or parcel of land any paper, trash, garbage, junk, rubbish or any matter or material commonly known as trash. It is not the intent of this subsection to prevent the normal and orderly handling and disposition of trash and rubbish within the confines of private property occupied by the owners or lessees, provided there does not exist a condition that is unsightly or an eyesore. 
(d)  Any person who drops or permits to be dropped or thrown upon any street or highway any destructive or injurious material or other material such as dirt, shell, oil, etc., which would be detrimental to the use or appearance of the street or highway shall immediately remove such or cause it to be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-5. - Unlawful accumulation. 
Rubbish shall be removed by the owner or occupant of the premises on which it is located, at his/her own expense and in a neat and sanitary manner, and shall not be permitted to accumulate on any premises beyond a reasonable length of time. No violation shall be charged under this section unless ten (10) days' notice of such unlawful accumulation shall have been given by the sanitation department and the unlawful accumulation is not corrected within such time. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-6. - Unlawful hauling for business. 
In order for the city to provide general sanitation and health of the city and in order to provide garbage collection for the city, it shall be unlawful for any person not under contract with the city to haul any garbage any time or to commercially haul any rubbish or rubble on any established route or regular basis over the city streets. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-7. - Contracts with private collectors. 
The city shall enter into a contract with a private contractor for the collection of all garbage throughout the city. Such contract shall provide for a complete collection once weekly, shall provide for the type of vehicles to be used and shall provide for the type of garbage containers and their placement for collection purposes. The contract shall provide for a unit price to be paid to the contractor. Nothing in this section shall prohibit the city from engaging in garbage collection if determined necessary and appropriate by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-8. - Covering vehicles hauling refuse. 
In order to protect the health and welfare of the citizens of the city and to provide against any undue health hazards, all persons hauling garbage and rubbish of any type within the city limits shall provide such vehicle with a full top or cover so that no garbage or rubbish may escape therefrom and no flies or other insects can get into or out of the unit. Such cover shall be securely fastened so that the cover shall not come loose or the contents be exposed in any manner. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-9. - Illegally dumping trash. 
That the city hereby offers a reward of fifty dollars ($50.00) for information leading to the arrest and conviction of any person or persons found guilty of illegally dumping trash or refuse within the city. This reward is a standing offer, and shall be paid out of the general fund of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-14, § 1, 6-4-02) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2002-14, § 1, adopted June 4, 2002, did not specifically amend the Code, therefore § 10-9 was added at the discretion of the editor. See editors' note for chapter 10.  
Secs. 10-10—10-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 10-26. - Use of city collection service, or designated collection agency, mandatory. 
(a)  To assist in maintaining the general sanitation and health of the city, it shall be the duty of every person occupying or having control of the occupancy of any premises located on a regularly established garbage and rubbish route to notify the city at the beginning of such occupancy and to request, accept and use the garbage and rubbish pickup and collection service. Failure of any owner, rental agent or occupant of such premises to make such request shall not prevent or any way impair or impede the city from adding the address of such premises to the proper garbage and rubbish collection route records and providing such service and otherwise enforcing, by appropriate action, the regulatory measures prescribed in this subsection and causing the fees or charges therefor to be paid. 
(b)  The city, or the designated collection agency, shall regularly collect and remove properly prepared garbage, trash and rubbish from the premises of residences and commercial establishments. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-27. - Fees. 
The rates for garbage pickups for the city shall be as follows: 
(1)  Residential rates shall be as specified by city council, the amounts of which are on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(2)  Commercial rates shall apply to all apartments and commercial establishments. The rates shall be as specified in a contract with a private collector. The commercial establishment may designate the size container needed and the number of weekly pickups. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-28. - Disposal of heavy accumulations. 
(a)  Heavy accumulations, such as brick, broken concrete, rock, stones, ashes, lumber, clinkers, cinders, dirt, plaster, sand, gravel, automobile frames, dead trees, tree limbs and other bulky, heavy material shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or person controlling such. The fee shall be as specified by the city council, the amount of which is on file in the office of the city secretary. 
(b)  If trash and rubbish is of such nature that it cannot be placed in a receptacle, it shall be prepared in units or pieces under fifty (50) pounds in weight and placed at a point designated by the director of public works. 
(c)  Tree limbs, shrubs and hedge cuttings must be bundled so as not to exceed five (5) feet in length or so as not to be over fifty (50) pounds in weight. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-29. - Unauthorized handling. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner, employees of the city or persons operating under a contract with the city, to empty the garbage cans or trash and rubbish receptacles or to transport garbage, trash or rubbish on the public streets, alleys or public thoroughfares of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner, employees of the city or persons operating under a contract with the city, to disturb or tamper with the contents of any garbage can or trash or rubbish receptacle in the city. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-30. - Unacceptable items. 
The city contractor or city employees are not permitted to transport or dispose of any hazardous or toxic wastes, including, but not limited to, oil, paint, pesticides, batteries and tires. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-31. - Burning. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any garbage within the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to burn trash or rubbish within the city, except with the written permission of the fire marshal and in compliance with the city fire code and the Texas Clean Air Act, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 382.001 et. seq. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Secs. 10-32—10-40. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONTAINERS 
 
Sec. 10-41. - Required; specifications. 
(a)  Every owner, occupant, tenant or lessee using or occupying any building, house or structure within the corporate limits for residential, church, school, college, lodge, commercial business or other purposes shall use the receptacle provided by the collection agency, but, if no receptacle is provided, shall provide and maintain garbage cans and trash and rubbish receptacles of sufficient size and number to hold the garbage, trash and rubbish which normally accumulates on the premises. 
(b)  Garbage cans required by this section shall have a capacity of not fewer than ten or more than ninety-five (95) gallons, shall be constructed of substantial material, shall be equipped with a tight-fitting lid or cover and with handles sufficiently strong for workers to empty conveniently, and shall be tapered so that they are smaller on the bottom than the top. Tote carts or heavy-duty tied plastic bags may be used if there is no collection agency. 
(c)  The total weight of any garbage can and contents or any trash and rubbish receptacle and contents shall be seventy-five (75) pounds or fewer. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-42. - Protection of contents. 
(a)  The lids or covers of garbage cans or containers shall at all times be secured and fastened so that flies and other insects may not have access to the contents thereof, and such lids or covers shall only be opened while the cans are being filled or emptied. 
(b)  The contents of trash or rubbish receptacles shall be protected so that the wind cannot scatter the contents over the premises or over the city streets and alleys. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-43. - Preparation of deposits. 
(a)  All garbage and all trash and rubbish mixed with water or other liquids shall be drained before being placed in the can or receptacle. 
(b)  All garbage which has been drained shall be well-wrapped in paper or other combustible material before being placed in the can or receptacle. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-44. - Placement and location. 
The required garbage cans and receptacles for trash and rubbish shall be placed on residential premises in accordance with instructions of the director of public works and the collection agency or, in the absence of such instructions, at the most accessible point for collection and removal. Garbage, rubble, trash, rubbish and debris shall not be placed at curbside for collection prior to 5:00 p.m. of the day prior to the day of collection. Garbage cans and receptacles for trash and rubbish shall be removed prior to 7:00 a.m. of the day following the day of collection. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Secs. 10-45—10-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS 
 
Sec. 10-56. - Compliance. 
It is ordered that all commercial establishments handling food for human consumption, whether on the premises or off, shall provide garbage containers as provided in this division and shall comply in all respects with the requirements of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-57. - Container specifications. 
Garbage at commercial food establishments shall be placed in containers, with the combined weight of the garbage and container not exceeding one hundred (100) pounds, except for mechanical type dumpster units which are approved by the city. The container shall be a watertight receptacle of a solid and durable material and shall be provided with suitable handles on the outside and with a tightly fitting cover equipped with a handle. The container must not have any inside structures such as inside bands or reinforcing angles or anything within the container to prevent the free discharge of the contents. Garbage containers that have deteriorated to the extent of having holes or jagged or sharp edges capable of causing injury to the garbage collectors or others whose duty it is to handle the containers or to such an extent that the lids will not fit tightly or securely, will be condemned by the city and may not be used. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, §, 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Sec. 10-58. - Removal of garbage. 
(a)  For a commercial food establishment, the contents of any garbage container which is so overloaded that the lid will not fit securely on the container will not be picked up by the garbage collectors, and garbage in a container not in compliance with this division will not be picked up. The contents of any garbage container which, with the container, weighs more than one hundred (100) pounds will not be picked up, unless it is in a mechanical dumpster-type container. 
(b)  Any person desiring to place garbage for collection shall place the containers on his/her property at an accessible place at such residence or place of business not later than 7:30 a.m. on those days designated by the city proper authorities for the collection of garbage. After the garbage has been collected by the collection agency, the owner of the containers shall remove the containers immediately from the front of any property, and no containers may be left out overnight unless the mechanical dumpster-type container is in a location approved by the city. All containers shall be decontaminated or purified at periodic intervals and as often as may be necessary. 
(c)  Rubbish shall be removed from all business premises every day and as often as deemed necessary by the county health officer. 
(d)  Garbage must be disposed of at least on every garbage collecting day and more often if deemed necessary by the city. If it is disposed of more often than regular collection days, it shall be removed at the sole expense of the party involved, but in compliance with city rules and regulations and all applicable city ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2002-27, § 2(Exh. A), 11-19-02)  
Secs. 10-59—10-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - REGULATION OF DUMPSTERS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Since Ord. No. 2002-27, adopted November 19, 2002, which added a new chapter 10, did not specifically repeal Ord.
