c.  Sexual assault; or aggravated sexual assault as described in Chapter 22 of the Texas Penal Code; 
d.  Incest; solicitation of a child; or harboring a runaway child as described in Chapter 25 of the Texas Penal Code; 
e.  Gambling; gambling promotion; keeping a gambling place; communicating gambling information; possession of gambling devices or equipment; or possession of gambling paraphernalia as described in Chapter 47 of the Texas Penal Code; 
f.  Forgery; credit card abuse; or commercial bribery as described in Chapter 32 of the Texas Penal Code; 
g.  A criminal offense as described in Chapter 481, Subchapter D of the Health and Safety Code; 
h.  A criminal offense as described in Chapter 34 of the Texas Penal Code; 
i  Criminal attempt; conspiracy; or solicitation to commit any of the foregoing offenses; or any other offense in another state that, if committed in this state, would have been punishable as one or more of the aforementioned offenses; or 
j.  A violation of these regulations described in subsection 12-89(a). 
(5)  The SOBE, as proposed, is a prohibited SOBE pursuant to subsection 12-89(b); the SOBE does not meet all the requirements of these regulations; or the SOBE is otherwise prohibited by local, state, or federal law; 
(6)  The applicant has knowingly made a misleading statement of a material fact by omitting or falsifying information in the application for the SOBP or failed to provide information reasonably necessary for the issuance of an SOBP in the application or at any time during the application process. 
(7)  The applicant (if an individual) is under eighteen (18) years of age. 
(8)  The applicant or enterprise operator has had an SOBP revoked for the same SOBE or for another SOBE located at the same business location within the twelve-month period immediately preceding the date the application was filed; 
(9)  An applicant or any individual related or associated with the applicant is delinquent in the payment to the City of South Houston, Texas, fees, fines, or penalties assessed or imposed regarding the operation of an SOBE or has allowed any of its ad valorem taxes, whether on the property subject to these regulations or any other real or personal property owned by the applicant, owed to the City of South Houston, Texas, or to any taxing jurisdiction which levies ad valorem taxes on property owned in the City of South Houston, Texas, to become delinquent: provided that nothing herein shall impair the right of the applicant to challenge, in accordance with the requirements of Chapters 41 and 42 of the Tax Code, the appraised value of any of its property if, but only if, it follows all steps to perfect that challenge in the year in which the disputed appraisal is rendered; 
(10)  The application or renewal fee required by these regulations has not been paid; or 
(11)  An applicant or enterprise operator has owned or been employed in a managerial capacity of a business or location within the preceding twelve (12) months and during that period the business or location constituted a common or public nuisance as defined in Chapter 125 of the Texas Civil Practice and Remedies Code. 
(f)  The executive director shall attach reasonable conditions on an SOBP pursuant to the recommendations of the hearing officer if a public hearing was held under section 12-80. These conditions shall address the public health and safety concerns identified in the hearing. 
(g)  An SOBP shall be valid for one year from the date it is issued, unless the SOBP is revoked or suspended pursuant to these regulations. 
(h)  In the event the executive director determines that the SOBP is denied pursuant to these regulations, the applicant shall be given written notice of the reason for that determination. The written notice does not prohibit the City of South Houston, Texas, in litigation on appeal, from presenting evidence of additional or alternative facts that support denial of the SOBP. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XIV, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-81. - Revocation or suspension. 
(a)  The executive director shall have the authority and power to initiate a proceeding to revoke or suspend an SOBP if there is probable cause to believe that one or more of the following events or conditions has occurred: 
(1)  The enterprise operator negligently allowed a person under eighteen (18) years of age to remain on the premises of the SOBE during the hours of operation; 
(2)  The enterprise failed to comply with a duty specifically imposed by these regulations; 
(3)  The applicant provided materially false, fraudulent, or untruthful information on the original or renewal SOBP application form; 
(4)  The SOBP should not have been issued pursuant to these regulations; or 
(5)  The enterprise operator commits or is convicted of a criminal offense listed in subsections 12-80(e)(4)a.—j. of these regulations. 
(b)  If probable cause is found to believe any of the stated events or conditions occurred, the executive director shall forward to the SOBP holder or its designated agent a written notice of revocation. The notice shall set out the reasons for the action. Subject to a request for hearing pursuant to this section, the revocation shall become final on the eleventh (11 th ) business day after notice is provided pursuant to these regulations. 
(c)  The SOBE or its designated agent shall have the opportunity to appear before a hearing examiner appointed by the mayor upon written request submitted to the executive director within ten (10) business days of delivery of the notice of revocation. The hearing examiner shall not have participated in any investigation of the alleged grounds for the revocation. The hearing will be held as soon as is reasonably possible, but preferably within fourteen (14) business days of the request for hearing. The SOBE and the executive director will be provided an opportunity to present evidence and cross-examine witnesses. They also may be represented by legal counsel. The rules of civil evidence for a non-jury trial shall apply. 
(d)  Upon finding that the facts presented at the hearing support a finding that grounds exist for revoking or suspending the SOBP, the hearing examiner may request that the parties present relevant evidence to show whether suspension or revocation of the SOBP is more appropriate. The hearing examiner may also request that evidence be presented for the purpose of identifying appropriate conditions to be attached to an SOBP if the SOBP is suspended. Reasonable conditions may be attached to an SOBP by the hearing examiner based on the evidence presented at the hearing. 
(e)  If the hearing examiner determines that an SOBP should be revoked, the hearing examiner shall issue a written order revoking the SOBP when notice is provided to the enterprise operator pursuant to these regulations. 
(f)  If the hearing examiner determines, based upon the nature of the violations, that a suspension in lieu of revocation is appropriate, operation of the SOBP may be suspended for a period of time not to exceed two (2) weeks. The hearing examiner shall issue a written order suspending the SOBP and attaching conditions, if applicable, upon notice to the enterprise operator pursuant to these regulations. 
(g)  Revocation shall be subject to the hearing provisions of this section. But revocation shall take immediate effect upon notice being sent, subject to reinstatement resulting from appeal, when there is a necessity for immediate action to protect the public from injury or imminent danger. 
(h)  A revocation shall be in effect for a minimum of three (3) months. After three (3) months, another application could be made for an SOBP. The circumstances surrounding the revocation may be considered by the executive director. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XV, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-82. - Notice. 
(a)  Any notice required to be given by the executive director under these regulations to any applicant or enterprise operator may be given by personal delivery or by United States mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the most recent address as specified in the application for the SOBP or the most recent notice of address change. 
(b)  Mailed notice shall be deemed served five (5) days after deposit in the United States mail. Personal notice shall be deemed served when delivered to an enterprise operator or, if the enterprise operator is not available, posted at the entrance to the SOBE. If the notice is served or posted, the individual serving or posting the notice will note the time and date of his/her action on a copy of the notice posted and return the copy to the executive director. 
(c)  If a notice given by mail is returned by the postal service as undeliverable, it will be presumed the enterprise operator did not comply with the affirmative duty to notify the executive director of any change of address. This presumption may be rebutted by the enterprise owner's showing there was an error on the part of the post office. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XVI, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-83. - Temporary SOBP provisions. 
If the executive director fails to take action on an application within the times specified, or if the hearing officer fails to timely conduct or give notice of the decision after the hearing, the applicant shall be entitled to an immediate issuance of a temporary SOBP upon written demand. The applicant must file the demand with the executive director. A temporary SOBP shall be valid only until notice of the executive director's action on the application or the hearing examiner's order. This section shall not apply if the delay is wholly or partially caused by the action or inaction of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XVII, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-84. - SOBP renewals. 
(a)  SOBP renewal applications must be filed not more than thirty (30) days prior to the expiration date of the SOBP. The renewal application form will be provided by the executive director. 
(b)  An annual non-refundable renewal fee of six hundred dollars ($600.00) will accompany the application for renewal to defray costs of inspections and investigation. Only cashier checks and checks drawn on business or corporate accounts will be accepted. Cash will not be accepted. 
(c)  The renewal application must contain: 
(1)  Certification by the applicant that there have been no changes in the information provided in the initial application or the information which has changed since the initial application, supported by related documentation as required in the initial application. 
(2)  Certification the SOBE is in operation. The permit will not be renewed if the SOBE has not commenced operation as proposed in the initial SOBP application. 
(d)  The executive director shall determine if the permit may be renewed based on the information contained in the renewal application. The renewal permit will be denied upon a finding of any of the conditions identified in subsections 12-80(e) (4)a.—j. Notice of renewal or denial will be issued within fourteen (14) days of receipt of the completed renewal application or by the expiration date of the previous SOBP, whichever period is longer. 
(e)  If a renewal application is submitted fewer than fifteen (15) days before the previous SOBP expires, there shall be no temporary SOBP issued to extend the SOBP. The original SOBP will expire and, until the executive director's determination on renewal, there will be no valid SOBP for operation during that period. Upon expiration of an SOBP, the City of South Houston, Texas, shall mail a notice to the SOBE advising that the SOBP has expired. Such notice shall be mailed to the SOBE within five (5) days of the expiration of the SOBP. The SOBE shall have thirty (30) days from the date of receipt to renew its expired SOBP. The renewal fee for an expired SOBP shall be nine hundred dollars ($900.00). 
(f)  If a permit has been suspended pursuant to section 12-81 of these regulations, the renewed permit will be suspended until the suspension period has elapsed. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XVIII, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-85. - Investigation. 
Upon receiving the application for an SOBP or an application for renewal, the executive director shall perform an investigation to determine compliance with these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XIX, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-86. - Inspections. 
The executive director or his/her designees shall make such reasonable, periodic inspections of the premises of all SOBEs that are permitted under these regulations as they deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XX, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-87. - Transfer prohibited of new SOBPs. 
(a)  A new SOBP issued under these regulations is not transferable, assignable, or divisible. It is a violation of these regulations for any person or other legal entity to attempt to do so. Upon transfer by bequest or operation of law upon the death of the SOBP holder, the SOBP will continue in effect for forty-five (45) days after the death of the SOBP holder. Upon the filing of a new application and fee, and posting the application with the prior SOBP, the SOBE may continue to operate until the final determination on the new SOBP. In no application is filed within forty-five (45) days after the death of the SOBP holder, the SOBE shall be in violation of these regulations each and every day it continues to operate without a new SOBP. 
(b)  If an SOBE had been previously permitted under any prior enacted SOB ordinance or regulation, its permit may be transferred to a new operator upon notification to the Executive Director by submitting an SOBP transfer form and payment of a one thousand two hundred dollars ($1,200.00) transfer fee. A transference of an existing SOBP must qualify as a new applicant for an SOBP. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXI, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-88. - Lost or destroyed SOBP. 
(a)  If an SOBP is lost or destroyed, a replacement may be obtained by filing a lost SOBP application and paying a lost permit fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). 
(b)  A replacement SOBP will be issued immediately upon confirmation of the identity of the applicant through the executive director's records. A replacement permit will expire on the same date as the original permit. 
(c)  It shall not be a defense to prosecution for conducting business without an SOBP that an SOBP was lost or stolen. An SOBE may not conduct business as an SOBE, in the areas covered under these regulations, until a replacement SOBP is obtained. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXII, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-89. - Operating requirements for enterprises. 
(a)  The following shall be violations of these regulations punishable as authorized in Section 243.010(b) of the Local Government Code. Each day a violation continues constitutes and is punishable as a separate offense: 
(1)  For any employee, enterprise operator or other SOBP holder to negligently allow any person below the age of eighteen (18) years to remain upon the premises or within the confines of the SOBE during the hours of operation; 
(2)  For any SOBE to exhibit signs, billboards, advertisements, displays, or other promotional materials at the premises that are characterized by specified sexual activities or specified prohibited anatomical areas and are visible from a public road, sidewalk, or other public place; 
(3)  For any person to conduct business as an SOBE in the incorporated areas of South Houston, Texas, without a valid SOBP issued in accordance with these regulations; 
(4)  For any person to counterfeit, forge, change, deface, duplicate, or alter an SOBP; 
(5)  For any person to knowingly make any false, fraudulent or untruthful material representation, written or oral, or in any other way knowingly conceal any material fact required in the SOBP application. 
(6)  For the enterprise operator to fail to comply with the conditions attached to the SOBP; each and every day the SOBE fails to comply with an SOBP condition is a violation of these regulations. 
(7)  For any person to attempt to transfer, assign, or devise an SOBP unless otherwise provided herein. 
(b)  The following categories of SOBEs are prohibited: 
(1)  Sexually oriented modeling studios or nude modeling studios; 
(2)  Escort agencies; 
(3)  Escorts; 
(4)  Sexual encounter centers; and 
(5)  Any SOBE whose employees appear in a state of total nudity, except SOBEs which were previously permitted under any previously enacted ordinances or regulations; and 
It is a violation of these regulations to engage in prohibited SOBEs. Any person found to be engaged or participating in the business of a prohibited SOBE will be subject to the penalties and enforcement provisions of these regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXIII, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-90. - Additional regulations for adult motels. 
(a)  Evidence that a sleeping room in a hotel, motel, or similar commercial establishment has been rented and vacated two (2) or more times in a period of time that is less than twelve (12) hours creates a rebuttable presumption that the establishment is an SOBE adult motel under these regulations if the motel also provides patrons with closed-circuit television transmissions, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, or other reproductions which are characterized by the depiction or description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section. 
(b)  For purposes of this section, the terms "rent" or "sub-rent" mean the act of allowing a room to be occupied for any form of consideration. 
(c)  An adult motel permitted pursuant to these regulations may have a resident manager living on site. This shall not be considered a dwelling under the location requirements of section 12-76. 
(d)  No individuals under the age of eighteen (18) may live on the site of an adult motel. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXIV, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-91. - Regulations pertaining to exhibition of sexually explicit films or videos. 
A person who operates or causes to be operated an SOBE or any other enterprise that exhibits on the premises in a viewing room of fewer than two thousand (2,000) square feet of floor space, a film, motion picture, video cassette, DVD, computer program, or other visual reproductions, depicting specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, has the duty to comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  The SOBE has the duty to maintain at least one employee on duty and situated in each manager's station at all times that any patron is present inside the premises; 
(2)  The interior of the premises shall be configured in such a manner that there is an unobstructed view from the owner, operator, or manager's station of every area of the premises, excluding restrooms, to which any patron is allowed access for any purpose; and 
(3)  If the premises has two (2) or more owners, operators, or managers' stations designated, the interior of the premises must be configured so that there is an unobstructed direct line of sight view from at least one station to all portions of the premises where patrons are allowed access, excluding restrooms. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXV, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-92. - Persons younger than eighteen prohibited from entry. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of these regulations to allow a person who is younger than eighteen (18) years of age to enter or be on the premises of an SOBE at any time the SOBE is open for business. 
(b)  An SOBE has the duty to station an attendant at each public entrance to the enterprise at all times during the SOBE's business hours. The attendant shall not allow any person under the age of eighteen (18) years of age to enter the SOBE. It shall be presumed that an attendant knew a person was under the age of eighteen (18) unless the attendant asked for and was furnished: 
(1)  A facially valid operator's, commercial operator's, or chauffeur's driver's license; or 
(2)  A facially valid personal identification certificate issued by the Texas Department of Public Safety reflecting that such person is eighteen (18) years of age or older. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXVI, 3-26-02)  
Sec. 12-93. - Operative date/amended and superseded regulations. 
The effective date of these regulations is April 3, 2002. 
Except as otherwise stated below, these regulations supplement any previously enacted SOB ordinances or regulations enacted by the City of South Houston, Texas. 
Should any provision in these regulations directly conflict with any provision contained in any previously enacted ordinances or regulations enacted by the City of South Houston, Texas, the language contained in these regulations will control, but only to the extent of the conflict. 
(Ord. No. 2002-02, § XXVII, 3-26-02; Ord. No. 2002-04, § 1, 4-2-02)  
Secs. 12-94—12-98. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - GRAFFITI 
 
Sec. 12-99. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, unless the context of their usage clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Owner or occupant means the record owner of the lot or parcel of land or other person specifically authorized in writing by the record owner to authorize the placement of any painting, scratching, writing or inscription upon the owner's property, or the tenant of a residential or commercial property. 
Unauthorized means without the consent of the owner or occupant or without authority of law, regulation or ordinance. Unless the owner proves otherwise, lack of consent will be presumed under circumstances tending to show (i) the absence of evidence of specific authorization of the visual blight by the owner, (ii) that the visual blight is inconsistent with the design and use of the subject property, or (iii) that the person causing the visual blight was unknown to the owner. 
Visual blight means any unauthorized graffiti or any other unauthorized form of painting, scratching, writing or inscription, including, without limitation, initials, slogans, or drawings. Regardless of the content or nature of the material that has been applied to any wall, building, fence, sign, or other structure or surface and is visible from any public property or right-of-way or is visible from the private property of another person. 
(Ord. No. 97-013, § 2, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 12-100. - Declaration; notice. 
Visual blight is declared to be a public nuisance. Whenever the existence of visual blight on any lot or parcel of real estate situated within the city shall come to the knowledge of the building official or his representative, such official may forthwith cause a written notice identifying the visual blight and directing its removal to be delivered to the owner of the property, provided that the time allowed in the notice for abatement of the nuisance shall not be less than ten (10) days, and such a notice shall further state that the owner is entitled to request a hearing to be held in the manner described herein. 
(Ord. No. 97-013, § 3, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 12-101. - Hearing. 
The owner or occupant of a lot or parcel subject to abatement under this article may request a hearing by notifying the building inspector within ten (10) days following the date the city delivers the required notice. The hearing shall be conducted by the building inspector for the purpose of determining whether the conditions constitute a public nuisance under the provisions of this article. Unless notice is waived by the owner, the owner shall be provided written notice of the time and place of the hearing at least ten (10) days prior thereto. At the hearing, the owner or occupant and city officials may present any evidence relevant to the proceedings, in accordance with reasonable rules adopted by the city council. If the building inspector finds that conditions constituting a nuisance hereunder exist, the building inspector shall issue an order so stating. 
(Ord. No. 97-013, § 4, 5-13-97)  
Sec. 12-102. - Abatement by the city; expenses and liens. 
(a)  The city shall be authorized to carry out the abatement of visual blight on any property with fifty (50) percent of the costs charged to the owner or occupant, provided that the property's owner or occupant requests or consents to such abatement within ten (10) days of notification from the building official or an authorized representative. Extensions may be granted at the discretion of the building official or an authorized representative. 
(b)  If the owner or occupant fails to abate the visual blight, request or consent to its removal by the city, or request a hearing, or if it is determined at a hearing that the condition of the property constitutes a nuisance under this article, then the city shall be authorized to carry out the abatement of the visual blight and to assess its expenses and place a lien on the property. 
(c)  If a lien is to be filed, the building official of the city shall file a statement of expenses incurred under this article, giving the amount of such expenses and the date on which the work was done or improvements made, with the county clerk and the city shall have a privileged lien on such lot or real estate upon which the work was done or improvements made to secure the expenditures so made, in accordance with the provisions of the law. 
The amount of such expenses shall bear six (6) percent interest per annum as allowed by law from the date such statement is filed. For any such expenditures and interest, suit may be instituted and recovery and foreclosure of such lien may be had in the name of the city and the statement of expenses so made, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima facie proof of the amount expended for such work or improvement. The building official is authorized to accept payments for such liens in installments and give releases or partial releases as necessary. 
(d)  If the abatement involves painting the blighted surface, the city will paint over the visual blight area, but paint may not match exactly. 
(e)  The city council authorizes the use of funds and provision of material as available for this graffiti abatement program, including application to a reward fund including monies recovered by fines assessed by the municipal court against perpetrators of graffiti vandalism; and including provision of free paint to volunteer groups for anti-graffiti efforts. 
(Ord. No. 97-013, § 5, 5-13-97)  
Secs. 12-103—12-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - RESERVED[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 97-026, § 1, adopted September 9, 1997, repealed article VII in its entirety. Formerly, such article pertained to public dances, dancehalls and nightclubs and derived from Ord. No. 97-024, 8-26-97. 
 
Secs. 12-111—12-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - RESIDENCES OF SEXUAL OFFENDERS 
 
Sec. 12-151. - Findings and intent. 
That repeat sexual offenders, sexual offenders who use physical violence and sexual offenders who prey on children are sexual predators who present an extreme threat to the public safety. Sexual offenders are extremely likely to use physical violence and to repeat their offenses and most sexual offenders commit many offenses, have many more victims than are ever reported, and are prosecuted for only a fraction of their crimes. This makes the cost of sexual offender victimization to society at large, while incalculable, clearly exorbitant. 
It is the intent of this article to serve the city's compelling interest to promote, protect, and improve the health, safety, and welfare of the citizens of the city by creating areas around locations where children regularly congregate in concentrated numbers wherein certain sexual offenders and sexual predators are prohibited from establishing temporary or permanent residences. 
(Ord. No. 2006-20, § 1, 7-11-06)  
Sec. 12-152. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Permanent residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for fourteen (14) or more consecutive days. 
Temporary residence means a place where the person abides, lodges, or resides for a period of fourteen (14) or more days in the aggregate during any calendar year and which is not the person's permanent address or a place where the person routinely abides, resides, or lodges for a period of four (4) or more consecutive or nonconsecutive days in any month and which is not the person's permanent residence. 
(Ord. No. 2006-20, § 2, 7-11-06)  
Sec. 12-153. - Sexual offenders' residence prohibition; penalties; exceptions. 
(a)  If a person is required to register on the Texas Department of Public Safety's sex offender database, it is unlawful for that person to establish a permanent residence or temporary residence within one thousand (1,000) feet of any premises where children commonly gather, including but not limited to, a school, day-care facility, playground, public or private youth center, neighborhood or public swimming pool, or video arcade facility, as those terms are defined in V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code of the State of Texas § 481.134. It shall be prima facie evidence that this section applies to such a person if the person's record appears on the database. 
(b)  For the purpose of determining the minimum distance separation, the requirement shall be measured by following a straight line from the outer or nearest property line of the permanent or temporary residence to the outer or nearest property line of the premises where children commonly gather, as described herein. A map generally depicting the prohibited areas or zones is attached to this article for representation purposes. The city shall review this map at least annually for changes. 
(c)  In cases of dispute over measured distances, it shall be incumbent upon the person(s) challenging the measurement to prove otherwise. 
(d)  Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation that violates this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(e)  Exceptions. A person residing within one thousand (1,000) feet of those places where children commonly gather, as specified herein, does not commit a violation of this article if any of the following apply: 
(1)  The person established the permanent or temporary residence and has complied with all the sex offender registration laws of the State of Texas prior to the date of the adoption of this article. 
(2)  The person was a minor when he/she committed the offense and was not convicted as an adult. 
(3)  The person is a minor. 
(4)  The premises where children commonly gather, as specified herein, within one thousand (1,000) feet of the person's permanent or temporary residence was opened after the person established the permanent or temporary residence and complied with all sex offender registration laws of the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2006-20, § 3, 7-11-06; Ord. No. 2012-11, § 2, 8-14-12)  
Sec. 12-154. - Property owners prohibited from renting real property to sexual offenders; penalties. 
(a)  It is unlawful to sell, let or rent any place, structure or part thereof, manufactured home, motor home, trailer, boat or other conveyance with the knowledge that it will be used as a permanent or temporary residence by any person prohibited from establishing such permanent or temporary residence pursuant to the terms of this article, if such place, structure or part thereof, manufactured home, motor home, trailer, boat or other conveyance is located within one thousand (1,000) feet of any premises where children commonly gather, including but not limited to, a school, day-care facility, playground, public or private, youth center, public swimming pool, or video arcade facility, as those terms are defined in V.T.C.A. Health and Safety Code Art. 481.134. 
(b)  Penalties. Any person, firm or corporation who violates this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 2006-20, § 4, 7-11-06)  
Chapter 13 - MOBILE HOMES AND MOBILE HOME PARKS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 732, adopted Dec. 3, 1985, amended Ch. 13 to read as herein set out. Prior to said amendment, Ch. 13 pertained to mobile homes and mobile home parks and was composed of substantive provisions contained in Art. I, §§ 13-1—13-3; Art. II, §§ 13-16—13-22; Art. III, Div. 1, §§ 13-34, 13-35, and Div. 2, §§ 13-44—13-52; Art. IV, Div. 1, §§ 13-64—13-78, and Div. 2, §§ 13-86—13-95. These former substantive provisions of Ch. 13 derived from Ord. No. 585, §§ 1—7 and 9, adopted Dec. 1, 1970. 
Cross reference— Buildings and general building regulations, Ch. 6; electrical code, Ch. 8; plumbing and gas fitting, Ch. 17; water, sewers and sewage disposal, Ch. 24; zoning ordinance, App. A. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
The words and phrases to be given special definitions and contained in this chapter are defined as follows. Words or phrases not specially defined herein shall be defined in accordance with their accepted meaning as used in context with the pertinent subject or as further defined in other ordinances or resolutions passed by the city council of the City of South Houston. 
License: An authorization, or written evidence thereof, issued by the City of South Houston, to maintain and operate a mobile home park within its corporate limits, and an authorization, or written evidence thereof to place a mobile home on private property. 
Mobile home: A one-family dwelling unit of vehicular, portable design built on a chassis and designed to be moved from one site to another by a power connected thereto. 
Mobile home park: Any lot, lots, block, tract or parcel of land used, in whole or in part, for mobile home parking facilities and accommodations provided by day, week, or for a period of time, with or without compensations, composed of two (2) or more units for human habitation, or living, or sleeping quarters incidental thereto. It is the complex for which mobile home park permits are issued. 
Occupant: A person having custody and control of a mobile home, or a member of the family of such person within the third degree of consanguinity or the second degree of affinity and living with such person in such trailer. 
Owner: Any person, firm, partnership, corporation, association, organization, or groups thereof, who has title to or control, direction, maintenance, and supervision of a mobile home park, or a mobile home as defined herein. 
Parking space: An area of eight and one-half (8 1 / 2 ) feet wide by twenty (20) feet long situated on a mobile home park street. 
Parking stall: An area of sufficient size to accommodate two (2) automobiles, minimum dimensions of such area to be eight and one-half (8 1 / 2 ) feet wide by eighteen (18) feet long per automobile. 
Permit: An authorization, and the written evidence thereof, issued by the City of South Houston to construct and equip mobile home park, which, for the purposes to this chapter shall be any mobile home park other than one owned and operated by the government of the United States, the State of Texas, or political subdivisions thereof, within such corporate limits under the terms of this chapter, called "mobile home park." 
Plat: The map, drawing or chart on which a developer's plan of a mobile home park is presented to the City of South Houston [with the] form of dedication. 
Street: Any street, area, avenue, boulevard, drive, public place or highway designed for or commonly used for the purpose of travel by vehicles within the corporate limits of the city. Distinctions are made in this chapter between public, or streets outside the premises of the mobile home park, and private, or streets inside the mobile home park premises. 
Tenant: A person or persons having custody and control of a mobile home. 
Unit: Any place, plot, or parcel of ground located within a mobile home park where mobile homes are parked, erected or placed, used, intended or designated as human habitations, boarding, sleeping, or living quarters, or any combination thereof. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-2. - Chapter does not permit violations of zoning ordinance. 
Nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to permit property to be used contrary to provisions of the zoning ordinance of the city. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-3. - Mobile home parking limitations; four-hour street parking. 
No person shall park, place, or locate any mobile home upon any public street or public park within the corporate limits of the City of South Houston for a period of more than four (4) hours. Any mobile home shall be parked parallel to the right side curb, completely clear of driving lanes or areas of said street or park, and facing in the direction which traffic shall be designated to travel on said street or in said driving area. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Secs. 13-4—13-15. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME TAXATION; MOVING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 13-16. - Ad valorem taxation; mobile home moving permit and fee. 
(a)  Any mobile home located within a mobile home park or upon a private lot or tract of land as of January first (tax assessment date) of each year shall be rendered for taxation by the mobile home owner to the assessor-collector of taxes as provided for in the Property Tax Code, Section 1.04(2), (3), 11.01, and 25.08, Vernon's Annotated Texas Statutes. If both the land and the mobile home are owned by the same person, the mobile home shall be rendered as real property. If the owner of the mobile home is not the owner of the land, the mobile home shall be the liability of the owner of the mobile home and not a liability of the landowner. The "Over 65 Residential Homestead Exemption" shall be granted in those cases where applicable. Persons paying taxes under this section shall be issued a small sticker or decal indicating the taxes have been paid for the current year. Such sticker or decal shall be displayed in such a manner and location on said mobile home so as to be visible from the nearest street or drive within the mobile home park or upon the private lot. Each mobile home park owner shall inform the city secretary in writing on "mobile home information" cards furnished by the city of each mobile home located in his park as of January first. 
(b)  Before any mobile home shall be moved within the city limits of South Houston, either entering or leaving a mobile home park or a private lot or tract of land, a mobile home moving permit must be obtained for such move. Said permit shall be issued by the city secretary and shall be issued to the owner of said mobile home being moved or to the mobile home moving contractor involved in moving said mobile home. The fee for said mobile home moving permit shall be twenty dollars ($20.00) plus 6¢ per square foot in chapter 6, building permit fees. The mobile home moving permit shall state the name and address of the mobile home moving contractor, the name and address of the mobile home owner, the present location and the proposed location of the mobile home, the type, size and serial number of the mobile home. All taxes, fees and other adjudicated debts owning to the city by said mobile home owner shall be made in full payment before said permit shall be issued. Persons issued a permit under this section shall be issued a sticker or decal indicating the date of issue and the present and proposed locations of the mobile home, approximately six (6) feet above the ground or road surface on the side nearest the center of the roadway, and shall remain affixed to the mobile home until it arrives at its proposed location. 
(c)  Before issuance of a permit to move a mobile home which was located in the city on January first to a location outside the city, prior to the establishment by the city council of the current year's tax rate, an estimated tax based on the current year's appraisal method and the previous year's tax rate shall be made. Such payment may be made "under protest," subject to appellate procedures provided under the Property Tax Code. 
(d)  Any movement of a mobile home permitted herein shall comply with traffic regulations. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 2, 6-14-11)  
Secs. 13-17—13-33. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOMES LOCATED OUTSIDE MOBILE HOME PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 13-34. - General prohibition. 
Except as otherwise specifically provided in this article, no mobile home shall be parked for use or occupancy on any tract of ground within the city limits, except in a duly authorized mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-35. - Temporary location. 
The building inspector may permit the parking, use and occupancy of a mobile home outside of a duly authorized mobile home park for a period of time not exceeding ten (10) days, when such mobile home is occupied by persons employed in the operation of a temporary recreational, amusement or civic activity, or for a period of time not exceeding one hundred twenty (120) days, when such mobile home is parked adjacent to and in conjunction with the construction of a residence. A mobile home may be parked on the construction site of a nonresidential structure for a period of time not exceeding the duration of actual construction. Such temporary parking, use and occupancy of a mobile home shall be permitted only when the mobile home is parked on the same premises on which the activity is located and only when adequate sanitary facilities are available upon the premises for the use of the occupants of the mobile home. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Secs. 13-36—13-43. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMANENT LOCATION 
 
Sec. 13-44. - Application of division; authority for permanent location. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to a mobile home permanently located on real property within the city outside an authorized mobile home park. Such location is authorized, when all of the provisions of this division are complied with, subject to the provisions of the zoning ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-45. - Compliance with building code and other ordinances; supervision and inspection of placement. 
All applicable requirements of the building code and other ordinances of the city applicable to the installation of plumbing, electricity, water and gas must be complied with and the necessary permits acquired prior to the mobile home being placed on a private lot under the provisions of this division [and the building inspector] shall supervise and inspect the permanent placement of a mobile home in compliance with this division. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-46. - Location with respect to other structures; setback requirements. 
The mobile home shall be so situated upon the lot or tract of land that it will not be within ten (10) feet of any structure and shall be set-back a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet from the front of the property line. There will be a five-foot set-back from each side of the property line and a five-foot set-back from the rear property line. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85; Ord. No. 95-012, § 1, 9-5-95; Ord. No. 2016-07, § 2, 4-12-16)  
Sec. 13-47. - Minimum size of slab; use of slab restricted to one mobile home. 
No slab shall be less than twenty (20) feet wide but wide enough for the mobile home and slab shall be the total length of mobile home with minimum length being fifty (50) feet. No more than one mobile home shall be permitted on a single slab. 
(Ord. No. 97-036, § 1, 12-9-97)  
Sec. 13-48. - Mobile home shall be skirted. 
Skirting or screening of material and composition so as to prevent the ingress of rodents and other animals beneath the home shall be attached to the home with galvanized screws or bolts. 
(Ord. No. 97-036, § 2, 12-9-97)  
Sec. 13-49. - Reserved.  
Sec. 13-50. - Water and sewer connections. 
A mobile home governed by this division shall be connected to and provided with water lines and sanitary sewer connections. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-51. - Automobile parking stall. 
The lot or tract of land upon which a mobile home subject to this division is situated shall be large enough to accommodate a parking stall thereon for the of-street parking of automobiles. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Secs. 13-52—13-63. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MOBILE HOME PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 13-64. - Operating license. 
(a)  Upon the approval of the final plat of a proposed mobile home park, prior to the issuance of the construction permit under division 2 of this article, an annual license for the maintenance and operation of such mobile home park shall be issued to the owner thereof by the city secretary, upon payment to him of a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). Said license shall be valid for the calendar year for which it is issued and shall expire on December 31st of each year, unless sooner suspended, revoked or surrendered. Such license may be renewed annually in advance thereafter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or operate a mobile home park within the city, unless a current license therefor has been under this section. 
(c)  Penalty for violation of ordinance provisions. Any person, firm, corporation or the agent violating any of the provisions of this ordinance shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and in case of willful and continuous violation of the provisions of this article, the building official shall revoke and repeal all permits and privileges granted to person, firm or corporation. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85; Ord. No. 97-036, § 3, 12-9-97; Ord. No. 2011-15, §§ 4, 6, 6-14-11)  
Sec. 13-65. - Construction standards generally. 
All mobile home park construction and installation required or permitted by this article shall conform to ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-66. - Minimum size of slabs; use of slab restricted to one mobile home. 
No slab shall be less than twenty (20) feet wide but wide enough for the mobile home and slab shall be the total length of mobile home with minimum length being fifty (50) feet. No more than one mobile home shall be permitted on a single slab. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85; Ord. No. 97-036, § 4, 12-9-97)  
Sec. 13-67. - Setback requirements for units and mobile homes. 
Each side of each unit adjacent to a mobile home park street or driveway shall be set back at least five (5) feet therefrom. Each side of each mobile home in the park and adjacent to a public street shall be set back at least five (5) feet therefrom. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-68. - Parking stalls or spaces generally. 
Each unit in a mobile home park shall be so laid out as to be provided with at least one parking stall. Every mobile home park shall average, by arithmetic means, two (2) parking places, including parking stalls and/or parking spaces, per unit. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-69. - Clearance between mobile homes. 
All parking stalls and concrete foundations or supports in a mobile home park shall be so laid out as to provide a minimum distance of ten (10) feet between the front and/or rear ends of adjacent mobile homes parked thereon, and no mobile home shall be so parked that either side thereof is nearer than ten (10) feet to either side or end of any other mobile home parked thereon. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-70. - Mobile home foundations or supports. 
Each unit shall be so constructed as to provide a reinforced four-inch concrete pad with minimum dimensions of twenty (20) feet by fifty (50) feet. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-71. - Water lines and sewer connections. 
Each unit in a mobile home park shall be provided with water lines and sanitary sewer connections, subject to all applicable ordinances, rules and regulations of the city and in accordance with the mobile home park standards referred to in section 13-65. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-72. - Off-street parking. 
Parking shall be provided at the rate of not less than two (2) parking spaces per mobile home space, located on the individual lot or within a common off-street parking lot. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-73. - Utility easements. 
Easements shall be provided for installation of utilities, exclusive of water and sewer which shall be the sole responsibility of the owner. Additional requirements for public utility easements shall be determined by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-74. - Mobile home anchorage. 
Every mobile home shall be blocked and anchored in accordance with specifications set by the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-75. - Drainage easements. 
Where a mobile home park is traversed by a water course, drainage way, channel or stream, there shall be provided a storm water easement or drainage right-of-way conforming substantially with the lines of such water course, and of sufficient width, as determined by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-76. - Mobile home patio or porch. 
Each unit within the mobile home park shall have constructed a four (4) inch thick concrete slab with minimum fifty (50) square feet area, reinforced with six (6) inches by six (6) inches wire mesh to be used as the floor of either a covered or uncovered porch or patio. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-77. - Sewage system installation. 
Sanitary sewers. Sanitary sewers shall be installed to serve each lot in all mobile home parks where connection is to be made immediately to a community disposal system or to a public sewage system as may be specified by the City of South Houston. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-78. - Water system installation. 
All water supply, treatment, storage and distribution facilities shall be furnished and installed in compliance with the requirements of the standard specifications of the City of South Houston the current policies and specifications of the building inspector and the Texas State Department of Health. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-79. - Sanitary sewer specifications. 
(a)  All gravity sewers shall be vitrified clay, epoxy lined asbestos cement sewer pipe or schedule 40, polyvinyl chloride (pvc) drain-waste-vent pipe or better conforming to A.S.T.M. and the National Sanitation Foundation Standard 14 and Commercial Standard CS 272-65 and CS 207-60. 
(b)  The minimum size of lateral sewer mains within the mobile home park area shall be six (6) inches in diameter. Minimum grades shall be sufficient to produce a velocity of 1.6 ft. per second. 
(c)  All outfall mains shall be of sufficient size to accommodate the maximum anticipated flow from the entire area tributary to the line as approved by the building inspector. 
(d)  Lift stations shall be furnished where necessary, of such size and design as approved by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-80. - Water main specifications. 
(a)  All water distribution mains shall be cast iron, asbestos cement pipe, or polyvinyl chloride (pvc) type 1120, schedule 40 or better and installed in conformance to A.S.T.M. standard D1784-60T with the specifications of the city public works department. Other suitable material may be used when authorized by the building inspector. 
(b)  The minimum size of lateral water mains shall be six (6) inches in diameter, except that a small main may be used when a looped system designed to serve less than eighteen (18) families is approved by the building inspector. 
(c)  All principal mains shall be of sufficient size to meet all anticipated requirements of the system as approved by the building inspector. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-81. - Specifications and standards for mobile home plats. 
Preliminary plats and data for conditional approval. The preliminary plat shall include the following information and other pertinent data as required to support the preliminary design of the proposed development: 
Topographic Data: 
(a)  Existing boundary lines, bearings and distances, and acreage of the proposed mobile home park. 
(b)  Location, size and centerline of all existing utilities, drainage structures, water courses, railroads, and other physical features affecting the proposed development. 
(c)  Location, name, type and width of surfacing of all streets and alleys on or adjoining the proposed development. 
(d)  Location, size and purpose of all easements and public areas on or adjoining the proposed development. 
(e)  Name and width of each street. 
(f)  Number to identify each lot, site and block. 
(g)  Minimum building setback lines on all lots and other sites. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-82. - Report of mobile homes entering park. 
The owner of a mobile home park shall inform the building inspector, in writing, of each mobile home that enters his park and for which utility and sanitary services are desired, in order to allow the permit department to inspect the mobile home location and service connections. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-83. - City agents' right of entry. 
Duly authorized representatives from the department of health, fire department police department, department of taxation, water and sewer department, sanitation department and street department shall be permitted access to every mobile home park and the streets, utility lines and connections and structures thereon, when performing city business, as a condition to the issuance of a permit and license under this article. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-84. - Mobile home shall be skirted. 
Skirting or screening of material and composition so as to prevent the ingress of rodents and other animals beneath the home shall be attached to the home with galvanized screws or bolts. 
(Ord. No. 97-036, § 5, 12-9-97)  
Sec. 13-85. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONSTRUCTION PERMIT 
 
Sec. 13-86. - Required. 
No mobile home park shall be constructed within the city, the owner thereof shall first obtain a permit from the city with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-87. - Application generally. 
Written application for a permit required by this division shall be filed with the city secretary. Such application shall be submitted on a form prepared by the city and shall include, but not be limited to, the name and address of the parties to be in charge of the proposed mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-88. - Fee. 
At the time of filing an application for a permit under this division, the applicant shall pay a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). This is an application fee and inspection fee for the investigation for approval of the application and shall not be returnable, in whole or in part, whether a permit is granted or not. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85; Ord. No. 2011-15, § 8, 6-14-11)  
Sec. 13-89. - Map and preliminary plat to accompany application. 
Each application for a permit under this division shall be accompanied by a location map, showing the location within the city of the platted property, and a preliminary plat of the proposed mobile home park. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-90. - Approval by building inspector, two or less units. 
If the permit application is for no more than two (2) units, upon a finding by the building inspector that the written application meets all of the terms, conditions and procedures described in this chapter and that adequate sewage and utility facilities are available, the building inspector may approve such application and thereupon a permit will be issued, upon payment of all fees. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-91. - Approval or disapproval of preliminary plat; more than two units. 
On applications for permit for three (3) or more units, the following procedures shall be followed: 
(a)  Within twenty-one (21) days after the date of the filing of an application for a permit under this division, the preliminary plat filed with the application shall be presented to the city council at a regularly scheduled council meeting. The applicant or his agent shall be entitled to present evidence and argument to the council at such meeting. 
(b)  Within thirty (30) days after the presentation of a preliminary plat pursuant to subsection (a), the council shall approve or disapprove the preliminary plat, and written notice shall be given of its decision. If the plat is disapproved, the notice shall state the reasons for disapproval. If the plat is disapproved, it may be resubmitted to the city council, with the necessary recommended changes, and the council must act upon such plat within thirty (30) days from the resubmission date. 
(c)  In the event the city council fails to act on a preliminary plat within the time prescribed by this section, the plat shall be deemed approved. Fraud or material misrepresentation in the permit application or the plat, however, shall wholly defeat and bar such automatic approval. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-92. - Final plat—Filing; form; accompanying plans and specifications. 
When the preliminary plat of a proposed mobile home park is approved, as provided in section 13-91 above, a final plat thereof must be filed with the building inspector within thirty (30) days after the date of preliminary approval, unless an extension of filing time is requested by the applicant and granted by the city council prior to the expiration of such thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-93. - Same—Approval or disapproval; recording. 
The city council shall approve or disapprove the final plat of a proposed mobile home park within thirty (30) days after its presentation and file the same with the city secretary within thirty-seven (37) days after its presentation. In the event the council fails to act upon such plat within thirty (30) days, the same shall be deemed approved as of the thirty-sixth day after its presentation. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-94. - Issuance. 
Upon a finding by the city council that a proposed mobile home park will meet with all of the terms, conditions and requirements prescribed by this chapter, and upon approval of the final plat for such park by the city council, and upon issuance of the license provided for in section 13-64, the city secretary shall issue to the applicant the permit required by this division. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-95. - Suspension. 
In the event of violation, during the construction and equipping of a mobile home park, of any provision of this article or of the permit, plat, application, plans or specifications provided for in this division, the building inspector shall have the right to suspend the permit issued under this division. In addition, he may issue stop-work orders and take other corrective action, as provided in the building code. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-96. - Termination. 
A permit issued under this division shall automatically terminate, if construction of the mobile home park is not commenced within six (6) months after the final plat thereof is approved, unless a six-month renewal is obtained from the city council. It shall be unlawful for any person to commence any work on such mobile home park after the permit has so terminated. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Sec. 13-97. - Grandfather clause. 
Lawful mobile home parks in existence at the time of the effective date of this Ordinance Number 732, may continue in use without being in violation of sections 13-65, 13-66, 13-67, 13-68, 13-69, 13-70, 13-72, 13-73, 13-75, 13-76, 13-79, 13-80 and 13-81 as to existing facilities only. 
(Ord. No. 732, 12-3-85)  
Chapter 13.3 - MUNICIPAL COURT 
 
Sec. 13.3-1. - Municipal court building security fund. 
(a)  The Clerk of South Houston Municipal Court ("court") shall collect a three-dollar ($3.00) municipal court building security fee from a defendant convicted after passage of this section in the court in a trial for a misdemeanor. The clerk shall pay the security fee to the municipal treasurer. 
(b)  In this section, a person is considered convicted if: 
(1)  A sentence is imposed on the person; 
(2)  The person receives community supervision, including deferred adjudication; or 
(3)  The court defers final disposition of the person's case. 
(c)  The municipal treasurer shall deposit the fee in a fund to be known as "the municipal court building security fund." 
(d)  The funds designated herein may be used only to finance items when used for the purpose of providing security services for building housing a municipal court, as appropriate, including: 
(1)  The purchase or repair of x-ray machines and conveying systems; 
(2)  Handheld metal detectors; 
(3)  Walkthrough metal detectors; 
(4)  Identification cards and systems; 
(5)  Electrical locking and surveillance equipment; 
(6)  Bailiffs, deputy sheriffs deputy constables, or contract security personnel during times when they are providing appropriate security services; 
(7)  Signage; 
(8)  Confiscated weapon inventory and tracking systems; or 
(9)  Locks, chains, alarms, or similar security devices; 
(10)  The purchase or repair of bullet-proof glass; and 
(11)  Continuing education on security issues for court personnel and security personnel. 
(e)  The municipal court building security fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 96-018, §§ 1—5, 8-27-96; Ord. No. 99-021, §§ 1—5, 9-28-99)  
Sec. 13.3-2. - Municipal court technology fund. 
(a)  Establishment. 
(1)  There is hereby created and established a municipal court technology fund, herein known as the fund, pursuant to Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(2)  The fund may be maintained in an interest-bearing account and may be maintained in the general revenue account 
(b)  Establishment of amount of the fee and assessment and collection. 
(1)  The fee shall be in the amount of four dollars ($4.00). 
(2)  The fee shall be assessed and collected from the defendant upon conviction for a misdemeanor offense in the municipal court as a cost of court. A defendant is considered convicted if: 
a.  Judgment, sentence, or both are imposed on the person; 
b.  The person is placed on deferred disposition; or 
c.  The court defers final disposition or imposition of the judgment and sentence 
(3)  The fee shall be collected on conviction for an offense committed on/or the date this section is finally passed and approved. 
(4)  The clerk of the court shall collect the fee and pay the fee to the municipal treasurer of the City of South Houston, Texas, who shall deposit the fee into the municipal court technology fund. 
(c)  Designated use of the fund and administration. 
(1)  The fund shall be used only for the purpose of financing the purchase of/or to maintain technology enhancements for the Municipal Court of the City of South Houston, Texas. "Technology enhancements" shall include any and all items described in Article 102.0172 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 
(2)  The fund shall be administered by or under the direction of the City Council of the City of South Houston. 
(d)  Administration of fund. The purpose of the use of any funds remaining in the fund shall continue to be used and administered as required by this section and for that purpose this section remains in effect. 
(Ord. No. 99-018, §§ 1—3, 7, 9-14-99; Ord. No. 2004-10, §§ 1—3, 7, 4-6-04)  
Chapter 14 - OIL AND GAS WELLS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference— Oil and gas, V.T.C.A., Natural Resources Code ch. 81 et seq. 
Annotation— For a case upholding the validity of Ordinance No. 101, from which this chapter is basically derived, see Tyson Oil Company v. Railroad Commission of Texas, 12 F. Supp. 201 (1935). 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Chapter does not affect rights of land owners. 
Neither this chapter nor any permit issued hereunder shall be interpreted to grant any right or license to the permittee to enter upon or occupy in any respect in the drilling or production operations any land except by the written consent of the owner, nor shall it limit or prevent the free right of any lot owner to contract for the amount of royalty to be paid with respect to his own land, or for damages, rights or privileges with respect thereto. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 10, 2-14-35)  
Sec. 14-2. - Use of streets and alleys in drilling or production operations. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drill any oil or gas well within any of the streets or alleys of the city, or to block or incumber or close up any street or alley in any drilling or production operations, except by special permit by order of the city council, and then only temporarily. All excavations in or upon any of the streets and alleys in such operations shall be under the reasonable direction of the street superintendent, and done without expense or cost to the city. 
(Ord. No. 101, §§ 5, 11, 2-14-35) 
Cross reference— Authority of holder of permit issued under article II of this chapter to lay and maintain necessary pipelines under public property, § 19-5(b).  
Sec. 14-3. - Drilling districts. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance establishing drilling districts or prescribing areas wherein the drilling of oil and gas wells is permitted or prohibited and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Sec. 14-4. - Fire extinguishers at drilling plants. 
All drilling plants at oil and gas wells shall be equipped with fire extinguishers, which shall be maintained in good order. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 8, 2-14-35; Ord. of 2-9-37, § 3)  
Sec. 14-5. - Safety rules for certain gas facilities and equipment. 
The following safety rules shall be applicable to gas facilities and equipment which operate with a pressure in excess of fifty (50) pounds psi: 
(1)  There shall be installed a regulator which will reduce the well pressure to not to exceed seven hundred (700) pounds psi before such gas may be transported through pipelines within the city. 
(2)  All installations, including the well, must be enclosed by a chain link fence which shall not be less than six (6) feet in height. 
(3)  Any equipment in connection with which a flame is used shall not be closer than thirty (30) feet to the property line or a public street and shall not be closer than one hundred (100) feet to any gas well. 
(4)  No grass or weeds shall be permitted to grow within six (6) feet of any equipment or installation. 
(5)  An automatic shutoff valve shall be installed in the equipment of each such gas well which will shut off the flow of gas in the event that the pressure in the line shall drop as much as one hundred (100) pounds. 
(6)  All federal and state rules and regulations in connection with the producing of gas must be complied with, including the transportation of gas through pipelines. 
(7)  "No Smoking" signs shall be installed at all producing wells and installations. 
(Ord. No. 554, § 2, 8-16-66)  
Sec. 14-6. - Removal of oil, gas and water. 
All oil, gas and water produced or arising from operations authorized by a permit issued under this chapter shall, within a reasonable time after production, be piped or otherwise conveyed or removed from the territory of the city. This section shall not prohibit the ordinary use of a slush pond and usual production facilities. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 11, 2-14-35)  
Secs. 14-7—14-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PERMIT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Authority of holder of permit issued under this article to lay and maintain necessary pipelines under public property, § 19-5(b). 
 
Sec. 14-21. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drill or commence to drill a well for oil or gas within the city limits or to work upon or assist in any way in the prosecution of any such well, without a permit for such well and for the prosecution of the development having first been issued by authority of the city council in accordance with the terms of this article. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 1, 2-14-35)  
Sec. 14-22. - Application generally. 
(a)  Every application for a permit under this article shall be in writing, signed by the applicant or some person in his behalf and filed with the city secretary. No single application shall be made for a permit covering more than one drilling district. 
(b)  An application filed under this section shall state the drilling district and the particular lot, block and location in the drilling district where the proposed well is to be located, and have attached to it certified copies or photostatic copies of all oil and gas leases, or other drilling contracts with the owners of land in the drilling district which applicant may have, together with abstracts or certificates of title satisfactory to the city council, to the end that the application will show what proportion and what parts of the drilling district the applicant owns in fee or holds under lease or contract from the owner. The application shall also be accompanied with a plat or map of the drilling district showing the exact location of the proposed well. 
(c)  An application filed under this section shall be accompanied by the applicant's affidavit showing the name and last known address of each land, mineral, royalty or lease owner to whom notice is required to be given under section 14-27, and the names of such land, mineral, royalty or lease owners to whom such notice is required to be given, but whose addresses are unknown to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 101, §§ 6, 7, 2-14-35; Ord. of 2-9-37, § 2)  
Sec. 14-23. - Applicant must own or have rights to drilling site. 
No permit shall be granted or issued under this article for the drilling of a well except upon ground owned by the applicant or held by him under an oil and gas lease or drilling contract from the owner, giving the owner's permission to drill the well. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 9, 2-14-35; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 8-16-66)  
Sec. 14-24. - Required interest of applicant in drilling district. 
It shall be a requisite for a permit to drill an oil and gas well within the city that the applicant must have at least seventy-five (75) percent of the South Houston resident mineral ownerships in the drilling district under lease or ownership in fee. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 4, 2-14-35; Ord. No. 403, § 2, 5-2-57)  
Sec. 14-25. - Applicant's bond. 
(a)  Each applicant for a permit required by this article shall file with the city secretary, at the time of filing the permit application, a bond meeting the requirements of this section and approved by the mayor. 
(b)  The bond required by this section shall be executed by the applicant, as principal, and a surety company authorized to do business in this state, as surety. It shall run to the city for the benefit of the city and all persons concerned and shall be conditioned that if the permit is granted and if drilling operations are commenced thereunder, the applicant and his assigns will comply with the terms and conditions of this chapter in the drilling and operation of the well; will restore the streets and sidewalks and other public places of the city which may be disturbed in the operations to their former condition; will clear the block and lots of all litter, machinery, derricks, buildings, oil and other substances, erected, used or allowed in the drilling or producing operations, whenever the well shall be abandoned or the operation thereof discontinued; and that he will pay any and all damages suffered by any person from fire or from oil, gas or water caused by or originating from the operations connected with such well, and will hold the city harmless from any or all liability growing out of the granting of such permit. 
(c)  The bond required by this section shall be in the sum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), except that where the applicant holds oil and gas leases on the entire drilling district, the bond shall be in the sum of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00). In cases where there are no buildings or other improvements on the drilling district, the bond need not be in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00). 
(d)  Upon the expiration of ninety (90) days next after the completion of any producing well, the bond theretofore given in connection with such well shall be reduced to five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), except that if the bond theretofore given was in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), such bond shall be reduced to two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(e)  If any permit issued under this article shall terminate and become inoperative, as in this article provided, or if the permittee files with the city council written notice of his election to surrender his permit and abandon the premises covered thereby, and the well is plugged and abandoned, the permit fee theretofore furnished by the permittee under this section, shall be immediately returned to him, provided he has fully complied with all of the terms and conditions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 101, §§ 6, 9, 2-14-35; Ord. of 2-9-37, § 2; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 8-16-66)  
Sec. 14-26. - Fee. 
The fee for a permit required by this article shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), which fee shall be paid at the time the permit application is filed. Such fee shall be returned to the applicant, if the permit is denied. 
(Ord. No. 101, §§ 6, 7, 2-14-35; Ord. of 6-5-51)  
Sec. 14-27. - Notice of and hearing on application. 
(a)  Notice of the filing of an application for a permit under this article shall be given by the applicant, in the manner hereinafter provided, to each owner of minerals, royalty, fee or oil and gas leasehold estate in lands within the drilling district in which the lot upon which the applicant seeks a permit to drill is located, as such ownership is disclosed by the deed records of Harris County, except that no notice need be given to the owners of the fee, royalty or mineral estates in lands within such district on which the applicant holds oil and gas mineral leases. Such notice shall be in words and figures as follows: 
"Notice is hereby given that _______ acting under and pursuant to the terms and provisions of Chapter 14 of the Code of Ordinances, City of South Houston, Texas, and any and all ordinances amendatory thereof, did on the _______ day of _______ 19___, file with the City Secretary of the City of South Houston an application for a permit to drill a well for oil and/or gas upon Lot No. _______, Block No. _______, South Houston Townsite, in Drilling District No. _______, as defined by Ordinance No. _______ A hearing upon such application will be held in the office of the City Secretary of the City of South Houston, Texas, at ___ on the _______ day of _______, 19___, at ___." 
(b)  At least ten (10) days prior to the date of the hearing on such application, as fixed in the notice, referred to in subsection (a), a copy of such notice shall be mailed by registered mail, addressed to the last known address of such land, mineral, royalty or lease owner, if known to the applicant, and a copy of such notice shall be published, at the expense of the applicant, in every issue of the official newspaper of the city for ten (10) days prior to the date of such hearing. If the official newspaper is published weekly, the publication shall be made in one issue thereof. Proof of such publication shall be made by the printer or publisher of the newspaper, by affidavit filed with the city secretary, which shall be prima facie evidence of such publication. 
(c)  At the time fixed in the notice given under this section, a hearing on the application shall be held in the office of the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 6, 2-14-35; Ord. of 2-9-37, § 2)  
Sec. 14-28. - Limitation on number to be issued for same reservoir. 
No permit shall be issued under this chapter for more than two (2) wells to each reservoir, as recognized by the state railroad commission as a separated reservoir, in each drilling district; provided, however, that an application may be made and a permit may be issued for a replacement well or wells, but there shall not be more than two (2) wells producing from each such reservoir in each drilling district. 
(Ord. No. 600, § 2, 6-6-72)  
Sec. 14-29. - Issuance or refusal. 
(a)  Upon the approval by the city council of an application for a permit under this article, the city secretary shall issue the permit. Such issuance shall automatically operate as a rejection and denial of all other applications for a permit covering the drilling district, or any portion or portions thereof, included within and covered by the permit so issued, and which applications are pending at the time of the issuance of such permit or which may be filed during the life thereof. 
(b)  The city council shall have the power and hereby reserves the authority to refuse any application for a permit under this article where, by reason of the location of the proposed well and the character and value of the permanent improvements already erected on the drilling district in question, or adjacent thereto, and the use to which the land and surroundings are adapted for civic purposes, or for sanitary reasons, the drilling of an oil or gas well will be a serious disadvantage to the city and its inhabitants as a whole. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 7, 2-14-35)  
Sec. 14-30. - To specify location of well; drilling elsewhere prohibited. 
A permit issued under this article shall specify the particular location of the well to be drilled, and it shall be unlawful for the permittee to drill elsewhere in the drilling district. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 7, 2-14-35)  
Sec. 14-31. - Rights of owners or lessees of land in district not owned or leased by permittee. 
(a)  In case a permit for the drilling of a well is issued to a person not owning, or holding oil and gas leases or drilling contracts with the owners of, all the area in a drilling district, it shall be a condition of the permit that the permittee, his successors and assigns, shall deliver to the credit of each of such owners whose land shall not be under lease held by the permittee, free of cost, in the pipe line to which the well may be connected, a share of oil produced and saved from such well, equal to one-sixth of the proportion of the whole production that the square feet of ground so owned bears to the square feet contained in such drilling district, exclusive of the streets and alleys, and a like proportion of the proceeds of gas and casinghead gas produced from the well and used off the premises.
