(b)  In case a permit is issued to persons who do not own or hold leases or other valid drilling contracts in writing from the owners of all of the land within the drilling district, other than streets and alleys, any owner of unleased land in the drilling district and any person, other than the permittee, holding oil and gas leases on land in the drilling district, shall have the option, in lieu of the provisions of subsection (a) above, to share in the ownership and benefits of such oil or gas well in the proportion that the area of his land or lease bears to the area of the drilling district, exclusive of streets and alleys; provided that, within ten (10) days from the date of the issuance of such permit, he shall file with the city secretary his election, in writing, to pay to the holder of the permit or his assigns a like proportion of the total cost and expense of drilling and operating the well, and shall, within that time, make and file with the city secretary a bond, with an authorized surety company as surety, and in an amount representing that portion of the estimated maximum cost of the well that the area of ground owned or held under lease by the principal bears to the whole area of the drilling district, conditioned that the principal in the bond will pay to the permittee and his assigns such proportion of the cost of drilling and operating the well, from time to time, as required in the drilling and operation thereof, such bond to be approved by the mayor and held by the city secretary for the benefit of all persons interested. 
(Ord. No. 101, §§ 3, 4, 2-14-35; Ord. No. 403, §§ 1, 2, 5-2-57)  
Sec. 14-32. - Termination for failure to commence drilling. 
A permit issued under this article shall terminate and become inoperative, without any action on the part of the city unless within ninety (90) days from the date of issue, actual drilling of the well shall have commenced. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 9, 2-14-35; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 8-16-66)  
Sec. 14-33. - Termination for cessation of drilling operations. 
(a)  After the drilling of a well under a permit issued pursuant to this article has commenced, the cessation of the drilling operations for a period of six (6) months shall operate to terminate and cancel the permit and the well shall be considered as abandoned for all purposes of this chapter, and it shall be unlawful thereafter to continue the operation or drilling of such well without the issuance of another permit; provided that, if the well is a producer and shall thereafter cease to produce, the permittee shall have the right to conduct deepening or reworking operations on the well within six (6) months after cessation of production, without having to procure a new permit. 
(b)  After the six (6) months period referred to in subsection (a) has elapsed and the permit has terminated and become inoperative, if the permittee desires to deepen, rework or recomplete the well, the city secretary is hereby authorized to issue a new permit for such well, upon the payment of a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. No. 101, § 9, 2-14-35; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 8-16-66)  
Sec. 14-34. - New permit when oil well converted to gas well. 
In the event an oil well (as classified by the state railroad commission), for which there exists an unexpired permit issued under this article, is changed to a gas well (as classified by the state railroad commission), either by reworking operations or natural change during producing operations, and the operator sells the gas produced from such well, the operator shall secure another well permit from the city. The city secretary is hereby authorized to issue a new permit for such well upon the payment of a fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which fee shall cover all operations in connection with converting the well from an oil well to a gas well by deepening or reworking operations or otherwise, including the installation of all equipment and appurtenances necessary or convenient to produce the well as a gas well. 
(Ord. No. 101, § 9, 2-14-35; Ord. No. 554, § 1, 8-16-66)  
Chapter 15 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 

Footnotes:

Cross reference— Parking of mobile homes in parks, § 13-3; required park and recreation area in mobile home parks, § 13-76; public property generally, Ch. 19. 
 
Sec. 15-1. - South Houston Recreation Center and Park. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall effect the validity of the ordinance adopted on September 6, 1949, accepting and regulating the use of the South Houston Recreation Center and Park, and such ordinance is recognized as continuing in full force and affect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.  
Chapter 16 - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 771, § 1, adopted Nov. 3, 1987, amended former Ch. 16, §§ 16-1—16-3, relative to peddlers and solicitors, in its entirety to read as herein set out in Art. I, §§ 16-1—16-17. The provisions of former Ch. 16 derived from Ord. No. 370, §§ 1—3, adopted Oct. 17, 1955. 
Cross reference— Soliciting contributions on streets, § 19-14. 
 
ARTICLE I. - PEDDLERS AND SOLICITORS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 771, § 1, adopted Nov. 3, 1987 amended former Ch. 16, §§ 16-1—16-3, relative to peddlers and solicitors, in its entirety to read as herein set out in Art. I, §§ 16-1—16-17. The provisions of former Ch. 16 derived from Ord. No. 370, §§ 1—3, adopted Oct. 17, 1955. 
Cross reference— Soliciting contributions on streets, § 19-14. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Peddlers or solicitors engaged in interstate commerce—Registration. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for persons engaged in interstate commerce to go from house to house or place to place in the city soliciting, selling or taking orders for or offering to sell or take orders for any goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines or subscriptions to magazines, without having first registered with the chief of police of the city, giving the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and local address, if any, of the registrant. 
(2)  The name and address of the person, firm or corporation, if any, that he represents or for whom or through whom orders are to be solicited or cleared. 
(3)  The nature of the articles or things which are to be sold or for which orders are to be solicited. 
(4)  Whether the registrant, upon any sale or order, shall demand or receive or accept payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery. 
(5)  The period of time which the registrant wishes to solicit or sell in the city. 
(b)  The registrant, at the time of registration, shall pay the tax assessor and collector a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to defray the cost of handling registration. 
(c)  The term "interstate commerce," as used in this section, means soliciting, selling or taking orders for or offering to take orders for any goods, wares, merchandise, photographs, newspapers or magazines, or subscriptions to newspapers or magazines which, at the time the order is taken are in another state or will be produced in another state and shipped or introduced into this city in the fulfillment of such orders. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-2. - Same—Proof of identity. 
At the time of the registration provided for in section 16-1, the registrant shall submit for inspection of the chief of police written proof of his identity, which may be in the form of an automobile operator's license or an identification letter or card issued to the registrant by the person for whom or through whom orders are to be solicited or cleared. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-3. - Same—Bond required. 
(a)  At the time of the registration provided for in section 16-1, the registrant shall file with the chief of police a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) signed by the registrant and signed, as surety, by some surety company authorized to do business in the state, conditioned for the final delivery of goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs and magazines in accordance with the terms of any order obtained prior to delivery, and also conditioned to indemnify any and all purchasers or customers for any and all defects in material or workmanship that may exist in the article sold by the principal of the bond at the time of delivery or that may be discovered by such purchasers or customers within thirty (30) days after delivery, which bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons who may make any purchase or give any order to the principal or to an agent or employee of the principal. All such bonds so filed shall be subject to the approval of the tax assessor and collector. 
(b)  In case a registrant engages in any activity mentioned in section 16-1 through one or more agents or employees, such registrant shall be required to enter into only one bond, in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), as above required, which bond shall be made to cover the activities of all his agents or employees. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-4. - Selling, soliciting, etc., prohibited between certain hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any activity mentioned in section 16-8, whether he is licensed so to do or not, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-5. - Going upon posted residence without invitation. 
The practice of going in and upon private residences in the city, whereon a sign bearing the words "no solicitors, no peddlers, or similar wording" is displayed, by itinerant vendors, itinerant merchants, peddlers and persons selling or taking orders for goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines or subscriptions to magazines, not having been requested or invited so to do by the owner or occupant of such private residence, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares, or merchandise, or disposing of, or peddling or hawking the same, is declared to be a nuisance and punishable as such nuisance as a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-6. - Construction of article. 
This entire article is and shall be deemed an exercise of the police power of the state and of the city for the public safety, comfort, convenience and protection of the city and its citizens, and all of the provisions hereof shall be construed for the accomplishment of that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-7. - Sales to occupants of vehicles on streets or public property; aiding a minor in violation of section. 
No itinerant vendor licensed under this article shall sell or offer for sale any goods or merchandise to the occupants of any vehicle which is in a street or on other public property, whether or not such vehicle is moving, stopped or parked and whether or not the itinerant vendor is on public street or public property. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or aid a minor in conduct prohibited by this section or to provide goods or merchandise to a minor with knowledge that the minor intends to sell or offer for sale such goods in contravention of this section. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE FOR ITINERANT MERCHANTS AND VENDORS 
 
Sec. 16-8. - Definitions. 
An "itinerant merchant" or "itinerant vendor," as the terms are used in this article, shall be held to be any person who goes from house to house or from place to place in the city, soliciting, selling, or taking orders for or offering to sell or take orders for any goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs, magazines, or subscriptions to magazines. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-9. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any activity described in section 16-8, without first having obtained a license so to do from the city chief of police. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-10. - Application. 
Any person desiring to engage in any activity mentioned in section 16-8 shall make written application to the tax assessor and collector for a license so to do, which application shall show the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the person, firm, or corporation, if any, that he represents and the kind of goods offered for sale, and whether such applicant, upon any such sale or order, shall demand, accept or receive payment or deposit of money in advance of final delivery, and the period of time such applicant wishes to sell or solicit in the city. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-11. - Bond required of applicant. 
(a)  The application for a license under this division shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) signed by the applicant and signed, as surety, by some surety company authorized to do business in the state, conditioned for the final delivery of goods, wares, merchandise, services, photographs and magazines in accordance with the terms of any order obtained prior to delivery and also conditioned to indemnify any and all purchasers or customers for any and all defects in material or workmanship that may exist in the article sold, by the principal of such bond, at the time of delivery, and that may be discovered by such purchaser or customer within thirty (30) days after delivery, which bond shall be for the use and benefit of all persons that may make any purchase or give any order to the principal thereon, or to an agent or employee of the principal. 
(b)  In case the applicant is engaging in any activity mentioned in section 16-8 through one or more agents or employees, such applicant shall be required to enter into only one bond in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) as above required, which bond shall be made to cover the activities of all his agents or employees. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-12. - Fee. 
(a)  The fee for an itinerant merchant's or itinerant vendor's license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00). When any person engages in any activity mentioned in section 16-8 through one or more agents or employees, such person shall, in addition to such fifty dollar ($50.00) fee, pay a license fee of thirty dollars ($30.00) for each agent or employee so engaged. The fees provided for herein shall be used for the purpose of defraying expenses incident to the issuing of such licenses. No such fee shall be prorated. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the above provisions, no license fee shall be required of churches, civic clubs, fraternal organizations or charitable, literary or educational clubs or organizations. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-13. - License not to be issued to certain persons. 
Any person convicted of violating any provision of this article shall not be eligible to receive a license under this division for a period of one (1) year from the date of such conviction. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-14. - Term of license. 
Any license issued under this division shall be valid for one (1) year from the date of issuance. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-15. - License to be carried on person. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any activity mentioned in section 16-8, unless he is carrying on his person, at all times while so engaged, a valid license issued under this division. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-16. - Exemptions from division. 
The provisions of this division shall not apply to sales made to dealers by commercial travelers or sales agents in the usual course of business, nor to sales made under authority and by order of law, nor to vendors of milk, bread, pastries, and newspapers, who make such sales on customary routes or from fixed places, nor to persons engaged in interstate commerce, as that term is defined in section 16-1. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87)  
Sec. 16-17. - Itinerant vendors on roadway. 
No itinerant vendors shall conduct a stationary business within twenty-five (25) feet of a public roadway. 
(Ord. No. 771, § 1, 11-3-87) 
Cross reference— Soliciting contributions on streets, § 19-14; display of merchandise on streets or other public property, § 19-17.  
ARTICLE II. - COMMERCIALLY OPERATED TRANSIENT AMUSEMENTS 
 
Sec. 16-18. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following terms, phrases, words and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural number include the singular number and words in the singular number include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely directory. 
(a)  City is the City of South Houston. 
(b)  Building official is the license officer or permit officer of the City of South Houston. 
(c)  Transient amusement is any circus, carnival, concession, game, ride, exhibit or any other type of public amusement device which is of a type generally considered to be of a transient nature, but shall not include such amusements operated by a school or a church and all of the persons engaged in the operation and control are members of the school or church organization which is operating such amusement. 
(d)  Licensee is any person having a city license in full force and effect issued hereunder for a transient amusement. 
(e)  Person is any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or organization of any kind. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-19. - License required. 
No person shall install, construct, operate or maintain a transient amusement within the city without having a valid license therefor in force and effect under the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-20. - Application procedure. 
Applications for licenses issued hereunder for a transient amusement shall be made upon blank forms to be prepared and made available by the building official and shall state: 
(a)  The name, home address and proposed business address of the applicant; 
(b)  The hours of operation for said transient amusement; 
(c)  The names, addresses and number of employees, exhibitors and other persons to be engaged in the operation of the transient amusement; and 
(d)  If the applicant is a firm, association, partnership or corporation, then all of the information required of an individual shall be required of each individual of the said firm, association, partnership or corporation; and 
(e)  If a corporation, the application shall state: 
(1)  That the applicant is either a domestic corporation duly organized and existing under the laws of the State of Texas, or, if a foreign corporation, the state of its incorporation and that it is duly authorized to transact business in the State of Texas; 
(2)  The name of its registered agent and the address of its registered office in the State of Texas; 
(3)  The name, home address and proposed business address of the operator or person in charge of the operation of the transient amusement to be licensed hereunder; and 
(4)  The name, home address and business address of the president and of each member of the board of directors of such corporation. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-21. - Application fee. 
An application hereunder shall be accompanied by an application fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to defray the expense of investigation of the application and said fee is nonreturnable if the application for a license is refused or not issued after an investigation has been made. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-22. - License fee. 
After investigation of an application is completed and a license is to be issued, the building official shall notify the applicant and upon payment of a license fee in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00), for each day or part thereof that the transient amusement is to be operated, the building official shall issue the license for the operation of the transient amusement for the period set forth in the application and covered by the license fee paid. Any license issued by the building official shall be to the applicant named at the location designated in the application. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-23. - Transfer of licenses; changes in partnerships or corporations. 
A license may be transferred to a different location within the city upon application and payment of a transfer fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(a)  A license issued to a partnership is not voided by withdrawal of one or more partners so long as one of the original partners remain. 
(b)  All changes in the membership of the partnership and all changes in the identity of the principal officers of the corporation shall be reported to the building official within ten (10) days after they occur. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-24. - Investigation of application. 
The building official shall forward a copy of each application filed under section 16-19 hereof to the chief of police for investigation. The building official and chief of police shall complete their investigation within two (2) days from date of filing of the application. The report of the chief of police shall include the number of special police that applicant shall, at its own expense, have on duty at the location during the operation of the transient amusement and the building official, when an application is approved, shall give written notice, with the license issued, of such requirements. Every special policeman to be employed by a licensee must be approved by the chief of police prior to his employment. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-25. - Standards for issuance. 
The building official shall issue a license hereunder when and if he finds that the requirements of this article and of all other governing laws and ordinances have been met. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-26. - Duties of licensee. 
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to operate a transient amusement in the city without complying with the following requirements and standards of operation: 
(a)  Conduct and operation. The licensee shall maintain good order upon the premises where any transient amusement is operated. 
(b)  Standards for maintenance of premises. 
(1)  Access. The licensee shall provide access available to public streets or other public ways at all times to facilitate departure of persons from the premises where the transient amusement is operated and to permit entrance of fire apparatus or other emergency equipment in case of emergency. 
(2)  Lighting. Licensee shall provide suitable and necessary artificial light whenever natural light is inadequate. 
(3)  Electrical installations. The electrical system shall be installed, maintained and operated in a safe and workmanlike manner. All electrical equipment must meet the requirements of the electrical code of the city. Cables on the ground in areas traversed by the public shall be protected by approved covers. The electrical installations shall be inspected and approved by the city electrical inspector before the transient amusement is opened to the public and shall thereafter be open to inspection by the electrical inspector at all reasonable hours. 
(4)  Fire extinguishing equipment. Fire extinguishing equipment shall be furnished by the licensee in such type and quantity and in such locations as may be directed by the city fire marshal. Fire extinguishing equipment shall be inspected and approved by the city fire marshal before the transient amusement is open to the public and shall thereafter be open to inspection by the city fire marshal at all reasonable hours. 
(5)  Sanitary facilities. When sanitary facilities are to be made available to the public they shall be inspected and approved by the department of health. 
(6)  Attendants. At all times when a transient amusement is open to the public, the licensee shall provide an adequate number of attendants and special police who shall be responsible for seeing that order is maintained, that disorderly or immoral conduct is prevented, that the entrances and exits are kept free from congestion and that this article and all other governing ordinances, rules and regulations pertaining to transient amusements are observed. 
(7)  Noise. The transient amusement shall be operated in such manner as to comply with Chapter 12 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of South Houston. 
(8)  Concessions. Any sales of items covered by any health ordinance of the City of South Houston shall be strictly in compliance with such ordinance and licensee shall obtain the required permits and health certificates prior to the making of such sales to the public. 
(9)  Inspection. Officers of the police department are hereby authorized and empowered to enter upon the premises where any transient amusement is being operated within the city, at any time, for the purpose of inspection, for preservation of law and order and to determine compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Standard for vacated premises. 
(1)  Licensee shall, upon removal of a transient amusement licensed hereunder, clean the premises of any trash, rubbish and other unsightly or unsanitary matter, which has accumulated thereon, within twenty-four (24) hours after removal of the transient amusement. 
(2)  Licensee shall, to guarantee compliance with the foregoing subsection (1), prior to the time a license is issued for the operation of a transient amusement, post with the building official a bond in the minimum amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00), which shall be issued by a company doing business in the State of Texas. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-27. - Suspension of license; appeal. 
The health officer, building official, chief of police, fire marshal or fire chief shall, upon discovery of a transient amusement being operated in violation of the terms of this article, immediately suspend the license to operate such transient amusement until such violations are removed. Suspension shall be by notice to the licensee or to the person in charge of the operation of such transient amusement. The official who acts to suspend a license under the terms of this section shall, within twenty-four (24) hours following such action, file a written report with the building official setting forth the exact violation, the date and hour of suspension and whether the violation has been removed by the licensee. Where a license has been suspended hereunder and not thereafter reinstated, the licensee may appeal such action to a court of competent jurisdiction; provided, however, that such proceedings shall be instituted within fifteen (15) days and not thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-28. - Penalty. 
Any person, persons, operator, owner, owners, partners, licensee, or the agents of a corporation, or whoever is in charge or control of a transient amusement, or any part thereof, who shall violate or allow or cause any person or persons to violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for such offense; and the license or licenses shall be subject to revocation or suspension for a violation of any provision of this article or of any other provision of the Code of Ordinances of the City of South Houston or any violation of the laws of the State of Texas. Any remedy prescribed by this article shall be merely cumulative and shall not preclude resort to any other remedy provided by law. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
Sec. 16-29. - Accrued rights and remedies preserved for benefit of city. 
All rights and remedies which have accrued in favor of the city under this article and amendments thereto shall be and are preserved for the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 818, § 1, 10-18-88)  
ARTICLE III. - COIN-OPERATED MACHINES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 16-30. - Definitions. 
For the purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
Coin-operated machine. The term "coin-operated machine" means every machine or device of any kind or character which is operated by or with a coin, metal slug, token, electronic card, check or similar object. Music coin-operated machines and skill or pleasure coin-operated machines, as hereinafter defined, including, but not limited to, coin-operated video games, shall be included in the term "coin-operated machine". 
Music coin-operated machine. The term "music coin-operated machine" shall mean and include every coin-operated machine of any kind or character which dispenses or vends, or which is used or operated for dispensing or vending music and which is operated by or with coins, metal slugs, tokens, checks or similar objects. The following are expressly included within such term: Coin-operated phonographs, pianos, gramophones, radios and all other coin-operated machines which dispense or vend music. 
Operator. The term "operator" shall mean and include any person, firm, company, association or corporation who exhibits, displays or permits to be exhibited or displayed, in his or its place of business or upon premises under his or its control, any coin-operated machine in the city. 
Owner. The term "owner" means any person, individual, firm, company, association, business organization or corporation owning any "coin-operated machine" in this city. Owner is solely responsible for paying to the city the occupation tax on each coin-operated machine exhibited or displayed within the city and for securing the city decal evidencing payment of such tax on each coin-operated machine. 
Service coin-operated machine. The term "service coin-operated machine" means pay toilets, pay telephones and all other machines or devices which dispense service only and not merchandise, music, skill or pleasure. 
Skill or pleasure coin-operated machine. The term "skill or pleasure coin-operated machine" means every coin-operated machine or device of any kind or character that is used or capable of use for pleasure or requires or is capable of rewarding or recognizing some degree of user skill in its use or operation or for any purpose other than dispersing or vending of merchandise, music or service exclusively as those terms are defined herein. The following are expressly included within such term: Electronic video games, marble machines or marble table machines, pin ball machines, marble shooting machines, pachinko machines, miniature golf machines, miniature bowling machines, coin-operated billiard or pool tables and all or any other coin-operated machines which satisfy some sense of skill or pleasure, including but not limited to every coin-operated machine or device that dispenses or vends merchandise, prizes, trinkets, novelties, commodities or confections or that plays music with or in addition to such games or devices. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 851, § 1, 10-17-89; Ord. No. 2010-12, §§ 1—3, 8-24-10)  
Sec. 16-31. - Tax imposed; amount; registration. 
(a)  Every "owner," save an owner holding an import license and holding coin-operated machines solely for resale, who exhibits, displays or who permits to be exhibited or displayed in this state any coin-operated machine shall pay, and there is hereby levied on each coin-operated machine, except those that are exempt under section 16-36, an annual fee the maximum percentage of the State of Texas' annual occupation tax for such devices that a city in Texas may charge, (which at this time is one-fourth (¼) of sixty dollars ($60) per annum the state charges or fifteen dollars ($15.00) maximum for the city in the year 2010). All occupation taxes for coin-operated machines are payable annually in advance. Upon payment of the tax, every owner shall register each machine by make, model and serial number with the city tax assessor and collector or his designated agents. At this time the agent is the city building official. There is hereby established and levied a late fee on any such annual fee equal to the amount of the fee itself in addition to the annual fee due and paid late. 
(b)  Whenever an owner shall exhibit or display, or permit to be exhibited or displayed, any coin-operated machine for commercial use, there shall be securely attached thereto a decal issued by the building official evidencing payment of the tax applicable thereto. Each coin-operated machine is subject to the occupation tax when exhibited or displayed for commercial use within the city. Since the tax is payable in advance on an annual calendar year basis, the following pro rata tax rate schedule will be applicable to a coin-operated machine which is first exhibited or displayed for commercial use within the city during any quarter of the calendar year. 
(1)  First quarter—January 1 to March 31: An amount equal to the applicable annual occupation tax; 
(2)  Second quarter—April 1 to June 30: An amount equal to three-quarters of the applicable annual occupation tax; 
(3)  Third quarter—July 1 to September 30: An amount equal to one-half of the applicable annual occupation tax; and 
(4)  Fourth quarter—October 1 to December 31: An amount equal to one-quarter of the applicable annual occupation tax. 
In computing any tax payable under the aforesaid pro rata tax rate schedule, amounts calculated thereunder shall be rounded to the next higher full cent amount as required. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 851, § 1, 10-17-89; Ord. No. 2010-12, § 4, 8-24-10; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 2, 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2011-23, § 2, 6-28-11)  
Sec. 16-32. - Display and issuance of decal evidencing payment; penalties for noncompliance. 
(a)  The decal issued by the city permit and inspection department to evidence payment of the tax levied herein shall be securely attached with its own adhesive to be a fixed, noninterchangeable part of the coin-operated machine so as to be easily seen by the public and in such a manner that continued application of steam and water be required to remove the same. 
(b)  During the period commencing on December 15 and ending on December 31 of each year, owners shall pay the occupation tax, register the machines taxed, and thereby receive a decal for each coin-operated machine to be within the city as of January 1. At the same time, owners may also pay taxes and receive decals for unregistered machines, up to ten (10) percent over the number registered. As a decal is placed on an additional machine the owner shall notify the building official of taxes of each machine's make, model and serial number, thereby registering it. 
(c)  If, during each calendar year, an owner desires to secure more decals than the additional ten (10) percent which may be obtained during the period from December 15 through December 31, such decals shall be issued upon payment of the tax applicable to the calendar quarter in which such decals are obtained. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for an owner to permit to be exhibited or displayed for commercial use any coin-operated machine which does not have properly attached thereto a decal evidencing payment of the applicable occupation tax. The owner of a coin-operated machine on which the tax has not been paid or which does not have a decal thereon evidencing payment shall forfeit to the City of South Houston as a penalty the sum of two hundred dollars ($200.00). The penalty, if not paid, shall be recovered by instituting a suit in a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 4, 6-14-11)  
Sec. 16-33. - Sealing machine for nonpayment, generally. 
After January 31 of each year, the permit and inspection department or the departmental employees, will seal, in a manner that will prevent further operation, any coin-operated machine upon which the tax required by this article has not been paid or upon which the decal is not properly displayed. Any owner subject to this article shall be required to pay a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) for the release of any machine sealed as provided herein for nonpayment of the tax or for failure to properly display the decal evidencing the payment of the tax. Upon proof of payment of the occupation tax provided for in this article, the penalties provided for in section 16-32 and the thirty-five dollar ($35.00) release fee, the permit and inspection department or the departmental employees will remove the seal. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 851, § 1, 10-17-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 6, 6-14-11)  
Sec. 16-34. - Penalty for removal of sealed machine. 
It shall be unlawful to remove from the premises any machine that has been sealed pursuant to section 16-33. Whoever shall remove a machine that is sealed shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall upon conviction, be punished by a fine in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-35. - Penalty for breaking seal. 
Whoever shall break the seal affixed pursuant to section 16-33 or exhibit, display or remove any machine on which such seal has been broken, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon conviction, shall be punished by a fine in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-36. - Exemptions. 
Gas meters, pay telephones, pay toilets, food vending machines, confection vending machines, beverage vending machines, merchandise vending machines, and cigarette vending machines which are now subject to an occupation or gross receipts tax, stamp vending machines, and "service coin-operated machines," as that term is defined, are expressly exempt from the tax levied herein, and the other provisions of this chapter. 
Coin-operated machines that have been remanufactured or altered not to accept coins are expressly exempt from the tax levied in this division unless they are opened by payment of a fee. 
Coin-operated machines operated solely in a private residence and not available to the general public are expressly exempt from the tax levied in this division. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-37. - Division does not authorize illegal machines. 
Nothing contained in this division shall be construed or have the effect to license, permit, authorize or legalize any machine, device, table or coin-operated machine, the keeping, exhibition, operation, displaying or maintenance of which is illegal or in violation of any article of the Penal Code of this State, or the constitution of this state. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
DIVISION 2. - REGULATION OF MUSIC AND SKILL OR PLEASURE COIN-OPERATED MACHINES 
 
Sec. 16-38. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this division is to provide comprehensive regulation of music and skill or pleasure coin-operated machines. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-39. - Construction. 
Notwithstanding any language in this chapter or any other chapter to the contrary, the term "music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine" shall include coin-operated billiard and pool games and shall exclude coin-operated amusement machines designed exclusively for children. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-40. - Definitions. 
In this division unless the context requires a different definition, 
(1)  Person includes any natural person, association of natural persons, trustee, receiver, partnership, corporation, organization, or the manager, agent, servant, or employee of any of them; 
(2)  Financial interest includes any legal or equitable interest, and specifically includes the ownership of shares or bonds of a corporation. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-41. - License. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in business to manufacture, own, buy, sell, or rent, lease, trade, lend or furnish to another or repair, maintain, service, transport within the City of South Houston, store, or import, a music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine without a license or registration certificate issued under this article. 
(b)  No license is required for a corporation or association organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, educational, or benevolent purposes, no part of the net earnings of which inure to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual, to own, or lease or rent from another, a music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine for the corporation's or association's exclusive use and in furtherance of the purposes for which it is established. No tax may be assessed against any of these entities if otherwise prohibited by law. 
(c)  No license or tax is required for any individual to own a music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine for personal use and amusement in his private residence. 
(d)  No license is required for any person subject to regulation by the Railroad Commission of Texas to transport or store in the due course of business a music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine not owned by him. 
(e)  A person who knowingly violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor, and, upon conviction, may be fined in an amount in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-42. - Nature of license. 
(a)  A license issued under this article: 
(1)  Is an annual license which expires on December 31st of each year, unless it expires as provided in subdivision (e) of this section or is suspended or cancelled earlier; 
(2)  Is effective for a single business entity; 
(3)  Vests no property or right in the license except to conduct the licensed business during the period the license is in effect; 
(4)  Is nontransferable, nonassignable, and not subject to execution; and 
(5)  Expires upon the death of an individual licensee, or upon the dissolution of any other licensee. 
(b)  An application for the renewal of a license must be made to the permit and inspection department before December 1st of each year. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-43. - Temporary extension of license. 
When a license issued under this article expires because of the death of an individual licensee, or the dissolution of any other licensee, or upon conditions involving receivership or bankruptcy, the permit and inspection department, except for good cause shown, shall permit the successor in interest to operate the business under the same license through December 31st of the year. The permit and inspection department shall give this permission in writing upon certification by the county judge of the county in which the business is located that the person requesting the extension is the successor in interest. The extended license is subject to suspension or cancellation as is any other license issued under this article. An original license application is necessary upon expiration of the extension. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-44. - Display; penalty. 
(a)  A person licensed to do business under this article shall prominently display his current license certificate at his place of business at all times. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-45. - Application for license. 
(a)  An application for a license to do business under this article shall contain a complete statement regarding the ownership of the business to be licensed. This statement of ownership must specify: 
(1)  The nature of the business entity to be licensed; 
(2)  The name and residence address of every person who has a financial interest in the business, and the nature, type, and extent of that financial interest, except corporate applicants may omit any shareholder holding less than ten (10) percent of the corporate shares. 
(b)  The application shall designate a single individual who is responsible for keeping a record and reporting to the permit and inspection department the following information regarding each music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine owned, possessed or controlled by the licensee: 
(1)  The make, type, and serial number of machine; 
(2)  The date put in operation; 
(3)  The dates of the first and most recent registration of the machine; 
(4)  The specific location of each machine; and 
(5)  Any change in ownership of a machine. 
(c)  The application shall be accompanied by a sworn written statement executed by the individual designated to maintain the records and make reports that he is aware of and accepts this responsibility. 
(d)  The individual designated to maintain the records and to make reports must have the following relationship to the business to be licensed: 
(1)  The owner of a sole proprietorship; 
(2)  A partner of the partnership; 
(3)  An officer of the corporation; 
(4)  A trustee of the trust; 
(5)  A receiver of the receivership; or 
(6)  An officer or principal member of the association, joint venture, organization, or other entity not specified. 
(e)  The permit and inspection department may require any other pertinent information to be included in the application. 
(f)  The application must contain a statement that the information contained in it is true and complete, and this statement shall be made under oath. 
(g)  The statement of ownership contained in the application becomes a public record upon issuance of a license. Other information in the application is confidential. 
(h)  The application shall designate an office in this state where the applicant proposes to maintain the records which he is required to maintain by this article, otherwise by law, or by rule or regulation of the permit and inspection department. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-46. - Fee with application. 
The application must be accompanied by the annual license fee in the form of cash, cashier's check, or money order payable to the City of South Houston, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-47. - Types of licenses. 
(a)  A person who wishes to engage in certain business dealing with music coin-operated machines or skill or pleasure coin-operated machines shall apply for a general business license, or an import license, or a repair license, or any combination of these. 
(b)  A general business licensee may engage in business to manufacture, own, buy, sell, rent, lease, trade, repair, maintain, service, transport or exhibit within the state, and store music and skill or pleasure coin-operated machines. 
(c)  An import licensee may engage in business to import, transport, own, buy, repair, sell, and deliver, music and skill or pleasure coin-operated machines, for sale and delivery within this state. 
(d)  A repair licensee may engage in the business of repairing, maintaining, servicing, transporting, or storing music, skill or pleasure coin-operated machines. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-48. - Fees. 
(a)  The annual license fee for a general business license shall be as follows: 
For an applicant with 50 or fewer machines: ..... $3,000.00 
For an applicant with 51—200 machines: ..... $6,000.00 
For an applicant with over 200 machines: ..... $7,500.00 
(b)  The annual license fee for an import license is: ..... $7,500.00 
(c)  The annual license fee for a repair license is: ..... $750.00 
(d)  The permit and inspection department may not refund any part of a license fee after the license is issued. In the event a license is not issued, the permit and inspection department and collector may retain thirty-five dollars ($35.00) to cover administrative costs, and may refund the balance. 
(e)  A person must renew an unexpired license by paying to the permit and inspection department before the expiration date of the license the annual license fee. If a person's license has been expired for not more than ninety (90) days, the person must renew the license by paying to the permit and inspection department a fee that is one and one-half (1½) times the annual license fee. If a person's license has been expired for more than ninety (90) days but less than two (2) years, the person must renew the license by paying to the permit and inspection department a fee that is two (2) times the annual license fee. If a person's license has been expired for two (2) years or more, the person may not renew the license. The person must obtain a new license by complying with the requirements and procedures for obtaining an original license. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 8, 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2018-10 , § 2, 7-24-18)  
Sec. 16-49. - Exemptions. 
(a)  A person who owns or exhibits coin-operated machines is exempt from the licensing and record keeping requirements imposed by this article if: 
(1)  He operates or exhibits his machines exclusively on premises occupied by him, and in connection with his business; and 
(2)  He owns no machine subject to the occupation tax imposed by this chapter located on the business premises of another person; and 
(3)  He has no financial interest, direct or indirect, in the coin-operated music, skill, or pleasure machine industry, except for the interest he owns in his machines used exclusively on premises occupied by him. 
(b)  Machines which are exhibited by a nonlicensed owner exempt under this section must be registered with the permit and inspection department. The owner shall obtain a registration certificate each year. The registration certificate shall show the name and address of the location of each machine and shall certify that the machine has a valid tax stamp affixed to it. The owner shall obtain his registration certificate by filing sworn application. 
(c)  Each time the location of a machine is changed, the owner of the registration certificate shall notify the permit and inspection department of the change by filing an amendment to the registration certificate within ten (10) days of the change. 
(d)  An application for the renewal of a registration certificate must be made to the permit and inspection department before December 1st of each year. 
(e)  A person must renew an unexpired registration for a machine by paying to the permit and inspection department before the expiration date of the registration the required registration fee, except that, if a person's registration has been expired for two (2) years or more, the person may not renew the registration. The person must obtain a new registration by complying with the requirements and procedures for obtaining an original registration. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-50. - Removal of stamp prohibited; penalty. 
(a)  No person other than the permit and inspection department may intentionally remove a current registration stamp from a music or skill or pleasure coin-operated machine. 
(b)  A person who violates this section is guilty of a misdemeanor in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-51. - License or permit as consent to entry. 
Acceptance of a license or permit issued under this article constitutes consent by the licensee or permittee that the permit and Inspection Department of the City of South Houston or any peace officer may freely enter upon the licensed or permitted business premises during normal business hours for the purpose of ensuring compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-52. - Grounds for refusal, suspension or revocation of license. 
(a)  The permit and inspection department may not issue a general business or import license for a business under this article if it finds that the applicant as set out in section 16-45 of this article: 
(1)  Has been finally convicted of a felony in a court of competent jurisdiction during the five (5) years preceding the filing of the application; or 
(2)  Has been on probation or parole as a result of a felony conviction during the two (2) years preceding the filing of the application. 
(b)  The permit and inspection department may not issue or renew a license for a business under this article, and shall suspend for any period of time, or cancel a license, if the permit and inspection department finds that the applicant or licensee is indebted to the city by judgment for any fees, costs, penalties, or delinquent taxes. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
DIVISION 3. - SPECIAL REGULATIONS AFFECTING SKILL OR PLEASURE COIN-OPERATED MACHINES 
 
Sec. 16-53. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this division, the following words or phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Skill or pleasure coin-operated machines. The term "skill or pleasure coin-operated machines" shall mean and have the same definition as is set forth in section 16-30. 
Video game. The term "video game" shall mean any skill or pleasure coin-operated machine which is a computer-based console equipped with color screen providing special effects wherein the player participates in the action upon the screen. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-54. - Hours. 
It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person owning or having control of premises upon which there is located one or more skill or pleasure coin-operated machines to permit any person under the age of sixteen (16) years to play at any skill or pleasure coin-operated machine before 3:30 p.m. on any day in which the public schools located within the City of South Houston are in session unless such minor is accompanied by his or her parent, or managing or possessory conservator. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-55. - Spacing requirements. 
No skill or pleasure coin-operated machine, either taxable or licensed under this chapter shall be placed in an area not providing a minimum of one (1) foot of area on each side of said machine, plus an area of four (4) feet in front of the device. In no event shall more than three (3) persons ever occupy at one time the area around a video game detailed by the foregoing description. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
DIVISION 4. - GAMEROOMS 
 
Sec. 16-56. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meaning respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
Gameroom. The term "gameroom" shall mean any building, room, hall, part of a building or other enclosure or any enclosed or partially enclosed space where more than five (5) skill or pleasure coin-operated machines are available to the public and which derives more than fifty (50) percent of its gross revenues in the city from skill or pleasure coin-operated machines or dedicates more than fifty (50) percent of its usable floor area to the placement of and provision for skill or pleasure coin-operating machines; provided, however, that premises which have been licensed by the Texas Alcoholic Beverage Commission shall not be construed to be gamerooms within the meaning of this division. 
Gameroom operator. The term "gameroom operator" means any person who owns or leases or rents or manages or is in any way responsible for controlling the operation of a gameroom. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 10, 6-14-11)  
Sec. 16-57. - Gameroom operator responsible for violation. 
Any gameroom operator who permits, allows or in any manner condones a violation of any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof be fined in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-58. - Gameroom employees subject to penalties. 
Any employee of a gameroom who violates or permits patrons or customers of said gameroom to violate any provision of this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in accordance to section 16-71. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-59. - Unobstructed view to interior. 
Each amusement hall shall have unobstructed windows or open space on at least one (1) side, so that the area is open to view by members of the public passing by on a public street, or using a corridor, lobby or other room to which the public resorts and is admitted without charge. The operator of such gameroom shall not permit any obstruction of such public view by the use of drawn shades, blinds, screens, partitions or other structures. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-60. - Operator's responsibility. 
(a)  No operator, owner, manager or employee shall, knowingly or recklessly, permit any person to illegally possess, use or sell any controlled substance on the premises. 
(b)  No operator, owner, manager or employee shall knowingly or recklessly, permit any person to possess, consume or sell any alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to possess, consume or sell any alcoholic beverages on the premises. 
(d)  No operator, owner, manager or employee shall permit any gambling, wagering or betting to be conducted on said premises. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-61. - Operation of business; license required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation, partnership or other entity to engage in the business of operating a gameroom unless said gameroom shall have been first licensed by the City of South Houston in accordance with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-62. - License not to issue in violation of deed restrictions or zoning ordinance; duty of applicant with respect to deed restrictions. 
(a)  No license shall be granted under the terms of this article for the location of any gameroom where it is prohibited by any deed restrictions recorded in the office of the County Clerk of Harris County and any applicable zoning ordinance. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the applicant for a gameroom license to search the records of the county clerk's office to insure that this type of business is not prohibited by any deed restrictions, and the applicant must file an affidavit that the location of the premises for which he is applying for a license is not prohibited by deed restrictions. 
(c)  No license shall issue nor be renewed to any game room located within one thousand (1,000) feet of any school, public or private, or any hospital, home for the aged or infirm or any funeral parlor, day-care, church, reception hall and any city park. No license shall issue to any game room located within three thousand (3,000) feet of any other game room. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 12, 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2012-02, § 2, 1-24-12; Ord. No. 2013-04, § 2, 2-12-13)  
Sec. 16-63. - Fees. 
The fee to be collected by the City of South Houston for the issuance or renewal of a license to operate a game room shall be three thousand dollars ($3,000.00). All ad valorem taxes on any and all property, personal or real, necessary to the operation of any game room must be paid prior to the issuance of any license or permit for said operation; provided, however, that no fee shall be required of persons licensed and paying fees under section 16-48 thereof. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 14, 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2018-10 , § 4, 7-24-18)  
Sec. 16-64. - Application. 
Any person, corporation, partnership, or other business entity desiring a license to operate a gameroom shall present to the City of South Houston, through the city permit and inspection department, a duplicate copy of the application submitted to the Texas Comptroller required by said comptroller for license or registration certificate issued pursuant to Article 8817. Such application will then be investigated by the permit and inspection department who will then recommend to the issuing department as to the issuance of a license. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 851, § 1, 10-17-89)  
Sec. 16-65. - Appeal from refusal. 
In the event the City of South Houston shall refuse to grant a license to any applicant under this division such action shall be final, unless the applicant shall, within ten (10) days after the refusal to grant such license, file a written appeal with the city secretary addressed to the city council, requesting a hearing upon the question as to whether or not his application shall be granted. In the event such appeal is filed, the City of South Houston shall provide the city council with a record of all proceedings theretofore had with reference to the application, including the written application, together with the action of the City of South Houston and the reasons for such action. The city council shall, within thirty (30) days, grant a hearing thereon to determine the correctness of the action of the City of South Houston, at which hearing, the council may make such investigation as it may deem fit, whether all the pertinent facts appear in the application or not. Within seven (7) days after final adjournment of the hearing, the city council shall cause a written deduction of its judgment thereon to be filed with the city secretary. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-66. - Posting. 
A license issued under this division shall be posted in a prominent place in the gameroom for which it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-67. - Transfer. 
A license issued under this division may be transferred to a different lawful location, upon sworn application and payment of a transfer fee of ten dollars ($10.00); so long as the new location violates no deed restrictions or other location provisions of this article. Such a license shall not be transferred to a different licensee. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-68. - Renewal. 
A license issued under this division shall be valid from January 1st through December 31st of each calendar year, unless sooner suspended or revoked, and the same must be renewed by January 1st of each year. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-69. - Does not grant vested rights. 
No license granted under the terms of this division shall be deemed the granting of a vested right, but such license shall remain subject to the terms and provisions of this article and subject to such future regulations as shall be promulgated by the city council by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-70. - Revocation. 
If a person holding a license issued under the terms of this division violates any provision of this article, this Code or the laws of the state, or if a gameroom licensed under this division is not being conducted in accordance with this article, this Code and the laws of the state, or is being conducted in violation thereof, the City of South Houston may at any time give notice in writing to the operator, licensee, manager, or other person in control of the operation and maintenance of such gameroom that the license issued for the operation and maintenance of such gameroom has been revoked, stating therein the reason or reasons for such revocation. Such notice of revocation shall become a final revocation after the expiration of ten (10) days from the date of the service of same upon the operator, licensee, manager or other persons in charge of the gameroom, unless, on or before the expiration of such ten (10) days, the licensee, operator, manager or other person in charge of the hall shall file with the city secretary a written appeal addressed to the city council, in which it is requested that the city council grant him a hearing upon the question of whether or not the license shall be revoked. Such appeal, if made and filed as prescribed herein, shall operate as a stay or postponement of the revocation, until such time as the city council shall grant a hearing and make final adjudication upon the question of whether or not the license should be revoked. Such hearing shall be held within thirty (30) days after the date of the filing of the appeal. Within seven (7) days after final adjournment of the hearing, the city council shall cause a written judgment thereon to be filed with the city secretary. Such action and judgment of the city council, after hearing all the evidence and facts, shall be final and conclusive as to all parties, and shall be, in all cases, by a majority vote. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89)  
Sec. 16-71. - Penalty. 
Any person, persons, operator, owner, owners, partners, licensee, or the agents of a corporation, or whoever is in charge or control of a transient amusement, or any part thereof, who shall violate or allow or cause any person or persons to violate any provision of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined not fewer than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for such offense; and the license or licenses shall be subject to revocation or suspension for a violation of any provision of this article or of any other provision of the Code of Ordinances of the City of South Houston or any violation of the laws of the State of Texas. Any remedy prescribed by this article shall be merely cumulative and shall not preclude resort to any other remedy provided by law. Each day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 831, § 1, 2-21-89; Ord. No. 2011-18, § 16, 6-14-11)  
Sec. 16-72—16-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CREDIT-ACCESS BUSINESSES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1, adopted August 13, 2013, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, such ordinance has been added as §§ 16-81—16-93 at the editor's discretion. 
 
Sec. 16-81. - Short title and purpose. 
(a)  This article may be known and cited as "Credit-Access Businesses Regulation." 
(b)  The purpose of this article is to protect the welfare of the citizens of the City of South Houston by monitoring credit-access businesses in an effort to reduce abusive and predatory lending practices. To this end, this article establishes a registration program for credit-access businesses, imposes restrictions on extensions of consumer credit made by credit-access businesses, and imposes recordkeeping requirements on credit-access businesses. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.010), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-82. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter: 
Certificate of registration means a certificate of registration issued by the director under this article to the owner or operator of a credit-access business. 
Consumer means an individual who is solicited to purchase or who purchases the services of a credit-access business. 
Consumer's language of preference is the language the consumer understands best. 
Credit-access business has the meaning given that term in V.T.C.A. Finance Code § 393.601. 
Deferred presentment transaction has the meaning given that term in V.T.C.A. Finance Code § 393.601. 
Director means the director of the department designated by the city council or mayor, or city council's or mayor's designee, to enforce and administer this chapter. The City of South Houston hereby designates the city building official (or his or her designee) as the director. 
Extension of consumer credit has the meaning given that term in V.T.C.A. Finance Code § 393.001. 
Motor vehicle title loan has the meaning given that term in V.T.C.A. Finance Code, § 393.601. 
Person means any individual, corporation, organization, partnership, association, financial institution, or any other legal entity. 
Registrant means a person issued a certificate of registration for a credit-access business under this chapter and includes all owners and operators of the credit-access business identified in the registration application filed under this chapter. 
State license means a license to operate a credit-access business issued by the Texas Consumer Credit Commissioner under V.T.C.A. Finance Code Ch. 393, Subch. G. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.020), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-83. - Violations; penalty. 
(a)  A person who violates a provision of this chapter, or who fails to perform an act required of the person by this chapter, commits an offense. A person commits a separate offense for each and every violation relating to an extension of consumer credit, and for each day during which a violation is committed, permitted, or continued. 
(b)  An offense under this chapter is punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(c)  A culpable mental state is not required for the commission of an offense under this article and need not be proved. 
(d)  The penalties provided for in subsection (b) are in addition to any other remedies that the city may have under city ordinances and state law. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.030), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-84. - Defenses. 
It is a defense to prosecution under this article that at the time of the alleged offense the person was not required to be licensed by the state as a credit-access business under V.T.C.A. Finance Code Ch. 393, Subch. G. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.040), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-85. - Registration required. 
A person commits an offense if the person acts, operates, or conducts businesses as a credit-access business without a valid certificate of registration. A certificate of registration is required for each physically separate credit-access business. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.050), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-86. - Registration application. 
(a)  To obtain a certificate of registration for a credit-access business, a person must submit an application on a form provided for that purpose to the director. The application must contain the following: 
(1)  The name, street address, mailing address, facsimile number, and telephone number of the applicant. 
(2)  The business or trade name, street address, mailing address, facsimile number, and telephone number of the credit-access business. 
(3)  The names, street addresses, mailing addresses, and telephone numbers of all owners of the credit-access business, and the nature and extent of each person's interest in the credit-access business. 
(4)  A copy of a current, valid state license held by the credit-access business pursuant to V.T.C.A. Finance Code Ch. 393, Subch. G. 
(5)  A copy of a current, valid certificate of occupancy showing that the credit-access business is in compliance with the City of South Houston's Code. 
(6)  A non-refundable application fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). This application fee may be modified from time to time by the City of South Houston by Resolution. 
(7)  A non-refundable, annual fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be due and payable to the City of South Houston before the city issues the renewal of the application. This renewal fee may be modified from time to time by the City of South Houston by resolution. 
(b)  An applicant or registrant shall notify the director within forty-five (45) days after any material change in the information contained in the application for a certificate of registration, including, but not limited to, any change of address and any change in the status of the state license held by the applicant or registrant. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.060), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-87. - Issuance and display of certificate of registration; presentment upon request. 
(a)  The director shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration upon receiving a completed, satisfactory application hereunder. 
(b)  A certificate of registration issued under this section must be conspicuously displayed to the public in the credit-access business. The certificate of registration must be presented upon request to the director or any peace officer for examination. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.070), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-88. - Expiration and renewal of certificate of registration. 
(a)  A certificate of registration expires on the earliest of: 
(1)  One year after the date of issuance; or 
(2)  The date of revocation, suspension, surrender, expiration without renewal, or other termination of the registrant's state license. 
(b)  A certificate of registration may be renewed by making application in accordance with section 16-86(a)(7). A registrant shall apply for renewal at least thirty (30) days before the expiration of the registration. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.080), 8-13-13; Ord. No. 2013-25, § 2, 8-27-13)  
Sec. 16-89. - Non-transferability. 
A certificate of registration for a credit-access business is not transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.090), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-90. - Maintenance of records. 
(a)  A credit-access business shall maintain a complete set of records of all extensions of consumer credit arranged or obtained by the credit-access business, which mush include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the consumer. 
(2)  The principal amount of cash actually advanced. 
(3)  The length of the extension of consumer credit, including the number of installments and renewals. 
(4)  The fees charged by the credit-access business to arrange or obtain an extension of consumer credit; and 
(5)  The documentation used to establish a consumer's income under section 16-91 of this article. 
(b)  A credit-access business shall maintain a copy of each written agreement between the credit-access business and a consumer evidencing an extension of a consumer credit (including, but not limited to, any refinancing or renewal granted to the consumer). 
(c)  A credit-access business shall maintain copies of all quarterly reports filed with the Texas Consumer Credit Commissioner under V.T.C.A. Finance Code § 393.627. 
(d)  The records required to be maintained by a credit-access business under this section must be retained for at least three years and made available for inspection by the city upon request during the usual and customary business hours of the credit-access business. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.100), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-91. - Restriction on extension of consumer credit. 
(a)  The cash advanced under an extension of consumer credit that a credit-access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining in the form of a deferred presentment transaction may not exceed twenty (20) percent of the consumer's gross monthly income. 
(b)  The cash advanced under an extension of consumer credit that a credit-access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining in the form of a motor vehicle title loan may not exceed the lesser of: 
(1)  Three (3) percent of the consumer's gross annual income; or 
(2)  Seventy (70) percent of the retail value of the motor vehicle. 
(c)  A credit-access business shall use a paycheck or other documentation establishing income to determine a consumer's income. 
(d)  An extension of consumer credit that a credit-access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining and that provides for repayment in installments may not be payable in more than four (4) installments. Proceeds from each installment must be used to repay at least twenty-five (25) percent of the principal amount of the extension of consumer credit. An extension of consumer credit that provides for repayment in installments many not be refinanced or renewed. 
(e)  An extension of consumer credit that a credit-access business obtains for a consumer or assists a consumer in obtaining and that provides for a single lump sum repayment may not be refinanced or renewed more than three (3) times. Proceeds from each refinancing or renewal must be used to repay at least twenty-five (25) percent of the principal amount of the original extension of consumer credit. 
(f)  For purposes of this section, an extension of consumer credit that is made to a consumer within seven (7) days after a previous extension of consumer credit has been paid by the consumer will constitute a refinancing or renewal. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.110), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-92. - Requirement of consumer understanding of agreement. 
(a)  Every agreement between the credit-access business and a consumer evidencing an extension of consumer credit (including, but not limited to, any refinancing or renewal granted to the consumer), must be written in the consumer's language of preference. Every credit-access business location must maintain on its premises, to be available for use by consumers, agreements in the English and Spanish languages. 
(b)  For every consumer who cannot read, every agreement between the credit-access business and a consumer evidencing an extension of consumer credit (including, but not limited to, any refinancing or renewal granted to the consumer) must be read to the consumer in its entirety in the consumer's language of preference, prior to the consumer's signature. 
(c)  For every consumer who cannot read, every disclosure and notice required by law must be read to the consumers in its entirety in the consumer's language of preference, prior to the consumer's signature. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.120), 8-13-13)  
Sec. 16-93. - Referral to consumer credit counseling. 
A credit-access business shall provide a form, to be prescribed by the director, to each consumer seeking assistance in obtaining an extension of consumer credit which references non-profit agencies that provide financial education and training programs and agencies with cash assistance programs. The form will also contain information regarding extensions of consumer credit, and must include the information required by section 16-90(a)(1)—(5) of this article specific to the loan agreement with the consumer. If the director has prescribed a form in the consumer's language of preference, the form must be provided in the consumer's language of preference. 
(Ord. No. 2013-23, § 1(1.130), 8-13-13)  
Chapter 16.5 - POLICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Police civil service, § 2-59 et seq.; police assigned to motorcycle duty, § 12-6. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 16.5-1. - Office of city marshal. 
(a)  There is hereby created the office of city marshal. There may be more than one (1) such marshal at a later date, but initially there shall only be one (1) city marshal. 
(b)  The term of the city marshal(s) shall be for two years commencing when officers are created after the election of the mayor. At this time there shall only be one (1) city marshal's office created. The office shall be appointed and filled by appointment of the mayor, subject to council approval. The first city marshal shall fill a shorter term, which is the remainder of the term that would have been underway had the office existed when new offices were filled by the mayor after the last election. Thereafter, the term shall be a full two (2) years. If and when council deems it necessary to create another marshal's position or office, council may authorize same by resolution without the necessity of changing or amending the ordinance from which this section derives. And if and when another such marshal's position is authorized by council, the method of selection and approval of the person to fill the office shall be as specified herein. 
(c)  City marshals shall serve under the direction and supervision of the judge of the municipal court. The judge shall oversee and supervise the marshal(s) in the exercise of their duties. 
(d)  City marshals shall serve and execute warrants of arrest, subpoenas, and other legal processes issuing out of the municipal court of the city, as well as subpoenas and other legal processes issuing out of the civil service commission, the council, any board or commission or department requiring legal process for hearings, condemnation (eminent domain or regulation or eradication of dangerous buildings) hearings or the like; and marshals shall perform any other services or duties that may be assigned to them by the municipal judge or the city council.
