(e)  Each city marshal shall meet all qualifications for service as a Texas Peace Officer as established by the Texas Commission on Law Enforcement and shall seek and receive such peace officer certification within the time prescribed by Texas law, as a necessary precondition for continued employment as a city marshal. Once certified, the marshal shall have full police authority in the exercise of his or her assigned duties, but shall not be a member of the South Houston Police Department nor shall he or she be subject to or enjoy the benefits of the regulations and protection of the South Houston Civil Service Commission or the benefit of police officers' minimum wages, hours of employment or pension rights unless separately authorized in writing. 
(f)  Nothing herein shall prevent, inhibit, invalidate or interfere with the duties of a regular police officer of the city in the service or execution of any process issued out of the municipal court, which process may be placed in the hands of such police officer(s) to be served and executed. Neither a marshal nor a regular police officer has an exclusive duty in that regard. Both are authorized and empowered. 
( Ord. No. 2017-35 , §§ 1—6, 8-22-17)  
Secs. 16.5-2—16.5-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - UNCLAIMED, UNIDENTIFIED OR ABANDONED PERSONAL PROPERTY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 785, §§ 1—10, adopted March 1, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code and at the discretion of the editor said provisions have been included herein as Art. II, §§ 16.5-31—16.5-40. 
Cross reference— Junked vehicles, § 11-33 et seq. 
 
Sec. 16.5-31. - Sale of unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified personal property; definition; return of property used as evidence. 
(a)  The city is hereby authorized to sell at a public auction, through the agency of its chief of police, that personal property which has been in the possession of the police department for a period of at least six (6) months, which property has remained unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by its rightful owner, and which is not being held by that department as evidence for trial or trials and pending cases filed of record, and has not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession of the property by any justice of the peace, county judge or district judge. 
(b)  The following articles are designated as personal property, to-wit: All jewelry, wearing apparel, suitcases, cameras, radios, television sets, phonographs, tape recorders, sewing machines, office equipment, cash registers, typewriters, sporting goods equipment, automobile and truck tires, auto accessories and tools, hand tools, gasoline and electric motors, lawn mowers, electrical and building supplies, household furnishings and fixtures, household appliances and utensils, linens, paintings, paint material and equipment, leather goods, silverware, dishes, lanterns, cash or any other negotiable securities, and all other miscellaneous personal property of the general types and classes described. 
(c)  The city municipal court judge shall have the authority to order that property in possession of the police department be returned to its rightful owner after final disposition of the case in which the said property was being held for evidence. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 1, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-32. - Disposition of motor vehicles, auto accessories and tires; exception. 
(a)  All motor vehicles, auto accessories and tires which have been in the possession of the city police department for a period of at least ninety (90) days, and remaining unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owner, and which is not being held by that department as evidence for trial or trials and pending cases file of record, and has not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession of the motor vehicle by any justice of the peace, county judge, district judge or federal judge, may be retained by this city for official use only, or may be sold at public auction as set out in section 16.5-37. 
(b)  A list shall be prepared by the police department of all motor vehicles, tires and all auto accessories that have been returned to their rightful owner and of those items retained by the city for official use only. 
(c)  A list shall be prepared by the police department of those automobiles not returned or sold, or being officially used, and a copy of said list shall be mailed to local junk dealers (or advertised) requesting bids for same and stating a three-day period to submit a bid for said vehicles. 
(d)  The highest bidder shall be contracted to bring the said amount (in cash or cashier's check) to the police department and the bidder shall transport the vehicles at his expense and shall have transported all said vehicles within twenty-four (24) hours. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 2, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-33. - Disposition of firearms; exception. 
(a)  All firearms which have been in the possession of the city police department for a period of at least one (1) year remaining unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owner and which are not being held by that department as evidence for trial or trails and pending cases filed of record, and have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession of the said firearms by any justice of the peace, county judge, district judge or federal judge, shall be retained by the city police department for its official use and officially placed in the police arsenal. If said firearms are non-usable, then said property shall be destroyed after reporting such disposition to the bureau of alcohol, tobacco and firearms. 
(b)  Those firearms not retained for official use shall be transported to an established firm that melts steel and said firearms shall be destroyed by melting same. The chief of police shall, or he may direct the identification and records division officer of that police department to supervise this requirement. 
(c)  A list of all firearms that are retained by the police department shall be made by the chief of police, which shall consist of a physical description of the firearms (which shall include the serial number, brand name, etc.), and a copy of said list shall be sent to the mayor and identification and records division officer. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 3, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-34. - Disposition of bicycles and tricycles; exception. 
(a)  All bicycles and tricycles which have been in the possession of the city police department for a period of at least ninety (90) days, which same have remained unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owner, and which are not being held by that department as evidence for trial or trials and pending cases filed of record, and have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession of the property by a justice of the peace, county judge or district judge, shall be sold at public auction as set out in section 16.5-37. 
(b)  Those bicycles and tricycles not sold at public auction nor returned to their rightful owners, and still in the possession of the city police department on the first day of December of any year, may be donated to any organization, at the discretion of the chief of police, and said organization shall repair same and donate same to needy children. 
(c)  A list shall be prepared by the police department of the bicycles and tricycles that are donated for charity and a copy shall be delivered to the city secretary and city council and a copy of same shall be retained by the police department identification officer. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 4, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-35. - Fitness of property for official use or for sale. 
The mayor and the city council hereby authorize the chief of police to decide on the fitness or suitability of the property for official use, or to be sold at public auction, or to be destroyed, or to be donated to a charitable organization. Said organization shall be of the class of the Salvation Army type organization. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 5, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-36. - Disposition of alcoholic beverages. 
Alcoholic beverages in any type of containers which have been in possession of the city police department for at least thirty (30) days, which have remained unclaimed, abandoned or unidentified by their rightful owner, and which are not being held by that department as evidence for trial or trials and pending cases filed on record, and have not been ordered returned to the person entitled to possession of the property by any justice of the peace, county judge, district judge or federal judge, and any container which seal is intact, shall be destroyed under the supervision of the chief of police and he shall certify to such destruction to the mayor within ten (10) days of such destruction. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 6, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-37. - Sale by public auction; procedure. 
(a)  The chief of police of the city shall establish a proposed date for the sale at public auction of the property hereinbefore described whenever, in his opinion, sufficient amounts of such property have accumulated to justify such a sale. At least sixty (60) days before the proposed date of the auction the chief of police shall file an inventory of the property with the city secretary as a public record. While such inventory is on file as a public record the city secretary shall refer any persons who claim to be the rightful owners of any of the property listed thereon to the chief of police. The chief of police shall return any property listed on the inventory to persons who prove to his satisfaction that they are the rightful owners of such property. At least forty-five (45) days before the proposed date of the auction the chief of police shall send the city secretary a list of all items from the inventory to be sold. The city secretary shall then send the mayor, the city council and each department head of the city administration a copy of an inventory of the remaining property. Each department head, including the chief of police, who desires to use, and has a need to use, any of the property listed on the inventory in the official conduct of the activities of his department shall submit a request for such property to the mayor, through the city secretary, within ten (10) days after receipt of the inventory. After the mayor has received all such requests for the department heads, he shall decide, by approval of city council, whether the property, or any part thereof, shall be sold at public auction or shall be retained for the official use of the city. In the event two (2) or more department heads request the use of the same property, the mayor shall decide which department is to use the property. After it has been decided which property is to be retained for official use of the city, the city secretary, for the mayor, shall send the chief of police a list of such property and the mayor and the city council shall by motion authorize him to sell the remaining property at public auction. Before the remaining property may be sold at public auction, the chief of police shall, through the city secretary, cause to be published, ten (10) days' notice of the auction in a daily newspaper of the City of South Houston. The notice shall be published at least three (3) times and shall give the hour, place, and date of the auction and shall contain a list of the classes of property to be sold at the auction. 
(b)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to appoint a police officer, whose rank shall not be lower than a captain, to do that which this article orders and/or authorizes the chief of police to do, in compliance with this article. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 7, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-38. - Storage charges. 
(a)  A charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per day shall be levied against each designated item of personal property as storage charges for each and every day such item or items shall remain in the possession of the police department as abandoned and unclaimed property, commencing seven (7) days after final disposition of the case involving the item or items of property and/or seven (7) days after the rightful owner has failed to pick up said property after being notified by the police department of its whereabouts. 
(b)  The fee for storage of motor vehicles shall be ten dollars ($10.00) for each and every day that they remain in the possession of the police department. 
(c)  An officer shall make a notation to be entered on the file as to the date that the rightful owner of the property was notified. 
(d)  A storage fee shall commence seven (7) days after a diligent search by the police department has been unable to locate the rightful owner of the property which has been in the possession of the police department. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 8, 3-1-88; Ord. No. 2002-08, § 1, 4-16-02)  
Sec. 16.5-39. - Disposition of funds from public sale. 
(a)  All monies derived from any auction or auctions provided for herein shall be applied first to the storage charge accrued against the personal property sold hereunder and secondly to the general revenues of the city. Provided, however, that all monies received hereunder shall be deposited by the city treasurer into a special escrow account established for that purpose and held for a period of two (2) years prior to being transferred to the general fund of the city or the storage account as the case may be. 
(b)  The city shall not in any instance, however, be liable to any person or persons for damages as compensation for any property retained for official use or sold at public auction. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 9, 3-1-88)  
Sec. 16.5-40. - Rights and remedies preserved. 
All rights and remedies which have accrued in favor of the city under this article and amendments thereto shall be and are preserved for the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 785, § 10, 3-1-88)  
Secs. 16.5-41—16.5-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL WARRANT SERVICE SYSTEM[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 94-027, §§ 1—12, adopted Sept. 6, 1994, has been codified herein at the discretion of the editor as art. III, §§ 16.5-51—16.5-62. 
 
Sec. 16.5-51. - Participation procedure. 
(a)  Participation in the municipal warrant service system shall be on a voluntary basis and will be open to any commissioned member of the South Houston Police Department. 
(1)  Any nonparticipant may begin participation at any time by submission of a written request to the chief of police, unless barred from participation for a specified time. 
(2)  Any participant may withdraw at any time by giving written notice to the chief of police. 
(b)  Any member who is so barred from participation may apply for re-entry into the system only upon completion of the mandatory period of suspension. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 1, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-52. - Hours of warrant system activity. 
All self-initiated activity relating to the serving of a warrant by the participation to whom the warrant is issued shall be conducted during the member's off-duty hours only. If a subject who is named in a warrant calls the police station and requests to speak to the participant holding the warrant during the member's tour of duty, he/she shall be referred to the warrant system supervisor or his/her designee. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 2, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-53. - Funding. 
(a)  The funding for the municipal warrant service system will be generated through the collection of warrant fees. 
(b)  A warrant fee of sixty dollars ($60.00) will be assessed for each warrant issued by the municipal court. 
(c)  A separate warrant and warrant fee will be assessed for each class C misdemeanor for which a person has been charged. 
(d)  The warrant fee shall apply to and be included in all bonds posted (cash bonds, appearance bonds and pr bonds) and all capias pro fines collected. Only one (1) warrant fee will be assessed for each capias pro fines warrant issued regardless of the number of offenses for which the fine was originally levied. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 3, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-54. - Remuneration. 
(a)  All warrant fees collected shall go into the municipal general fund and participants shall be remunerated therefrom. Payment shall normally be made on or about the fifteenth of each month for all payment vouchers submitted to the city treasurer by the ninth of the month; however, when circumstances cause the chief of police to deem it necessary to submit the payment vouchers after the ninth of the month, payment will not be made until the end of month. 
(b)  Payment shall be in the form of a check (separate from participant's city payroll check) from which no taxes will be withheld. Participants will be treated as contract labor for purposes of municipal warrant service system pay. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 4, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-55. - Earned fees. 
(a)  Only the warrant holder (the participant to whom wrote the citation) can earn the warrant fee for the execution of the warrant. 
(b)  Further, the warrant must be executed as a direct result of the warrant holder's documented activity and must occur during the period of time that the warrant is physically in the possession of the warrant holder or within the fifteen-day period. The warrant belongs to warrant holder for fifteen (15) days after being issued by court. 
(c)  The warrant may be executed by: 
(1)  The bond or fine being paid, either in person or by mail; 
(2)  The physical arrest of the person named in the warrant; or 
(3)  The surrender of the person named in the warrant. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 5, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-56. - Unearned fees. 
Warrant fees shall be considered unearned by the warrant holder and shall be retained in the municipal general fund under the following circumstances: 
(1)  If a person named in a warrant is arrested by another agency, the warrant fee shall not be considered earned by the warrant holder regardless of whether: 
a.  The arresting agency collects the bond or fine and forwards it to South Houston Police Department; 
b.  Another person comes to South Houston Police Department and pays the bond or fine to gain the release of the person arrested; or 
c.  The person arrested is transferred to the custody of South Houston Police Department. 
(2)  If a person named in a South Houston Police Department warrant is arrested by an on-duty commissioned member of this agency (including the warrant holder), the warrant fee shall not be considered earned by the warrant holder, unless the warrant holder can provide empirical evidence (VIA Activity Documentation), combined with the supporting declaration of the person named in the warrant, that the person arrested was enroute to South Houston Police Department to post said bond as a result of the warrant holder's contact efforts. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 6, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-57. - Warrant execution by arrest. 
(a)  Participants are encouraged to use alternative means to execute their issued warrants prior to incarcerating warrant suspects when practical, however, when affecting such arrest, commissioned members shall adhere to relevant laws and department policies. 
(b)  Participants shall be further governed by the following guidelines concerning all warrants that are executed by arrest: 
(1)  They will be executed only by a uniformed commission member of South Houston Police Department. 
(2)  The commissioned member thus executing a warrant must be in a marked South Houston Police Department vehicle. The use of this vehicle must be approved by the chief of police or his/her designee; all commissioned members using this vehicle must be in uniform. 
(3)  When executed inside the corporate limits of South Houston by one (1) South Houston Police Department commissioned member. 
(4)  When executed outside the corporate limits of South Houston by one (1) South Houston Department commissioned member, he/she shall before entering another city call and request a backup from the law enforcement agency having primary jurisdiction at that location. 
(5)  When executed outside the corporate limits of South Houston by two (2) or more South Houston Police Department commissioned members, they shall notify the law enforcement agency having primary jurisdiction at that location and inform them of their intentions, but will not be required to have a member of that agency present. 
(6)  Commissioned members shall contact the chief of police or his/her designee for instructions prior to attempting to arrest any person on a municipal warrant (except as the result of a routine traffic stop) when that person: 
a.  Has prior felony convictions; 
b.  Is currently a fugitive from justice; or 
c.  Has a history of any assaultive offense. 
(7)  Noncommissioned members shall not participate in the physical arrest of persons named in any municipal warrants. 
(8)  Noncommissioned members are expressly prohibited from accompanying any commissioned member in a marked police vehicle while conducting any warrant service activity without explicit authorization from the chief of police. (This singular exception would be for the positive identification of a warranted subject only). 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 7, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-58. - Work locations. 
(a)  All participants are authorized to perform their warrant service activities (i.e., telephoning, mail-out preparation, paperwork, etc.) from their homes. However, the following areas within the police station shall be available for participant's convenience as long as the use thereof does not interfere with on-going, on-duty police activity: 
(1)  Xerox room—Available to all off-duty participants. 
(2)  Patrol sergeant's office—Off-duty patrol sergeants only. 
(3)  Commissioned members' work stations—Off-duty commissioned members only. 
(b)  Warrant service activity shall not be conducted in the dispatch office. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 8, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-59. - Restrictive guidelines. 
(a)  Participants must receive express authorization from the supervisor or his/her designee prior to using any South Houston Police Department equipment or on-duty members, except as permitted elsewhere in the policy. 
(b)  Participants shall not contact the court clerk in reference to warrant service problems, but shall consult with their supervisor. 
(c)  Participants shall not use the telephones, equipment, and/or office at city hall. 
(d)  Before placing any long distance phone calls which will be billed to the department, participants shall confer with their supervisor to ascertain if a less costly approach might be feasible. All authorized long distance calls shall be logged with long distance telephone slips and left with clerk. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 9, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-60. - Warrant issuance/return. 
(a)  Original issuance. 
(1)  Active warrants, ready to be issued, shall be issued to officer writing citation for fifteen (15) days. The method of dividing the warrants into bundles and issuing the bundles to participants shall be one that affords all participants a relatively equal opportunity for success as determined by the chief of police. 
(2)  Participants or their designated proxy must pick up their warrants within one hundred twenty (120) hours (five (5) days) of the official posting that warrants are ready for issuance. 
(3)  Upon the official posting that warrants are ready for issuance participants will return all unexecuted warrants remaining in the previously issued bundle to the court clerk. 
(b)  Second issuance. 
(1)  After unexecuted warrants from an original issuance have been returned for a period of fifteen (15) days, they shall be eligible for any participant to serve. 
(2)  All unexecuted warrants shall be moved to the inactive files fifteen (15) days after being returned, whereas they may be served by any participant. 
(c)  Reassigned issuance original issuance warrants not picked up within the one hundred twenty-hour limit will be reassigned and issued to those participants who picked up their warrants in a timely fashion. 
(d)  Special request any participant who has reason to believe that he/she can execute a warrant that has been moved to the inactive files may request the warrant. 
(e)  Executed warrants when a warrant is executed, the warrant holder shall immediately complete the officer's return portion of the warrant and return it to the warrant system supervisor. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 10, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-61. - Agreements between participants. 
(a)  Participants may make any agreements and/or arrangements with other participants as they deem equitable and practical to accomplish the execution of warrants assigned to them; however, warrant fees will only be paid to the assigned warrant holder. The payment of any monetary amounts due other participants as a result of such agreements shall be the responsibility of the warrant holder and any conflicts arising therefrom will not be resolved by the administration. 
(b)  Any officer wishing to participate in the warrant fee system will be required to be on an active call out list. This list will be on a weekly basis. The call out list will be used when other agencies call and have a subject in custody they need [to have picked up]. The shift supervisor will be responsible for making the decision as to whether an officer should be called or if the working shift can handle it. Any officer called out will receive call out time. Any officer that does not wish to be on the call out list will not be eligible to participate in the warrant program. Only in sickness or emergency will an officer be dismissed from call out. It will be permissible for officers to trade weeks as long as [it is confirmed] in writing and agreeable with both officers. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 11, 9-06-94)  
Sec. 16.5-62. - Severability. 
The governing body of the City of South Houston, Texas, does hereby declare that if any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause, phase, word, or portion of this article is declared invalid, or unconstitutional, by a court of competent jurisdiction that, in such event, it would have passed and ordained any and all remaining portions of this article without the inclusion of that portion or portions which may be so found to be unconstitutional or invalid, and declares that its intent is to make no portion of this article dependent upon the validity of any other portion thereof, and that all remaining portions shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 94-027, § 12, 9-06-94)  
Secs. 16.5-63—16.5-85. - Reserved.

(Ord. No. 2010-14, § 1, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 2017-33 , § 1, 7-25-17)
