Chapter 18 - STANDARD SIGN CODE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2011-16, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 14, 2011, repealed the former Ch. 18, §§ 18-1—18-22, and enacted a new Ch. 18 as set out herein. The former Ch. 18 pertained to signs and derived from Ord. of 10-2-51, §§ 1—14; Ord. No. 518, §§ 2, 3, 10-1-63; Ord. No. 97-025, § 1, 8-26-97; Ord. No. 99-031, §§ 1, 2, 11-23-99; Ord. No. 2001-08, §§ 1—4, 6-5-01. 
Cross reference— General requirements of the electrical code as to electrical signs, § 8-6; electrical sign contractor's license, § 8-91, et seq.; circuits for unsupported electric signs, § 8-141; painting signs on street or sidewalk pavement, § 19-20; attachment of signs to trees growing on public property, § 19-51. 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Scope. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all signs, as that term is defined herein, within the extraterritorial jurisdiction or the corporate limits of the City of South Houston, Texas. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-2. - Purpose and intent. 
It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to establish the reasonable, orderly, and effective display of outdoor advertising existing and proposed in the corporate limits of the City of South Houston. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-2.1. - Superiority clause. 
If any subdivision or individual tract of land contains restrictions or covenants relating to signs, or any person or persons enter into a legally binding agreement which provides for the regulating of signs in a particular development, which are more restrictive than these regulations, the more restrictive requirements shall apply. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-3. - Definitions. 
The following definitions shall apply to this chapter: 
Advertising shall mean to seek the attraction of or to direct the attention of the public to any goods, services, or merchandise whatsoever or a location that provides goods, services or merchandise. 
Alterations or repair to an advertising display means repairs or improvements to a display, sign, or sign structure. 
Banner shall mean any piece of cloth, plastic, canvas or similar material on which there appears a display, typically supported at both ends. 
Building inspector or code enforcement officer shall mean the building inspector or code enforcement officer as defined herein and those representatives that he may designate. 
Business shall mean the erection or use of any property, building or structure, permanent or temporary, for the primary purpose of conducting in said building or structure or on said property a legitimate commercial enterprise compliant with all ordinances and regulations of the City of South Houston, governing such activity; business purpose shall not include any property, building, or structure erected or used for the primary purpose of securing a permit or erecting a sign. 
City shall mean the city of South Houston, Texas. 
Display shall mean the message of any sign whether it be in words, symbols or objects. 
Face shall mean the total display area and border of a sign. 
Federal primary system shall mean the interstate and freeway primary system and the non-freeway primary system. 
Intersection shall mean the intersection of streets, driveways, alleys or any two surfaces intended for motor vehicles. 
Interstate and freeway primary system shall mean the portion of the national system of interstate and defense highways located within Texas which are now or hereafter may be officially designated the "interstate system" by the Texas Department of Public Transportation Commission and approved pursuant to Title 3. United States Code, Section 131, as amended. 
Nameplate shall mean a non-electrical sign identifying only the name and occupation or profession of the occupant(s) of premises on which the sign is located and not exceeding six (6) inches by eighteen (18) inches. 
Non-freeway primary system shall mean that portion of the connective main highway located within Texas which now or hereafter may be designated the "primary system" by the Texas Highway and Public Transportation Commission and approved pursuant to Title 23, United States Code, Section 131, as amended. 
Owner shall mean the person who owns or leases the on-premises sign. 
Person shall mean an individual, company, corporation, partnership, association, or any other entity. 
Primarily residential area shall mean the right-of-way (and adjoining property area) between two (2) intersecting public streets in which a majority of the total front footage is used for residential purposes. 
Public street shall mean the entire width between property lines of any road, street, way, alley, bridge, or other similar thoroughfare, not privately owned or controlled, when any part thereof is open to the public for vehicular traffic, is the responsibility of the city or other public agency to maintain, and over which the city has legislative jurisdiction under its police power. 
Reconstruction shall mean the repair of a sign. 
Registration shall mean the registration of the currently existing signs. 
Relocate shall mean the removal of a sign and any supporting structure from one location and placing it or its replacement at a new location. 
Residential purposes shall mean property devoted to use as a single family or multi-family residence. Residential purposes shall include, but not be limited to, property used for houses, duplexes, condominiums, town homes, patio homes and apartments; property used for hotels, motels, and boarding houses shall not be considered as used for residential purposes. Property devoted to both residential and nonresidential use shall be considered as used for residential purposes. 
Right-of-way shall mean the property fronting or immediately adjacent to, and on either side of a public street or a non-public street which the public authority has the authority to use for the road or street. 
Sight triangle shall mean the triangle formed at an intersection by intersecting curb lines and a non-curb line joining the curb lines. The triangle is shown in section 22-73 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of South Houston. 
Sign shall mean any structure, or part thereof, device, inscription, symbol, or object which is located upon, attached to, or painted or represented on any land, or on the outside of any building or structure, or on an awning, canopy, marquee or similar appendage, or permanently affixed to the glass of a window or door, so as to be seen from the outside of the building or structure, and which displays or includes any numeral, letter, word, model, banner, emblem, insignia, symbol, device, monogram, heraldry, trademark, light or other representation used as, or in the nature of, an announcement, advertisement, attention-arrester, direction, warning or designation of any person, firm, group, organization, corporation, association, place, commodity, product, service, business, profession, enterprise, industry, activity, or any combination thereof. Where the word "sign" is used herein without further modification, the same shall be understood to embrace all regulated signs. 
Sign appeals committee shall mean the committee as defined herein and appointed as established herein. 
Sign company shall mean the person who engages in the business of leasing, constructing, or maintaining signs or sign structures. 
Sign structure shall mean any structure which supports or is capable of supporting any sign. A sign structure may be a single pole and may or may not be an integral part of a building. 
Time periods shall mean calendar days unless otherwise specified. Such periods shall start on the day following the event starting the time period to run and end at 5:00 p.m. local time on the last day of such period. Any period ending on a day the City Hall is closed for any reason shall be extended until the next actual working day at the City Hall of the City of South Houston. 
Visible shall mean that the message, copy area or advertising display seen (whether or not it is legible) without visual aid by a person of normal visual acuity or simply stated, it can be seen. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 1, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-4. - Sign classifications. 
(a)  Site classification. For the purpose of this chapter, signs shall be first classified as either an "on-premises sign" or an "off-premises sign". 
(1)  On-premises sign shall mean any sign identifying or advertising the business, person, activity, goods, products or services primarily sold or offered for sale on the premises where the sign is installed and maintained when such premises are used for business purposes or which convey information or messages. 
(2)  Off-premises signs should not be allowed. 
(b)  Type classification. All signs shall further be classified into one of the following type signs: 
(1)  Ground sign shall mean a sign which is supported by uprights or braces in or upon the ground. 
(2)  Marquee sign shall mean a projecting sign attached to or hung from a canopy or covered structure projecting from and supported by a frame or pipe support extending beyond a building. 
(3)  Monument sign shall mean any sign six (6) feet or less from the natural ground level to the top of the sign. Such sign shall be solid from the ground to the top and permanently affixed to the ground at intersections. 
(4)  Projecting sign shall mean any sign which is affixed to any building wall or structure and extends beyond the building wall or structure more than twelve (12) inches. 
(5)  Roof sign shall mean any sign erected, constructed or maintained above or upon the roof of any building. 
(6)  Wall sign shall mean any sign affixed to or painted upon the wall of any building. 
(7)  Flag sign shall mean any sign constructed of cloth, canvas, light fabric or material affixed to a building, wall, fence or on a staff or pole set in a concrete foundation. 
(8)  Awning sign shall mean any sign made of cloth, metal or plastic with a metal frame attached to a building and projecting over a sidewalk, thoroughfare, or parking area when the same is so erected as to permit its being raised to a position flat against the building when not in use; should not extend off of private property. 
(9)  Canopy sign shall mean any sign, other than an awning attached to a building, projecting over a thoroughfare, sidewalk, or parking area and not erected so as to permit its being raised to a flat position against the building, does not permit use of marquee letters, and is commonly supported by poles or uprights set upon the underlying ground; should not extend off of private property. 
(10)  Multiple business sign shall mean that type of sign that is a single structure but has a different display for each different business such as may be found at a shopping center. 
(c)  Special function classification. Any on-premises or off-premises sign of any type may also be included within one or more of the following additional classifications according to the special functions of that sign: 
(1)  Electrical sign shall mean any sign containing electrical wiring or utilizing electric current, but not including signs illuminated by a light source exterior to the sign structure. 
(2)  Portable sign shall mean any sign designed or constructed to be easily moved from one location to another, including signs mounted upon a motor vehicle or designed to be mounted upon a trailer bench, wheeled carrier, or other non-motorized mobile structure. A portable sign with the wheels removed shall still be considered a portable sign hereunder. For the purpose of this chapter, trailer signs and signs on benches are "portable signs". 
(3)  Spectacular sign shall mean any sign which has any automatically changing advertising, which is equipped with glaring or rotating strobe or spotlights, or which has any moving message whatsoever. 
(4)  Temporary sign shall mean any sign including a banner constructed of cardboard, wallboard, or other light materials, not to exceed twelve (12) square feet in size. Further, a temporary sign is intended to be used for a specific period of time (not to exceed thirty (30) days) and then removed. A portable sign and flag sign shall not be considered a temporary sign. 
(5)  Moveable sign shall mean signs designed to be moved by hand and normally stored inside the building during the nighttime. (NOT ALLOWED) 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 2, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-5. - Sign administration and enforcement. 
(a)  Building inspector or code enforcement officer. The mayor shall appoint or shall designate a building inspector or code enforcement officer to administer and enforce the terms and conditions of this chapter and all other provisions of the laws relating to signs. The building inspector or code enforcement officer is empowered to delegate the duties and powers granted to and imposed upon him/her by this chapter to other persons serving under the building inspector or code enforcement officer. The building inspector or code enforcement officer and such other persons shall constitute the sign administration section. The building inspector or code enforcement officer is directed to enforce and carry out all provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Enforcement responsibility. The duties of the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall include not only the approval of issuance of permits as required by this chapter, but also the responsibility of ensuring that all signs comply with this chapter and all other applicable law, and that all signs for which a permit is required do in fact have a permit. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall make such inspections as may be necessary and initiate appropriate actions to bring about compliance with this chapter and other applicable laws if such inspection discloses any instance of noncompliance. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall investigate thoroughly any complaints of alleged violations of this chapter. 
(c)  Powers of the building inspector or code enforcement officer. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall have the power and authority to administer and enforce the conditions of this chapter and all other laws relating to signs. Included among such powers are the following specific powers: 
(1)  Inspection and approval. Every sign for which a permit is required shall be subject to the inspection and approval of the building inspector or code enforcement officer. When deemed advisable by the building inspector or code enforcement officer, a sign may be inspected at the point of manufacture if such point is within or adjacent to the city limits of the City of South Houston. 
(2)  Warrantless search. Presentation of proper identification to the owner, agent, or tenant in charge of such property will admit the building inspector or code enforcement officer or his representative to the premises to inspect said premises concerning the sign. The applicant, owner or other person in charge of the premises where the sign is located agrees, by making application for a sign or renewal for a sign permit, to admit the building inspector or code enforcement officer or representative for the purposes of inspecting and investigating signs or sign structure, any building, structure, or other premises or property between the hours of 7:30 a.m. and 5:30 p.m., Monday through Thursday, and 7:30 a.m. and 11:30 a.m. on Friday; provided, however, that in cases of emergency where extreme hazards are known to exist which may involve imminent injury to persons, loss of life or severe property damage, and where the owner, agent or tenant in charge of the property is not available after the building inspector or code enforcement officer has made a good faith effort to locate same, the building inspector or code enforcement officer may enter the aforementioned structures and premises at any time upon presentation of proper identification to any other person on the premises. 
(3)  Stop order. When the building inspector or code enforcement officer or his/her representative discovers that a sign is being constructed not in conformance with this chapter he/she shall issue a "stop work order" to the person or persons known to be so engaged. Upon notice and issuance of a stop order from the building inspector or code enforcement officer, work on any sign being conducted in a manner contrary to the provisions of this chapter or being conducted in a dangerous or unsafe manner shall be immediately stopped. Such notice and order shall be in writing and shall be given to the owner of the property, or to his agent, or to the person doing the work, and shall state the conditions under which work may be resumed. Where an emergency exists, written notice shall not be required to be given by the building inspector or code enforcement officer. The stop order shall contain a notice of the right to appeal as provided herein. Work shall not resume until the condition causing the stoppage is corrected to the building inspector or code enforcement officer's satisfaction or the appeal process results in a reversal of the administrator's stop order. 
(4)  Permit and license revocation. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall have, and is hereby granted, the power and the authority to revoke any and all licenses or permits authorized by this chapter for violation of the terms and provisions of this chapter. 
a.  Appeal procedure. Upon revoking such license or permits, the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall notify by certified mail with return receipt requested to the address given by the permittee or licensee on the application for such permit or license, to advise the permittee or licensee of such revocation and notify the permittee or licensee that the revocation will become final if not appealed to the sign appeals committee within ten (10) days. 
(5)  Establish procedures. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall have the authority to adopt procedures and provide forms required to implement the provisions of this chapter. 
(6)  Enforce state and federal regulations. Pursuant to and in accordance with any agreement between the City of South Houston and the State of Texas, or the United States Government, the building inspector or code enforcement officer is hereby authorized to enforce any applicable terms and provisions of the Texas Highway Beautification Act, Texas Civil Statutes Annotated, Article 6624v.1, the Agreement for Carrying out National Police Relative to Control of Outdoor Advertising, entered into between the United States of America and the State of Texas, by instrument dated May 2, 1972, and any supplements or amendments to that agreement, and any rules or regulations promulgated by the State of Texas and/or the Texas Highway Department, pursuant to the said act or agreements, with regard to signs. 
(7)  Issue citations. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall have the authority to issue citations in the amount of $500.00—$2,000.00. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, §§ 1, 3, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-6. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-28, § 4, adopted October 14, 2014, repealed § 18-6, which pertained to sign appeals committee. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 18-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-28, § 4, adopted October 14, 2014, repealed § 18-7, which pertained to appeals to city council. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 18-8. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  General. Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction by a court of competent jurisdiction thereof, be punished by a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) to two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each violation. Each day in which any violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. In addition, the city attorney is hereby authorized to take all actions, both legal and equitable, necessary to assure compliance with this chapter. 
(b)  Subterfuge. Any permit secured before or after the effective date of this chapter which in the opinion of the building inspector or code enforcement officer has been secured through subterfuge and not in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the building inspector or code enforcement officer. 
(c)  Denial of entry for inspection. Whenever the building inspector or code enforcement officer or his/her representative, after showing proper identification, is denied admission to inspect any premises, the building inspector or code enforcement officer may revoke all sign permits. 
(d)  Work done without a permit. Any person, firm or organization installing, erecting or reconstructing a sign or changing the location of a sign without a proper permit will be assessed an amount twice the applicable permit fees or two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), whichever is greater, in addition to any penalties, civil or criminal, which may be assessed as a result of a violation of the terms of this chapter. 
(e)  Illegal political campaign signs. No political campaign signs of any description shall be allowed on publicly-owned property or the property of a public utility. All political campaign signs posted on private property shall be posted only with the consent of the owner or lessee of such property. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, §§ 1, 5, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-9. - Sign applications, permits and fees. 
(a)  Application procedure. Applications for permits required by this chapter shall be made upon forms provided by the building inspector or code enforcement officer and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. This shall be kept current at all times. 
(2)  Location of the building, structure, or lot to which or upon which the sign is to be attached or erected, including lot, block, section number and subdivision name, or a metes and bounds description. 
(3)  Position of the sign in relation to nearby buildings or structures and all street rights-of-way bounding any part of the lot on which such sign is to be placed. 
(4)  Two (2) blueprints or ink drawings on a scale not smaller than one (1) inch to fifteen (15) feet of the plans and specifications showing the method of construction and attachment to the building or in the ground. 
(5)  Applications for new signs shall be accompanied by a drawing of the sign structure and sign prepared by and certified by a professional engineer registered in the State of Texas. 
(6)  Reserved. 
(7)  A copy of stress sheets and calculations showing how the structure is designed for dead load and for wind pressure on every point in the display surface. 
(8)  Reserved. 
(9)  Reserved. 
(10)  Any electrical permit required and issued for the sign. 
(11)  Evidence of the insurance policy and bonds required by this chapter. 
(12)  Such other information as the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall require to show full compliance with this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the city. 
(13)  Permission to enter the property under the provisions herein set out for inspection of the sign and its structure. 
(b)  Permit required. No person shall hereafter erect, construct, reconstruct, relocate, alter or use a sign without first having secured written permit as herein provided from the City of South Houston. All signs illuminated by direct or indirect lighting, shall, in addition, be subject to the electrical code and the permit requirements thereof. Permits are not transferable and will be used only by the person to whom they were issued. A copy of the permit will be posted at each erection site. 
(c)  Construction permit duration. Any permit for construction of a sign shall become null and void unless construction of the sign is completed within one hundred eighty (180) days, or the permit is renewed for an additional one hundred eighty (180) days, in which case an additional fee shall be payable equal to the original fee paid and the proposed sign shall meet all of the requirements of this chapter on the date of renewal. 
(d)  Reports required. 
(1)  Change in condition. Any person holding a permit shall report any change in condition that makes the sign nonconforming within ten (10) days of when that condition becomes known to the permit holder. 
(2)  Damage to the structure. Any person holding a permit shall report any damage to the structure that makes the sign structure nonconforming within ten (10) days of when that condition becomes known to the permit holder. 
(3)  Change of address. Any change of address of the permittee must be provided to the building inspector or code enforcement officer within ten (10) days of such change. 
(e)  Relocation permits. Relocation permits are required before any sign may be removed for relocation. 
(f)  Definition of permits. Applications and fees. The following is a list of the various required applications and permits and for which a fee is charged: 
(1)  Application. There shall be an application made for all permits or renewal of permits. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Construction/reconstruction permit. The permit required to construct or reconstruct a sign or sign structure. 
(4)  Operating permit. Permit required to display and operate any sign other than a portable sign and an exempt sign. These permits shall be valid for one (1) year and shall expire on December 31. Each face requires a separate operating permit. 
(5)  Inspection. Inspection, except for portable and exempt signs, will consist of three (3) phases: 
a.  Site inspection required for pylon or pole before a sign may be located; and 
b.  Hole inspection; and 
c.  Final inspection. 
(6)  Inspection of portable signs. Inspection of portable signs will consist of two (2) site inspections and a final inspection after installation. 
(7)  Portable sign operating permit. Permit required for right to operate portable sign during permit term. All portable sign permits shall expire thirty (30) days after permits are taken out. A new portable sign permit will be given after a six-month period, and then only for thirty (30) days. A portable sign permit will be issued only twice in one (1) calendar year. 
(8)  Reinspection. When the initial inspection reveals nonconforming items, inspection must continue until there are no nonconforming items. A fee for each reinspection will be charged. 
(9)  Renewal of operating permits. Before the expiration of each operating permit, the owner shall apply for a new operating permit. 
(g)  Fees. The applicant for a permit or holder of a permit shall not be entitled to a refund of any fee paid in the event the permit is revoked. 
(1)  Reserved. 
(2)  Reserved. 
(3)  Fees for permits and other administrative procedures shall be as follows: 
  	On-premises Signs 	Off-premises Signs 
Non-portable Application fee 	$10.00 	Not Allowed 
Re-inspection fee 	$50.00 	
Multiple business signs permit 	Flat fee - $500.00 	
Sign permit charge per sq. ft. 	$2.50 per face 	
Operating permit every two years bi-annual 	$25.00 per face 	
Flag sign 	$20.00 per flag/year 	
Portable sign fee 	$150.00 per year 	
Application fee 	$10.00 	
Re-inspection fee 	$50.00 	
 
(h)  Registration. All nonexempt signs not possessing a current operating permit shall be registered and receive permits on the basis of the owner's affidavit that they meet or exceed the safety standards set out herein. Any sign registered without an affidavit of safety shall be removed. Any registered sign not meeting the safety standards herein shall have one (1) year from registration to meet the standards. 
(i)  Electrical signs. Any electrical sign shall conform fully to the requirements of the prevailing City of South Houston Electrical Code and shall additionally receive a permit under the provisions of that code. 
(j)  Political campaign signs. No political candidate shall post political campaign signs or cause to be posted any political campaign sign if that candidate has not first made a cash deposit of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) as a bond and fee with the permit department, and obtained a permit to post such signs. If there are no violations of the sign code by the candidate and all signs are removed as herein provided, one hundred dollars ($100.00) of the deposit will be refunded to the candidate. The remaining fifty dollars ($50.00) will be considered as the operating fee. No political campaign sign shall be posted or displayed before the candidate has officially filed for the office for which the campaign is conducted. All political campaign signs must be removed by the candidate within seven (7) days of the deciding election for that candidate. 
(k)  Reserved. 
(l)  Permits not transferable. Permits are issued to the applicant only and no permits are transferable except as herein provided. 
(m)  Exemptions. No permit shall be required under this chapter for the following on-premises signs unless any such sign is a spectacular sign or a portable sign. Any sign listed hereunder shall be erected and maintained in conformity with the provisions otherwise of this chapter. 
(1)  Reserved; 
(2)  Directional and regulatory signs erected by the city, State of Texas (including its political subdivisions, such as counties and school districts), or the federal government and the lessees of such governmental entities; 
(3)  Railroad signs; 
(4)  Legal notices, house numbers, "no trespassing", "no parking" and other similar warning signs, not exceeding two (2) in number; 
(5)  Temporary signs smaller than twelve (12) square feet, provided the number of such signs on any one address does not exceed one (1) in number; 
(6)  Signs required by federal, state, or local law; 
(7)  On-premises signs setting forth the location of or directions to parking or buildings located on the premises or regulating the flow of on-premises traffic, only if they do not include any electrical wiring; 
(8)  Signs displayed, designed, or used for or upon motor vehicles as long as such vehicles are used by the business for delivery or identification. (This is not to be construed to exempt signs built or placed upon a motor vehicle solely for the purpose of advertisement.); 
(9)  Signs designed and used for display upon or with heavier-than-air craft; 
(10)  Signs within a stadium, open-air theater, arena, public or recreational area which are designed primarily to be viewed by patrons within such stadium, open-air theater or arena; 
(11)  On-premises real estate signs five square feet or less; 
(12)  Christmas displays and similar temporary displays erected without advertising; however, such displays shall be subject to the fire and electrical code and fire safety rules promulgated by the fire marshal; 
(13)  A sign not over forty (40) square feet in area setting forth information concerning a building or other structure under repair or construction or advertising the sale or rental of the premises; 
(14)  Subdivision identification signs, one (1) per subdivision forty (40) square feet or under; 
(15)  One (1) flag of the United States and/or the State of Texas and/or the flag of the City of South Houston; 
(16)  Fast food establishments may have in and out directional signs with the company logo if they do not exceed one and one-half (1.5) square feet in addition to the five (5) allowed by this subsection; 
(17)  Any on-premises sign viewed only from within the premises and not visible from any public road; 
(18)  Any name-plate sign placed on the entrance door or within six (6) inches of the entrance opening; 
(19)  Signs exempt from operating permit only. 
a.  Any "on-premises" sign used for the purpose of perpetuating the doctrines and teachings of any generally recognized church or religious organization holding a valid "non-profit" charter which has been filed in the office of the Secretary of State of the State of Texas and for which a current tax exemption certificate has been issued by the Internal Revenue Service; or 
b.  Any on-premises sign operated by and used to further the interests of other recognized charitable organizations holding valid "non-profit" charters which have been filed in the office of the Secretary of State of the State of Texas and for which current certificates have been issued by the Internal Revenue Service. 
It shall be the duty of any person, company, organization or entity claiming exemption status under this section to provide any documentation or other items of proof to the building inspector or code enforcement officer. An organization claiming exemption status as a tax-exempt organization shall submit a photocopy of its charter and state and federal tax exemption certificates to the building inspector or code enforcement officer. 
(n)  Normal maintenance, changing of electric light bulbs. No sign permit is required for the change of any of the ornamental features or normal maintenance of a sign previously permitted. This provision shall not release a person from complying with all other applicable permitting requirements of the City of South Houston, including those of the 2006 Edition of the International Building Code. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, §§ 1, 6—12, 10-14-14; Ord. No. 2014-31, § 1, 10-28-14; Ord. No. 2017-16 , § 1, 2-28-17)  
Sec. 18-10. - Sign companies. 
(a)  License required. Any person or company wishing to engage in the business of leasing, repairing, constructing or erecting signs shall first obtain a license from the City of South Houston. A notarized form, approved by the building inspector or code enforcement officer, shall be completed by the person or company, submitted to the building inspector or code enforcement officer and placed on file with the City of South Houston. This license requirement shall apply to any business or individual erecting, repairing or constructing. 
(b)  License fee. Any person required to obtain a license under the terms of this section shall pay an annual license fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
(c)  Address and agent for service of process. Any person who is required to obtain a license under the terms of this section shall provide a current address, and keep such address current at all times, at which services of process may be had, or provide the current name and address of its registered agent, such agent's name and address to be kept current. Any person failing to comply with this provision is subject to having his/her license revoked. 
(d)  Insurance. Each person licensed under the terms of this section shall submit copies of policies of insurance certified by the agent issuing them, together with written proof that the premiums have been paid, showing that the performance of work in connection with each sign will be covered by approved public liability and property damage insurance in the amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for any person injured; one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to more than one (1) person; and fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for property damage. Such policies of insurance shall be in a form selected or approved by the city and shall name the city as an additional insured. In addition, such policies of insurance shall be issued by an insurance company duly authorized to do business and issue such policies of insurance in the State of Texas and maintaining an office or represented by an authorized agent in the State of Texas, shall expressly state that it may not be canceled unless ten (10) days' written notice is given to the building inspector or code enforcement officer before cancellation of the policy, and must contain an endorsement to the effect that the issuer waives any claim or right in the nature of subrogation to recover against the city, its officers, agents or employees. Whenever any policy of insurance is canceled, the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall require that all work to which such policy applies be stopped immediately. No permits shall be issued until such time that the person or company complies with these insurance requirements. 
(e)  Number to be displayed on vehicle. Vehicles owned or operated by a duly licensed sign installer shall have displayed thereon, at all times, the license number shown on such installer's license, prefixed by the initials "S.H.I." 
(f)  Electrical sign contractors. Each person licensed under the terms of this section whose operations include signs that in any manner include the use of electrical power shall adhere to the requirement provisions of the electrical code of the City of South Houston as that code now exists or may hereinafter be amended. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 1, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-11. - Sign maintenance and removal. 
(a)  Maintenance. 
(1)  The area around any sign location must be maintained and kept clean by the owner. Grass will be cut a minimum of six (6) feet from said sign on all sides and entirely to the street curb on the side nearest the street, and debris, etc., will be removed at least weekly. 
(2)  All signs shall be thoroughly painted as often as is necessary; unless constructed of galvanized or noncorroding metal or treated with appropriate wood preservative, and shall be kept in good repair consistent with good maintenance. All braces, bolts, clips, supporting frame and fastenings shall be free from deterioration, termite infestation, rot, or loosening. All signs shall be able to withstand safely at all times the wind pressures specified elsewhere in this chapter. In case any sign is not so maintained, the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall give written notice to the owner or lessee thereof to so maintain the signs, or to remove the sign. Non-maintenance shall be considered a misdemeanor and penalty shall be assessed accordingly. 
(b)  Unsafe signs. Should any sign, in the opinion of the building inspector or code enforcement officer, become unsecure or in danger of falling or otherwise unsafe, the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall give written notice of the condition of the sign to the person owning the sign. Said person so notified shall correct the unsafe condition of the sign in a manner to be approved by the building inspector or code enforcement officer in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. 
(c)  Unlawful signs. In case any sign shall be installed, erected, constructed or maintained in violation of any of the terms of this chapter, in addition to any other rights and remedies provided herein, the building inspector or code enforcement officer shall give written notice to the owner, lessee, or person responsible for said sign ordering said owner, lessee or person to alter the sign such that it complies with this chapter, or to remove the sign. 
(d)  Removal of signs. 
(1)  Signs with current permits. Any sign with a current operating permit that is in violation of the previsions herein shall be subject to removal. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall notify the person responsible for the sign by certified mail, return receipt requested, to repair or remove within twenty (20) days. If the sign is not repaired or removed, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and a lien may be placed against the property of the owner for such expense. 
(2)  Signs without current permits. Any sign without a current operating permit that is in violation of the provisions herein shall be subject to removal. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall notify the person responsible for the sign by certified mail, return receipt requested, to remove the sign within ten (10) days. If the sign is not removed, the city may remove the sign at the owner's expense and a lien may be placed against the property of the owner for such expense. 
(3)  Abandoned signs. Any abandoned sign or sign structure shall be treated as a sign without a current permit. 
(4)  Removal of unlawful signs by the city. The following procedures will be followed by the city in removal of unlawful signs by the city: 
a.  Signs found on public property. All signs found on public property or public utility property or easement may be removed and discarded by the city without notice to the owner. This removal does not relieve the owner of any penalties. 
b.  Portable signs found on public property. The owners of portable signs that have the proper identification on them found on public property or public utility property or easement may be removed by the city and stored for ten (10) days after the notice of removal is received by the owner for the owner to reclaim. If not reclaimed within ten (10) days, the sign will be sold at auction. The cost to reclaim shall be the sum of the following: 
1.  Two hundred dollars ($200.00) civil penalty. 
2.  Actual cost of removal and hauling: Minimum fifty dollars ($50.00). 
3.  Storage fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per day. 
4.  One hundred dollars ($100.00) for employee's time to administer such confiscation. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 1, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-12. - Prohibited use of signs. 
(a)  Signs not to be posted on or to public property. It shall be unlawful for any sign other than official signs erected by the city, county, independent school district, State of Texas or railway company to be placed or caused to be placed, painted, printed, posted or affixed in any manner, any picture, bill, sign or other advertising matter whatsoever on any curb, sidewalk, pavement, telephone pole, electric pole, traffic signal standard or pole, or other public improvement in any public street or grounds, or upon any bridge, overpass, underpass or parts of the same, median, esplanade, road right-of-way, or public utility easement, traffic island, or public building, structure or erection of any type belonging to the city. 
(b)  No sign shall resemble an official sign. No sign shall be constructed which resembles any official marker erected by the city, state or any governmental agency or which, by reason of position, shape or color, could conflict with or be confused with emergency vehicle lights, especially blinking lights. Use of words such as "stop", "look", "danger", or any other word, phrase, symbol, or character in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead, or confuse traffic is prohibited. 
(c)  Signs not to interfere with official ones. Signs may not be located or illuminated in such a manner as to obscure or otherwise interfere with the effectiveness of an official traffic sign, signal or device, or to obstruct or interfere with the view of a driver or approaching, emerging or intersection traffic. All such signs shall comply with the provisions of section 22-73 of the City Code. 
(d)  Proper shielding of lighted signals; interference with drivers' motor vehicles. Signs containing lights which are not effectively shielded as to prevent beams or rays of light from being directed at any portion of the traveled way from which the sign is primarily viewed and which are of such intensity or brilliance as to cause glare or to impair the vision of the driver of any motor vehicle, or which otherwise interfere with any driver's operation of a motor vehicle, are prohibited. 
(e)  Spectacular signs. The following types of spectacular signs shall be deemed prohibited: 
(1)  Signs with strobe, rotating strobe, or blinking strobe lights. 
(2)  Signs with flashing spotlights, rotating spotlights, or blinking spotlights shall not operate in a capacity which will interfere with traffic. 
(3)  Automatically changeable advertising signs with more than one message which changes every three (3) seconds. 
(4)  Flashing lights with bulbs of greater than fifteen (15) watts. 
(5)  Spectacular signs placed perpendicular to the roadway with the exception of automatically changeable advertising as regulated above. 
(f)  Signs not to obstruct egress. 
(1)  No sign shall be erected, constructed, or maintained so as to obstruct any means of egress, or any opening necessary for required light, ventilation or fire fighting or for escape from the premises, or so as to prevent free passage from one part of a roof to any other part thereof. 
(2)  No sign shall be attached to any exterior stairway, fire escape, fire tower balcony, or balcony serving as a horizontal exit. 
(3)  No sign shall be erected, constructed, or maintained so as to interfere with the operation of a counterbalanced section of a fire escape, and no projecting sign shall be erected, constructed or maintained without a minimum of seven (7) feet of clearance over any such counterbalanced section. 
(4)  No sign shall obstruct the free use of any window above the first story. 
(g)  Emitting signs prohibited. No emitting sign shall be permitted and is strictly prohibited at any location within the city. 
(h)  Signs employing motion picture machines. No sign shall employ a stereopticon or motion picture machine. 
(i)  Signs not to create easements. No permit for a sign extending beyond private property onto a public street, public sidewalk or public alley shall constitute a permanent easement, and every such permit shall be revocable at any time by action of the city council. The city shall not be liable for any damages to the owner by reason of such revocation. The only time such a permit shall be issued shall be in the case of a projecting sign extending over a public sidewalk when such sidewalk abuts the front of the building to which the projecting sign is attached. Nor shall any sign, by virtue of its longevity, create an interest in real property by limitations or otherwise. 
(j)  Location on vacant building. No sign or sign structure shall be permitted to remain for more than ninety (90) days on any vacant building or premises, except a conforming sign pertaining to the lease or sale of the building or premises, or a sign which is maintained in a manner conforming to the requirements of this chapter. After ninety (90) days of vacancy, the message must be blanked out. 
(k)  Vision restrictions prohibited. Any sign that restricts vision necessary for safety is prohibited. If such a sign is erected and it does restrict vision so as to be a safety hazard, it will be removed or modified to correct such restriction and eliminate the hazard. It is the responsibility of the person owning and erecting the sign to ensure that the sign does not create such a hazard. The following are guidelines to construction to prevent such restrictions of vision: 
(1)  Any sign over pedestrian traffic shall be no lower than eight (8) feet above the pedestrian surface. 
(2)  Any sign over passenger vehicle traffic shall be no lower than ten (10) feet above the vehicular traffic surface. 
(3)  Any sign over general vehicular traffic shall be no lower than fourteen (14) feet six (6) inches above the traffic surface. 
(4)  Any sign which obstructs vision within the sight triangle. 
(l)  Obscene signs prohibited. No obscene sign shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 13, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-13. - On-premises and off-premises sign regulations. 
(a)  General requirements. 
(1)  No sign in sight triangle. All ground signs discussed in this section shall meet all requirements of section 22-73 of the City Code, and shall not be placed in, or extend on public streets, easements, or rights-of-way. 
(2)  Shall not obstruct view. No sign shall in any way obstruct the view of traffic over the sight triangle or as defined in this chapter. 
(3)  Roof sign clearance. Roof signs must have one foot of open space between the roof line and the bottom of the sign, and three (3) feet of open space shall be required between the sign structure and edge of the roof, and between sign structures. 
(b)  Identification of signs. Every off-premises (not allowed) sign shall have identification (ID) marks assigned to it. Every business which has on-premises signs shall have one set of identification (ID) marks assigned to it. Each off-premises sign shall display the sign permit sticker provided by the city and the (ID) marks painted or attached in a conspicuous place on the sign. Each business sign shall display the sign permit sticker provided by the city on each sign and one set of (ID) marks painted or attached in a conspicuous place on the most noticeable sign. The required (ID) marks are to be four letters assigned by the building inspector or code enforcement officer at the time the sign is permitted. The (ID) marks shall be one (1) inch in height for each forty (40) feet or fictional part thereof from the center of the nearest public road. The (ID) marks may be black on a white background or yellow on a black background only. The marks must be readable from the nearest public road. 
(c)  Height restrictions. An on-premises sign may not be erected that exceeds an overall height of forty-two and one-half (42½) feet, excluding cutouts extending above the rectangular border, measured from the highest point on the sign to the ground level of the ground. A roof sign may not at any point exceed twenty-five (25) feet above the roof level. A variance up to twenty-five (25) feet above the adjacent roadway may be granted for good cause shown. 
(d)  Face restriction. 
(1)  No business may have more than five (5) faces per on-premises location except for wall signs. For signs on a double-faced, back-to-back, four-sided or V-type nature, each face is considered a separate sign in computing the face area. A curved surface sign shall be considered as three (3) faces and a circular sign shall be considered as four (4) faces. Those five (5) signs may not exceed in total face area the greater of: 
a.  Three hundred (300) square feet; or 
b.  One (1) percent of the total useable square feet of the building, plus one square foot for each linear foot of frontage on the adjacent streets. 
c.  The total area of all wall signs shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the area of the wall of the building below the roof line. 
(2)  No off-premises billboards allowed. 
(e)  Size and quantity of types restrictions. Total number of on-premises signs allowed at any one business shall not exceed five (5) except for wall signs. The maximum of the individual types of categories of signs are as follows: 
(1)  One (1) portable sign only permitted once a full year. The frame and wheels shall be enclosed so the portable sign will look like a monument sign and meet the safety requirements for the protection of the public. 
(2)  One (1) monument, maximum of sixty (60) square feet on each side. 
(3)  Two (2) monument signs if business has frontage on two roads with a total street frontage of three hundred (300) feet or more. 
(4)  One (1) marquee sign. 
(5)  Two (2) canopy signs. 
(6)  One (1) ground sign per separate street frontage. 
(f)  Monument signs. All on-premises signs shall be of the monument style insofar as it is feasible. 
(g)  Cutout areas permitted. Exclusions or appendages (cutouts) shall not exceed twenty (20) percent of the total sign face area and shall not exceed five (5) additional feet in height or three (3) feet of additional width. 
(h)  Spacing. No on-premises pole sign shall be erected within five hundred (500) feet of a pole sign for the same business on the same street; except each business within the limit of five (5) signs shall be permitted one sign for each street frontage. 
(i)  Multiple business signs. Multiple business signs, in addition to all other regulations herein contained, shall observe the following rules that apply to the installation and operation of multiple business signs. 
(1)  If there is a multiple business sign it shall be the only sign within one hundred (100) feet of the nearest street except for signs on the buildings of the business or directional signs. 
(2)  There shall be only one multiple business sign per multiple business center per five hundred (500) feet of street frontage on one street. 
(3)  There can be one or more multiple business signs on each separate street for which the multiple business center has at least two hundred (200) feet of frontage. 
(j)  Reserved. 
(k)  Subdivision signs. Only one off-premises sign with the name of the subdivision and directions thereto will be permitted in addition to the one exempt sign for a residential subdivision situated within the city limits of the City of South Houston that has been approved by the city and duly platted and recorded in the records of Harris County, Texas. The size of such sign inclusive of all sides shall not exceed a total of three hundred (300) square feet. Such sign is allowed for a maximum period of two (2) years and shall be promptly removed at the end of the two-year period. If the subdivision is less than ninety-five (95) percent sold, the sign may be re-permitted for two (2) years. 
(l)  Relocation. A site for relocation of a billboard sign must be obtained within six (6) months of removal and construction completed within one hundred eighty (180) days thereafter. 
(m)  Accumulation of rain water prohibited. All signs shall be designed, constructed and maintained to prevent the accumulation of rain water in or on the sign. 
(n)  Garage sale signs. The person obtaining the permit for the sale is entitled to post original on-premises and five (5) off-premises temporary signs on private property only not to exceed one and one-half (1.5) square feet in size. All signs must be removed after the sale or the holder of the sale is subject to penalties. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, §§ 1, 14, 15, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-14. - Structural requirements; generally and for specific signs. 
(a)  Design. 
(1)  General. All sites and sign structures shall be designed and constructed to resist wind forces as specified in this section. All bracing systems shall be designed and constructed to transfer lateral forces to the foundations. For signs on buildings, the dead and lateral loads shall be transmitted through the structural frame of the building to the ground in such manner as not to over-stress any of the elements thereof. The overturning moment produced from lateral forces shall in no case exceed two-thirds ( 2/3 ) of the deal load resisting moment for all signs. Uplift due to overturning shall be adequately resisted by proper anchorage to the ground or to the structural frame of the building for all signs. The weight of earth superimposed over footings may be used in determining the dead-load resisting moment such earth shall be carefully placed and thoroughly compacted. 
(2)  Wind loads. All signs and sign structures shall be designed to resist wind loads as follows: 
Wind Load Pressures in Pounds per Square Foot for All Signs 
Height Above Ground*, Feet 	Pressure, Pounds/Sq. Ft. 
0—50 	30 
 
*Measured above the average level of the ground adjacent to the structure. 
(3)  Vertical design loads. Vertical design loads, except roof live loads, shall be assumed to be acting simultaneously with the wind loads. 
(4)  Working stress. All signs shall be designed to conform with the requirements of the 2006 Edition of the International Building Code, regarding allowable working stresses. The working strength of chains, cables, guys or steel rods shall not exceed one-fifth ( 1/5 ) of the ultimate strength of such chains, cables, guys or steel rods. 
(5)  Registered engineer's seal. All commercially erected signs shall be approved by a professional registered engineer registered in the State of Texas and all plans shall contain the engineer's seal. 
(b)  Construction. 
(1)  General. The supports for all signs or sign structures shall be placed in or upon private property and shall be securely built, constructed and erected in conformance with the requirements of the 2006 Edition of the International Building Code. 
(2)  Materials. Materials for construction of all signs and sign structures shall be of the quality and grade as specified for building in the 2006 Edition of the International Building Code. 
(3)  Nonstructural trim. Non-structural trim and portable display surface may be of wood, metal, approved plastics, or any combination thereof, consistent with the 2006 Edition of the International Building Code. 
(4)  Anchorage members supporting unbraced signs shall be so proportioned that the bearing loads imposed on the soil in either direction, horizontal or vertical, shall not exceed the safe values stated in section 18-14(a)(1) herein. All ground signs shall be anchored to resist the wind load specified in section 18-15(a)(2) herein, acting in any direction. Anchors and supports shall be designed for safe bearing loads on the soil and for an effective resistance to pull out amounting to a force twenty-five (25) percent greater than the required resistance to overturning. 
(c)  Electrical requirements. All electrical fixtures, equipment, and appurtenances installed in conjunction with a sign shall be designed and installed in accordance with the City of South Houston's Electrical Code as it now exists or may hereinafter be amended. 
(d)  Clearances: 
(1)  Clearances from high voltage power lines. Signs shall be located a minimum distance of twelve (12) feet measured horizontally and twelve (12) feet measured vertically from overhead electrical conductors commonly called distribution lines and a minimum distance of five (5) feet measured horizontally and five (5) feet measured vertically from what are commonly called service drop lines. The term "electrical conductors" as used in this subsection means any electrical conductor, either bare or insulated, installed above the ground. 
(2)  Clearance from poles. No sign shall be erected nearer than five (5) feet horizontally or eight (8) feet vertically from any telephone pole or cable pole or cross-member of that pole. 
(e)  Exempt signs not exempt from this section. No sign which is otherwise exempt is exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-15. - Portable signs. 
(a)  Hitch. Every portable sign shall be equipped with a trailer hitch and locking device approved by the building inspector or code enforcement officer to hold the trailer in a securely locked position during transport. All such hitching equipment shall also comply with all applicable federal, state and local laws regulating same. 
(b)  Anchoring. Every portable sign not in transit shall be securely anchored to the ground by cables, ground supports, or such other methods in order to comply with the wind load requirements set out herein or so anchored so that the sign will fall to its side without moving beyond the limits of that fall. All anchoring systems intended to be used by the sign company or sign owner shall be approved by the building inspector or code enforcement officer and the application for a portable sign, whether it be original, re-permit or re-location, shall designate the anchoring system to be used on that particular sign. 
(c)  Standards. Portable signs for the purposes of this chapter shall be subject to all provisions of this chapter, including the structural requirements, spacing requirements, permitting and fee requirements, insurance and bonding requirements, and all other provisions of this chapter applicable to ground signs unless a provision specifically includes or excludes a portable sign. 
(d)  Maintenance. The area where any portable sign is located must be maintained and kept clean by the owner. Grass will be cut a minimum of six (6) feet from said sign on all sides and entirely to the street curb of the side nearest the street and debris, etc., will be removed at least every seven (7) days. 
(e)  Electrical. No portable sign may contain electrical components. Extension cords may not be laid across any sidewalk, driveway or any other line of traffic. 
(f)  Changeable face protection. Portable signs with changeable face display shall be secured by a locked cover so that the message cannot be tampered with and the changeable items will not be blown away by any wind. 
(g)  Size. No portable sign shall exceed in outside dimension six and one-half (6½) feet vertical or twelve and one-half (12½) feet horizontal. The advertising space on each side shall not exceed seventy-two (72) square feet or a dimension of six (6) feet by twelve (12) feet. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 1, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-16. - Registration of existing nonpermitted signs. 
The owners of all signs now existing in the city that are not exempt as herein provided and do not have current operating permits and are subject to the provisions hereof, have the responsibility to register or permit each and every sign. Any sign not currently permitted or registered by the provisions hereof by January 31 of each year shall be considered in violation of these provisions and subject to the penalties herein contained. 
All signs that were erected prior to the date of passage hereof, if they have been either continuously permitted since erection or continuously permitted since October 18, 1983, which do not conform to the provisions hereof shall be considered nonconforming, but legal, signs; provided, however, that all signs after January 31, 1996, shall fully comply with the identification provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-17. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2014-28, § 16, adopted October 14, 2014, repealed § 18-17, which pertained to variance procedure and committee. See Code Comparative Table for complete derivation.  
Sec. 18-18. - Miscellaneous provisions. 
(a)  Adverse possession. No sign or its location will gain any future rights to that location or rights to a sign no matter how long it has been displayed. 
(b)  Presumptions of ownership. There is a rebuttable presumption of ownership under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Printed name of the owner on the sign. 
(2)  Molder of the permit number on the sign. 
(3)  The beneficiary of the display on the sign. 
(4)  The property on which the sign is located. 
(c)  Current address required. Any person, company, firm, partnership or corporation who is required to obtain any permit under this chapter will maintain his current address with the building inspector or code enforcement officer. The last address furnished by the entity holding the permit shall be presumed to be the correct address and any notice sent to that address shall be effective delivery of notice. 
(d)  Presumption of notice. Each notice required hereunder shall be sent to the listed owner of any sign by certified mail with return receipt requested and at the same time by regular mail. If the registered mail is not picked up, refused, or undeliverable, but the regular mail is not returned, it will be presumed that the notice sent by regular mail was delivered on the 5 th day after posting or the date of first notice of the registered or certified mail was given to the addressee. 
(e)  Notice to presumed owner. Notice of a violation will be sent to the person presumed to be the owner in the order above set out and if the presumed owner refused to acknowledge that he is responsible for the sign, the city may without further notice remove the sign. 
(f)  City permit is not an endorsement. Any approval of a sign or its structure by the city is not a verification or endorsement of the worthiness of the sign and any failure of the sign or its structure is strictly the responsibility of the owner, operator, designer or person erecting the sign and its structure. 
(g)  The sanitation division is designated to assist in removals. The sanitation division of the public works department is designated as the division of the city government to assist and aid the building inspector or code enforcement officer in the removal of signs. The building inspector or code enforcement officer shall make a request in writing on forms provided and prepared by him to the sanitation division indicating the sign and its location and the location to which it is to be removed. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11; Ord. No. 2014-28, § 1, 10-14-14)  
Sec. 18-19. - Use of temporary structures, fences and barricades for advertising purposes. 
(a)  Temporary structures used for advertising. Temporary structures, fences and barricades placed around excavations or used during building operations, whether on public or private property, maybe e used for advertising purposes during the necessary maintenance of the barricades, so long as their use does not become a public nuisance. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-20. - Signs within 100 feet of city's war memorial. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place a sign on public property within one hundred (100) feet of the city's War Memorial located at Virginia and State Highway 3 in South Houston, Texas. 
(b)  The penalty for any violation shall be a fine not to exceed the amount of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per sign for each day or any part thereof during which a sign is located in the prohibited area. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Sec. 18-21. - Signs in or adjacent to the memorial park. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to place any sign, including political signs, upon any public street, public sidewalk, public right-of-way, public curb, or other public improvement abutting or adjacent to the city's Memorial Park or in or upon the Memorial Park property unless express consent thereof shall have been first granted by the city council. 
(b)  Any unlawful sign found in violation of this chapter shall be seized and removal thereof is hereby authorized. The code enforcement officer, employees of the police department, and the department of public works are hereby authorized to impound any such signs which shall be transported to a location to be designated by the code enforcement officer for storage. Snipe signs which have a value of less than fifty dollars ($50.00) may be disposed of immediately. The custodian of the storage area shall maintain records of where such signs were located when they were so impounded and the date on which they were so impounded and shall hold the same in the storage area for a period of not more than thirty (30) days. Any sign so held may be redeemed by the owner thereof upon the payment of a fee to the City of South Houston consisting of a total of fifty dollars ($50.00) for hauling the same to storage, plus ten dollars ($10.00) per day storage fee for each day the sign is stored. Such fee shall be in addition to, and not in lieu, of, any fine imposed upon the owner for violation of this subsection. Any sign impounded and stored and not redeemed by the owner thereof within thirty (30) days may be sold at public auction in the same manner as surplus property of the city. 
(c)  For the purpose of the chapter, snipe signs are defined as signs which are tacked nailed, posted, pasted, glued, or otherwise attached to trees, stakes, fences, or other like objects, the advertising matter of which is not applicable to the present use of the premises on which the sign is located. 
(Ord. No. 2011-16, § 2(Exh. A), 6-14-11)  
Chapter 19 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PROPERTY[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 19-1. - Certain ordinances relating to streets not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be construed as repealing or otherwise affecting the validity of any ordinance: 
(1)  Dedicating, accepting, naming, renaming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, improving, widening or vacating any street or other public way in the city; 
(2)  Establishing or otherwise relating to any system of numbering blocks and assigning street numbers for buildings or lots; 
(3)  Relating to street maintenance agreements with the state; or 
(4)  Establishing or prescribing grades for streets; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.  
Sec. 19-2. - Encroachments by buildings. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any building or structure which encroaches upon any public street or other public property. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 8, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-3. - Obstructing drains. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct any drain in any public street or other public property. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 9, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-4. - Permission for erection or maintenance of poles and wires. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any poles or wires on or over any street, alley or other public way or public place, without having first secured permission from the mayor and council. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 10, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 2012-08, adopted June 12, 2012, repealed the former § 19-5. At the editor's discretion, new provisions have been added as a new Art. III in this Chapter. The former § 19-5 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 102, § 1, 8-13-35; Ord. of 9-10-35.  
Sec. 19-6. - Permit for placement of drainage pipe or culvert in street right-of-way. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or cause to be placed any drainage pipe across or upon any drainage ditch or bar ditch located upon any street right-of-way in the city, or to construct any culvert thereupon, without first having obtained a permit therefor from the city secretary. Application for such permit shall be made on a form furnished by the city secretary, which shall show the location, size of the pipe and such construction details as may be required by the city secretary, including the location of all drainage outlets, which shall be paid for by the applicant. 
(b)  Prior to the issuance of a permit under this section the applicant shall post with the city secretary a one hundred dollar ($100.00) bond or one hundred dollars ($100.00) in cash, which shall be refundable upon the inspection of the site by the building inspector and his that the drainage opening. 
(c)  The placement of pipes residential lots on which are situated single family dwellings is exempt from the provisions or this section. 
(Ord. No. 602, §§ 1, 4, 6-6-72)  
Sec. 19-7. - Walking or driving on or injuring new pavement. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement, while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft or newly laid pavement. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 1, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-8. - Repair of pavement. 
All public street, alley and sidewalk pavements shall be in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the city or by the abutting property owner, shall be under the supervision of the superintendent of streets. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 2, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-9. - Barricades and lights for paving work and excavations. 
(a)  Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place or making an excavation in the same shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury of any person or by reason of the work. Such barricades shall be by a light at night. Any defect in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury, and any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation, while the same remains open, shall guard the same with proper barricades and lights. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to disturb or interfere with any barricade or lights lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 469, §§ 5, 6, 11-5-60) 
Cross reference— Use of barricades for advertising purposes, § 18-20.  
Sec. 19-10. - Unlawful use of streets, sidewalks and easements generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any public street, alley or easement for any purpose other than that for which it was dedicated. 
(Ord. of 8-1-50)  
Sec. 19-11. - Street and sidewalk obstructions generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way, except as may be specified by ordinance or by the superintendent of streets. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 4, 11-14-60)  
Sec. 19-12. - Construction or maintenance work obstructing streets. 
(a)  Any person desiring to perform any construction or maintenance work in the city which may block any street or impede any traffic shall first obtain a permit prior to performing such construction or maintenance work. Such person may obtain such permit by applying for same at the police department of the city and paying a ten dollar ($10.00) fee for new construction and a one dollar ($1.00) fee for maintenance work. Such permit shall specify the location and approximate time, in specific hours, that the person will block such street or impede traffic. A permit shall not be required for emergency maintenance work which can be performed within one hour or less, provided that the police department is notified and gives its approval prior to commencement of the work. 
(b)  A flagman or policeman shall be required to direct traffic during the progress of work done pursuant to a permit issued under this section. 
(Ord. No. 618, §§ 1—4, 1-23-75)  
Sec. 19-13. - Living in streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dwell, sleep or live in any railway coach, motor vehicle or tent located or situated in any street in the city, or to otherwise dwell or live in any such street. 
(Ord. No. 463, § 1, 8-2-60)  
Sec. 19-14. - Soliciting contributions on streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit contributions of any nature, whether for charity or otherwise, on the paved portion of any street in the city. 
(Ord. No. 588, 1-19-71)  
Sec. 19-15. - Openings or stairways in streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street, sidewalk or alley, without a permit from the city council. All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or railing approved by the superintendent. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 13, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-16. - Rock gardens, boulders, benches and fences prohibited in parkways. 
No rock gardens, boulders, benches or fences shall be built or maintained in any parkway. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 14, 11-15-60) 
Cross reference— General prohibition against fences on city right-of-way, § 6-4.  
Sec. 19-17. - Display of merchandise on streets or other public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use any street, public right-of-way, public easement, city owned and controlled land, sidewalk or other public place for the display of goods or merchandise for sale. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 7, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-18. - Gasoline pumps prohibited on streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain any gasoline pump on any public street or sidewalk in the city. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 11, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-19. - Playing games on streets and other public property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to play any game upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place, where such game causes unnecessary noise or interferes with traffic or pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 12, 11-15-60) 
Cross reference— Noise generally, § 12-3; traffic, Ch. 22.  
Sec. 19-20. - Writing, painting, etc., on pavement. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to write upon or paint or mark any sign or advertisement upon any street, sidewalk or alley pavement. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 7, 11-15-60) 
Cross reference— Signs, Ch. 18.  
Sec. 19-21. - Deposit of injurious material on streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit on any street or sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any glass or other articles which may do injury to any person, animal or property. 
(Ord. No. 469, §§ 22, 23, 11-15-60) 
Cross reference— Deposit of garbage and trash on public property, § 10-5.  
Sec. 19-22. - Burning of leaves, paper, etc., on streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to burn any leaves, paper, rubbish or other substances upon any of the public streets, sidewalks or alleys in the city. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 24, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-23. - Duty of city officers and employees to report street and sidewalk defects and obstructions. 
It shall be the duty of every city officer and employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the supervisor of street and bridge, as soon as possible. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 3, 11-15-60; Ord. No. 2001-22, § 1, 11-6-01) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2001-22, § 1, adopted November 6, 2001, did not specifically amend the Code. Such ordinance abolished the job position superintendent of street and bridge and created the supervisor of street and bridge. Therefore, this reference was changed at the discretion of the editor.  
Sec. 19-24. - Supervisor of street and bridge department. 
(a)  Position created. There is hereby created the job position of supervisor of street and bridge department. 
(b)  Appointment. The supervisor shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the city council, and may be discharged by the mayor with the consent of city council. 
(c)  Salary. The salary of the supervisor shall be set by the city council. 
(d)  Duties. The supervisor of the street and bridge department shall have supervision of all employees of that department and of employees temporarily assigned to that department while they are performing work for street and bridge. He shall perform all other duties as prescribed by the mayor and city council. He shall be responsible to the mayor and city council for the proper administration and operation of the street and bridge department and affairs, and shall make frequent reports to the mayor and city council. 
(e)  [Budget provisions.] The budget provisions for salary of superintendent of street and bridge are hereby transferred to supervisor of street and bridge. 
(Ord. No. 2001-22, §§ 2, 4, 11-6-01) 
Editor's note— Ordinance No. 2001-22, § 2, 4, adopted November 6, 2001, did not specifically amend the Code. Therefore, § 19-24 was added at the discretion of the editor.  
Sec. 19-25. - Construction of facilities within the public rights-of-way. 
(a)  No persons, firm, or company shall commerce the construction or installation of facilities within the public rights-of-way in the city without a valid construction permit form the city. 
(b)  No permit for construction in the public rights-of-way shall be issued until the city has enacted an ordinance providing for registration and construction permits, providing for construction standard, providing for "plans of record", providing for conformance with public improvements; providing for type of facilities; providing for revocation or denial of permit and such other provisions as the city council may deem appropriate.
