(c)  The city may institute all appropriate legal action to prohibit any person, firm, or corporation from knowingly using the public rights-of-way unless the person, firm or corporation has complied with the terms of this section. 
(d)  The fact the present ordinances and regulations of the city, due to state legislation, have become inadequate to control right-of-way management within the corporate limits to the city, creates an emergency for the immediate preservation of the public business, property, health, safety, and general welfare of the public which requires that this section shall become effective from the after and date of its passage. 
(Ord. No. 2000-13, §§ 1—4, 10-30-00)  
Sec. 19-26. - Paving of public alley. 
(a)  Finding that alleys shall not be paved without preapproval, including an acceptable drainage and paving plan. The city council finds that the unpaved public alleys of the city shall not be paved or permitted to be paved by abutting lot owners or any other persons, firms or corporations unless the paving is conducted entirely pursuant to a permit granted by the city, after an acceptable drainage and paving plan for the paved area and its surroundings has been filed with and approved by the city, and then only if the paving is done in a good and workmanlike manner in accordance with city paving specifications and is paid entirely by the person, firm or corporation seeking such paving approval. 
(b)  Prohibition against unauthorized paving of an alley and establishing criteria for a paving permit. It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to pave or cause to be paved a public alley in the City of South Houston, Texas, unless and until the paving has been approved by the city and the permit fee has been paid. And it shall be unlawful for a person, firm or corporation who has obtained a permit to pave an alley, to allow the paved alleyway to fall into disrepair. Should the alley fall into disrepair and should the permit holder for the paving fail to promptly repair same upon written notice, the city may perform the repairs and charge them, and its attorney's fees for that action, if any, to the applicant/permit holder; and those charges shall be promptly paid to the city in reimbursement. A condition precedent to the issuance of such a paving permit shall be the requirement that the applicant for the permit shall file, or cause to be filed, a drainage and paving plan from a registered professional engineer (bearing his/her professional seal) for the alley and its surrounding properties that assures the city that the normal sheet flow of surface drainage for the unpaved area shall not be adversely impacted in any way by this paving project. The failure to file such a plan showing no such impact shall be grounds for denial of the permit. The city may charge a reasonable administrative fee for this discretionary program. Another condition precedent for such an approval shall be the assumption of financial responsibility for all paving costs and inspection costs from the city, so that the net effect of this approval shall be at no cost to the city for the project. Finally, the application for the permit shall contain these conditions precedent, shall be agreed to and accepted by the applicant and shall further state and applicant shall agree that in the event that the city must excavate the area paved in the future for a public purpose such as, but not limited to, the removal or replacement or repair of buried utility equipment, lines, cables or apparatus of any kind, the city shall not be responsible for the repair of the excavated area and the applicant shall indemnify the city for and shall promptly pay for such costs. Such a commitment and assurance to the city for this permitted encroachment may be incorporated into a consent to encroachment agreement to be signed by the applicant and the city, but even if no such separate agreement is executed, the conditions and terms of the consent by the city for this paving shall be governed by this section with or without such a signed consent to encroachment agreement. The person, firm or corporation who paves the alley or who causes it to be paved, or who parks on the paved alleyway, shall never acquire any ownership or right to park or use the paved area in the alley. This shall be a privilege and not a right and this privilege may be withheld or withdrawn if the applicant or user fails to meet all the ordinance requirements, including, but not limited to, the continuing obligation to maintain the alleyway paved in a good state of repair. The cessation of use by the applicant/user shall not terminate any continuing responsibility of the applicant for the continued maintenance and repair of the paving unless and until the city permanently removes said paving at applicant's expense. 
(c)  Penalty. It shall be unlawful to violate any provision of this section and the penalty shall be the applicable penalty provided for ordinance violation in the City Code. 
(Ord. No. 2010-09, §§ 1—3, 7-13-10)  
Secs. 19-27—19-45. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TREES AND SHRUBS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 19-46. - Certain trees prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to plant, set out or propagate in any public street, parkway or other public place any of those species of trees commonly known as soft maple, poplar, willow or catalpa or any variety thereof. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 14, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-47. - Permit to plant; approval of city council. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to plant any tree or shrub in any public street or parkway or other public place, without having secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the city secretary and referred by him to the superintendent of streets before issuance. All trees and shrubs so planted shall be placed subject to the direction and the approval of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 14, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-48. - Permit to remove or cut down. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cut down any tree or shrub growing in any street, parkway or other public place, without having secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permit shall be made to the city secretary and shall be referred to and approved by the city council before issuance. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 15, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-49. - Trimming or removal when obstructing public way or are likely to fall. 
(a)  Any tree or shrub which overhangs any sidewalk, street or other public place in the city in such a way as to impede or interfere with traffic or travel, or within ten (10) feet of a street or seven (7) feet of a sidewalk level, shall be trimmed by the owner of the premises abutting or on the premises on which such tree or shrub grows, so that the shall cause. 
(b)  Any tree or limb of a tree which has become likely to fall on or across any public way or place shall be removed by the owner of the premises on which the tree grows or stands. 
(c)  The superintendent of streets may trim any such tree or shrub or remove any such tree or branch thereof so that the obstruction or danger to traffic or passage shall be done away with. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 18, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-50. - Injury generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to injure any tree or shrub planted or growing in any street, parkway or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 16, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-51. - Attachment of signs, advertisements or notices. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any street, parkway or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 17, 11-15-60) 
Cross reference— Signs, Ch. 18.  
Sec. 19-52. - Attachment of wire or rope. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to attach any wire or rope to any tree or shrub in any public street, parkway or other public place without the permission of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 19, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-53. - Duties of persons maintaining utility poles and wires. 
Any person who maintains poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places shall, in the absence of a provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles free from and away from any trees and shrubs in such places, as far as may be possible, and keep all such trees and shrubs near such wires and poles properly trimmed, subject to the supervision of the superintendent of streets, so that no injury shall be done either to the poles or wires or to the shrubs and trees by their contact. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 19, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-54. - Protection from gas leaks. 
Any person maintaining any gas pipe in the city shall keep such pipes free from leaks, so that no injury shall be done thereby to any trees or shrubs located in any street, parkway or other public place. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 20, 11-15-60)  
Sec. 19-55. - Protection from excavating work. 
In making excavations in streets or other public places, proper care shall be taken to avoid injury to the roots of any tree or shrub, wherever possible. 
(Ord. No. 469, § 21, 11-15-60)  
Secs. 19-56—19-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - INSTALLATION OF PIPELINES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERAL 
 
Sec. 19-71. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Accidental release means any unplanned, uncontrolled or unconfined release of hydrocarbons or other chemicals from a pipeline or pipeline facility. 
Adjustment means the horizontal or vertical repositioning of a pipeline due to reasons unrelated to pipeline operations. 
Interstate gas pipeline means a pipeline used in the transportation of a natural gas, flammable gas or a gas which is toxic or corrosive which is subject to the jurisdiction of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission under the Natural Gas Act, except that it shall not include any pipeline within a state which transports gas from an interstate gas pipeline to a direct sales customer within such state purchasing gas for his own consumption. 
Interstate liquid pipeline means a pipeline used in the transportation of hazardous liquids in interstate or foreign commerce which are subject to the Hazardous Liquid Pipeline Safety Act of 1979, as amended. 
Intrastate pipeline means a pipeline which is not an interstate pipeline. 
Leak (gas) means any accidental release of hydrocarbons or other chemicals which are a gas or vapor in the pipeline. 
Leak (liquid) means any accidental release of more than five barrels (forty-two (42) gallons each) of hydrocarbons or any other chemicals, excluding water, which are a liquid in the pipeline. 
Owner or operator means the individual, partnership, corporation or other entity that operates the pipeline. As used in this article, one term is always inclusive of the other unless otherwise specified. 
Pipeline means any pipe used in the transportation of gaseous or liquid hydrocarbons or any other chemicals, except pipelines which transport gaseous or liquid hydrocarbons through onshore production facilities, including flow lines, gathering lines and gas lift lines, and except pipelines located within property owned or leased by the pipeline owner and part of any oil refining or petrochemical plant, pipeline station or terminal or other industrial manufacturing or processing facility. 
Repair means to restore or replace any broken, leaking or defective part of a pipeline or replace any portion of the corrosion protection system. 
Replacement means any new pipeline or new section of a pipeline replacing any old pipeline or old section of pipeline being removed from service for any purpose other than to repair existing facilities. Replacement must occur in the same easement as the line being removed from service. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 1, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-72. - Effect of other laws; zoning compliance. 
This article shall be subject to any federal and state legislation, rules or regulations enacted or adopted to the extent that such laws and regulations shall preempt or supersede the authority of the city with respect to this article. Any pipeline constructed, operated and maintained in compliance with this article shall be deemed to be a conforming use under any zoning ordinance of the city then in effect. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 2, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-73. - Penalty for violation. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to violate or fail or refuse to comply with any of the sections of this article or of any permit issued under division 2 of this article or to fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof in violation of this article. Each such person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of this article is committed or continues, and upon conviction such person shall be punished by a fine up to the highest amount permitted by law. In addition, the permit may be revoked. 
(b)  The city council further finds, determines and ordains that the operation of any pipeline in violation of section 19-85 and division 3 of this article constitutes a condition which imperils and threatens the public health, safety and welfare; which interferes with and endangers the reasonable and peaceful use of public property; and which is a nuisance. Any such violation shall be subject to all of the remedies by law or equity. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 3, 6-12-12)  
Secs. 19-74—19-80. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 
 
Sec. 19-81. - Required. 
No new pipeline shall be installed or existing pipeline adjusted, relocated or replaced and thereafter maintained within the city without permit of the city granted pursuant to this division. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 4, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-82. - Application. 
(a)  Generally. Prior to beginning any work or preparation for any pipeline activities within the city, an application for a permit to do so, in the form described in this section, must be filed with the building official. Within fourteen (14) days of receipt of such application, the building official shall advise the applicant as to the acceptability of his proposed pipeline location and route. If a permit application, as to location and routing, is denied, the building official shall explain in writing to the applicant the reasons for denying the permit. If the proposed route or location is approved by the building official, the application shall be presented to the city council for consideration for final approval, and if the application meets all applicable departments of transportation regulations and the terms of this article, the city council shall approve the application within thirty (30) days. 
(b)  Intrastate pipelines. Every permit application for an intrastate pipeline submitted pursuant to this section shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, business address and telephone number of the applicant and of the pipeline owner when the applicant is the operator but not the owner. 
(2)  The names, titles and telephone numbers of the persons: 
a.  Preparing the application; 
b.  Designated as the principal contact for information; and 
c.  Who will operate the pipeline if other than the applicant. 
(3)  The origin and destination of the pipeline. 
(4)  The material to be transported through the pipeline. 
(5)  The maximum allowable operating pressure on the pipeline as determined according to the applicable United States Department of Transportation or state railroad commission procedure. 
(6)  The normal pressure at which the pipeline is to be operated. 
(7)  Drawings or maps showing the horizontal and vertical location of the pipeline. 
(8)  Complete and detailed cross-sections for all public street, right-of-way and easement crossings. 
(9)  An affidavit to the effect that the pipeline will be constructed, operated and maintained in accordance with the lawful requirements of this article. 
(10)  A hold-harmless agreement, bond and liability insurance policy as set forth in section 19-85. 
(11)  The required permit fee as set forth in section 19-84. 
(12)  Written consent from the owner of any pipeline corridor or easement in which the pipeline will be installed and or operated. 
(c)  Interstate pipelines. Every permit application for an interstate pipeline submitted pursuant to this section shall include the following: 
(1)  The name, business address and telephone number of the applicant and of the pipeline owner when the applicant is the operator but not the owner. 
(2)  The name, title and telephone numbers of the persons: 
a.  Preparing the application; 
b.  Designated as the principal contact for information; and 
c.  Who will operate the pipeline if other than the applicant. 
(3)  The origin and destination of the pipeline. 
(4)  The material to be transported through the pipeline. 
(5)  The normal pressure at which the pipeline is to be operated. 
(6)  Drawings or maps showing the horizontal and vertical location of the pipeline. 
(7)  Complete and detailed cross-sections for all public streets, right-of-way and easement crossings. 
(8)  An affidavit to the effect that the pipeline is an interstate pipeline. 
(9)  Liability insurance, bond and hold-harmless agreement as prescribed herein. 
(10)  The required permit fee as set forth herein. 
(11)  Written consent from the owner of any pipeline corridor or easement in which the pipeline will be installed and or operated. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 5, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-83. - Fees. 
The following fees are applicable until changed by resolution of the City of South Houston City Council: 
(1)  Initial fee for permit and construction phase assessed at one dollar ($1.00) per linear foot of pipeline utilized: One dollar ($1.00) per linear foot or two thousand dollars ($2,000.00), whichever is greater. 
(2)  Administrative fee for data and inspections: One thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). 
(3)  Annual fee for renewal and administrative tasks, additional engineering review and safety training of staff, as needed: One thousand dollars ($1,000.00) (assuming no new construction). 
4.  Any new construction requires a new permit. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 6, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-84. - Indemnity; bond; insurance. 
(a)  Any person, firm or corporation making an application for a pipeline permit, which shall include a pipeline within, under, across or along a public street, alley or other public way or easement, shall, as a condition precedent to the granting of such permit, hold the city harmless, indemnify the city for any liability arising out of or connected with the granting of such permit or any construction or operating pursuant thereto as it pertains to a public street, alley or other public way or easement except for the negligence of the city. In addition, the applicant shall furnish a bond on a form and with corporate surety satisfactory to the city in an amount of twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for each location involving the crossing of all or a part of a public street, alley, way or easement and ten dollars ($10.00) per linear foot of line within such public street, alley, way or easement in cases other than a crossing. An aggregate total bond shall not be required in excess of seventy-five thousand dollars ($75,000.00), regardless of the number of crossing or linear feet of line within a public street, alley, way or easement. Such bond shall inure to the benefit of the city for any loss which may result from the applicant's operation under his permit, as it pertains to a public street, alley or other public way or easement, during the period until completion of installation of the line is approved in writing by the city engineer. The applicant shall further maintain, at all times during the life of the permit, comprehensive general liability insurance for bodily injury and property damage, including explosion, collapse and underground hazard coverage, in the minimum combined single limit amount of three million dollars ($3,000,000.00) as it pertains to a public street, alley or other public way or easement. 
(b)  A certificate of insurance specifying the coverage required in subsection (a) of this section with an insurance company having acceptable insurance rating shall be furnished to the city secretary prior to the issuance of any permit. Such certificate of insurance shall provide that at least fifteen (15) days' prior written notice of the termination of insurance or any modification of insurance shall be given to the city. 
(c)  Any bond provided pursuant to this section may be terminated upon completion of the installation of the pipeline to which it relates upon the written certification of completion by the city engineer and provided that the permittee shall maintain liability insurance as required under subsections (a) and (b) of this section. The termination of the bond shall not affect any claim, damage, injury or cause of action arising thereon prior to the date of termination. 
(d)  In lieu of the bond or liability insurance required under this section, a permit applicant may furnish evidence of financial responsibility which demonstrates the applicant's qualification as a self-insurer. Such evidence may take the form of the most recent corporate financial report which is acceptable to the city council as giving assurance of the applicant's financial ability to comply with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 7, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-85. - Liability. 
Each permit issued under this article shall specify and each permittee by his written acceptance thereof shall agree that the permittee shall be liable to the city for the city's reasonable attorney fees, expert witness fees, other direct expenses and court costs in any legal proceedings resulting in a ruling in favor of the city and a finding of permit violation. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 8, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-86. - Revocation. 
The city may at its option revoke any permit granted under this article and order the cessation of operation of any pipeline or pipeline system constructed or maintained pursuant to such permit. Prior to the revocation of any permit, the city council shall set a time and place for hearing on such revocation. The city secretary shall be directed to give written notice to the holder of such permit by registered mail at least fifteen (15) days prior to the date set for such hearing. The following shall be grounds for revocation of the permit by the city council: 
(1)  The permit was obtained by fraud or misrepresentation. 
(2)  The owner or operator of the pipeline has violated this article. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 9, 6-12-12)  
Secs. 19-87—19-100. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 19-101. - Notice of repairs. 
Prior to making planned normal repairs to a pipeline or pipeline facility which would disturb a public street, alley or any other public land within the city or interfere with the use of such public property, the owner or operator of such pipeline or pipeline facility shall give written notice of the work to be done to the building official in such manner that the building official has at least five (5) days' advance notice before any on-site work is begun. If in his discretion the building official believes the magnitude of the work to be done justifies it, he may direct the owner or operator to post a performance bond, not to exceed twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) in value prior to beginning on-site work. For emergency repairs necessary to stop an accidental release from a pipeline or pipeline facility, the written notice requirement will be waived. However, telephone notification shall be given as soon as possible, but in any event within twenty-four (24) hours, to the building official or chief of police if the building official is not available. This notification shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the pipeline operator; 
(2)  The name and telephone number of the reporter; 
(3)  The location of the accidental release; 
(4)  A description of the material released; and 
(5)  Any other significant information. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 10, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-102. - Notice of transfer of ownership. 
Notice of transfer of ownership must be given by the new owner to the building official in each instance of the transfer of ownership of an existing pipeline within the city. The notice shall include the following: 
(1)  If previously permitted: 
a.  The original permit number. 
b.  The material to be transported through the pipeline. 
c.  An affidavit that the pipeline will comply with the standards and permit required by this Ordinance and the prior permit. 
d.  A fee prescribed to cover the administrative costs incurred. 
e.  Liability insurance, bond and hold-harmless agreement as prescribed herein. 
(2)  If not previously permitted: 
a.  The origin and destination of the pipeline. 
b.  The material to be transported through the pipeline. 
c.  Drawings of the location and alignment of the pipeline. 
d.  An affidavit that the pipeline will comply with the standards required by this Ordinance and the prior permit. 
e.  A fee as prescribed to cover the administrative costs incurred. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 11, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-103. - Location, routings to be established. 
(a)  The city council, upon the recommendation of the building official, shall establish locations for routings of pipelines within the city in accordance with the following criteria: 
(1)  Where feasible, new pipelines shall be located within pipeline corridors as delineated upon the pipeline corridor maps of the city, which is on file in the office of the city secretary. The map is made a part of this section as if the map were set forth in this section in detail. 
(2)  When it is not feasible for new pipelines to be located within designated corridors, they should: 
a.  Acquire title to the new right-of-way. 
b.  Follow property boundaries of existing easements to avoid unnecessary fragmentation of land, avoid diagonal routes except if following manmade or topographical features and avoid the creation of slivers of land between rights-of-way. 
c.  Avoid areas of unique recreational or aesthetic importance, environmentally sensitive areas and areas of historical or cultural significance. 
d.  Avoid conflict with existing urban development. 
(3)  Permits issued under this article shall authorize the location of a new pipeline only in accordance with vertical and horizontal routings established as provided in this section. Permits shall be issued subject to all necessary rights-of-way being acquired by the applicant. 
(b)  Production lines need not comply with this section. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 12, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-104. - Minimum standards, specifications and expense of change or alteration (intrastate). 
(a)  All new intrastate pipelines within the city shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the latest approved minimum standards established by the United States Department of Transportation, the state railroad commission or the county commissioner's court, whichever is more stringent, and any special requirements for street crossings established as a condition of permit approval by the city. The operation and maintenance of all pipelines within the city, including without limitation existing pipelines, shall conform in all respects to the standards, rules and regulations established by the United States Department of Transportation or the state railroad commission, whichever is more stringent. 
(b)  No new pipeline or existing pipeline shall be laid, maintained or repaired in such a manner as to interfere with the construction, maintenance or repair of any city road, street, roadbed, ditch, easement or right-of-way in, over, across or along which such pipeline is constructed. If any such pipeline does interfere in any manner with the construction, maintenance or repair of any city road or street, in, under, across or along which it is constructed because of the depth at which such pipeline has been laid, because of widening, improving, maintaining or repairing of such city road, street, roadbed, ditch, easement or right-of-way or for reasons of public safety and welfare, upon the requirement of the city engineer such pipeline shall be changed or altered promptly under the existing right-of-way by the owner or operator of such pipeline in such a manner as to interfere no longer with such construction, maintenance, repair or the safety of the traveling public. The owner or operator of such pipeline shall, upon demand of the city council, bear all of the cost and expense of such change or alteration. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 13, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-105. - Information on existing pipelines. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any existing pipeline within the city shall furnish the building official with the following: 
(1)  Maps or drawings showing the location of such pipeline; 
(2)  A description of the materials transported, their source and their destination; 
(3)  The normal and maximum operating pressures on the line; 
(4)  The name, title and telephone number of the person responsible for the operation of the pipeline; 
(5)  The name, title and telephone number of the person to be contacted in an emergency; 
(6)  An affidavit that the pipeline will comply with the applicable standards required by this article; and 
(7)  An affidavit as to whether the pipeline is an interstate or intrastate pipeline. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate and maintain a pipeline in the city unless or until the information enumerated in subsection (a) of this section has been provided to the building official. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 14, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-106. - Markers to indicate location. 
Where practical, the owner or operator of any pipeline within the city shall place line markers as close as possible over each pipeline crossing of a public street, utility easement, alley or other public land and each crossing of drainage canals and railroad rights-of-way. Such markers shall be of permanent-type construction of metal or concrete and shall contain a permanent label identifying the pipeline owner or operator, telephone number and type of product in the line. Products may be broadly classified as crude oil products, natural gas or light hydrocarbons. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 15, 6-12-12)  
Sec. 19-107. - Required reports for intrastate pipelines. 
(a)  Every person operating an intrastate pipeline within the corporate limits shall file with the city council, on or before January 15 of each year, a copy or an original of all reports submitted to the United States Department of Transportation and the state railroad commission for the preceding year relating only to the pipeline being operated and maintained within the corporate limits, including, but not limited to, the following: 
(1)  Operating and maintenance plans and reports; 
(2)  Emergency plans and reports; 
(3)  Annual reports; 
(4)  Construction and maintenance reports; 
(5)  Safety inspection plans and reports; 
(6)  Pipeline rupture or leakage reports; and 
(7)  Pressure test reports. 
(b)  Every person operating an intrastate gas pipeline within the corporate limits shall file a written leak report with the building official, within twenty (20) days of the discovery of any leak. Such report shall provide at a minimum the information required on the most current U.S. Department of Transportation or state railroad commission leak report form, and the report may be copies of reports given to those agencies. 
(Ord. No. 2012-08, § 16, 6-12-12)  
Chapter 20 - TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Appointment and removal of tax collector, §§ 2-3, 2-5; city secretary to be tax assessor and collector, § 2-13. 
State Law reference— Taxation generally, V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 1 et seq.; municipal taxation, V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 301. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 20-1. - Code does not affect tax levies. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall be deemed to affect the validity of any ordinance levying any tax, and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.  
Sec. 20-2. - Homestead exemption for persons sixty-five years of age or older or disabled persons. 
(a)  Forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) of the market taxable value of all residence homesteads, as now defined by law, of all persons sixty-five (65) years of age or older before the first day of January of each calendar year are hereby exempted from all ad valorem taxes levied by the city after the thirty-first day of December, 1989. 
(b)  Forty thousand dollars ($40,000.00) of the market taxable value of all residence homesteads, as now defined by law, of all disabled persons, as now provided by law, are hereby exempted form all ad valorem taxes levied by the city after the thirty-first day of December, 1989, provided that any person qualifying in both categories may claim only one exemption. 
(c)  The filing period for applications for such exemptions shall be for the tax year 1989 and thereafter. 
(Ord. No. 670, § 1, 5-6-80; Ord. No. 683, § 1, 12-16-80; Ord. No. 857, § 1, 12-27-89) 
State Law reference— Residence homestead, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 11.13. See also Texas Constitution art. VIII, § 1-b.  
Sec. 20-3. - Continuation of tax on sale and distribution of gas and electricity for residential use. 
The City of South Houston, by majority vote of the membership of its governing body, hereby votes to continue the taxes authorized by the Local Sales and Use Tax Act (Article 1066c, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes) on the receipts from the sale, production, distribution, lease or rental of, and the use, storage or other consumption of gas and electricity for residential use, effective October 1, 1979, as authorized by Section 6 of House Bill No. 1 Acts 1978, 65th Legislature, Second Called Session. 
(Ord. No. 648, § 1, 2-20-79) 
Editor's note— Section 20-3 is derived from Ord. No. 648, § 1, which ordinance was nonamendatory of this Code.  
Sec. 20-4. - Fee for tax certificate. 
(a)  The tax collector and assessor of the city is hereby authorized to charge a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) for each tax certificate which is issued by the city tax collector and assessor for property for each taxing unit. 
(b)  The tax collector and assessor is hereby authorized to deposit said funds into the general funds of the city. 
(Ord. No. 773, § 1, 2, 11-24-87)  
Secs. 20-5—20-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - HOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 714, §§ 1—8, adopted Feb. 8, 1984, enacted provisions which did not specifically amend the Code which at the discretion of the editor have been include herein as Art. II, §§ 20-21—20-28. 
 
Sec. 20-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms, and phrases are, for the purposes of this article and except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning, defined as follows: 
Assessor-collector shall mean the assessor-collector of taxes of the City of South Houston, Texas. 
Consideration shall mean the cost of the room in such hotel only if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping and shall not include the cost of any food served or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the cleaning and readying of such room for occupancy. 
Hotel shall mean any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term shall include hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodging houses, inns, rooming houses, or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a consideration but "hotel" shall not be defined so as to include hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes. 
Occupancy shall mean the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room in a hotel if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping and if the occupant's use, possession, or right to use or possession extends for a period of less than thirty (30) days. 
Occupant shall mean anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses or has a right to use or possess any room in a hotel if the room is one ordinarily used for sleeping. 
Person shall mean any individual, company, corporation, or association owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel. 
Quarterly period shall mean the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first quarter being composed of the months of January, February and March, the second quarter being the months of April, May and June, the third quarter being the months of July, August and September, and the fourth quarter being the months of October, November and December. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 1, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-22. - Tax levied; amount; exceptions. 
There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any sleeping room furnished by any hotel where such cost of occupancy is at the rate of two dollars ($2.00) or more per day, such tax to be equal to four (4) percent of the consideration paid by the occupant of such room to such hotel; provided, however, that no tax shall be hereby imposed on a corporation or association that is organized and operated exclusively for a religious, charitable or educational purpose if no part of the net earnings of the corporation or association inure to the benefit of a private shareholder or individual. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 2, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-23. - Collection of tax. 
Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel shall collect the tax imposed by section 20-22 hereof for the city. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 3, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-24. - Quarterly reports to tax assessor-collector. 
On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person required in section 20-23 hereof to collect the tax imposed herein, shall file a report with the assessor-collector of taxes showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies in the preceding quarter, the amount of the tax collected on such occupancies and any other information the assessor-collector of taxes may reasonably require. Such person shall pay the tax due on such occupancies at the time of filing such report. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 4, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-25. - Reimbursement for tax collection. 
The person required to file a report under this article may deduct and withhold from the taxes otherwise due to the city on the quarterly return, as reimbursement for the cost of collecting the tax, one (1) percent of the amount of the tax due as shown on the report. If taxes due under this article are not paid to the city within the time required or if the person required to file a report fails to file the report when due, the person forfeits the claim to reimbursement that could have been taken if the tax had been paid or the report filed when due. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 5, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-26. - Rules and regulations of tax assessor-collector; access to books and records. 
(a)  The assessor-collector of taxes shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as are reasonable and necessary to effectively collect the tax levied hereby. 
(b)  After the assessor-collector gives reasonable notice to a person that the assessor-collector intends to inspect the books or records of the person, the assessor-collector has access to the person's books or records necessary for the assessor-collector to determine the correctness of a report filed under this article or the amount of taxes due under this article. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 6, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-27. - Penalties for delinquent reports and payments. 
If any person shall fail to file a report as required herein or shall fail to pay to the assessor-collector of taxes the tax imposed herein when said report or payment is due, he shall forfeit five (5) percent of the amount due as a penalty, and after the first thirty (30) days he shall forfeit an additional five (5) percent of such tax. Provided, however, that such penalty shall never be less than one dollar ($1.00). Delinquent taxes shall draw interest at the rate of ten (10) percent per annum beginning sixty (60) days from the date due. The first report and payment required by this article shall be on the last day of the month following the first quarterly period, as hereinabove defined, of 1984. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 7, 2-8-84)  
Sec. 20-28. - Use of funds derived from levy of hotel occupancy tax. 
The revenue derived from the hotel occupancy tax shall be used for the following purposes and none other: 
(a)  The acquisition of sites for and the construction, improvement, enlarging, equipping, repairing, operation, and maintenance of convention center facilities including, but not limited to, civic center convention buildings, auditoriums, coliseums, civic theaters, museums, and parking areas or facilities for the parking or storage of motor vehicles or other conveyances located at or in the immediate vicinity of the convention center facilities; 
(b)  The furnishings of facilities, personnel and materials for the registration of convention delegates or registrants; 
(c)  For advertising for general promotional and tourist advertising of the city and its vicinity and conducting a solicitation and operating program to attract conventions and visitors either by the city or through contracts with persons or organizations selected by the city; 
(d)  The encouragement, promotion, improvement and application of the arts, including music (instrumental and vocal), dance, drama, folk art, creative writing, architecture, design and allied fields, painting, sculpture, photography, graphic and craft arts, motion pictures, television, radio, tape and sound recording, and the arts related to the presentation, performance, execution, and exhibition of these major art forms; 
(e)  Historical preservation and restoration. 
Provided that a portion of the said tax revenue equal to at least one (1) percent of the cost of occupancy of hotel rooms shall be reserved for the purpose of advertising and conducting solicitation programs to acquaint potential users with public meeting and convention facilities, and for promotion of tourism and advertising of the city and its vicinity either by the city or through contract with organizations or persons selected by the city. 
(Ord. No. 714, § 8, 2-8-84)  
ARTICLE III. - GROSS RECEIPTS TAX ON BINGO GAMES 
 
Sec. 20-29. - Tax authorized. 
The city is hereby authorized to collect a tax of one (1) percent of the taxable gross receipts on bingo games conducted within the corporate city limits of the City of South Houston, Harris County, Texas, in accordance with Article 179D, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, and as may be hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 826, § 1, 1-3-89)  
Chapter 21 - TAXICABS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 870, § 1, adopted July 17, 1990, repealed the substantive provisions of former Ch. 21, relative to taxicabs, and § 2 of said ordinance enacted a new Ch. 21 to read as herein set out. The provisions of former Ch. 21 derived from Ord. No. 472, §§ 1—8, adopted Nov. 19, 1960. 
Cross reference— Traffic, Ch. 22. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 21-1. - Definitions. 
(a)  Taxicab. The term "taxicab" as used in this chapter, shall mean every motor vehicle used for transportation of passengers for hire, under the directions of the passenger or person hiring the same, over the public streets of the city with the exception of ambulances, hearses, transport for the aged and physically handicapped and vehicles operated over fixed routes or on regular schedules. 
(b)  Permit. The term "permit" means a certificate of public convenience and necessity, issued by the secretary, authorizing the holder thereof to conduct a vehicle-for-hire business in the city. 
(c)  Person. The term "person" includes an individual, corporation, a partnership, any unincorporated association or other legal entity. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-2. - Franchise acquired. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct a taxicab business within the city unless a written franchise therefore shall first have been obtained from the city council. A person desiring to operate a taxicab business within the city shall obtain such franchise from the city in addition to the license and permits required by the terms of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-3. - Certificate of public convenience and necessity required. 
No person shall operate or permit a vehicle for hire owned, leased or controlled by him/her to be operated as a vehicle for hire within the territorial limits of the city without having first obtained a vehicle-for-hire permit from the city council. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-4. - Application for permit. 
[The permit application shall contain the following information:] 
(1)  The name and form of business under which the taxicab will be operated (if a partnership or corporation, copy of the partnership agreement or article of incorporation must be attached). 
(2)  The number of permits requested. 
(3)  A schedule showing the model, type, make and ownership of vehicles that will be put into operation. 
(4)  The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate vehicles of the applicant, if any. 
(5)  Such further information as the city council may require. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-5. - Public hearing. 
(a)  Upon the filing of an application, the city secretary shall fix a time and place for a public hearing thereon. Written notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant and to all persons who may have vehicle-for-hire permits. Due notice shall also be given to the general public by publishing notice of said hearing in the official newspaper of the city at least seven (7) days prior to the hearing. Said public hearing shall be held at a regular scheduled council meeting. Any interested person may file with the city secretary a memorandum in support of or opposition to the issuance of a vehicle-for-hire permit. 
(b)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the issuance of the taxicab permit to the applicant, the city council shall take into consideration the following requirements but are not limited to such: 
(1)  The financial responsibility of the applicant. 
(2)  Number of vehicles to be operated. 
(3)  Make, model, type and ownership of vehicle or vehicles to be used. 
(4)  Color scheme to be used. 
(5)  The total number of taxicab permits in operation. 
(6)  Whether the requirements of public convenience and necessity can be met and complied with only by the issuance of additional permits. 
(7)  The resulting effect upon the business of existing permit holders. 
(8)  Any other facts the city council may deem relevant. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-6. - Police investigation of applicant; traffic and police. 
The applicant shall be in compliance with the police investigation requirements of the City of Houston and the City of Pasadena regarding their ordinances controlling vehicles-for-hire. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-7. - Issuance of vehicle-for-hire permit. 
If the city council finds that further vehicle-for-hire service in the city is required by the public convenience and necessity, and that the applicant is fit, willing and able to furnish public transportation and to conform to the provisions of this chapter and the rules promulgated by the chief of police, the city secretary shall issue a permit certificate, stating the name and address of the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under said certificate and the date of issuance; otherwise, the application shall be denied. 
In making the above findings, the city council shall take into consideration the number of vehicles for hire already in operation; whether existing transportation is adequate to meet the public need; the probable effect of increased service on local traffic conditions; and the character, experience and police record of the applicant. 
Such permit shall be in effect for the remainder of the calendar year. A permit for every calendar year thereafter shall be issued upon the payment of a renewal fee, unless the permit for the preceding year has been revoked. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-8. - Street rental charges. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to operate any taxicab in this city unless there has been paid in advance, an annual street rental charge for said taxicab operated by any person in accordance with the following schedule. 
1 to 5 cabs ..... $ 100.00 
6 to 10 cabs ..... 200.00 
11 to 25 cabs ..... 500.00 
26 to 50 cabs ..... 1,000.00 
51 to 150 cabs ..... 1,500.00 
151 to 350 cabs ..... 2,000.00 
351 cabs or more ..... 2,500.00 
(b)  Each person affected hereby shall file, before beginning taxicab operations in this city, with the chief of police of this city, a written schedule (hereinafter called "initial schedule") detailing the total number of cabs to be operated, the make model of each taxicab, the color such taxicab is painted, and the company number or other identifying taxicab number painted upon such taxicab, together with a showing as to the franchise or permit under which it is operated. Such initial schedule shall normally be filed on or before the first day of January of each year, but any person subsequently commencing operations in this city after such date may lawfully file such initial schedule on the date of commencement but shall pay a pro rata rental for the remainder of the calendar year. The prescribed street rental charge shall be an annual charge and shall cover the period from January 1 to December 31 of each year. No person paying a street rental shall operate any taxicab not shown on the initial schedule, or on a supplemental schedule, filed with the chief of police. If a vehicle is added during the year, a supplemental schedule must be filed with the chief before the vehicle is operated on the street; the additional sum of money required by this section shall be paid to the city, prorated to cover the unexpired portion of the year. Any person filing an initial schedule or supplemental schedule shall simultaneously file an exact copy of same, reproduced by photostat or copying machine methods, which copy shall be endorsed by the chief of police with the date of filing and with the chief's certificate that the same is a true copy of the schedule filed, which copy shall be forthwith delivered to the person filing. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-9. - Indemnity bond or liability insurance required. 
(a)  No vehicle-for-hire permit shall be issued or continued in operation unless there is in full force and effect an indemnity bond for such vehicle authorized in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury to any one (1) person; in the amount of three hundred thousand dollars ($300,000.00) for injuries to more than one (1) person which are sustained in the same accident; and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for property damage resulting from any one (1) accident. Said bond or bonds shall inure to the benefit of any person who shall be injured or who shall sustain damage to property proximately caused by the negligence of a holder, his/her servants or agents. Said bond or bonds shall be filed in the office of the city secretary and shall have as surety thereon a surety company authorized to do business in the State of Texas. 
(b)  The city council may, at its' discretion, allow the holder to file, in lieu of bond or bonds, liability insurance policy issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the State of Texas, which maintains a duly authorized agent in the city. Said policy shall conform to the provisions of this section relating to bonds. 
(c)  Before any taxicab permit shall be issued to any person, before renewal of such permit shall be granted, the applicant shall file an insurance policy evidencing insurance coverage complying with the requirements contained in subsection (d) below or give proof that he has qualified as a self-insurer, as the term is defined in the Texas Motor Vehicle Safety-Responsibility Act as now in force or thereafter amended. 
(d)  Insurance coverage in subsection (c) above means an insurance policy covering all licensed taxicabs of the insured issued by a company qualified to do business in the State of Texas and performable in the county. Such policy must contain a provision or an endorsement requiring that the city secretary given fifteen (15) days' notice before the policy can be cancelled for any cause. Such policy shall provide no less than the minimum coverage required to "show proof financial responsibility" as that term is defined in the Texas Motor Vehicle Safety-Responsibility Act as now in force or hereafter amended. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-10. - Transfer of application. 
No vehicle-for-hire permit may be sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred without the written consent of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-11. - Suspension and revocation of permit. 
A permit issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked by the city council at a regular meeting, or suspended temporarily, if the holder thereof has: 
(1)  Violated any of the provisions of this chapter; 
(2)  Given false information on the permit application; 
(3)  Discontinued operation for more than ten (10) days; 
(4)  Has violated any ordinance of the City of South Houston, or the laws of the United States or the State of Texas, which act reflects unfavorably on the fitness of the holder to furnish public transportation. 
Prior to suspension or revocation, the holder shall be given written notice of the proposed action to be taken and shall have an opportunity to be heard. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-12. - Identification of vehicles generally. 
No permittee shall drive or cause to be driven or operate or cause to be operated a taxicab in the city unless the taxicab shall have signs on the front doors on each side of the taxicab stating the telephone number and the name or the assumed name under which the owner operates or the name of the partnership, co-partnership, association, society or corporation under which the owner operates such taxicab, as is on file with the city secretary. Such name and numbers shall be in letters of not less than three (3) inches in height and not less than five-sixteenths of one (1) inch in width and shall be a solid color and of a color contrasting with that of the color of the taxicab where the sign appears. The telephone number shall also be placed on the rear of the taxicab and be plainly visible. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-13. - Receipt for payment. 
Every taxicab driver, upon receiving payment for a fare and upon request of the passenger, shall give a receipt to the passenger showing the amount so paid, the name of the company or person operating the taxicab, the vehicle number of the taxicab. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-14. - Failure to pay fare. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to pay the full fare of any taxicab after having hired the same, and any person who shall hire any taxicab with the intent to defraud the person from whom it is hired shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-15. - Records to be kept by licensee. 
(a)  Each licensee shall maintain its records in accordance with the guidelines designated by city council or its designated representative. All such records shall be kept current and must be made available for inspection by designated city personnel during business hours. 
(b)  Each licensee shall keep complete records of all physical properties used and useful in recording taxicab service in the city, showing date of purchase, purchase price, terms of payments, and to the extent to which such property has been depreciated, by principal items of property. Such property records shall be kept in accordance with sound accounting principals and up-to-date at all times and available for inspection by designated city personnel during business hours. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-16. - Expiration of license. 
All licenses issued under the provisions of this article shall expire on the thirty-first day of December of the year in which they are issued. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
ARTICLE II. - DRIVER'S LICENSE 
 
Sec. 21-17. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or act as a chauffeur of a taxicab within this city without having secured a valid taxicab driver's license form the City of Houston or the City of Pasadena. 
In the event that the driver has a taxicab license from the City of Houston or the City of Pasadena, in compliance with their ordinances, then he shall be deemed to have qualified to operate a taxicab in the City of South Houston. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-18. - Display of license. 
The driver of a taxicab in this city shall display said City of Houston or City of Pasadena taxicab driver's license in the rate card holder or have such license within their possession at all times. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-19. - Inspection authorized. 
Any police officer of the city shall have the right to inspect any taxicab at any time, to determine whether the taxicab is being operated in a safe condition and in compliance with these ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-20. - Vehicle equipment and maintenance. 
(a)  Safety requirements. It shall be unlawful to operate a vehicle for hire which does not meet the current State of Texas motor vehicle safety requirements. 
(b)  Periodic inspections. Every vehicle operating under this chapter may be periodically inspected by the police department. Should any vehicle be found in an unsafe condition, the chief of police shall have the power to suspend the holder's permit until the defects or unsanitary conditions are corrected and the vehicle for hire is reinspected. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Sec. 21-21. - Reports of accidents. 
All accident reports arising from or in connection with the operation of vehicles-for-hire which result in death or injury to any person, or in damage to any vehicle, or to any property shall be made available to the permit holder upon request. 
(Ord. No. 870, § 2, 7-17-90)  
Chapter 21.1 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 21.1-1—21.1-25. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REGULATION OF TOWERS 
 
Sec. 21.1-26. - Definitions. 
As used in this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings ascribed below, unless the context of their usage clearly indicates another meaning: 
Alteration means any modification, replacement, or reconstruction that increases the height or materially increases the dimension of a tower structure. 
Antenna means a tower, as herein defined, or a device or system of wires, poles, rods, dishes, discs or similar devices used for the transmission and/or receipt of electromagnetic waves. 
Building official means the building inspector, after consultation with and plan approval by the city engineer. 
Camouflage design or camouflage tower means the design of a tower or tower structure that blends into the surrounding environment and is visually unobtrusive. Examples of a camouflage design or tower are architecturally screened, roof-mounted antenna/array/equipment, building-mounted antenna/array/equipment that is painted and treated as an architectural element to blend with the existing building, designs that conceal the antenna/array/equipment, man-made trees, clock towers, bell towers, steeples, light poles, and similar alternative-design mounting structures. 
Department means a tower permit team consisting of the building inspector and the city engineer, who shall be responsible for the enforcement of this article. 
FCC means the Federal Communications Commission. 
Grade means the lowest point of elevation of the finished surface of the ground, paving or sidewalk within the area between the building or structure and a line five (5) feet from the building or structure. 
Height of the building means the vertical distance above a reference datum measured to the highest point of the coping of a flat roof or to the deck line of a mansard roof or to the average height of the highest gable of a pitched or hipped roof. The reference datum shall be selected by either of the following, whichever yields a greater height of the building: 
(1)  The elevation of the highest adjoining sidewalk or ground surface within a five-foot horizontal distance of the exterior wall of the building when the sidewalk or ground surface is not more than ten (10) feet above the lowest grade. 
(2)  The elevation ten (10) feet higher than the lowest grade when the sidewalk or ground surface described in item (a) above is more than ten feet above lowest grade. 
The height of a stepped or terraced building is the maximum height of any segment of the building. 
Height of the tower (or antenna) means the vertical distance between the finished grade at the base of the tower or the lowest point of contact with the building, and the highest point of the tower structure, excluding the antenna, if any. 
High mast light structure means a fixed, freestanding uninhabitable structure of a minimum height of one hundred (100) feet, specifically designed to carry light fixtures that is built on land on, along or adjacent to streets, roads, highways and bridges maintained by the state or political subdivision of the state. 
Park means any property of the state or political subdivision thereof that is designated for and restricted to use by the pubic for park purposes. 
Public utility means any person, company, corporation, cooperative corporation, partnership, or any combination thereof, that is subject to both a municipal franchise agreement and the comprehensive regulatory system established by and defined in the Texas Public Utility Regulatory Act, that owns or operates for compensation equipment or facilities for: 
(1)  Producing, generating, transmitting, distributing, selling, or furnishing electricity; or 
(2)  The conveyance, transmission, or reception of communications over a telephone system as a dominant carrier. 
The term "public utility" shall not include, as is defined in the Public Utility Regulatory Act, telegraph services, television stations, radio stations, community antenna television services, general radio-telephone services, or radio-telephone services authorized under the Public Mobile Radio Services rules of the Federal Communications Commission or private water companies. 
Residence means any permanent building or structure containing habitable rooms for nontransient occupancy, designed and used primarily for living, sleeping, cooking and eating, which is intended to be used or occupied as a dwelling place for residential purposes, whether or not attached, including homes, town homes, patio-homes, duplexes, triplexes, quadraplexes, condominiums and apartments. Multi-unit complexes shall be included at a ratio of one-eight acre of land, or any fraction thereof, as being equivalent to one residential tract. For purposes of calculating the ratio of multi-unit complex acreage to residential tracts, only that portion of the multi-unit complex acreage within the residential test area shall be considered. Hotels, motels, boarding houses, group homes, half way houses, nursing homes, hospitals, nursery schools, schools, and child care facilities shall not be considered residences. A building or structure located on a lot or tract of land used as the site of a tower shall not be considered a residence so long as its primary use is to contain, house, store, and protect materials or equipment directly related to the purpose and use of the tower. 
Residential means pertaining to the use of land for a residence as is defined in this section or any property zoned as either R1A, R1B, R2, R3, R4 or R5C. 
Residential area means the area within five hundred (500) feet of a proposed tower site that contains fifty (50) percent or more tracts wholly or partially therein that are subject to residential restrictions or are in use for residential purposes or that are zoned R1A, R1B, R2, R3, R4 or R5C. 
Residential lot means: 
(1)  A lot which is included within a recorded residential subdivision subject to any enforceable, valid and unexpired residential deed restrictions upon which a residence exists or may be constructed pursuant to those valid and applicable deed restrictions, or 
(2)  An unrestricted lot upon which a residence exits, or 
(3)  A lot zoned residential. 
Residential restrictions means one or more restrictive covenants limiting the use of the property to residential purposes that are contained or incorporated by reference in a property recorded map, plat, replat, declaration, deed, judgment or other instrument filed in the county real property records, map records or deed records. 
Setback area means the circular area surrounding a proposed tower structure and which delineates the area between the site of the proposed tower and the nearest residential structure or residential restricted tract of land as established in this article. 
Subdivision means all land encompassed within one or more maps or plats of land within the city that is divided into two (2) or more parts and are recorded in the deed, map or real property records of the county or counties in which the land covered by the map or plat is located. 
Tower or tower structure means a fixed, freestanding or guyed, uninhabitable structure, not designed as a shelter or to be occupied for any use. This definition includes, but is not limited to, any such structure supporting antennae that transmit or receive any portion of the electromagnetic spectrum of radio waves. The following are, by way of example but not limitation, towers or tower structures: guyed or freestanding monopole structures, lattice or open framed structures, antennae supports, water towers, and other simple self-supporting, trussed, or open framed structures. 
Tract means a contiguous parcel of property under common ownership. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-27. - Tower permit required. 
(a)  An application for a tower permit shall be submitted to the building department and approved in accordance with the provisions of this article prior to the construction, placement or alteration of any tower or tower structure, as defined in this article and not specifically excluded herein, that is located within the boundaries of the municipality. 
(b)  A tower permit shall not be required for any tower repaired, replaced, or modified with no resulting increase in height or dimension and any tower repaired, replaced or modified in order to comply with the requirements of any statute, regulation, order, or rule of the FCC, the FAA, or any other federal, state or governmental agency or authority. 
(c)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the owner of an antenna tower for which a tower permit and building permit were issued prior to April 15, 2000, may, without obtaining a new permit, upon written notice to the Building Official, replace the tower with a new tower if the new tower structure complies with the requirements of this article and: (1) is specifically designed to accommodate additional antenna arrays, (ii) is not more than ten (10) feet higher than the tower structure being replaced, (iii) is not more than fifteen (15) feet from the location of the tower structure being replaced and (iv) the center of the tower structure is no closer to the nearest residence than the center of the tower structure it replaces. The new tower structure shall be assigned the same permit number as the tower structure it replaces. A tower structure may be replaced only once under this subsection. 
(d)  A tower permit shall be renewed for a co-locator on an existing permitted tower. Co-location on the same tower is encouraged before a new tower is authorized. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-28. - Exemptions. 
This article does not apply to the following structures: 
(1)  Church bell towers and religious symbols associated with a place of worship; 
(2)  Tower structures less than fifty (50) feet in height; 
(3)  Tower structures that are attached to, placed upon, or constructed on top of a building provided that the height of the tower structure does not exceed twenty (20) feet or the height of tower structure does not exceed twenty (20) feet or the height of the building upon which the tower is constructed, whichever is less; 
(4)  Tower structures constructed or placed on land or other structures owned, leased, held or dedicated for use by the state or federal government or any political subdivision thereof, which land or other structures are used by the governmental entity primarily for rendering fire, police or other public protection services or utility services, whether or not the tower structure is used jointly by the governmental entity and any other public or private person or entity for other and additional public or private purposes; 
(5)  Temporary tower structures used as or in conjunction with construction cranes; and 
(6)  Co-locator apparatus mounted on a permitted existing tower. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-29. - Location of towers. 
(a)  A tower permit shall not be approved for the construction of a tower on a lot, tract or parcel of land where the construction of a tower is prohibited, expressly or impliedly, by duly recorded and unexpired deed restrictions or covenants running with the land. 
(b)  In a residential area, a tower permit shall not be approved for the construction or alteration of a tower structure. Such a permit may be approved in the following zones of the city: C1, C2 or M or any other zone not carrying an "R" designation. 
(c)  A tower permit shall not be approved for the construction or alteration of a tower structure unless the proposed tower structure is located a distance at least equal to the applicable setback area established by subsection (e). 
(d)  A tower permit shall not be used for the construction or alteration of a tower structure in a park or on a tract surrounded by a park. 
(e)  A tower permit shall not be approved for the construction or alteration of a tower structure unless the distance between the center of the base of a tower and the nearest residential (including but not limited to small neighborhood commercial uses in a Residential Area as herein defined) lot is at least one and one-half times the height of the tower or tower structure. The foregoing measurement shall be made to the nearest point on the property line of the residential lot, unless the tower permit application includes a category 3, condition II survey, as defined by the Texas Surveyors Association, of all properties within the setback area. If the survey is provided, the measurement shall instead be made as follows: 
(1)  If a residence has been constructed on the lot, the measurement shall be from the tower structure to the nearest outside wall of the residential structure on each lot; or 
(2)  If a residence has not been constructed on the lot, the measurement shall be from the tower structure to the center of the residential lot minus twenty-five (25) feet. 
(f)  A tower permit shall not be approved for the construction or alteration of a tower structure within one thousand (1,000) feet of an approved tower structure, other than a tower structure for which a permit would not be required under this article. For purposes of this requirement, a tower in considered to be "approved" when a tower permit has been issued pursuant to this article and the tower structure has been constructed or any building permit issued thereunder remains in effect. The building official shall promulgate rules and procedures for establishing precedent to the extent of conflict between two (2) or more tower structures. 
(g)  Property uses and distances referred to in this section shall be determined as of the date and time that the completed tower permit application is filed. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-30. - Tower structure. 
Each antenna tower structure for which a permit is approved and issued shall be designed, engineered and constructed to accommodate the placement of a minimum of two (2) antenna arrays. This requirement shall not apply to a camouflage tower. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-31. - Security fence. 
(a)  The base of a tower shall be completely enclosed by a fence, wall, or barrier which limits climbing access to the tower and any supporting systems, lines, wires, buildings or other structures. 
(b)  The fence, wall or barrier required by subsection (a) shall not be less than eight feet in height with no openings, holes or gaps larger than four inches measured in any direction. Gates and doors opening directly into the area enclosed by a fence, wall or barrier, as required by this section, shall be equipped with a lock to keep and capable of keeping the doors or gates securely closed and locked at all times. 
(c)  The requirements of this section do not apply to existing tower sites having security fences at least six (6) feet in height. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-32. - Screening fence. 
(a)  The base of a tower, including all mechanical equipment and accessory structures, shall be screened from view of residential lots by a wooden, substantially opaque screening fence designed and built to provide privacy with a minimum height of eight (8) feet. 
(b)  The screening fence may contain gates or doors allowing access to the tower and accessory structures for maintenance purposes, which shall be kept completely closed except for maintenance purposes and shall be located a minimum of twenty-five (25) feet from the public right-of-way. 
(c)  When both sections 21.1-31 and 21.1-32 of this article are applicable, a single fence conforming to all applicable requirements of both sections may be provided. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-33. - Landscaping and drainage. 
(a)  If he deems it necessary to screen the tower or antenna, the building official may require a tower site to have landscaping maintained in a healthy, growing condition at all times and in compliance with all applicable ordinances, deed restrictions and regulations. If so required the following subsections (b) through (f) shall control the landscaping. 
(b)  At a minimum, a tower site shall have one large shrub capable of reaching a minimum height of four (4) feet for each four (4) linear feet of required screening fence; provided that not less than eight (8) large shrubs shall be provided for each tower site. The shrubs required by this subsection shall be installed at the tower site along the exterior side of the screening fence required in section 21.1-32 of this article. 
(c)  At a minimum, a tower site shall have one street tree, with a minimum caliper of four (4) inches, for each fifty (50) linear feet of required screening fence; provided that not less than one street tree along each public right-of-way bordering the host tract shall be provided at each tower site. Hardwoods may be specified. 
(d)  The person or entity in whose name the tower permit is issued shall have complete responsibility for the maintenance of all landscaping required by this section. 
(e)  Any tower that is excluded from the screening requirements of subsection 21.1-32(c) of this article shall also be excluded from the landscaping requirements of this section for which any amount of linear footage of screening fence is required. 
(f)  A registered professional engineer shall certify that the structure shall not impact drainage of the lot in question or adjoining lands and that certificate and drainage plan shall accompany any permit application. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-34. - Signs and lights. 
(a)  Lettering, signs, symbols, images or trademarks large enough to be legible to occupants of vehicular traffic on any adjacent roadway shall not be placed on or affixed to any part of a tower, antenna array or antenna, other than as required by FCC regulations regarding tower registration or other applicable law. 
(b)  A tower or tower structure shall not be artificially lighted, unless required by the FAA or other applicable authority. If lighting is required by law or regulations, a design that reasonably minimizes disturbance to any adjacent residence(s) or landmark shall be utilized. 
(Ord. No. 2000-07, § 1, 4-11-00)  
Sec. 21.1-35. - Application procedures for a tower permit. 
(a)  An application for a tower permit shall be submitted to the department in the time and manner prescribed by the building official. The applicant shall, with the filing of the completed tower permit application, submit payment of a one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) tower or antenna permit fee. 
(b)  The application shall not be considered complete unless accompanied by any drawing, descriptive data, filing fees, ownership information, and other pertinent data that may be required by the building official. Each application for a tower permit or for a waiver shall include envelopes addressed to the owners and a complete list of those owners, as is indicated by the most recently approved tax rolls, of all properties within the residential test area of the proposed tower site. The application shall include: 
(1)  Location and vicinity map including a boundary survey executed by a professional licensed surveyor in Texas. 
(2)  Topographical survey based on nearest FEMA benchmark and executed by a licensed professional surveyor in Texas. 
(3)  Proposed site plan and layout prepared and executed by a licensed professional engineer in Texas. 
(4)  Drainage plan and layout executed by a licensed professional engineer in Texas. 
(5)  Plans, drawings, details (to scale) of the project, site, tower, antenna, foundation (for tower or antenna), structures, platforms, other foundations, utilities, electrical wiring and equipment, paving, drive ways, drives, access roads, drainage (on site and off site), specifications and notes, and a required by the building official (including the city engineer). All drawings of foundations shall be accompanied by a geotechnical design/report also executed by a license professional engineer in Texas. 
(6)  If any portion of the tract in question is platted, owner shall replat the entire tract in question in a manner acceptable in the city, which must include the preparation of the re plat by a executed by a licensed professional surveyor in Texas. 
(7)  FCC permit and any other required permit or approvals by applicable regulatory agencies. 
(8)  FAA permits and approvals. 
(9)  The application form of the city shall specify that the applicant certifies that the communications tower or antenna shall not harm any citizen or the public generally and shall not cause interference with radios, television sets or any small appliances in the vicinity of the tower and antenna nor shall it interfere with police and EMS communication systems and radios, nor city personnel communications systems and radios, nor the city's sewer system SCADA communications system.
