No. 2017-25 , § 1, 6-27-17; Ord. No. 2017-26 , § 1, 6-27-17; Ord. No. 2017-27 , § 1, 7-25-17; Ord. No. 2017-42 , § 1, 12-12-17; Ord. No. 2018-12 , § 1, 1-22-19; Ord. No. 2018-17 , § 1, 10-23-18; Ord. No. 2019-02 , § 1, 1-22-19) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to designate stop intersections, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 542.202, 542.203, 544.003.  
Sec. 22-22. - Duty of driver approaching stop or yield sign. 
(a)  Except when directed to proceed by a police officer or traffic-control signal, every driver of a vehicle approaching a stop sign at an intersection shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, in the event there is no crosswalk, shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway before entering the intersection. After having so stopped, such driver shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle which has entered the intersection from another highway or which is approaching so closely on said highway as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time when such driver is moving across or within the intersection. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle approaching a yield sign shall, in obedience to such sign, slow down to a speed reasonable for the existing conditions and shall yield the right-of-way to any vehicle in the intersection or approaching on another highway so closely as to constitute an immediate hazard during the time such driver is moving across or within the intersection. If required for safety, such driver shall stop before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection or, in the event there is no crosswalk at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway. If a driver is involved in a collision with a vehicle in the intersection, after driving past a yield sign without stopping, such collision shall be deemed prima facie evidence of his failure to yield right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. 345, § 4, 3-21-55) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 544.010, 545.153.  
Sec. 22-23. - Procedure upon approach of authorized emergency vehicle. 
(a)  Upon the immediate approach of an authorized emergency vehicle making use of audible or visual signals meeting the requirements of the laws of this state, or of a police vehicle properly and lawfully making use of an audible signal only, the driver of every other vehicle shall yield the right-of-way and shall immediately drive to a position parallel to, and as close as possible to, the right-hand edge or curb of the roadway, clear of any intersection, and shall stop and remain in such position until the authorized emergency vehicle has passed, except when otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(b)  This section shall not operate to relieve the driver of an authorized emergency vehicle from the duty to drive with due regard for the safety of all persons using the highway. 
(Ord. No. 345, § 5, 3-21-55) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.156.  
Sec. 22-24. - Procedure upon approaching stopped school bus. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle upon a highway, upon meeting or overtaking, from either direction, any school bus which has stopped on the highway for the purpose of receiving or discharging any school children shall stop the vehicle before reaching such school bus, when there is in operation on such school bus, when there is in operation on such school bus a visual signal as specified in section 124, article 6701d, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, and such driver shall not proceed until such school bus resumes motion or he is signaled by the school bus driver to proceed or the visual signals are no longer actuated. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle upon a highway with separate roadways need not stop upon meeting or passing a school bus which is on a different roadway or when upon a controlled-access highway and the school bus is stopped in a loading zone which is a part of or adjacent to such highway and where pedestrians are not permitted to cross the roadway. 
(Ord. No. 433, § 1, 10-7-58) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.066.  
Sec. 22-25. - Corner cutting. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle over any sidewalk area or through any driveway, parking lot or business or residential entrance without bringing the vehicle to a complete stop. No person driving a vehicle shall cross or drive in or on any such sidewalk, driveway, parking lot or entrance at an intersection for the purpose of making either a right or left turn from one street to another street. 
(Ord. No. 451, § 1, 5-3-60) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.423.  
Sec. 22-26. - Restriction on operation of motorcycles. 
(a)  No person shall drive or operate a motorcycle upon or over any public or private property within the city, except upon public roadways, officially designated motorcycle trails, and areas designated for vehicular traffic. It shall be an affirmative defense in a prosecution under this section that the defendant was operating a motorcycle on private property with the prior written consent of the owner of such property or his agent. 
(b)  As used in this section, the term "motorcycle" shall mean every motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the rider and designed to travel on not more than three (3) wheels in contact with the ground, but excluding a tractor and machinery for maintaining and cleaning streets. 
(Ord. No. 614, §§ 1, 2, 10-1-74)  
Sec. 22-27. - Operation of trucks restricted to certain streets; exceptions. 
(a)  For the purpose of this section, a "truck" is any motor vehicle with a rated carrying capacity of more than one (1) ton, other than a motor vehicle designed solely for the transportation of passengers. 
(b)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this section, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate a truck on any street in the city, except the following streets, which are hereby designated as truck routes, through their entire extension in the city: 
(1)  Allen-Genoa Road. 
(2)  Genoa Road. 
(3)  Main Street between College and Winkler. 
(4)  Michigan. 
(5)  Spencer Highway. 
(6)  State Highway No. 3, also known as Old Galveston Road and Houston Boulevard. 
(c)  The driver of a truck may depart from the truck routes designated above, where it is necessary to load or unload merchandise at locations situated off such routes; provided, however, such driver shall not leave a designated truck route until he has reached a turning off point that can be described as the shortest distance practical to the ultimate destination of the truck. Such driver may also depart from such designated truck routes for the purpose of traveling to and from a truck terminal, provided that he proceeds by the most direct route that is practical and consistent with the reasonable operation of the truck. 
(d)  Any person operating a truck upon any street or roadway which is not designated a truck route by this section shall have in his possession, for the inspection of police officers, his log book, delivery slips or other evidence of his destination and point of origin to justify the presence of the truck on a street or roadway other than a designated truck route. 
(e)  The chief of police shall erect appropriate signs and markings advising motorists of the truck routes established by this section and of streets restricted to passenger vehicle traffic. 
(Ord. No. 610, §§ 1—6, 4-16-74; Ord. No. 861, § 1, 3-6-90)  
Sec. 22-28. - Weight limits for vehicles transporting ready-mix concrete. 
(a)  The city council hereby determines that the public streets, highways and roads located within the city are found insufficient to carry the maximum gross vehicle axle loads authorized in section 1 of article 6701d-12, Vernon's Texas Civil Statutes, as amended. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle to transport ready-mix concrete over the public streets and highways within the city, and maintained by the city, in excess of the following: A single axle load shall not exceed twelve thousand (12,000) pounds; a tandem axle load shall not exceed thirty-six thousand (36,000) pounds; and the gross vehicle weight shall not exceed forty-eight thousand (48,000) pounds. 
(Ord. No. 636, §§ 1, 2, 9-6-77)  
Sec. 22-29. - Driving on sidewalks marked on paving of certain streets. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive a vehicle on the striped sidewalks marked on the paving of the following streets: 
(1)  Avenue A, north side, from Third Street to Perez Street. 
(2)  Avenue N, south side, from the 1600 block to Texas Avenue. 
(3)  Main Street, west side, from Washington Avenue to Nevada Avenue. 
This subsection shall be in effect from 7:00 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and from 1:00 p.m. to 3:30 p.m., on school days, and, notwithstanding the above provisions, a vehicle may be driven across such sidewalks at any time for the purpose of entering a private driveway, provided the driver brings such vehicle to a stop before crossing the striping, completely clear of the sidewalk, before entering and after passing over same. 
(b)  Stenciled lettering upon the concrete inside the sidewalks referred to in this section, warning that the walkway area is for pedestrians, especially children, shall be construed to be sufficient notice that vehicle traffic is forbidden thereon. 
(Ord. No. 479, §§ 1, 3, 4, 9-5-61) 
State Law reference— Driving on sidewalks, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.422.  
Sec. 22-30. - Negligent collision. 
(a)  If any driver or operator of a vehicle upon any public street, highway or upon any drive in a public park or upon any privately owned access ways or parking areas provided by business establishments, without charge, for the convenience of their customers, clients or patrons, but not upon privately owned residential property or the property of any garage or parking lot for which a charge is made for storage or parking of motor vehicles, within the corporate limits of the city, shall, with negligence, which term is hereby defined as the doing of that which a person of ordinary prudence would not have done under the same or similar circumstances, cause damage to or collide with any other vehicle of any kind whatsoever, or with any other property, resulting in a total damage to an apparent extent of fifty dollars ($50.00) or more, he shall be guilty of negligent collision, and upon conviction, shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00). 
(b)  Proof of no intent on the part of any operator of any vehicle charged with an offense under this section to collide with any other vehicle or with any other property shall be no defense to any charge filed under the authority of this section. 
(c)  Nothing contained in this section shall authorize the prosecution of any person for the violation of the same while such person is operating any fire department or police department vehicle of the city in the performance of his duty; provided, that it shall not be necessary in any complaint, action or proceeding under this section to negative any exception, but the same shall be proved by the defendant by way of defense. 
(Ord. No. 632, 6-21-77)  
Secs. 22-31—22-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC-CONTROL DEVICES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate traffic by means of traffic-control devices, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 542.202, 542.203, 544.002. 
 
Sec. 22-41. - Conformity with manual and specifications of state highway department. 
All traffic-control devices erected and maintained in the city shall conform to the manual and specifications approved and adopted by the state highway department. 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.002.  
Sec. 22-42. - Required obedience. 
The driver of any vehicle shall obey the instructions of any official traffic-control device applicable thereto and placed in accordance with this chapter and other traffic ordinances of the city, unless otherwise directed by a police officer. 
(Ord. of 6-7-54, § 1) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.004.  
Sec. 22-43. - Traffic-control signal legend generally. 
Whenever traffic is controlled by traffic-control signals exhibiting different colored lights, or colored lighted arrows, successively one at a time or in combination, only the colors green, red and yellow shall be used, except for special pedestrian signals carrying a word legend, and such lights shall indicate and apply to drivers of vehicles and pedestrians as follows: 
(a)  Green indication: 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing a circular green signal may proceed straight through or turn right or left, unless a sign at such place prohibits either such turn, but vehicular traffic, including vehicles turning right or left, shall yield the right-of-way to other vehicles and to pedestrians lawfully within the intersection or an adjacent crosswalk at the time such signal is exhibited. 
(2)  Vehicular traffic facing a green arrow signal, shown alone or in combination with another indication, may cautiously enter the intersection only to make the movement indicated by such arrow, or such other movement as is permitted by other indications shown at the same time. Such vehicular traffic shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection. 
(3)  Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian-control signal, pedestrians facing any green signal, except when the sole green signal is a turn arrow, may proceed across the roadway within any marked or unmarked crosswalk. 
(b)  Steady yellow indication: 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing a steady yellow signal is thereby warned that the related green movement is being terminated or that a red indication will be exhibited immediately thereafter when vehicular traffic shall not enter the intersection. 
(2)  Pedestrians facing a steady yellow signal, unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian-control signal, are thereby advised that there is insufficient time to cross the roadway before a red indication is shown and no pedestrian shall then start to cross the roadway. 
(c)  Steady red indication: 
(1)  Vehicular traffic facing a steady red signal alone shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, and may then turn right or, if the intersecting streets are both one-way streets and left turns are permissible, may turn left, after standing until the intersection may be entered safely, yielding right-of-way to pedestrians lawfully within an adjacent crosswalk and to other traffic lawfully using the intersection, unless signs are in place indicating that such turns are prohibited, in which case vehicular traffic facing such red signal shall remain standing until the green signal is shown. Traffic not so turning shall remain standing until an indication to proceed is shown. 
(2)  Unless otherwise directed by a pedestrian-control signal, pedestrians facing a steady red signal alone shall not enter the roadway. 
In the event an official traffic-control signal is erected and maintained at a place other than an intersection, the provisions of this section shall be applicable, except as to those provisions which, by their nature, can have no application. Any stop required shall be made at a sign or marking on the pavement indicating where the stop shall be made, but in the absence of any such sign or marking, the stop shall be made at the signal. 
(Ord. of 6-7-54, § 2) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 544.007, 552.001.  
Sec. 22-44. - Flashing signals. 
Whenever an illuminated flashing red or yellow signal is used in a traffic sign or signal, it shall require obedience by vehicular traffic as follows: 
(1)  Flashing red (stop signal). When a red lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles shall stop at a clearly marked stop line, but if none, before entering the crosswalk on the near side of the intersection, or if none, then at the point nearest the intersecting roadway where the driver has a view of approaching traffic on the intersecting roadway, before entering the intersection, and the right to proceed shall be subject to the rules applicable after making a stop at a stop sign. 
(2)  Flashing yellow (caution signal). When a yellow lens is illuminated with rapid intermittent flashes, drivers of vehicles may proceed through an intersection or past such signal only with caution. 
(Ord. of 6-7-54, § 3) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.008.  
Sec. 22-45. - Signal light intersections designated. 
The following intersections are hereby designated as "signal light" intersections: 
(1)  Houston Boulevard at College Avenue. 
(2)  Houston Boulevard at Nevada Avenue. 
(3)  Houston Boulevard at Spencer Highway. 
(4)  Houston Boulevard at Winkler Highway. 
(5)  College Avenue at Main Street. 
(6)  South Richey at Forest Oaks. 
(7)  Spencer Highway at Eighth Street. 
(8)  Spencer Highway at Allen-Genoa Road. 
(9)  Allen-Genoa Road at Avenue A. 
(10)  Spencer Highway at Perez Road. 
(11)  Spencer Highway at Texas Avenue. 
(12)  College Avenue at Austin Street. 
(13)  Main Street at Winkler Highway. 
(Ord. of 6-7-54, § 8; Ord. No. 709, § 3, 10-4-83; Ord. No. 720, § 1, 9-18-84; Ord. No. 723, § 1, 10-30-84)  
Sec. 22-46. - Altering, damaging, etc., devices. 
No person shall, without lawful authority, attempt to or in fact alter, deface, injure, knock down or remove any official traffic-control sign, device or signal or any railroad sign or signal, or any inscription, shield or insignia thereon, or any other part thereof. 
(Ord. of 6-7-54, § 4) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 544.005.  
Secs. 22-47—22-57. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - SPEED REGULATIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Speed of vehicles in cities and towns and authority of local authorities to alter prima facie speed limits established by state law, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 545.352, 545.356. 
 
Sec. 22-58. - Maximum limits generally. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate a motor vehicle within the city at a rate of speed greater than thirty (30) miles per hour. 
(b)  No person shall drive a vehicle on a street or highway at a speed greater than is reasonable and prudent under the conditions and having regard to the actual and potential hazards then existing. In every event, speed shall be so controlled as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person, vehicle or other conveyance on or entering the street or highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of all persons to use due care. 
(c)  The driver of every vehicle shall, consistent with the requirements of paragraph (b), drive at an appropriate reduced speed when approaching and crossing an intersection or railway grade crossing, when approaching and going around a curve, when approaching a hill crest, when traveling upon any narrow or winding roadway, and when a special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or other traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions. 
(Ord. No. 363, § 1, 8-1-55; Ord. No. 440, § 1, 4-2-59)  
Sec. 22-59. - Signs for special speed zones. 
The special speed zones and speed limits established by this article shall be marked by appropriate signs indicating the speed limit in such zones. At least one (1) plainly readable sign shall be placed at the beginning of each such zone and as many other signs as may be practical shall be placed in the zone. 
(Ord. No. 440, § 2, 4-2-59)  
Sec. 22-60. - Speed limits enumerated. 
Enumerated. The speed limits for all motor vehicles operating on public streets and highways of the City of South Houston shall be as follows: 
(a)  Thirty-five (35) miles per hour on the following streets or portions thereof: 
(1)  On Winkler Drive from Main Street to State Highway 3 (Houston Boulevard). 
(2)  On State Highway 3 (Houston Boulevard) from the southern city limit to the northern city limit. 
(3)  On Spencer Highway from Shaver Street to State Highway 3 (Houston Boulevard). 
(4)  On College Avenue from Easthaven Boulevard to State Highway 3 (Houston Boulevard). 
(5)  Along State Highway 3 (Houston Boulevard) from west city limit to the south city limit. 
(6)  On South Richey from State Highway 3 (Houston Boulevard) to Allen Street. 
(7)  Along State Highway 3 from a point five hundred twelve (512) feet west of Beaumont Road to the centerline of Galveston Road, a distance of approximately 0.406 mile. 
(8)  Along State Highway 3 from the centerline of Richey Road to the southern limits of the City of South Houston, a distance of approximately 1.559 miles. 
(b)  Notwithstanding any other provisions of this article, it shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle at a rate of speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour in any of the following designated school zones: 
(1)  On Avenue "A" from Perez Road to 11th Street. 
(2)  On Allen-Genoa from Avenue "A" to Kolb Road. 
(3)  On Perez Road from Avenue "A" to Edward Street. 
(4)  On Main Street from Michigan Avenue to College Avenue. 
(5)  On Waco Street from Michigan Avenue to Georgia Avenue. 
(6)  On Georgia Avenue from Main Street to Waco Street. 
(7)  On Main Street from College Avenue to Washington Avenue. 
(8)  On Washington Avenue from Main Street to Austin Street. 
(9)  On College Avenue from Beaumont Street to Galveston Street. 
(10)  On Austin Street from Washington Avenue to College Avenue. 
(11)  On Avenue "N" from 11 th Street to 14 th Street. 
(12)  On Kentucky Street from State Street to Main Street. 
(13)  On Georgia Street from State Street to Main Street. 
(14)  On Main Street from Nebraska Avenue to Missouri Avenue. 
(15)  On Austin Street from Missouri Avenue to Pennsylvania Avenue. 
(16)  Along State Highway 3, a school zone, from the point eighty-five (85) feet to west of Galveston Road to the point one hundred ninety-five (195) feet to east of the centerline of Brook Road, a distance of approximately 0.291 mile, the speed limit shall be twenty (20) MPH when flashing. 
(c)  The speed limit established in subsection (b) shall be in effect between 7:00 a.m. and 8:30 a.m.; and between 2:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday of each week from the first day of school of each and every school year, when the school zone is properly signed as a school zone (save and except the speed limit established specifically for Numbers 5, 8, 9, 14 and 15 [On Waco Street from Michigan Avenue to Georgia Avenue; on Washington Avenue from Main Street to Austin Street; on College Avenue from Beaumont Street to Galveston Street; on Main Street from Nebraska Avenue to Missouri Avenue; and on Austin Street from Missouri Avenue to Pennsylvania Avenue] in subsection (b) shall be in effect between 7:00 a.m. and 8:30 a.m.; and between 2:00 p.m. and 4:15 p.m. Monday through Friday of each week from the first day of school of each and every school year, when the school zone is properly signed as a school zone). Timed flashing lights, as well as fixed signs, may be used to indicate the designation of a school zone. 
(d)  Thirty (30) miles per hour on all other public streets and highways in the City of South Houston. 
Signs. Drivers of motor vehicles are hereby notified of the speed zones and of the speed limits as set out [above] by signs erected on the right-hand shoulder of the roadways whereon said public streets and highways the speed is regulated and, said signs state the times when the speed is reduced if applicable. If there is no sign on the shoulder of the road, thirty (30) mile per hour speed limit applies to such street or highway. At least one (1) plainly readable sign shall be placed at the beginning of all speed zones and as many other signs as may be practical in the zone. 
Violation and penalty. It shall be unlawful for the driver of any motor vehicle to drive and operate such vehicle on the public streets and highways in the City of South Houston, Harris County, Texas in excess of the speed limit hereinabove set for the area wherein said vehicle is being operated. Anyone who drives and operates a motor vehicle in excess of the lawful speed limit shall be committing a misdemeanor offense, and upon conviction, the offender shall be punished by a fine not to exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each offense. 
Emergency vehicles exempted. The provisions of this section do not apply to the drivers of police or fire-fighting vehicles, when said vehicles are being driven in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 639, § 1, 11-1-77; Ord. No. 640, §§ 1—4, 4-4-78; Ord. No. 698, § 1, 10-5-82; Ord. No. 709, §§ 4, 5, 10-4-83; Ord. No. 718, § 1, 8-23-84; Ord. No. 736, § 1, 5-6-86; Ord. No. 821, § 1, 11-1-88; Ord. No. 909 (8-91), § 1, 8-20-91; Ord. No. 94-036, § 1, 11-21-94; Ord. No. 97-023, 3-4-97; Ord. No. 98-010, § 1, 7-28-98; Ord. No. 99-015, § 1, 8-24-99; Ord. No. 2001-06, § 1, 5-1-01; Ord. No. 2001-13, § 1, 8-7-01; Ord. No. 2002-19, § 1, 9-3-02; Ord. No. 2004-12, §§ 1, 2, 5-14-04; Ord. No. 2004-25, § 1, 7-20-04; Ord. No. 2005-43, § 1, 11-15-05; Ord. No. 2005-49, § 1, 12-20-05; Ord. No. 2019-05 , § 1, 2-12-19) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 640, adopted April 4, 1978, consolidated all speed limit enumeration and in § 5 repealed all ordinances in conflict therewith; hence §§ 22-60 and 22-61 have been effectively repealed. Section 22-60 pertained to school zone speeds and was derived from Ord. No. 440, § 1, adopted April 2, 1959, Ord. of May 16, 1961, § 1, and Ord. of Oct. 16, 1962, § 1; while § 6-21 pertained to thirty-five mile an hour speed zones and was derived from Ord. No. 466, § 1, adopted Sept. 6, 1960 and Ord. No. 479, § 6, adopted Sept. 5, 1951. 
State Law reference— Authority to set speed limits, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.356.  
Sec. 22-61. - Reserved. 
Note— See editor's note following § 22-60.  
Sec. 22-62. - Construction speed zones. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance establishing speed limits for vehicles within the construction zones and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect, until the same expire under their own terms, to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code.  
Secs. 22-63—22-72. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Parking of wreckers at scene of accident, § 5-9; parking in fire lanes, § 9-51 et seq.; parking of mobile homes on streets, § 13-3; off-street parking requirements of zoning ordinance, App. A, §§ 5.1—5.3. 
State Law reference— Authority of city to regulate the stopping, standing and parking of vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 542.202(a)(2). 
 
Sec. 22-73. - General prohibitions. 
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic-control device, no person shall: 
(a)  Stop, stand or park a vehicle: 
(1)  On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street. 
(2)  On a sidewalk. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  On a crosswalk. 
(5)  Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty (30) feet of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of a safety zone, unless a different length is indicated by signs or markings. 
(6)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(7)  Upon any bridge or other elevated structure upon a highway or within a highway tunnel. 
(8)  On any railroad track. 
(9)  At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. 
(b)  Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge a passenger or passengers: 
(1)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(2)  Within fifteen (15) feet of a fire hydrant. 
(3)  Within twenty (20) feet of a crosswalk at an intersection. 
(4)  Within thirty (30) feet upon the approach to any flashing stop sign, yield sign or traffic-control signal located at the side of a roadway. 
(5)  Within twenty (20) feet of the driveway entrance to any fire station and, on the side of a street opposite the entrance to any fire station, within seventy-five (75) feet of said entrance (when properly sign-posted). 
(6)  At any place where official signs prohibit standing. 
(c)  Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or passengers: 
(1)  Within fifty (50) feet of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing. 
(2)  At any place where official signs prohibit parking. 
(Ord. No. 532, § 1, 8-3-65) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.302.  
Sec. 22-74. - Method of parking—Generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle on the streets and highways within the city in any manner which is contrary to the usual parking procedure for the particular parking area. Where the painted lines on the street designate angle parking, vehicles must be parked at an angle between such lines. Where the painted lines designate parallel parking, vehicles must be parked parallel to the road and within such lines. 
(b)  Any irregular parking which is adjudged to be hazardous under the particular circumstances is hereby made unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 365, § 1, 9-6-55)  
Sec. 22-75. - Same—At least ten feet of roadway to be left available for vehicular traffic. 
No person shall park any vehicle upon a street or alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten (10) feet of the width of the roadway for free movement of vehicular traffic. 
(Ord. No. 532, § 2, 8-3-65) 
State Law reference— Parallel and angle parking, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 545.303.  
Sec. 22-76. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying such vehicle for sale. 
(2)  Washing, greasing or repairing such vehicle, except such emergency repairs as may be necessary to enable such vehicle to be moved off of such roadway at the earliest possible moment. 
(Ord. No. 532, § 3, 8-3-65)  
Sec. 22-77. - Parking for more than forty-eight hours. 
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to remain parked upon any street or right-of-way within the City of South Houston for more than forty-eight (48) hours. 
(Ord. No. 553, § 2, 8-2-66; Ord. No. 702, 6-7-83) 
State Law reference— Definitions pertaining to abandoned motor vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.001.  
Sec. 22-78. - Parking of truck or bus between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any truck larger than a three-quarter ton pickup truck or any bus on the city streets between 6:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. In an emergency situation, where a truck or bus must remain on a city street between such hours for some reason, the operator of such vehicle shall notify the police department, as soon as he determines that such vehicle must remain on the street between such hours. The police department shall investigate the situation and, if necessary, place warning lights or barricades on the street to advise passing motorists of such parked vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 428, § 1, 9-16-58)  
Sec. 22-79. - Prohibited parking on specific streets. 
When signs or markings are in place giving notice thereof, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle on any of the following streets or portions thereof: 
Avenue A from its intersection with Perez Road to its intersection with Berry Bayou. 
Avenue H, 900 and 1,000 blocks. 
Avenue J, 900 and 1,000 blocks. 
Avenue N from its intersection with Texas Avenue to its intersection with Shaver Street. 
Avenue N, within the 1400, 1500 and 1600 blocks. 
East side of Austin Street , in the 1400 and 1500 Blocks thereof, between Washington Avenue and College Avenue. 
Dallas Street from its intersection with Georgia Avenue to its intersection with Washington Avenue. 
First Avenue from its intersection with Spencer Highway to its intersection with Pennsylvania Avenue. 
Fourth Street from its intersection with Spencer Highway to its intersection with Avenue A. 
Illinois Avenue from its intersection with Dallas Street to its intersection with State Highway No. 3. 
Main Street from its intersection with Michigan Avenue to the south city limits. 
Nevada Avenue from its intersection with Texas Avenue to its intersection with Main Street. 
Palestine Street from its intersection with First Avenue to the north city limits. 
Pennsylvania Avenue from its intersection with Palestine Street to its intersection with State Highway No. 3. 
Perez Road from its intersection with Spencer Highway to the north city limits. 
Texas Avenue from its intersection with Spencer Highway to its intersection with Avenue N. 
Virginia Avenue from its intersection with Palestine Street to its intersection with Main Street. 
Washington Avenue from its intersection with Dallas Street to its intersection with State Highway No. 3. 
York Avenue from its intersection with Berry Bayou to its intersection with Spencer Highway. 
(Ord. No. 462, § 1, 7-19-60; Ord. No. 593, § 1, 8-19-71; Ord. No. 2005-01, § 1, 1-18-05)  
Sec. 22-80. - Parking not to obstruct marked sidewalks on paving of certain streets of Avenue A. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park a vehicle on the north side of the paving on Avenue A, from Third Street to Perez Street, on the south side of Avenue N, from the 1600 block to Texas Avenue, or on the west side of Main Street, from Washington Avenue to Neveda Avenue, in such manner as will necessitate crossing the sidewalk line marked on such paving, or to park a vehicle in such manner as to obstruct such sidewalks either in driveway intersections of elsewhere. This section shall be in effect from 7:00 a.m. to 8:30 a.m. and from 1:00 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. on school days. 
(Ord. No. 479, § 2, 9-5-61)  
Sec. 22-81. - Removal of parked vehicles constituting traffic hazard. 
When any vehicle is parked on any street in such a manner as to become a hazard to traffic, the chief of police is hereby authorized to have such vehicle towed away immediately, if the owner is not available then and there to accept a notice from the police to remove such vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 553, § 3, 8-2-66)
